webTitle: Mendes to direct Tom Hanks movie

fields.headline: Mendes to direct Tom Hanks movie
fields.trailText: Sam Mendes, the great hope of British theatre, took a further step towards Hollywood yesterday, announcing that he had agreed to direct a gangster film starring Tom Hanks.
fields.body:
Sam Mendes, the great hope of British theatre, took a further step towards Hollywood yesterday, announcing that he had agreed to direct a gangster film starring Tom Hanks.

Mendes, whose US movie debut, American Beauty, won five Oscars, is to direct the all-American star in The Road to Perdition, a big budget 1930s drama based on a comic strip. Hanks will play a Chicago hitman dubbed The Angel, who seeks vengeance for the murder of his wife and two sons.

A spokeswoman for the director, who is also artistic director of the Donmar Warehouse theatre, in London, said: "The film will be based on the graphic novel, but it is not going to be exactly the same. It is an epic which will move from 1930s Chicago to the Badlands of North Dakota, and Tom is going to be playing a very different role to his normal ones."

American Beauty, starring Kevin Spacey and Annette Bening, was a sharp critique of the American dream which played surprisingly well with US audiences, winning Oscars for best actor, best film and best director.

Hanks, who won best actor Oscars for Philadelphia and Forrest Gump, has recently taken on a directorial role in episodes of the second world war series Band of Brothers.

Filming of The Road to Perdition is due to take place next year. In the meantime the director has pledged to continue his theatre work.

He recently announced he would direct a new play at the Donmar, the wartime piece To the Green Fields Beyond. The play, due to run from September 25, stars Dougray Scott, who appeared in Mission Impossible 2, and Ray Winstone as members of a tank unit.

In June, Mendes said that British theatre was in danger of being "held hostage by the lure of glamour" after the influx of US film adaptations and stars. Mendes himself persuaded Nicole Kidman to appear in The Blue Room at the Donmar Warehouse.

fields.headline: The best fugitive scene
fields.standfirst: Chicken run
fields.trailText: Chicken run
fields.body:
Having refused to help the chickens of coop 17 escape, the American flying rooster Rocky (voiced by Mel Gibson) has been reduced to hiding in the barn after the arrival at the Tweedy farm of his owner, Circus Man (John Sharian). He whispers furiously at Ginger (Julia Sawalha).

"Now listen here, sister - I'm not going back to that life. I'm the Lone Free Ranger - emphasis on free !"

"But that's what we want," Ginger replies. "Freedom."

Rocky gasps in horror as he sees Mrs Tweedy (Miranda Richardson) and Circus Man approaching with a torch.

"Fancy that," says Ginger. "They're coming this way."

"No! Oh no. They're on to me!"

"Teach us to fly and we'll hide you."

"And if I don't?"

Ginger lets out a high-pitched squawk. Rocky looks terrified.

"Was your father, by any chance, a vulture?"

"Do we have a deal?"

Rocky peers out of the barn at the advancing figures of Mrs Tweedy and Circus Man. With a sigh, he holds out his wing for Ginger to shake.

See also: In The Heat Of The Night, One False Move, Thelma And Louise, I Am A Fugitive, The Chain Gang

Don't see also: The Fugitive, US Marshalls

Pointless trivia: Mel Gibson once appeared as Juliet in an all-male school production of Romeo And Juliet.

fields.headline: The yeti hunter
fields.standfirst: Climber Reinhold Messner dismissed the yeti myth. Then he saw one, and spent years chasing them around the Himalayas. Now he thinks he has solved the mystery. Sam Wollaston reports
fields.trailText: Climber Reinhold Messner dismissed the yeti myth. Then he saw one, and spent years chasing them around the Himalayas. Now he thinks he has solved the mystery. Sam Wollaston reports
fields.body:
Reinhold Messner bumped into his first yeti somewhere in Tibet. It was 1986, and he had gone for a walk on his own and got a bit lost. A walk for Reinhold Messner is not what most people mean by a walk. On this one he was trying to follow a route taken by Sherpa people centuries ago in the flight from the lands of Dege to Lhasa. That's a walk of about 1,200 miles.

It was dusk; he was climbing a steep, densely vegetated slope. Suddenly something large and dark stepped out ahead of him. He watched it racing along in front, flitting in and out of the trees, upright like a man, but moving faster than any man could. Neither branches nor ditches slowed it down. At one point it stood motionless only 10 yards away, then disappeared.

He saw it again, later that night, running in the moonlight. It looked more than seven feet tall and immensely strong, but agile too. Covered in hair, with short legs and long, powerful arms, it made angry hissing noises, and for a second he saw its eyes and teeth before it ran off into the trees.

After his encounter with the strange beast, Messner became obsessed. He spent a large part of the following 12 years chasing yetis round the Himalayas - Pakistan, Nepal, Bhutan, India, Mongolia, Kazakhstan - trying to get to the bottom of a myth that has been around since Alexander the Great heard of them when he went to conquer the Indus valley in 326BC. Now he thinks he has solved the mystery, and has written a book about it.

If you know anything at all about climbing, you will have heard of Messner. The German-speaking Tyrolean Italian is probably the greatest mountaineer alive. The American climber Jon Krakauer says: "Messner is to climbing what Michael Jordan is to basketball." If you don't know anything about basketball think Tiger Woods, Michael Schumacher, Zinedine Zidane. Or Pele, because Messner is now 55 and cannot quite do what he used to - a little past his peak you could say, of a man who has conquered all the major peaks of the world.

He was the first man to climb all 14 of the 8,000m mountains, a feat impressive in itself, but more so because he did it without oxygen. In 1980, when attempts on Everest still relied on armies of Sherpas and equipment, Messner went up on his own. His single-minded passion for climbing has survived the loss of one of his brothers and all but three of his toes. And it is with that same single-minded determination that he has solved the yeti mystery.

We meet in the highly inappropriate surroundings of the European parliament building in Brussels, as Messner is now an MEP, albeit a slightly reluctant one. His office is down a long, grey, confusingly numbered corridor. He looks out of place and a little unhappy among all that bureaucracy. There are no books on the shelves and the view from the window is over another part of the same building. "I am not building up a political career. I will not run again. The Greens came to me. They came three times. The first two times I said no."

Messner's eyes have that wild look possessed only by people who do mad things. He has a mane and beard of straggly, rusty red hair. He still looks strong, but agile . . . actually, pretty much exactly like a yeti, though a bit shorter.And he probably doesn't throw rocks at people, or abduct women but I didn't dare ask."Before '86 I wrote in my books the yeti is bullshit. But then when I have seen this big animal, which I could not see exactly what it was, I understood that it was exactly matching with the legend." Messner says "bullshit" a lot - not as an expletive, just as a way of saying something is wrong. I don't believe Messner often thinks he himself is wrong. Frequently, he does not really answer questions, or even hear them, but just ploughs on stubbornly. I guess that is what got him up all those mountains. He becomes animated and excited when talking about yetis and mountains in a way he had not when we had been discussing globalisation and the European Union.

After 12 years of research and more than 20 trips to the Himalayas, scouring monasteries for relics and eventually seeing more "yetis" for himself in Lhasa and the Karakorum, Messner's conclusion is a little disappointing. The yeti does not exist. It is "bullshit", he would say, and does. There is no human-like abominable snowman living in the mountains. The yeti is in fact a Himalayan brown bear. "In the end I thought to myself: how could I need 12 years to come to the answer? It's so obvious."

Is he not disappointed? "Not for me. Because the brown bear is really a monster." What about for the people who live in the Himalayas and have lived with this legend for hundreds of years? "In the local areas they know all that - that this is an animal. But since only every 10 years someone is seeing a real example, so if they speak about it, all the children and normal people that never saw one, they are imagining they are talking about something that isn't a brown bear. We should see the yeti as the sum of the legend and the zoological reality."

Messner is not the first person to realise that the yeti is nothing more than a bear. Ernst Schäfer, who in 1939 headed a secret mission sponsored by the German Reich to incite the Tibetan army against the British, came to the same conclusion. He wrote to tell Messner this before he died in 1992. Messner recalls an encounter Schäfer had with a yeti. "The local people is saying to him, 'Up there in the mountains is a yeti, living in a cave,' and he say, 'Bullshit,' and he goes up with his gun and he is killing it. And he has a big Tibet bear."

Both Sir Edmund Hillary and the Dalai Lama, says Messner, agree that the yeti is just a bear. So what about about all those famous footprints of huge two-legged creatures in the snow? Messner shows me with his hands how a bear might walk on all fours, but with its back feet going into the prints of the front feet to make bigger prints which would appear to be of a two-legged animal.

It is not just the yeti myth that Messner has the answer to. Messner knows that George Mallory did not reach the summit of Everest - because of where his body was found and the shoes he was wearing. "The second step with these shoes is impossible. He could not have done it.

"But most of the people in their books, they say probably he was up, because this is selling much better. If you say it was impossible he was at the summit nobody is interested."

Messner may have the same problem with the yeti book. He has done a few lectures but has not had the turnout he hoped for. "A lot of people said, 'I'm not coming for a bear.' I would have much more success if it had been the other way round - if I'd claimed that it is some big human-like creature. But this is not the answer."

 My Quest for the Yeti is published by Macmillan on August 25, priced £14.99.

webTitle: Leader: Kennedy needs to step on the gas

fields.headline: Time to step on the gas
fields.standfirst: The Lib Dems need more from their leader
fields.trailText: 10 August 2000: Charles Kennedy does not need to read too many assessments of his first year as leader of the Liberal Democrats: he has already made one of his own. By his own admission, he has had a "slow-burn start" in the job - and there are few who would disagree.
fields.body:
Charles Kennedy does not need to read too many assessments of his first year as leader of the Liberal Democrats: he has already made one of his own. By his own admission, he has had a "slow-burn start" in the job - and there are few who would disagree. He has not enjoyed anything like the profile of his predecessor, but that is hardly a fair measure. Paddy Ashdown had 20 years to make his mark, Mr Kennedy has had just 12 months. But has he used that time wisely?

At the top of any credit column must be the triumph of Romsey. The Lib Dems stole the seat from the Tories in a May by-election, an achievement of great audacity coming three years after the landslide Tory defeat of 1997. Losing by-elections is what happens to governments; it is not meant to happen to oppositions. It was very much Mr Kennedy's victory. He campaigned in the constituency himself, daring to go mano a mano with William Hague on the live local issue of asylum. His defence of a truly liberal position on that question was bold, and paid off.

Mr Kennedy has also given his party a measure of clarity, concentrating his fire on three specific areas. He wants to position the Lib Dems as the party of moderate libertarianism, increased spending on public services and concern for the environment. To that end, he made his debut policy pronouncement on the decriminalisation of cannabis, followed by regular demands for Labour to spend more, coupled with lots of warm, green noises. The advantage of this approach is that it understands the limited attention span of the electorate: just getting the Lib Dems on to the national radar screen is achievement enough - transmitting more than three messages at once would clutter the airwaves.

There are two further, rather less obvious accomplishments. Under Mr Kennedy's leadership, the Lib-Lab joint cabinet committee has met only twice. That may look like a failure for "the project," but it could play well for Mr Kennedy. First, it will win over those Lib Dems who feared the new leader would be a poodle for Tony Blair. Second, it might reassure those wavering Tory voters who will come over to the Lib Dems so long as the party does not behave like a government subsidiary.

In the same vein, Mr Kennedy can make a virtue of Labour's recent failure at its policy forum to back Roy Jenkins's plan for voting reform. Officially, Lib Dems should be disappointed, for Labour has opted instead for a model which appears no more proportional than the current system. But Mr Kennedy can tell his party that Labour's policy is at least a step away from first past the post - and that Britain's historic paralysis on electoral reform is at last being broken.

That much the leader can be happy with. But he should not let himself off too easily. His performances in the House of Commons have been pretty dire; he has seemed faint and nervous. He may regard prime minister's questions as "street theatre", but his weakness on that stage matters - if only for the effect it has on his own troops. More generally, he has failed to impress. Even on television, his favourite arena, he resorts too often to political cliche and the pat answer. It is good that he is about to publish a book (though the title, The Future of Politics, is another cliche), for he really does need to gain some philosophical heft.

One year on, Mr Kennedy needs to work out a strategy beyond assuming that the anti-Tory hatred of 1997 will carry him through next time round. He is a man of talents, but he has to work them much harder.

webTitle: Professor Jean E Howard's top 10 books on Shakespeare from the 90s

fields.headline: Professor Jean E Howard's top 10 books on Shakespeare from the 90s
fields.trailText: Professor Jean E Howard teaches early modern literature at Columbia University, USA. She is president of the Shakespeare Association of America and co-editor of Marxist Shakespeares. Her previous publications include Engendering a Nation: A Feminist Account of Shakespeare's English Histories and The Stage and Social Struggle in Early Modern England
fields.body:
Professor Jean E Howard teaches early modern literature at Columbia University, USA. She is president of the Shakespeare Association of America and co-editor of Marxist Shakespeares. Her previous publications include Engendering a Nation: A Feminist Account of Shakespeare's English Histories and The Stage and Social Struggle in Early Modern England.
Buy Engendering a Nation at Amazon.co.uk

1. Suffocating Mothers: Fantasies of Maternal Origin in Shakespeare's Plays by Janet Adelman
Smart feminist psychoanalytic readings of the Bard's most canonised plays.

2. The Body Embarrassed: Drama and the Disciplines of Shame by Gail Paster
Penetrating and often hilarious account of how early modern conceptions of the body differ from our own. Chapters focus on bodily products such as blood, breast milk and urine.

3. Shakespeare Verbatim: The Reproduction of Authenticity and the 1790 Apparatus by Margreta de Grazia
Sophisticated account of how 18th-century editors constructed our modern understanding of Shakespeare's canon and his status as a literary giant.

4. Sodometries: Renaissance Texts, Modern Sexualities by Jonathan Goldberg
Theoretically dazzling inquiry into early modern sexual categories and practices. Stinging critique of the heterosexism that has dogged much modern Shakespeare criticism.

5. Shakespeare Among the Moderns by Richard Halpern
Incisive Marxist analysis of how Shakespeare was read and used by major figures of British modernism.

6. Economies of Race and Gender in Early Modern England by Kim Hall
Groundbreaking inquiry into the discourses of race in the early modern period.

7. Forms of Nationhood: The Elizabethan Writing of England by Richard Helgerson
Prize-winning book showing how early modern texts, including Shakespeare's, helped create the idea of England as a modern nation rather than a feudal kingdom.

8. Fashioning Femininity and English Renaissance Drama by Karen Newman
Theoretically astute and historically grounded inquiry into the languages and social practices that constructed early modern ideas of the feminine.

9. Shakespeare from the Margins: Language, Culture, Context by Patricia Parker
Dazzling work about Shakespeare's language, showing how politics is played out at the level of rhetoric.

10. Shakespeare Without Women by Dympna Callaghan
Trenchant analysis of the gap between Shakespeare's representations of women and people from different ethnic backgrounds and the reality of all-male, and probably all-white, acting troupes.

fields.headline: Getting the message
fields.trailText: 8 August: How an army man can keep hold of a hi-tech job - and increase his salary.
fields.body:
The problem

Since I joined the Royal Signals five years ago I have done a lot of different jobs in the army. Lately I have been managing two large IT networks in Bosnia. I would like to continue in the same work but I know that when I return to my old unit I will be in my old job.

There are people in the Signals who do the work I do at present but their pay band is higher. Is there anything I can do about this?

The solution

I suggest that you tell your superiors how much you are enjoying your current work and ask if there are any openings that you can apply for. I'm sure that you should be able to apply (and have a good chance of getting) any suitable post that might arise in the IT field. Your employer would be wise not to stand in your way since they can only benefit by having an enthusiastic worker in place in a field on their choice.

With regards to your second point about you doing the same work as others who are being paid more, unfortunately, you cannot do much to remedy this unfairness. You see, you are employed on a particular contract, at a particular salary scale, whilst they are employed on a different one. Your contract allows for you to effectively take on different trades at different times, but does not allow your pay to vary according to the trade you are currently working in. This has benefits too - it means that your pay cannot go down if you are doing work that the current incumbents are doing for a lower rate than you.

However, if you do manage change jobs and move into this field, you should, of course, receive the same salary as your contemporaries.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't

webTitle: Edinburgh review:  Carol Kidd/ Larry Adler

fields.headline: Carol Kidd/ Larry Adler
fields.standfirst:
Queens Hall
****

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText:
Queens Hall
****
fields.body:
Folded into a regal blue armchair, Larry Adler looks as fragile as a leaf, and you begin to wonder if he still has the breath to play the harmonica he cups like a baby in his hands. But he has, making it sound like a golden lacework surrounding the crystalline vocals of Carol Kidd. Their Someone To Watch Over Me was a wondrous moment, with Kidd, a great jazz balladeer, leaning close to the stick-thin Adler to catch every nuance in a unique double-bill that closed the Edinburgh Jazz Festival.

Adler is 86 and has been playing the harmonica like no one else for 70 years. He is the last link with the golden age of American music and tells bright tales of cocktails with Dietrich, spats with Sinatra and tennis with Garbo and Chaplin.

Kidd left the stage and Adler launched into Summertime - that glorious thing he has been playing since he worked with Gershwin. He spun out spiralling improvisations over melody lines that are possibly a little more ragged than before.

Kidd returned for I've Got A Crush On You, adding splashes of tone and colour. If anyone is carrying the Adler torch of the confluence of jazz and ballad, it is Kidd. You'd imagine - listening to her impeccable verve on Blue Skies, and achingly poignant Autumn Leaves - she was raised in New York or New Orleans. But she was born in Glasgow and can come over like a gallus Govan auntie who sings like Peggy Lee, although this doesn't dent her consummate vocal tenderness.

fields.headline: Electro-joy
fields.standfirst:
Mouse on Mars
ULU, London
****
fields.trailText:
Mouse on Mars
ULU, London
****
fields.body:
Inspired by Kraftwerk and My Bloody Valentine, Mouse on Mars' Jan St Werner (electronics) and Andi Toma (guitar) describe their style as "electro-kraut-dub-grind". Their wholly individual sound combines elements of ambient, dub, rock, drum'n'bass and techno - but they avoid an eclectic mish mash, instead achieving a genreless, multi-layered mesh of sounds.

As befits Stereolab's remixers of choice, a slice of lounge-kitsch-meets-Krautrock sets the insouciant tone, although it quickly grows harder. St Werner unleashes groans of dissonance and snatches of surreal samples from his Dat and laptop, while their drummer's fluid pace and hyperactivity provide a wonderful contrast to the beguiling guitar rhythms. Tracks from their third album Niun Niggung are presented loud, fast and furious without superfluous show.

Stylistically there are similarities with Luke Vibert and the Aphex Twin: they share a taste for melding epic melodic bombast with cracked voices and dusty electronics. However, Mouse on Mars' fast moving instrumentals are more emotionally charged. The spacious sound has an imaginative sweep and is full of incident and detail.

Mouse on Mars always appear to be dazed with pleasure. Toma dances while picking out notes on his guitar and St Werner encourages the audience to "freak out". Someone takes his proposal further by dancing on stage, and when he's booted off by a security guard, St Werner indignantly berates him. The security guard clearly didn't know that Mouse on Mars access the heart of something quietly unclassifiable: a cross-genre carnival that is both strange and joyous.

fields.headline: Greenspan's lovechild comes of age
fields.standfirst:
MPC takes a bold decision

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: For some in the financial markets, the Bank of England's decision to leave interest rates unchanged when inflation is projected to bust the government's 2.5% target will look like a blatant dereliction of duty. The reason we have a monetary policy committee, they would argue, is so that the authorities cannot play fast and loose with inflation. We now have a committee of Kenneth Clarkes instead of just one.
fields.body:
For some in the financial markets, the Bank of England's decision to leave interest rates unchanged when inflation is projected to bust the government's 2.5% target will look like a blatant dereliction of duty. The reason we have a monetary policy committee, they would argue, is so that the authorities cannot play fast and loose with inflation. We now have a committee of Kenneth Clarkes instead of just one.

Actually, the MPC should be applauded for its wait-and-see stance. As Mervyn King argued yesterday, there is no mechanistic link between the Bank's central projection for inflation in two years - about 2.7% - and the level of interest rates. The three-year history of the MPC shows that the Bank has consistently over-estimated the likely outturn for inflation, primarily because it has been repeatedly frustrated by sterling's refusal to fall. The high level of the pound has cut the cost of imports, helping to offset inflation generated by the domestic economy.

At some point, sterling probably will fall. But that depends on the euro reversing its 19-month decline against the US dollar and nobody knows for sure when that will happen. Aware that raising rates in anticipation of a fall in the exchange rate that might not happen would simply intensify the pressure on firms in the tradeable sector of the economy, the MPC - or at least a majority of it - is in no rush to act.

This may prove a foolhardy strategy, and there will be plenty of people in the City willing to say "I told you so" if inflation starts to take hold as a result. But for the time being, the MPC appears to be displaying a new maturity, with the expertise of its individual members clearly being felt in the decision-making process. Across the Atlantic, the suck-it-and-see approach has been tried with no little success by Alan Greenspan. If the MPC is becoming more like the Fed, that will be no bad thing.

Battling banks

The Barclays bid for Woolwich raises two immediate questions; one specific, the other more general. Take the specific first. Barclays is offering a hefty premium to the pre-bid Woolwich share price. But will it be sufficient to scare off other bidders?

There is a line of argument which suggests Woolwich is worth more to Barclays than to other possible bidders. Its mortgage book would be a handy boost to Barclays' ambitions to expand its presence in the home loans market. Its much admired internet bank would give Barclays - which has well over 1m online customers but which has not developed a stand alone internet bank - a very powerful position in the sector.

That will not stop others taking a long hard look at Woolwich. Even if they decide that the price of playing party pooper there looks too high they may feel encouraged to look further afield. That leads to the second question. In his report to the Treasury Don Cruickshank was cautious about banking consolidation, worrying that it could further weaken competition over current accounts, for example.

The Treasury, however, decided not to block bank mergers, so will the sector now see a mergers and acquisitions free-for-all? Lloyds TSB is one name that has been bandied about as a possible rival to Barclays for Woolwich. Bank of Scotland, loser in the battle for NatWest, clearly has unfulfilled ambitions. Even so, any outbreak of merger activity is likely to be more selective than simply "me-too". Bids will need to show similar focus to the Barclays move for Woolwich. Size alone is unlikely to sell - either to shareholders or the competition authority.

Impotent Opec

It doesn't take much at the moment to spook the markets when it comes to crude oil prices, and when the news emerged yesterday that US reserves have fallen to their lowest since the middle of the 1976 oil crisis, the reaction was predictable. Crude prices jumped back above $30 for the first time in six weeks, before falling back in late trading.

Attention is now focusing on Opec's next meeting, in late September. Bowing to pressure from the US, the producers' cartel has promised to turn on the taps if prices rise above its target band of $22-$28 a barrel.

However, analysts say that rather than acting as a ceiling on prices, $28 a barrel has become the floor: whenever oil prices fall below this level, the market assumes there will be no more quota increases and prices promptly rise again.

Opec has increased production by 235,000 barrels since Saudi Arabia threatened to take unilateral action in early July, but prices have remained stubbornly high. With the US presidential election looming, the question is whether the cartel is likely to opt for further quota increases rather than risk the world's largest oil producer going it alone.

fields.headline: Former societies remain targets
fields.trailText: Almost all the other former building societies, particularly Alliance & Leicester and Northern Rock , were last night cited as potential targets during any consolidation which might spread through the financial services sector.
fields.body:
Almost all the other former building societies, particularly Alliance & Leicester and Northern Rock , were last night cited as potential targets during any consolidation which might spread through the financial services sector.

This inevitable speculation about which bank would be next to fall after Woolwich's embrace by Barclays helped to give the former building societies a much-needed boost towards the prices at which they were floated on the stock market three years ago.

Woolwich was accompanied by Alliance & Leicester, Halifax and Northern Rock when it converted to a bank from a building society in 1997.

News of its takeover talks propelled Woolwich's shares closer to towards the 368p high they reached on their first day of trading.

However, investors who sold before the first day of trading three years ago received a price of 303p, well below the 362p at which the Barclays offer values the bank.

There was some light at the end of the tunnel for investors in Alliance & Leicester, widely believed to have hung up the "for sale" sign last year and still looking for a suitor. Its shares rose to 530p. They still remain below the 542.5p at which they made their stock market debut.

More to gain

For Northern Rock there is still more ground to cover before they touch the 452p at which they made their debut. Last night they closed at 392p after gaining 31p.

Halifax was still below the 774.5p at which it floated , ending last night at 531p. This is because Halifax was not regarded yesterday as an immediate candidate for a predator although Abbey National, the first of the building societies to convert 10 years ago, was considered to be a weaker position and more likely to stalked.

Abbey's shares ended at 754p, compared with the 130p investors received them at in 1989.

Barcwich

The Barclays television advertisement describing itself as the Big Bank would become true with a vengeance if it merged with Woolwich

The combined banks would have:

 2,130 British branches

 17m retail customers

 1.5m net customers

 76,400 employees

 a market capitalisation of £28.4bn

fields.headline: Airtours faces German takeover
fields.standfirst:
By contrast, internet helps Ryanair profits to rise by 26%

Special report: e-finance
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Airtours, Britain's largest tour operator, has run up losses of £75m in the first nine months of the year, leaving it extremely vulnerable to a takeover.
fields.body:
Airtours, Britain's largest tour operator, has run up losses of £75m in the first nine months of the year, leaving it extremely vulnerable to a takeover.

By contrast Ryanair, Europe's largest budget airline, saw its first-quarter profits soar 26% boosted by new routes and passengers getting cheap fares via the internet.

Airtours, which also operates a fleet of aircraft and offers holidays through Saga and Tradewinds, refused to comment on speculation that it is holding talks with C&N Touristic of Germany. Thomson Travel, another major British travel group was bought by Pressag of Germany earlier this year.

Ironically, one of the biggest drains on Airtours' profitability is a newly bought German company Frosch Touristik (FTi). Losses at FTi forced Airtours to issue a profits warning last month.

Airtours chairman David Crossland expressed disappointment that third quarter profits before tax, one-off costs and goodwill amortisation fell to £6.2m from £23.6m at the same period in 1999. Third quarter sales rose 19% to £1.2bn.

Losses in the North American division almost doubled to £15.2m, while the European arm was £17.9m in the red. Britain was the one bright spot, with Airtours notching up a 16% increase in summer bookings this year.

Airtours shares were up 25p at 300p last night showing relief that earnings were in line with expectations. Finance director David Jardine said 2000 had to be the year of restructuring, the benefits of which would show next year.

"We have spent the year getting the right focus and getting out of peripheral businesses. All the indications are now positive," he said.

Airtours plans to downsize its troubled Belgian operation, reorganise in Holland and quit France. It remains determined to expand the German operation through FTi but refused to comment on speculation about any talks with Germany's C&N Touristic.

Julian Easthope, leisure analyst at UBS Warburg, said it was hard to assess whether the company could pull round its US and continental businesses or would sell up to a predator such as C&N.

Meanwhile Ryanair was working hard to damp down City expectations that it can increase its spectacular growth rate and further increase the value of its shares. Chief executive Michael O'Leary said that the pre-tax profits in the first three months, which were up from €18m (£10.7m) to €22.7m (£13.6m), were helped by a strong pound and a successful fuel hedging policy.

The Dublin-based airline said it was amazed by the rapid take-up of online ticket sales, which had allowed Ryanair to cut commissions to travel agents by up to 7%.

KLM chairman Leo van Wijk yesterday said the company will probably present a plan for its merger with British Airways PLC to European and US competition authorities in September.

"Not everything is ready, but if I were to make a forecast, I think the conditions will be in place for everything to be ready in September," he said. He expects European competition commissioner Mario Monti to agree to the merger. "He knows that consolidation is a given on the European market," he said, adding that the two companies could be asked to reduce capacity on the Amsterdam-London route.

fields.headline: Static
fields.standfirst:
Pleasance Below
***

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText:
Pleasance Below
***
fields.body:
A man. A woman. He is going about his life in London, working, shopping, idly turning on the TV and watching the news. She is standing in a field, looking at the sky, a TV crew filming her bloodstained back. In the flicker of a cathode ray tube their lives suddenly collide and impact.

Chris Thorpe's two-hander, which takes the form of two intertwining monologues spoken by characters several hundred miles apart, is a very promising, very controlled piece of new writing about how TV news coverage brings tragedy and atrocity straight into our living rooms and how we dismiss it so easily. As the man says of the breaking news pictures of the woman with the corpse at her feet: "He is just special effects and she is just set dressing."

This is a very cunning, very simple piece of theatre that knows exactly what it is doing. The effect it is achieving with the stabbing emotional pain of the woman provides a sharp contrast with the casual, throwaway cynicism of the man who once "ran the world".

Paul Warwick's beautifully acted production is as sharp and clean as the writing. The performers, standing on sheets of paper, are almost completely immobilised. Only their shifting feet leave indelible stains on the dazzling white. Mud? Blood? More like our guilty indifference staring us in the face.

 Till August 28. Box office: 0131-556 6550.

webTitle: Bank of England warns of high inflation if rates are left on hold

fields.headline: Bank of England warns of high inflation if rates are left on hold
fields.trailText: Financial markets were last night pencilling in further increases in base rates after the Bank of England warned that inflation would breach the government's target if borrowing costs were left on hold at 6%.
fields.body:
Financial markets were last night pencilling in further increases in base rates after the Bank of England warned that inflation would breach the government's target if borrowing costs were left on hold at 6%.

There were signs at its meeting last week that the Bank's monetary policy committee was split over the need to raise rates. The City's money markets are therefore assuming the MPC will tighten monetary policy before the end of the year.

The Bank's deputy governor, Mervyn King, said that the MPC was carefully scrutinising demand and cost pressures in the economy. "In setting interest rates to keep inflation on track to meet the target, the MPC remains steady but ready," he said.

While Mr King was eager to deny any mechanical link between the Bank's inflation target and the level of interest rates, City economists said there would probably be more upward moves in the coming months.

The Bank is expecting inflation, excluding mortgage interest payments, to hit 2.7% in two years, above the 2.5% target set by the government."It is unusual, if not unprecedented, for the committee to forecast inflation above target, and not come back towards target, for the whole of the second year of the forecast," said Geoff Dicks of the Royal Bank of Scotland. The strength of sterling would determine the timing of what will probably be the last rate rise in this cycle, he said.

David Walton, chief UK economist at Goldman Sachs, said the recent rebound in sterling meant there was no immediate pressure on the Bank to move. "But we do expect the MPC to be troubled eventually by the factors it has identified. We continue to expect a 50 point rise in interest rates by next spring," he said.

The Bank's quarterly inflation report said private sector demand growth would need to slow down and that pay pressures in the tight labour market "must not intensify". The profile of inflation was slightly higher than it had been in May, with the fall in the value of sterling offsetting the easing of house price inflation and weaker earnings growth.

Mr King acknowledged that members had differed over the likely path of the exchange rate and the possible risks to the inflation forecast.

Any hopes for a cut in interest rates were dashed. "I think you would find it difficult, given this outlook for inflation, to think that the immediate outlook is one of cutting interest rates," Mr King told a press conference to launch the Bank's report.

He gave little support to the argument made by the Conservatives that the £43bn of extra spending announced by Mr Brown in last month's comprehensive spending review would increase inflationary pressure. Mr King said the projections were marginally higher than expected in the March Budget, chiefly due to past underspending.

He added that they might make "a small addition to overall demand growth".

According to the MPC there was no overall impact on the inflation project.

webTitle: Homebase to set up DIY website

fields.headline: Changing rooms
fields.standfirst:
Budding decorators learn online
Special report: e-finance
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Homebase, the DIY chain owned by Sainsbury's, is investing £21m in a website intended to "demystify" interior design. The site will provide advice and ideas and sell products online.
fields.body:
Homebase, the DIY chain owned by Sainsbury's, is investing £21m in a website intended to "demystify" interior design. The site will provide advice and ideas and sell products online.

Customers will have access to different decorating styles and will be given guidance on how to achieve a particular result. In addition there will be more than 5,000 purchases on offer for home delivery.

The site is intended to tackle a market for home improvement which Homebase believes is worth £625m.

Homebase's managing director, Kate Swann, said: "It is intended to offer inspiration, rather than just sell products."

She said it was difficult for staff in stores to provide detailed advice to each customer, although she added: "Bricks and clicks will be the model. People will still want to come in, feel and touch the products in the stores."

Homebase has already spent £10m on the project and the figure will rise to £21m by April, partly through marketing and advertising costs.

The company, which has 297 stores, claims to be the first in Britain to sell DIY products to consumers on the net. Over the years, it has widened its scope from "nuts and bolts" DIY products to more sophisticated furnishings.

The DIY market is going through a period of rapid expansion, partly due to the popularity of television programmes such as Changing Rooms.

Ikea, the Swedish furnishings retailer, recently announced it would open 20 new stores across the country.

fields.headline: The Wake
fields.standfirst:
Hill Street Theatre
*****

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText:
Hill Street Theatre
*****
fields.body:
Two women meet at a wake. Ellen, a widow racked by grief, sits sobbing, rocking back and forth. Chloe, the mortician's daughter, shouldn't be there, but can't resist the food or the chance to meet boys. What unfolds in this 25-minute play is blisteringly funny, a surreal and yet deeply true encounter in which the most unlikely friendship is made.

David Widdicombe's writing manages that rare trick of being observational on the bizarre aspects of life and death without dissolving into a forced zany-fest (see most of the rest of the comic-dramatic writing on the fringe).

So, the way Ellen's husband has died - you'll have to find out for yourself - is tragic, desperately and absurdly comic, and yet neatly underplayed. The one-liners, such as they are, are similarly understated. Chloe's short for Chloroform, she says, all absent-minded lost soul munching on a radish.

The play's success owes a lot also to the quality of the performances by Nicola Harrison and Susan Bovell. They manage to handle convincingly some tough terrain (wild grief, oddball persona, mad anger, ultra-short play) and some surreal lines that in the wrong hands could be thrown away as just another run-of-the-mill bit of kookiness.

 Till August 28. Box office: 0131-226 6522.

fields.headline: Net firms strike $7bn WAP deal
fields.standfirst:
Special report: e-finance
Net news
fields.trailText: Phone.com and Software.com, two internet software companies, announced a merger worth at least $6.8bn (£4.5bn) yesterday in a deal which underlines the fast-growing nature of so-called wireless access to the internet.
fields.body:
Phone.com and Software.com, two internet software companies, announced a merger worth at least $6.8bn (£4.5bn) yesterday in a deal which underlines the fast-growing nature of so-called wireless access to the internet.

Share prices in both companies increased sharply following the announcement of the merger, bringing the total value of the all-share transaction closer to $8bn by noon in New York.

Wall Street analysts said that the deal could make it easier to access the same communication service such as email from conventional land lines and mobile telephones.

Phone.com, which provides software and applications for wireless telephones, was instrumental in the adoption of the wireless application protocol - or WAP - standard, while Software.com has focused on providing communications services such as email and instant messaging for use on computers.

One analyst who declined to be named described the combination as a "wake-up call for Microsoft" because the world's largest software company still cannot provide a "carrier class" mobile service.

Simon Buckingham, an analyst at Mobile Lifestreams, a research company, said the deal guaranteed Phone.com's long-term future by adding a solid technology platform to its wireless base.

The California-based companies list British Telecommunications, Sprint, Telecom Italia Mobile and AT&T among their clients.

With little overlap, the companies hope they can cross-sell their products.

Donald Listwin is to leave US-based Cisco Systems, the world's largest internet infrastructure equipment supplier, to become chief executive of the combined group.

Yesterday he said the merger would create a "global software company" with a powerful position among communication service providers.

Alain Rossman, Phone.com's current chief executive, is to become chairman of the merged group.

Under the terms of the deal, shareholders in Software.com are to receive 1.6 shares in Phone.com, valuing their stake at $125 a share, based on Tuesday's closing price.

After Phone.com's share price rose almost 20% yesterday the shares were valued at more than $146. Shares in Software.com rose 33% on the news to $147.

The stock market performance of both companies since they launched at less than $30 a share 14 months ago shows that investors are still relatively bullish on the "internet infrastructure" - or simply network - sector.

However, even after yesterday's share price increase both are trading below the highs of $208 and $155 reached in March before the market-wide sell-off in technology shares.

Once completed, shareholders of each group are to own about 50% of the newly combined company.

The group is to confirm a new name once shareholders have given their consent to the planned merger.

Phone.com has between 200 and 300 sales staff in the US; no job cuts are anticipated as a result of the deal.

fields.headline: Lights on Broadway
fields.standfirst:
Sondheim Tribute/ Street Scenes
Royal Albert Hall, London
***
fields.trailText:
Sondheim Tribute/ Street Scenes
Royal Albert Hall, London
***
fields.body:
Kurt Weill once explained that he never acknowledged any difference between "serious" music and "light" music; there was only good music and bad. George Gershwin and Stephen Sondheim, who shared this prom with him, might well have agreed.

Sondheim celebrates his 70th birthday this year, and in celebration, singer Kim Criswell presented a six-number survey of his work. In front of the BBC Concert Orchestra, Criswell was every inch the Broadway diva, whether in the girl-next-door comic patter of Getting Married Today or the sustained love song Not a Day Goes By.

Gershwin's An American in Paris opened the concert in a spirited but rough-edged performance. It was another of Gershwin's more "serious" works, the opera Porgy and Bess, that inspired Kurt Weill to write a number of Broadway operas, of which one of the best known is Street Scene.

A concert sequence extracted from the opera and entitled Street Scenes here received its UK premiere. In making this new abridgement, Lys Symonette and Kim Kowalke cut out all the numbers that were deemed unnecessary to the central plot and concentrated on the story of the Maurrant family. The ironic result was that we were left with a single scenario rather than the several scenes of gritty social commentary of the complete opera.

With nothing to put it into relief the blow of tragedy was softened and the music became repetitive. The only lighter number left in the sequence, Wouldn't You Like to Be on Broadway?, sounded as though it had wandered in from another theatre. The soloists did a good job, but the performance showed that Weill is a more heavyweight composer if you leave his "light" music where it was intended.

fields.headline: Football crazy
fields.standfirst:
Wideboy
Gospel Project Arts Centre, Dublin
****
fields.trailText:
Wideboy
Gospel Project Arts Centre, Dublin
****
fields.body:
Ken Harmon's new one-man play kicks up football memories of 1995, when an England-Ireland friendly in Dublin was abandoned because, after the Irish scored, English yobs tore up the terraces and flung them at Irish police. The monologue charts the reaction from a world of rough West Dublin estates. It's a colourful, macho satire in which everyone is endemically criminalised.

Ronan Leahy plays Snorkie, a low-level mad bastard who is generally on the receiving end in life: from his grave-robbing stone-mason boss to his girlfriend Nicola, or indeed her brother Sammy "Duracell", a much-admired local psycho. The play kicks off with a drunken truth game in which Snorkie tells Nicola that he robbed a car - the crime for which the local paramilitaries hospitalised Duracell. So Snorkie's owed a hiding, and the England game only serves as a tension-diffuser.

The hilarity gets black as Snorkie describes the coming together of the local tribes in the pub. The staccato script is pure Dublin baroque, a great thump of contemporary slang. The "smell my middle finger" lad's humour, however, prevents any possible pathos, or much real penetration into the mad sectarianism of Harmon's subject matter.

Leahy's performance is like a controlled explosion. Under Jimmy Fay's direction, he choreographs it like one long martial arts manoeuvre: karate turns and air-punches, the percussive nose-hiss with every head-slap, malignantly searching every face in the auditorium after his more evil utterances.

Until Saturday. Box office: 00 353 1 679 6622.

fields.headline: Hitchcock's Half Hour
fields.standfirst:
Pleasance Upstairs
*

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText:
Pleasance Upstairs
*
fields.body:
Hitchcock's Half Hour's widely trumpeted Notorious isn't comedy so much as a psychological exercise on the folly of great expectations. The duo are flyposted all over Edinburgh as the "new young gods of comedy", but I can agree with only one aspect of that description. Unless their technical man is a god of soft, flattering lighting, neither of them is a day over 25. As a comedy double act, however, they are as much use as a plumber with a toolbox full of eels.

It really is time somebody from trades descriptions or customs did something about jokes that just aren't funny, because this pair have smuggled in a lorryload. Frequently spoofing pop songs, they are the first people ever to locate something that isn't funny about Elton John. The pitiful Eminem pastiche - "My name is enema" - is typical of the unappealing school humour that is the real reason local authorities have fenced off playgrounds. The occasional film material is very funny - they should definitely run with Poo Athletics - but they are further let down by poor stage presence and, unforgivably, forgotten lines. I was dying to laugh at the sketch where these two nincompoops assaulted each other to the strains of Britney Spears. Not, of course, for the reasons they intended.

 Till August 28. Box office: 0131-556 6550.

webTitle: Edinburgh review:  Pick Ups and Hick Ups

fields.headline: Pick Ups and Hick Ups
fields.standfirst:
Pleasance Upstairs
*****

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText:
Pleasance Upstairs
*****
fields.body:
Worryingly subtitled To Love, Honour & Castrate, this is a hilariously cynical look at mating and dating that should have grown men fearing for their genitals and comedy fans of both sexes clutching their sides.

Spawned by Seth Meyers and Jill Benjamin, from American comedy troupe Boom Chicago, Pick Ups is an exercise in improvised dialogue, directed by the audience. At one point Meyers (as hapless romantic Randy) has to construct a love plea using the (audience-supplied) ingredients "typing on a toe", "wet patch" and "naked mole-rat".

The pair's quick thinking would straighten a pubic hair, their one-liners curdle cream, while their blistering interplay has the sharpness of The Odd Couple or a Woody Allen movie. Benjamin's look of disgust is worth the admission price alone.

We are whisked through romantic episodes, many suggesting discomfort to the penis and one involving tabasco sauce. Visits to the deli may never be quite the same afterwards, but this is a one-night stand worth revisiting again and again.

 Till August 28. Box office: 0131-556 6550.

fields.headline: Bob Doolally
fields.standfirst:
The Stand
****

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText:
The Stand
****
fields.body:
What Al Murray is to publicans, Bob Doolally is to football punditry. Created by Paul Sneddon (who commentated on Euro 2000 for - appropriately - Australian radio), this alcohol- and bile-spewing madman is just as witheringly observed as the landlord. Crucially, he is not that much of an exaggeration of the neanderthal, nostalgia-obsessed has-beens who still crop up on the after-dinner circuit and Sky TV.

Like Andy Gray crossed with Jimmy Hill wearing Alex Ferguson's hair after 90 minutes in a microwave, Doolally polishes off Smirnoff rather than defenders. He is seemingly out of control but ceaselessly able to think on his feet, as demonstrated during a hilarious question-and-answer section on football.

Targets subject to red-card challenges include "great plarrrrrs" Keegan, Owen, Scots manager Craig Brown ("How did he get three girlfriends? Is Horlicks an aphrodisiac?"). The tale of how he received a "shite" in the post from Alex Ferguson has to be heard, if not believed. If you like football and don't mind swearing, you'll love Bob.

 Till August 28. Box office: 0131-558 7272.

webTitle: Edinburgh review: A Woman in Waiting

fields.headline: A Woman in Waiting
fields.standfirst:
Assembly Rooms
****

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText:
Assembly Rooms
****
fields.body:
Thembi Mtshali was born in a storm. Not just literally born "on the day the rains came"; she grew up in South Africa, suffering the indignities, injustices and inequities of being a black woman living under apartheid. All are related exquisitely in this exemplary, autobiographical one-woman show.

From her earliest years, counting the moons until Christmas when she could see her mother, through the ache of waiting to see her own daughter as she cared for other people's children, to the terror of night raids, A Woman in Waiting tells the story of many South African women - and of South Africa itself.

The story's ending is quite apparent - Mtshali is now one of South Africa's most celebrated artists - and as a result the piece suffers slightly from the problem of sustaining tension. But the relish with which the story of her life is told - from the undulating rhythms that permeate the piece; the themes of heritage, time and belonging that underpin it; and the sheer beauty of the language, which echoes around the simplest, sparest of sets - is exhilarating, moving and, above all, life-affirming.

 Till August 28. Box office: 0131-226 2428.

From her earliest years, counting the moons until Christmas when she could see her mother, through the ache of waiting to see her own daughter as she cared for other people's children, to the terror of night raids, A Woman in Waiting tells the story of many South African women - and of South Africa itself. The story's ending is quite apparent - Mtshali is now one of South Africa's most celebrated artists - and as a result the piece suffers slightly from the problem of sustaining tension. But the relish with which the story of her life is told - from the undulating rhythms that permeate the piece; the themes of heritage, time and belonging that underpin it; and the sheer beauty of the language, which echoes around the simplest, sparest of sets - is exhilarating, moving and, above all, life-affirming.  Till August 28. fields.headline: Woolwich boss wins big job
fields.standfirst: Barclays chief given reprieve as critical management roles are allocated in merged group
fields.trailText: John Stewart, the chief executive of Woolwich, is thought to have won one of the most senior management roles at Barclays on the successful completion of the £5.5bn takeover talks with its larger rival.
fields.body:
John Stewart, the chief executive of Woolwich, is thought to have won one of the most senior management roles at Barclays on the successful completion of the £5.5bn takeover talks with its larger rival.

The appointment of the Woolwich boss as deputy chief executive with special responsibility for mortgages and the net is expected to be positioned in such a way that John Varley, currently the most senior executive in the Barclays retail financial services operation, is able to cling on to his role - at least temporarily.

The banks, which were yesterday forced to publish sketchy details of their £5.5bn takeover talks after intense speculation, were last night racing to cement the details before a counter-bidder could step in to scupper the first strategic move by Barclays' chief executive, Matt Barrett.

Among the last points to be agreed ahead of a final announcement scheduled for to morrow were which executives should fill the senior roles in the combined bank and in particular the position of Mr Varley, the head of the bank's retail financial services operation during a time of unpopular branch closures and cash machine charges.

Under the terms of the Woolwich takeover both brands are to be retained via the banks' branches, although it was unclear how many would be earmarked for closure if the deal were completed. The possibility of job cuts was also raised.

News of the talks, widely regarded to be with Barclays' second choice for a deal, ignited the stock market amid speculation that a wave of mergers and takeovers would finally break out in the sector. Many City sources believe Mr Barrett would have preferred to clinch the agreement of Abbey National for a merger to achieve his goal of boosting mortgage market share.

Shares in Barclays, which plans to pay for Woolwich partly with its own shares, fell 49p to £16.15; Woolwich's rose to £3.41 - still below the £3.62 a share at which the Barclays bid was priced before yesterday's price movements.

Among the day's fastest rises were Alliance & Leicester and Northern Rock, both regarded as bid candidates. Lloyds TSB, which has built itself up through a series of mergers, fell back amid uncertainty about whether the bank would try to clinch another deal.

As the sensitive final details of the takeover were being negotiated, speculation mounted about the roles being allocated to Barclays executives after yesterday's hastily prepared statement by the two banks.

One of the aims was to incorporate "Woolwich's brand, management, products and capabilities to accelerate the achievement of Barclays' strategic ambitions, particularly in retail financial services."

An industry source said: "Part of the appeal for Barclays is the Woolwich management." It is understood that a senior role for Woolwich finance director Richard Meddings was under discussion last night.

The takeover talks follow a turbulent period for Barclays and mark the first major move by Mr Barrett - who became chief executive in October, just as the bid battle for his closest rival, NatWest, got under way.

With NatWest falling to Royal Bank of Scotland, Mr Barrett found himself running a bank consigned to fourth place in the market's ranking, behind HSBC, Lloyds TSB and Royal Bank of Scotland.

Even with the Woolwich, Barclays would remain in fourth place but make a big leap towards closing the gap.

webTitle: John Lewis to hide sales figures

fields.headline: John Lewis to hide sales figures
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The John Lewis Partnership, traditionally renowned for its openness, has stopped publishing weekly sales figures in its staff magazine. It fears that the information is falling into rivals' hands.
fields.body:
The John Lewis Partnership, traditionally renowned for its openness, has stopped publishing weekly sales figures in its staff magazine. It fears that the information is falling into rivals' hands.

The Gazette, which is circulated to "partners" - staff members - in all the group's stores, contains a list showing the change in sales for every product category each week.

Editor Paul Burden has informed readers that this practice is to stop, because the chain needs to be "a little less forthcoming" in what it reveals to its competitors.

A spokesman for John Lewis said: "The high street has become more and more competitive. The heads of rival retailers are all avid readers of this stuff."

He said that other chains kept a close watch on the progress of the various departments, and often copied the John Lewis product range in areas performing particularly well.

Last week's figures were the last to be published. They showed audio and television accessories as the star performers, with a 47% increase in year-on-year sales. Bridal wear took the wooden spoon, with revenue down by 25.4%.

Mike Godliman, an analyst at the retail research firm Verdict, said: "This is quite commercially sensitive information and it has to be a disadvantage for them to reveal it. Competition is heating up and companies need to stay one step ahead."

He said retailing rivalry had picked up over the past year as the number of shops had reached saturation point.

"For the first time in history, there are enough stores to supply the entire British public," he said.

New channels such as the internet, catalogue retailing and interactive television have caused a further squeeze.

Demographics have pushed down the demand for goods. "Baby boomers" are getting older and have got most of the consumer goods they want.

fields.headline: Takeover talk boosts banks
fields.standfirst:
Market forces Neil Hume

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: It was all rather predictable. Yesterday, the only thing that mattered on the London stock market was the banks.
fields.body:
It was all rather predictable. Yesterday, the only thing that mattered on the London stock market was the banks.

And they went up. Alliance & Leicester jumped 31p to 530p, Abbey National put on 19p to 754p, Northern Rock gained 25p to 392p and Halifax rose 10.5p to 531p as investors placed their bets on the next former building society to fall victim to the tide of consolidation sweeping the sector.

The indiscriminate buying, of course, was triggered by Barclays' forced admission of takeover talks with mortgage lender Woolwich, up 72p to 341p.

The favourites were Alliance & Leicester and Northern Rock, both of which are, by historic standards, cheap. With a market capitalisation of just £2.79bn, Alliance & Leicester in particular looks vulnerable, dealers said. Its shares have fallen steadily since the start of the year as investors have fretted about the fierce competition in the home loan lending market.

But with only 55% of its business in the mortgage market, Alliance is hardly over exposed and would appear to be cheap at current levels.

Moreover, with Alliance facing the prospect of relegation from the FTSE-100 at the next quarterly review, the pressure to do a deal is on.

Meanwhile, Barclays ended the day 49p weaker at £16.15, valuing Woolwich, under the terms of the possible cash and paper deal, at 352.8p per share. The fact that Woolwich shares closed below the offer price suggested the market was not expecting a counter offer from either Lloyds TSB, off 2.5p at 613, or Royal Bank of Scotland, 24p higher at £12.87.

With the Woolwich takeover finally out in the open, the speculative cash was looking for a new home and it settled on either support services group Hays, unchanged at 392p, or telecoms group Thus, up 7.25p to 130p on volume of 9.2m shares.

Since a profits warning last week, Thus has seen its shares nosedive and according to the gossips a number of network providers are already running the slide rule over the company.

As ScottishPower still retains a 50.1% stake, any deal would have to be agreed, but with Thus shares some 700p below their 52-week high, would it really sell out now?

Inspired by the performance of the banking sector, the blue-chip index closed in firm territory, though well off its earlier highs as a dull performance from Wall Street eroded earlier gains.

At the close, the FTSE-100 index was 55.9 points firmer at 6,414, off an earlier peak of 6,463.1, as 1.4bn shares changed hands.

Away from the banks, EMI recovered from Tuesday's mauling (closing 50p better at 650p) as fears over US legal action on compact disc prices waned.

UBS Warburg issued "strong buy" and said Tuesday's sell-off had presented a good buying opportunity.

Strong figures from networking company Cisco Systems on Tuesday, lent support to Marconi, which closed 26p stronger to £10.55, and the FTSE-250's BATM Advanced Communications was 22.5p better at 627.5p.

Elsewhere, Reed International, the London-listed arm of Anglo-Dutch publishing group Reed Elsevier, rose 39p to 566p after better than expected interim results and a well received meeting with City analysts. According to those present, chief executive Crispin Davis gave a polished performance.

Talk of corporate action at specialist shipping group James Fisher, up 3p to 86.5p, appears to be wide of the mark.

Finance director Mike Shields yesterday put the recent sharp rise in the share price down to tips in a couple of magazines and its deal to charter two cable laying vessels to a subsidiary of General Dynamics Advanced Technology Systems. The company reports interim figures on September 14.

webTitle: Boje claims five to give South Africa the edge

fields.headline: Boje claims five to give South Africa the edge
fields.trailText: Nicky Boje took his second five-wicket haul in Test cricket as South Africa gained a 21-run first-innings lead in the decisive third and final match against Sri Lanka yesterday.
fields.body:
Nicky Boje took his second five-wicket haul in Test cricket as South Africa gained a 21-run first-innings lead in the decisive third and final match against Sri Lanka yesterday.

South Africa extended their lead to 48 by reaching 27 for no wicket in their second in nings when rain ended play early on the third day. Boje took five for 62 to help dismiss Sri Lanka for 258 at tea.

The left-arm spinner had three wickets on the second day and added Mahela Jayawardene and Arjuna Ranatunga to his list of victims.

Jayawardene was caught at short third man by Gary Kirsten for 34 and Ranatunga was bowled for 14 when he attempted to sweep against the spin.

Mornantau Hayward had Kumar Sangakkara caught behind by Mark Boucher for 25. Shaun Pollock then cleaned up the tail with the second new ball.

Sri Lanka, resuming in the morning at 138 for four, lost their nightwatchman Chaminda Vaas in the last over before lunch after rain had delayed the start.

webTitle: Mullally's purple patch continues against old pals

fields.headline: Mullally's purple patch continues against old pals
fields.standfirst: Leicestershire 265-9  v Hampshire
fields.trailText: Leicestershire 265-9 v Hampshire
fields.body:
David Gower was said to be so laid-back he might as well be comatose. Arguably the biggest struggle Alan Mullally faces also lies in convincing people, selectors in particular, that he possesses a set of functioning sweat glands.

Evidence of toil is limited; the body language whispers. It is easier to imagine the Hampshire left-armer strumming his guitar and chanting "We Shall Overcome" than exhorting colleagues to more tangible defiance. He is, nevertheless, ranked world No2 in the one-day fray, yet losing his Test place stung, and now the county set are paying the price.

Mullally is enjoying a purple patch embroidered with lilac and mauve trimmings. Given that the parting was apparently more sweet than sorrowful, the visit by his former county was hardly likely to temper the renewed verve and aggression that had yielded three five-fers in his previous four innings, including a career-best nine for 93.

By stumps, sure enough, another quintet had been safely bagged; of the last 44 wickets taken by Hampshire, 25 have come courtesy of the artist commonly known as Pal.

The hosts were shorn of Shane Warne, back in Australia for the first one-day internationals to be held indoors. Eager, perhaps, to show they can get by without him, Hampshire's commitment was such that Robin Smith chased 40 yards then slid feet-first into the hoardings with a thump that suggested the LSO's timpani section was practising in the pavilion.

There were times, notably while Aftab Habib was punching 10 fours en route to 50, when Leicestershire promised prosperity, though Habib was fortune to get that far.

On 13, he inside-edged Dimitri Mascarenhas, tried to kick the ball clear but could only direct it towards the stumps. Timbers, though, refused to be shivered, leaving Habib to indulge in some bail-kissing. He was rather less gleeful to be adjudged caught behind off Mullally after a stylish 61.

Iain Sutcliffe, whose PPE degree from Oxford makes him one of the least well-qual ified blokes ever to play sport for a living, forged his first half-century of term before falling to a fine catch behind square by a sub, Irfan Shah.

There were also some lusty blows from Jon Dakin, whose demise, mis-driving to slip, ensured that Hampshire maintained their record of maximum bowling points in every match. Against a much weakened Leicestershire attack, a belated batting maximum beckons.

The hosts were shorn of Shane Warne, back in Australia for the first one-day internationals to be held indoors. Eager, perhaps, to show they can get by without him, Hampshire's commitment was such that Robin Smith chased 40 yards then slid feet-first into the hoardings with a thump that suggested the LSO's timpani section was practising in the pavilion. There were times, notably while Aftab Habib was punching 10 fours en route to 50, when Leicestershire promised prosperity, though Habib was fortune to get that far. On 13, he inside-edged Dimitri Mascarenhas, tried to kick the ball clear but could only direct it towards the stumps. Timbers, though, refused to be shivered, leaving Habib to indulge in some bail-kissing. He was rather less gleeful to be adjudged caught behind off Mullally after a stylish 61. Iain Sutcliffe, whose PPE degree from Oxford makes him one of the least well-qual ified blokes ever to play sport for a living, forged his first half-century of term before falling to a fine catch behind square by a sub, Irfan Shah. There were also some lusty blows from Jon Dakin, whose demise, mis-driving to slip, ensured that Hampshire maintained their record of maximum bowling points in every match. Against a much weakened Leicestershire attack, a belated batting maximum beckons.

webTitle: Lord's may not have switched on, but the floodlit game has a bright future

fields.headline: Lord's may not have switched on, but the floodlit game has a bright future
fields.standfirst: Nocturnal cricket is bringing back the spectators despite a chaotic fixture list.  Andy Wilson reports
fields.trailText: Nocturnal cricket is bringing back the spectators despite a chaotic fixture list. Andy Wilson reports.
fields.body:
Nasser Hussain will today seek to regain his batting form in the manner of England captains for the past century or more, in the restful environment of the county championship - in his case at Kidderminster, where Essex are playing Worcestershire.

But for Mike Atherton and Marcus Trescothick, the other two batsmen required in England's second innings at Old Trafford on Monday, the post-Test cricket will take a very different form: floodlit National League matches, with all the surrounding razzmatazz, in Atherton's case at Headingley and for Trescothick at Bristol.

Yorkshire and Gloucestershire, who are hosting fixtures with regional significance against Lancashire and Somerset respectively, are hoping for five-figure crowds. Whatever happens, they are each guaranteed to attract more paying spectators than today's six first-class matches, including Hussain's trip to Kidderminster and the West Indies' latest tour fixture at Derby, can muster in total.

As Dave Gilbert, the Australian general manager of Sussex, the only county to have so far installed permanent floodlights, says: "Day-night cricket is here to stay because people are voting with their feet. Floodlit cricket has definitely gone against the national trend which has been decreasing attendances."

Gilbert argues that the new, nocturnal form of the game is succeeding despite, rather than because of, the England and Wales Cricket Board. He points to the chaotic nature of the fixture list, with floodlit matches popping up on all days of the week, and the inadequacy of the temporary lights that are used at all grounds other than Hove.

A worrying number of the day-night matches have been won comfortably by the team batting first, leading to suspicions that the lights that the ECB hires and part-funds are not strong enough. "I went to Edgbaston for the one-day international between England and Zimbabwe and I was quite shocked at how murky the light was at 10 o'clock," said Gilbert. "For international cricket it's not good enough."

These are charges that Terry Blake, the ECB's marketing director, takes on board. "Alec Stewart was also critical after that Edgbaston game and yes, it's important that we've got good lights, but we have very good people putting in the temporary lights and it's not for the want of funding," he said. "The next step is permanent lights, but permanent lights of the substantial variety is a serious expenditure.

"With regard to the fixtures, I think chaotic is a strong word because the fixture system is incredibly complicated to work out. We are trying to fit a quart into a pint pot.

"I suppose in an ideal world you would say that we ought to have a floodlit festival in a more condensed period of time. It's a bit chilly in April and May, and maybe June is a bit ambitious because of the beginning of the international programme. So maybe July and August would be the time to concentrate on floodlit cricket, that's one way of looking at it.

"We are about halfway through an experimental phase. At the end of next season we will be having a review to see where floodlit cricket should fit into the domestic structure after 2002, when our current television deal expires."

Gilbert has some strong recommendations. "We want Friday nights," he said. "Then you get the best of both worlds, the corporate and also the kids because there's no school the next day.

"But unfortunately the way the fixture schedules are for the next couple of years, Championship cricket has to be Wednesday to Saturday. If the ECB are going to support floodlit cricket, they have to support it in terms of the evenings to hold it."

Where Gilbert and Blake do agree is on floodlit cricket's importance to the future of the English game at county and international level. "We have been doing a lot of exit research at floodlit matches and one-day internationals, and the statistics from last year suggested that we are getting to a new age group of 16 to 34, and more women, and more first-time users, and that's very important," said Blake.

"Floodlit cricket was certainly a brave new world and unfortunately there's still the doubting Thomases out there who want to see it fail," added Gilbert. "But it's not going to fail because you're putting cricket on when people can watch it, both at the ground and on TV.

"Cricket as a sport just can't keep relying on this is what we used to do. So many other sports have moved massively ahead in the way they promote and market themselves. And if cricket wants to keep saying this is the way we've always done it, well, you're going to get trodden on."

webTitle: Wenger puts his faith in lesser lights

fields.headline: Wenger puts his faith in lesser lights
fields.trailText: Arsenal fans have not been flocking to buy replica shirts emblazoned with the names Lauren or Demel, two of the summer arrivals. But those worried by the comings and goings at Highbury may be comforted by Arsène Wenger's attack yesterday on managers whose signing of ageing stars confuses reputation with reality.
fields.body:
Arsenal fans have not been flocking to buy replica shirts emblazoned with the names Lauren or Demel, two of the summer arrivals. But those worried by the comings and goings at Highbury may be comforted by Arsène Wenger's attack yesterday on managers whose signing of ageing stars confuses reputation with reality.

In an apparent reference to the recent deals which have taken Alen Boksic to Middlesbrough and George Weah to Manchester City, Wenger suggested the pensioner invasion was more likely to sell kits than win matches. Despite the loss of Emmanuel Petit and Marc Overmars, he will buy according to quality rather than quantity of caps.

"I do not want to become a victim to the star system, where you go and buy a name but the player is dead," the Arsenal manager said. "Everybody is happy about it at first but on the field you have a problem. I would prefer to buy a player with no name but who can give good performances.

"I'm not going to talk about individual players that clubs have bought but that is my overall view. When you buy a big name people might look at what you have got and say you have a good team just because of who you bought, but then on the field you can have a problem. You have to have the right quality of player."

The signing of Davor Suker, sold on to West Ham this summer, was one of the few occasions Wenger has bought a big-name player past his peak. And the success he has had with the relatively unknown Petit, Patrick Vieira and Nicolas Anelka is proof his policy can work.

"When I signed Petit nobody knew him," Wenger remarked. "He wasn't even a midfielder. And when it came to Overmars he had been on the market for five months and no other club wanted him." This season he said he intends to give a chance to young players, including Jermaine Pennant and the left-back Ashley Cole.

Wenger has high expectations of his two main close-season signings, the 23-year-old Cameroonian Lauren and the 27-year-old France midfielder Robert Pires. But having lost out on the Brazilian Edu because of passport problems, he said yesterday he was also "not very confident" of landing Sylvain Wiltord from Bordeaux.

The French club want more than the £10m Arsenal are thought to have offered and Wenger confirmed: "It's all about money because he wants to come." If the deal falls through, Wenger will look to sign one of the other strikers he has "on the horizon" before the first Champions League deadline on September 1.

Definitely bought is the 19-year-old French midfielder Guy Demel from Nimes. Arsenal have also reached an agreement to sign two Latvia international triallists, the winger Andrey Rubins and the centre-back Igor Stepanov, from Skonto Riga, subject to obtaining work permits.
