webTitle: Real tell McManaman he can earn £56,000 per week for doing nothing

fields.headline: Real tell McManaman he can earn £56,000 per week for doing nothing
fields.trailText: If he did not know it already, Steve McManaman discovered there was no room for sentiment in football yesterday when Real Madrid effectively declared him surplus to requirements.
fields.body:
If he did not know it already, Steve McManaman discovered there was no room for sentiment in football yesterday when Real Madrid effectively declared him surplus to requirements.

Little more than two months after scoring in a man-of-the-match contribution to their European Cup final victory over Valencia and only 14 months after signing from Liverpool, the England midfielder has been told in no uncertain terms he no longer figures in their first-team plans.

"I have spoken to Steve about the situation and told him he has little chance of playing this year," confirmed the Real coach Vicente del Bosque.

McManaman responded by reiterating his desire to remain at the Bernabeu, having turned down a chance to return to the Premiership with Middlesbrough.

"I've spoken to the coach and [technical director Jose Martinez] Pirri and they have told me that, in sporting terms, this year is going to be very hard for me.

"I told them I wanted to stay and they said: 'Fine, but it's going to be a battle for your place in the side.' I said no problem. I'm willing to work hard and I want to be successful here.

"I want to fight for my place in the team and push for my chances of playing. I have never had things easy but I have always ended up playing and now I hope the same thing happens again. I learned a lot in my first season here and I want to continue learning - to become a better player and a better person."

Del Bosque sees Luis Figo as his automatic choice on the right of midfield following his world-record £37m transfer from Barcelona and two other new signings, Claude Makelele and Flavio Conceicao, are expected to contest the central midfield position vacated by Fernando Redondo.

McManaman has three years remaining on his contract and the Spanish sports daily Marca, which noted that the midfielder had reverted to expressing himself in English, is reporting that Real want to sell him as part of an effort to reduce their wage bill. McManaman is believed to be earning about £56,000 a week - a consequence of arriving on a Bosman free transfer - making him one of the highest-paid players at the Bernabeu.

He was the only Real player not to figure in the Bayern Munich centenary tournament last weekend and it appears to be a question of when, rather than if, his time with the European champions is brought to an end.

The likelihood of him returning to the Premiership remains distant, however, with McManaman emphasising: "I don't see any reason to return to England."

fields.headline: Small charities find it hard to win lottery fundng
fields.standfirst: For smaller charities, it can seem harder to win lottery funding than to win the lottery itself.  Nicola Hill  reports
fields.trailText: For smaller charities, it can seem harder to win lottery funding than to win the lottery itself. Nicola Hill reports.
fields.body:
Chris Smith, the minister responsibile for the national lottery, has won just £50 on it in five years. So he has every sympathy with those good causes, at the other end of the operation, which have struggled equally long and hard to win lottery funding.

Following publication last week of the Quest report, proposing changes to simplify and rationalise the funding process, Smith is demanding change. "I've asked all the lottery distributors to look urgently at how they can implement the proposals that the Quest report has made," he says.

This will come as good news to people like Monica Hartwell, director of a small charity, Contact the Elderly, who has applied for lottery funding four times. She tells of one experience filling in a 25-page application form, spending two hours being interviewed on the telephone and then having to complete another form. She says: "It is very frustrating and can waste a lot of time, particularly if you are rejected after the second stage."

Volunteers at the Lincolnshire branch of the British Polio Fellowship (BPF) have had similar problems. After spending almost three years applying for lottery funding, they have finally received £3,750 to spend on an education programme. "The process was a complete nightmare," says spokesperson Peter Jay. "Three of us worked extremely hard and every time we reapplied, the goalposts had moved."

Anna Leatherdale, deputy director of the National Campaign for Arts, claims: "Obtaining a lottery award is often not about those with greatest need or fitness for purpose, but whether the applicant can find partnership funding and complete the necessary application procedures."

The report by Quest, the culture sector's official watchdog, found that applications for lottery grants of less than £100,000 can involve competition of 16-page forms containing 74 questions. It has proposed simpler procedures, especially for groups seeking less than £20,000; a single helpline to provide basic information about all available funding; and early warning if a proposal is unlikely to be successful.

Smith, the culture secretary, accepts there is a problem. But he is confident of rapid reform. He says the heritage fund has already asked the Plain English Campaign to rewrite all its literature - a move he describes as "a major step forward".

Charities say the problems extend beyond complexity, however. Even for those who make it over the application hurdles to the finishing post, the time on the winner's podium can be short.

The BPF's funding will last only six months. The money has been allocated to inform people about post-polio syndrome - the long-term effects of having had polio. Jay says: "We are all quite severely disabled, but we want to do roadshows, video presentations and follow-up visits. It is quite a lot to achieve within such strict time restraints."

Vision Aid, a Bolton-based charity for visually-impaired children and their families, had three-year funding to run an outreach programme. Lesley Green, its director general, says: "We vastly under-estimated demand. We anticipated servicing 500 families, but in fact we reached 2,000. Now the funding has finished, we are left trying to provide the same service with less staff."

Smith says there are no easy answers to this. "There is always a difficulty with lottery funding in that, because of its very nature, it can't commit to year-on-year funding for a never ending succession of years. It has to be a one-off intervention." His hope is that small projects funded by the lottery establish a local reputation to enable them to secure more money to further their work.

But Leatherdale, of the National Campaign for Arts, thinks there still needs to be a more strategic view of lottery giving "so that the long-term benefits of short-term lottery funded projects can be sustained within the communities they serve".

The minister's strategy is clearly to make life easier for smaller-scale organisations. Commenting on the drop in the average size of lottery grant from £250,000 to £40,000 in the past five years, he says: "I'm very pleased about that. One of the things I have been very keen to ensure is that the lottery is spreading out more widely, getting more closely into local communities, helping to fund genuinely voluntary, neighbourhood organisations. This is a good trend in the way in which lottery funds are going, although it doesn't rule out major capital schemes."

Such schemes, especially the Dome, which has now received £525m lottery money, are another sticking point for smaller organisations. Jay says: "You see huge sums of money being lobbed out to large organisations and they make it extremely difficult for us." Hartwell adds: "The money we are asking for is a drop in the ocean compared with the Dome."

webTitle: Army officer shot dead in northern Spain

fields.headline: Army officer shot dead in northern Spain
fields.trailText: A Spanish army officer was shot dead today in the northern city of Pamplona in an attack that bore the hallmark of the Basque separatist group Eta, the Spanish defence ministry said.
fields.body:
A Spanish army officer was shot dead today in the northern city of Pamplona in an attack that bore the hallmark of the Basque separatist group Eta, the Spanish defence ministry said.

The second lieutenant, identified as Francisco Vicente, was shot twice in the back of the head as he drove into the garage of his house on the outskirts of Pamplona, said a spokesman for the provincial government.

No group claimed responsibility, but the shooting came amid a wave of violence blamed on Eta. The group was blamed for two car bomb attacks yesterday, one in the northern Basque town of Zumaia in which one person was killed and another in Madrid which injured 11 people.

On Monday, four suspected Eta members were killed when their car, laden with explosives, blew up on the outskirts of the Basque city of Bilbao.

Pamplona is the capital of the Navarra region which Eta claims as part of a Basque homeland along with the adjacent Basque region itself and three provinces in France.

Eta has regularly targeted military personnel as part of its 32-year campaign for Basque independence. If the group's responsibility is confirmed Lieut Vicente would be its ninth victim since it ended a 14-month ceasefire in December.

The group normally claims responsibility for its attacks several weeks later.

fields.headline: Carbone finally signs for Bradford
fields.trailText: Benito Carbone has finally signed a four year deal with Bradford City.
fields.body:
Benito Carbone has finally signed a four year deal with Bradford City.

The diminutive Italian forward completed his move this afternoon, after a see-saw day which saw talks break down at 2am this morning only to be reconvened at 9am after a last-minute change of heart from Carbone.

At a press conference this afternoon Carbone said: "Bradford have a big ambition to grow. That's why I decided to come to this club.

"I am happy to be back in Yorkshire. I always said my three years in England were positive - I never said I did not want to come back," he added. "I have a big chance to play football here. I want to put in my best football. They love me here, the fans have confirmed that."

Bradford chairman Geoffrey Richmond then revealed how the on-off deal had unfolded in Milan. "It was a long night," he said. "The negotiations concluded at about 2am in the morning and came back again through a call at 4am.

"We were intending flying out on a 7.30 flight this morning. Giovanni called to say wanted a further meeting at 9am. Benito had thought about it, had slept on it and had decided to commit his future to Bradford City."

Hailing Carbone's signing as a mark of Bradford's ambition to hold their own in the top flight after escaping relegation on the final day of last season, Richmond said: "This signing spells out the ambition of the club. Last season we were thought of as boring Bradford. This season we are going to be entertaining Bradford and make our mark in the Premiership."

"Our statement on this signing is to the fans. We owe a duty to our fans to do the very best that we can not only to survive in the Premiership but to establish our place. We want to silence some of the national critics who say some ridiculous things about us," he added.

"The club is ambitious. It has moved forward every year for the last six years and will move forward again this season and every year. There are some fantastic years ahead."

When asked if he planned to see out the four years of his contract, Carbone said: "I have signed a contract for four years. I want to respect that contract, for sure.

"The contract is more important to me than money. It is more important that the club wants you and trusts you. That is what has happened to me here. They showed me everything I wanted.

"We tried to stay with Aston Villa but they never called my agent or me in the summer. The first English club that came for me was Bradford so I am very happy here now."

Manager Chris Hutchings said: "Benito is a fantastic striker with fantastic skills. He is here to excite you. That is what he hopes to do. We are happy with the signings we have made. We are putting the jigsaw together. Benito is part of that jigsaw."

fields.headline: Captured Britons plead innocence
fields.trailText: The two Britons and two Canadians, arrested last week in Montenegro on suspicion of terrorism, have pleaded innocent at the hearing into whether to raise formal charges against them.
fields.body:
The two Britons and two Canadians, arrested last week in Montenegro on suspicion of terrorism, have pleaded innocent at the hearing into whether to raise formal charges against them.

Djordje Djurisic, lawyer for detained British policemen Adrian Prangnell and John Yore, told reporters outside Belgrade's military court that a closed hearing had begun for them and the two Canadians, Shaun Going and Liam Hall.

"This is only a preliminary investigation, an examination of the suspects, nothing else," he said. "The public prosecutor will decide whether he will file charges... It is too early to say whether there will be an indictment at all." Djurisic said the detainees appeared to be in good shape but that he not had a chance to speak with them. "They have denied all the charges," he said.

A military prosecutor in Montenegro earlier proposed charges of violating the sovereignty of Yugoslavia, bringing in armed groups, arms and ammunition, attempted terrorism and coercion of military personnel.

Robert Gordon, Britain's top diplomat in Belgrade, hired Djurisic to defend the Britons following PrangnellÍs request for a new lawyer. A retired Yugoslav army colonel was originally appointed by Yugoslavian authorities to defend the four men.

The two lawyers defended two Australian aid workers for the CARE organisation who were arrested during NATO air strikes against Yugoslavia last year and charged with espionage before being released by Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic.

The Yugoslav army has lodged charges of attempted terrorism against the detainees, arrested by an army patrol last week in Montenegro, Yugoslavia's smaller, Westward-looking republic. The court in Belgrade must now decide whether to formally charge the men and proceed with the case.

Western officials say the two Britons were policemen working to train a new, post-war police force in neighbouring Kosovo. One of the Canadians, Shaun Going, owned a construction contracting firm and had taken his nephew, Liam Hall, along on a weekend break to Montenegro's Adriatic coast.

Shaun Going, one of the Canadians arrested along with his nephew Liam Hall, was a contractor doing reconstruction work in Kosovo and friends have said he might have been carrying demolition equipment used to destroy houses wrecked during the recent conflict.

Tensions are high between Serbia, the power base of Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic, and much smaller Montenegro, whose reform-minded leadership has moved toward independence, even though the two republics formally remain united as Yugoslavia.

Milosevic critics have claimed that the arrests have been timed to generate anti-Montenegrin sentiment ahead of September 24 presidential and local elections.

webTitle: Comment, John O'Farrell: Dyke has chosen a bad moment for his BBC big idea

fields.headline: Have I got news for you, Greg
fields.standfirst:
Dyke has chosen a bad moment to kick off his big idea for the Beeb

Special report: the future of the BBC

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText: Dyke has chosen a bad moment to kick off his big idea for the Beeb
fields.body:
Later this month Greg Dyke will be making a major speech on the future of the BBC at the Edinburgh International Television Festival. Given the usual manic atmosphere of the Edinburgh festival, all he needs to do is open his speech with a couple of good gags and he'll land himself a job presenting a new panel show on Channel 5.

The new director general's plans include setting up two new BBC channels to supplement BBC1 and BBC2. After a long and expensive consultancy by media strategists it has finally been decided that these channels will be named BBC3 and BBC4. They will incorporate BBC Choice (which most of us are unable to choose) and BBC Knowledge (which no one knows about), forming two exciting new specialised youth and culture channels.

Why is it that we have to have certain types of programmes bundled together on theme nights or on designated channels? If I ever have a programme controller to dinner I'm going to announce: "It's pudding night at John's house! Tonight's sumptuous four-course meal starts off with rhubarb crumble and custard. Then the main course, apple pie and cream, and that's followed by jam roly-poly and then bread-and-butter pudding to finish off."

The BBC's charter states that the corporation has a duty "to provide a properly balanced service consisting of a wide range of subject matter". It goes on to say: "Oh, and the BBC must also give Noel Edmonds a job for life", though many suspect that this bit was scrawled in later by a bearded man in a Mr Blobby costume. If the BBC goes down the road of specialised channels it will be in danger of losing the universal appeal that justifies the licence fee. We don't need one channel for every type of programme there is, as BBC News 24 has proved. It's still not clear whether the "24" refers to hours broadcast, millions spent or total viewers.

The debate on the future of broadcasting is hotting up because this autumn the government will publish a white paper on the future of communications. Submissions have been made by everyone who is concerned about the future of quality television - and Denise van Outen as well. All the BBC's top executives were invited to give their thoughts, but most of them failed to read the letter because it was not headed "Proposal for new celebrity gardening quiz hosted by Carol Vorderman".

Meanwhile, members of the Commons select committee on broadcasting have been spending a lot of time seeing how the BBC works at close hand; for example, that was actually Gerald Kaufman inside the Tinky-Winky costume. One of the most controversial proposals being mooted by the government was the abolition of the BBC board of governors. This has now been shelved, though it has been suggested that the board should contain more people with direct experience of broadcasting. So out would go Baroness Young of Old Scone and in would go Charlie Dimmock, Sabrina the Teenage Witch and Wolf from Gladiators.

Perhaps the answer would be to make the board of governors justify itself in terms of viewer appeal. Instead of meeting in a posh boardroom, they should all have to live together Big Brother-style; locked inside one communal house with fly-on-the-wall cameras everywhere. Then, as well as watching them discuss the future of public service broadcasting, we can also see who gets off with whom. "Midnight on day three and Baroness Hogg is tip-toeing across the corridor into Sir Christopher Bland's bedroom." Viewers could then vote to have members thrown off the board if they didn't have enough tattoos or hadn't been helping with the washing-up.

This approach has to be the way forward. Instead of spending lots of time and money changing the corporation, the process of reform itself should be made into a whole new raft of BBC programmes. The TV Regulators From Hell, Have I Got Select Committee Reports for You and then finally Ready, Steady, Murdoch!

That way the reinvention of the corporation will be left to the programme-makers. This will culminate in BBC1's most ambitious makeover show yet. Carol Smillie will introduce two teams who will have just one weekend to transform the BBC from a bureaucratic public service broadcaster into an dynamic modern communications provider using a bit of MDF and some stencils from Homebase. "Okay Red Team, how are you getting on?"

"Well, we found this cellar full of archive sports programmes so we've knocked up a little channel called BBC Sports Gold."

Perhaps this is the big idea that Greg Dyke will unveil at the end of the month. Sadly, most of us will never find out. Even if his ideas are announced on his own network, his exciting vision of a popular and commercial BBC will be completely upstaged that weekend. It is the start of the football season and everyone will be watching the new Match of the Day over on ITV.

fields.headline: Festival diary
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText: Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.body:
 There were strange signs in the sky yesterday, for it was the coming of Messiah, Steven Berkoff's new play about Jesus Christ, the bloke who likes his beer and his birds. The chosen few allowed into the Assembly Rooms for the first preview emerged muttering: "Masterpiece." The master himself, who passed up the chance to play God (directors are apparently more important), rose to acknowledge the rabble and even doffed his baseball cap. It appears we have been mistaken. Berkoff really is as great as he has been telling us all these years.

"What's shaking, Norm?" "All four cheeks and a couple of chins, Coach." Word reaches the Diary that Norm, aka actor George Wendt, arrives next week for a series of benefit gigs for an alcohol abuse charity. America's favourite barfly will be propping up the bar of the Queen's Hall in aid of Turning Point Scotland. Also perfoming are Wendt's improv buddies, Off the Wall, whose best known member was Robin Williams. Whisper it, but the organisers say Williams is "seriously" considering putting in an appearance.

 A new fringe sub-species has been identified; the cyberligger. The World Wideboy Web has created the perfect opportunity for freeloaders armed only with a URL and brass neck to blag their way into shows purporting to be critics for hollywoodcalling.com. The fringe press office reports that one would-be online reviewer was later spotted working behind the Assembly Rooms bar.

fields.headline: Take it to the Max
fields.standfirst:
For a man who made so many great movies, Max Ophuls remains oddly obscure. Now at last he is being celebrated. Ronald Bergan reports

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText: For a man who made so many great movies, Max Ophuls remains oddly obscure. Now at last he is being celebrated. Ronald Bergan reports
fields.body:
A shot that does not call for tracks
Is agony for poor dear Max,
Who, separated from his dolly,
Is wrapped in deepest melancholy.

James Mason

At the beginning of Max Ophuls's 1950 movie La Ronde, the Master of Ceremonies walks through a film studio on to a fin de siècle set, changes into an opera cloak, begins to sing an Oscar Straus waltz and spins a merry-go-round. It is a carousel of deceit, on which lovers meet. Then one of them turns to another, then that other turns to another, and so on until the circle is completed. At one point, the MC snips a length of film with a pair of scissors.

He is the alter ego of Max Ophuls, whose films are merry-go-rounds, moving to the sound of a waltz or a rondo capriccio as the camera tracks and circles. Like the couples in La Ronde, the earrings of Madame De... (1953) are passed from hand to hand until they, too, come full circle. In Lola Montès (1955) the ringmaster (Peter Ustinov), another of the director's surrogates, cracks his whip as the notorious courtesan, now reduced to a circus attraction, reminisces and the camera revolves 360 degrees to reveal her past.

The past returns in Leibelei (1932) as the camera tracks around the room where the doomed couple were happy, she having jumped to her death after he is killed in a duel. Similarly, the past is relived as the concert pianist reads the Letter From An Unknown Woman (1948), who is dead, just before he is likely to be killed in a duel. Love is Ophuls's theme and, as it is transitory - it exists in the past - the tracking, circling camera suggests time passing. "I adore the past. It is more restful than the present and more sure than the future," says the MC in La Ronde.

Ophuls, the subject of a retrospective at this year's Edinburgh film festival, does not wallow in nostalgia but summons up 19th-century Vienna or the Second Empire as part of the whirl of destiny in a danse macabre. For years, critics saw only the radiant surface and dismissed Ophuls as a minor director whose decorous style was but shallow artifice, his plots quaintly old-fashioned. However, like Viennese coffee, whipped cream covers bitterness. As Charles Boyer says in Madame De...: "It seems superficial superficially." His films are exquisite treatises on the mortality of love, nearly all of them seen from a female perspective.

Ophuls's life was as restless as his camera: he moved from Germany to Italy to Holland to France to Hollywood, then back to Paris after the second world war. He was born Max Oppenheimer in 1902 in Sarrebrück, the son of a German-Jewish department store owner. To protect his family's reputation he changed his name when he entered the "disreputable" entertainment business. (In Hollywood, it was changed again briefly to Max Opuls so that, according to some mogul, nobody would confuse it with "offal" or "awful".)

In Germany, Ophuls was a celebrated stage director who turned his hand to films when talkies came in. The second of them was a wonderfully sung (in German) performance of Smetana's delightful Czech opera The Bartered Bride (1932). Not content merely to record the opera, the director managed, by complex cam era angles, to present his own comment on the filming of opera.

His last film in Germany, before the Reichstag fire indicated it was time for him and his family to leave, was Leibelei, an adaptation of Arthur Schnitzler's play of doomed love. Far less ironic and more romantic than the play (witness the invigorating sleigh ride), the film's emphasis is on music, sound and camera movement rather than dialogue.

Schnitzler was also the source for La Ronde, and for Stanley Kubrick's final film, Eyes Wide Shut - an attempt to emulate Ophuls. Kubrick once said: "Highest of all I would rate Max Ophuls, who for me possessed every possible quality. He has an exceptional flair for sniffing out good subjects, and he got the most out of them. He was also a marvellous director of actors."

Schnitzler was a doctor as well as a writer, and, like his Viennese contemporary Sigmund Freud, he had an abiding interest in the way sex shapes people's lives. This theme runs through the films Ophuls made as an exile in France in the 30s.

Divine is about an innocent country girl who comes to Paris where she becomes a chorus girl, gets involved with a dope-peddling snake charmer, a milkman and a lesbian, who fancies her. Though the film was dismissed at the time, François Truffaut later called it "a real little masterpiece, with, naturally, that Ophulsian frenzy which drives the camera up staircases, into the flies, in and out of the wings". Ophuls then turned Goethe's 18th-century tale Werther into a wild 19th-century romance, shifting the tragedy from the hero to the heroine. (He later considered he had betrayed his beloved Goethe, a copy of whose Faust was beside his bed when he died in hospital in Hamburg in 1957 aged 55.)

Mayerling to Sarajevo, his last completed film before his departure for the US, found Ophuls relishing the sort of thing he did best - casting an ironic eye on the extravagances and absurdities of the aristocracy and portraying a bitter-sweet romance against a background of balls, operas and rides through the woods.

Ophuls arrived in Hollywood in 1941, and had to wait six years before he was given a film to direct. Like other European auteurs at the time, such as Jean Renoir and Fritz Lang, he was treated shabbily by the American film industry. He didn't have much liberty on his first American film, a rarely seen costume drama The Exile (1947), shot in sepia tones, starring Douglas Fairbanks Jr as the exiled Charles II of England. (Two endings were shot: the never-before-seen one will be shown at Edinburgh in a new print.) He also made two brooding films noirs, Caught and The Reckless Moment (both 1949), starring James Mason as romantic doctor and slimy blackmailer respectively - rare instances of Ophuls dealing with a contemporary setting. The only film he made in the US that suggests the European period, and one of the best of that underestimated genre "the women's picture", was Letter From an Unknown Woman (1948), a heart-rending tale in which turn-of-the-century Vienna is lovingly recreated.

In 1949, Ophuls returned to Paris, where he made his last four masterpieces: La Ronde; Le Plaisir (1952), based on three Guy de Maupassant stories; Madame De...; and Lola Montès - his only work in colour.

In the first story in Le Plaisir, a masked dancer sweeps into a dance hall, the camera moving with him as he whirls and whirls, the music getting livelier until he falls. Madame De... has a dizzying sequence in which a couple (Danielle Darrieux and Vittorio De Sica) dance from ball to ball as their relationship deepens. Lola Montès tells the story of Lola's love affairs with, among others, Franz Liszt, King Ludwig I of Bavaria and a student. The extraordinary treatment of space on the CinemaScope screen (using masking and other devices), the crane shots and elaborate camera movements have the virtuosity of a Liszt sonata. It was an expensive film that lost a great deal of money, and was shown in a heavily cut version for years. Ophuls, who had been suffering from a cardiac problem, spent his last two years fighting to prevent the movie from being shown in the mutilated form. He died not long after its disastrous release. However, the restored film is now considered a classic.

 The Max Ophuls retrospective starts on August 14 as part of the Edinburgh film festival (0131-623 8030) and will be followed by a season at the National Film Theatre in September

Ophuls's life was as restless as his camera: he moved from Germany to Italy to Holland to France to Hollywood, then back to Paris after the second world war. He was born Max Oppenheimer in 1902 in Sarrebrück, the son of a German-Jewish department store owner. To protect his family's reputation he changed his name when he entered the "disreputable" entertainment business. (In Hollywood, it was changed again briefly to Max Opuls so that, according to some mogul, nobody would confuse it with "offal" or "awful".) In Germany, Ophuls was a celebrated stage director who turned his hand to films when talkies came in. The second of them was a wonderfully sung (in German) performance of Smetana's delightful Czech opera The Bartered Bride (1932). Not content merely to record the opera, the director managed, by complex cam era angles, to present his own comment on the filming of opera. His last film in Germany, before the Reichstag fire indicated it was time for him and his family to leave, was Leibelei, an adaptation of Arthur Schnitzler's play of doomed love. Far less ironic and more romantic than the play (witness the invigorating sleigh ride), the film's emphasis is on music, sound and camera movement rather than dialogue. Schnitzler was also the source for La Ronde, and for Stanley Kubrick's final film, Eyes Wide Shut - an attempt to emulate Ophuls. Kubrick once said: "Highest of all I would rate Max Ophuls, who for me possessed every possible quality. He has an exceptional flair for sniffing out good subjects, and he got the most out of them. He was also a marvellous director of actors." Schnitzler was a doctor as well as a writer, and, like his Viennese contemporary Sigmund Freud, he had an abiding interest in the way sex shapes people's lives. This theme runs through the films Ophuls made as an exile in France in the 30s. Divine is about an innocent country girl who comes to Paris where she becomes a chorus girl, gets involved with a dope-peddling snake charmer, a milkman and a lesbian, who fancies her. Though the film was dismissed at the time, François Truffaut later called it "a real little masterpiece, with, naturally, that Ophulsian frenzy which drives the camera up staircases, into the flies, in and out of the wings". Ophuls then turned Goethe's 18th-century tale Werther into a wild 19th-century romance, shifting the tragedy from the hero to the heroine. (He later considered he had betrayed his beloved Goethe, a copy of whose Faust was beside his bed when he died in hospital in Hamburg in 1957 aged 55.) Mayerling to Sarajevo, his last completed film before his departure for the US, found Ophuls relishing the sort of thing he did best - casting an ironic eye on the extravagances and absurdities of the aristocracy and portraying a bitter-sweet romance against a background of balls, operas and rides through the woods. Ophuls arrived in Hollywood in 1941, and had to wait six years before he was given a film to direct. Like other European auteurs at the time, such as Jean Renoir and Fritz Lang, he was treated shabbily by the American film industry. He didn't have much liberty on his first American film, a rarely seen costume drama The Exile (1947), shot in sepia tones, starring Douglas Fairbanks Jr as the exiled Charles II of England. (Two endings were shot: the never-before-seen one will be shown at Edinburgh in a new print.) He also made two brooding films noirs, Caught and The Reckless Moment (both 1949), starring James Mason as romantic doctor and slimy blackmailer respectively - rare instances of Ophuls dealing with a contemporary setting. The only film he made in the US that suggests the European period, and one of the best of that underestimated genre "the women's picture", was Letter From an Unknown Woman (1948), a heart-rending tale in which turn-of-the-century Vienna is lovingly recreated. In 1949, Ophuls returned to Paris, where he made his last four masterpieces: La Ronde; Le Plaisir (1952), based on three Guy de Maupassant stories; Madame De...; and Lola Montès - his only work in colour. In the first story in Le Plaisir, a masked dancer sweeps into a dance hall, the camera moving with him as he whirls and whirls, the music getting livelier until he falls. Madame De... has a dizzying sequence in which a couple (Danielle Darrieux and Vittorio De Sica) dance from ball to ball as their relationship deepens. Lola Montès tells the story of Lola's love affairs with, among others, Franz Liszt, King Ludwig I of Bavaria and a student. The extraordinary treatment of space on the CinemaScope screen (using masking and other devices), the crane shots and elaborate camera movements have the virtuosity of a Liszt sonata. It was an expensive film that lost a great deal of money, and was shown in a heavily cut version for years. Ophuls, who had been suffering from a cardiac problem, spent his last two years fighting to prevent the movie from being shown in the mutilated form. He died not long after its disastrous release. However, the restored film is now considered a classic.  The Max Ophuls retrospective starts on August 14 as part of the Edinburgh film festival (0131-623 8030) and will be followed by a season at the National Film Theatre in September

webTitle: Indonesia's president hands power to deputy

fields.headline: Indonesia's president hands power to deputy
fields.trailText: Bowing to pressure from MPs who say his maverick style has worsened Indonesia's many crises, President Abdurrahman Wahid announced today he would hand over day-to-day administration to his popular deputy, Megawati Sukarnoputri.
fields.body:
Bowing to pressure from MPs who say his maverick style has worsened Indonesia's many crises, President Abdurrahman Wahid announced today he would hand over day-to-day administration to his popular deputy, Megawati Sukarnoputri.

Mr Wahid said he would trim and restructure his cabinet to increase its efficiency and effectiveness under the leadership of Vice President Megawati, but retain overall control.

"I understand the need to change the management of the government," Mr Wahid said in a speech to the 700-member People's Consultative Assembly. "Because of this I will ask the vice president to carry out daily technical duties."

She would remain accountable to him under Indonesia's existing presidential form of government Mr Wahid said, adding that he would take more interest in foreign policy. Until now, Ms Megawati has played a silent back-seat role to the maverick Mr Wahid, leading to accusations that she lacks ability and confidence despite her popularity and pedigree as the daughter of Indonesia's founding president Sukarno.

Mr Wahid said Ms Megawati would be in charge of formulating cabinet agendas and deciding priorities for the implementation of policy.

Mr Wahid's decision to surrender greater powers to Ms Megawati came the day after senior MPs demanded such a move. Most factions within the 700-member People's Consultative Assembly accused Mr Wahid of mishandling the nation's affairs during his first 10 months in office. Some claimed that his unpredictable behaviour had harmed Indonesia's economy and imperiled political stability.

Earlier, several of Mr Wahid's aides had said the president had been considering the appointment of a prime minister to work under himself and Ms Megawati. The decision to abandon this plan and empower Ms Megawati was warmly received by the assembly.

Akbar Tandjung, the parliament's speaker, said Ms Megawati could lighten the burdens of office now shouldered by the nearly blind Mr Wahid, who has been weakened by a series of strokes.

"We believe the vice president can take over the daily operations of the government," said Mr Tandjung, whose Golkar party controls the second largest number of seats in the legislature behind Ms Megawati's party.

webTitle: Edinburgh festival 2000: Michael Billington applauds The Bogus Woman

fields.headline: People like us
fields.standfirst:
The tabloids are hysterical; the politicians are craven. But at least drama can inject a little humanity into the argument over asylum. Michael Billington applauds The Bogus Woman

Special report: the Edinburgh festival 2000
fields.trailText: Edinburgh festival 2000: The tabloids are hysterical; the politicians are craven. But at least drama can inject a little humanity into the argument over asylum. Michael Billington applauds The Bogus Woman
fields.body:
Only yesterday I suggested that women dramatists take an oblique view of politics. But now along comes a play that frontally attacks the abuse of human rights in Britain. It is called The Bogus Woman, is written by Kay Adshead and is stunningly performed by Noma Dumezweni at Edinburgh's Traverse Theatre.

Adshead's central character is a journalist and poet who has fled civil strife in Africa where she has seen her father, husband and child killed before her eyes. Once in Britain, however, she suffers the ritual humiliations of the asylum-seeker. At Campsfield Detention Centre she witnesses and endures racial abuse and protests by going on hunger strike. The British authorities make basic mistakes in verifying her credentials. Her case goes through a protracted legal process worthy of Bleak House. And, even when she is granted temporary admission, she finds life economically impossible, is driven into homelessness and prostitution and is eventually sent back home to await certain death.

Adshead has researched her play thoroughly and has come up with a terrifying scenario: one that attacks the system of entrusting detention centres to private security firms, of Kafka-esque appeal tribunals and judicial reviews, and, not least, of the weekly £30 food vouchers that barely cover life's basic necessities. My only cavil is that the play pins the entire blame on New Labour which, we are told, "is looking for scalps to hang on the Home Office belt". No mention is made of the rancid xenophobia of the middle-market tabloids or the braying hysteria of the Tories, both of which have helped to create the climate of fear that surrounds the issue of asylum seekers.

But this is a powerful, passionate, committed piece of theatre that, if seen widely enough, might change hearts and minds. If I were Greg Dyke, I would put it straight on BBC TV and invite Jack Straw to respond in the course of a properly focused, rational debate. But, even if that doesn't happen, at least this production, staged by the Red Room and Mama Quillo, shows that theatre still has the capacity to address public issues. It is also brilliantly played by Dumezweni, who switches astonishingly from playing the abused, suffering protagonist to portraying the warders, nurses, lawyers and fellow asylum seekers she encounters on her journey through a land that once stood for tolerance and liberty.

Political issues surface more obliquely in Say Nothing, also at the Traverse, by the two-man Northern Irish group Ridiculusmus. They are like the Right Size with a cutting edge; and their subject here is the lack of real communication in Northern Ireland and the fakery of assumed reconciliation. A Craigavon man with a PhD in peace and conflict studies returns to his native soil and is confronted by circular conversations, latent aggression or meaningless, feel-good workshops with names like Hands Across the Barricades.

The two actors - Jon Hough and David Woods - spend the entire play standing in a turf-filled suitcase while behind them a silent actor mimes the unassuaged reality of Northern Irish life. The humour is decidedly black. At one point Hough attempts to lead us in a community sing-song with a jovial number about frogs; behind him, a legless figure drags himself across the stage.

Earlier on we hear about the side benefits of the peace process: not least the fact that Northern Irish amateur marksmanship has shot up in the world ratings. The show's deliberate physical confinement means that words sometimes get lost. But Ridiculusmus use comedy to make serious political points: in particular, that Northern Ireland is a society based on love of the mask and that it is pure delusion to imagine that sectarian hatred has been banished by the peace process.

 The Bogus Woman and Say Nothing are at the Traverse (0131-228 1404) till August 13 and 26.

webTitle: The pros and pros of the overseas player

fields.headline: The pros and pros of the overseas player
fields.trailText: The annual race to 1000 first-class runs has been more of a marathon than a sprint in this seam-friendly summer. But the outcome was no less predictable. The first three past the post were Michael Bevan (Sussex), Darren Lehmann (Yorkshire) and Matthew Hayden (Northants) - all hard-hitting, left-handed Australians who are unwanted by their Test side but continue to feast on the juicy titbits served up by county cricket's buffet. Kent's Indian import Rahul Dravid is next in line with 979 runs and could pass the mark today against Durham. The leading Englishman? Somerset's Peter Bowler, on 945 - and even he grew up down under. In the bowling, Worcestershire's Glenn McGrath is runaway leader with 62 wickets.
fields.body:
The annual race to 1000 first-class runs has been more of a marathon than a sprint in this seam-friendly summer. But the outcome was no less predictable. The first three past the post were Michael Bevan (Sussex), Darren Lehmann (Yorkshire) and Matthew Hayden (Northants) - all hard-hitting, left-handed Australians who are unwanted by their Test side but continue to feast on the juicy titbits served up by county cricket's buffet. Kent's Indian import Rahul Dravid is next in line with 979 runs and could pass the mark today against Durham. The leading Englishman? Somerset's Peter Bowler, on 945 - and even he grew up down under. In the bowling, Worcestershire's Glenn McGrath is runaway leader with 62 wickets.

So the imports are at it again, showing up our homegrown players and preventing our youngsters from playing regular first-team cricket. Hmm. First old chestnut first: when it comes to the averages, overseas cricketers are operating on a playing field that makes Lord's look level. Where they get to face county attacks for the entire season, England's best are either on Test duty or, because of central contracts, resting from the county games - and thus missing out on easier runs. A Lehmann might face a Caddick-less Somerset, while a Stewart will be up against Curtly and Courtney. The numbers crunch accordingly.

The second point - that foreigners stunt our growth - is made every now and then, usually by county members after their team's overseas player has just failed to score 150 or take six-for. But the argument holds about as much water as a sponge in a desert. Who is blocking the progress of, say, Ian Flanagan at Essex - Stuart Law or Paul Prichard? Who's preventing Ed Smith becoming a regular in Kent's team - Dravid or Alan Wells? And who's keeping out Sussex's young Dutchman Bas Zuiderent - Bevan or Tony Cottey? It certainly isn't J. Foreigner's fault. And while it's harsh to blame gnarled old pros for earning a living, it's easy to criticise a system that allows them to cling on and clog up. It really is time to say bye-bye to benefits.

Overseas players are obvious scapegoats for English failings. Yes, they learn a lot by playing in England conditions, but we send A teams all over the world in the name of cricketing education. And if it wasn't for the fact that our best players are busy with England all year round, maybe more of them would try their hand in the Pura Cup or the SuperSport Series.

In any case, overseas cricketers bring as much expertise with them as they take away. Worcestershire's Alamgir Sheriyar gets to open the bowling with McGrath, who probably earns Sheriyar wickets by keeping it impossibly tight at the other end. Owais Shah of Middlesex gets to learn, in theory at least, the art of how to build an innings from Justin Langer. And Gloucestershire's James Averis gets to watch first-hand as Australian Ian Harvey teases the batsmen with his brilliant slower ball at the end of a one-day innings. It's an extended masterclass - and no other domestic competition in the world offers anything like it.

In fact, every county should have two overseas players. It would improve overall standards, raise the profile of the competition (people are still talking about Shane Warne's duel with Dravid at Portsmouth in July), and even draw bigger crowds (not too difficult). What it wouldn't do is hold back the great undiscovered cream of English talent. Because, as we all know, the cream always rises anyway.

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com. To read the last County View, on the downward spiral of Middlesex, click here

webTitle: Tiny tot, Flabby puppy and Stroppy Sol

fields.headline: Tiny tot, Flabby puppy and Stroppy Sol
fields.trailText: BEING DRIVEN ROUND THE BEN
fields.body:
BEING DRIVEN ROUND THE BEN

Benito Carbone's proposed move to Bradford has been described as "the most exciting in the club's history". Which is interesting, because from where the Fiver is sitting the whole affair is becoming increasingly tedious. First he's joining Bradford, then he's not, then he might be, then he is, oh no look he's changed his mind, now he's signing for Coventry, hold on, no, it's Bradford, er, Coventry, actually no, it's... look for God's sake will you make up your mind, man!

This whole process started a couple of days ago when Bradford chairman Geoffrey Richmond announced he was "very confident" of landing the tiny tot. Predictably enough, everything fell through early this morning after six hours of discussions in Milan. "Talks between Bradford and Benito Carbone broke down at two o'clock," announced City's managing director Shaun Harvey. "The player has decided not to accept the Bradford City offer," added chairman Richmond. "Our search for a new striker goes on."

It appeared that Carbone had dumped Bradford in favour of Coventry - Gordon Strachan had come in with a late offer and the player was expected to sign for the Highfield Road outfit with immediate effect. So you won't be too surprised that Carbone will lay his Alice band for good at Valley Parade later today. "Mr Carbone's advisors rang back at 4am asking us if we could reconvene at 9am this morning," said Harvey, who went on to inform everyone that a press conference will be held just after the Fiver goes out (gah!). So expect tomorrow's papers to be full of Carbone parading around in his new shirt... probably a Charlton or Sheffield United one.

GO AWAY

Alex Ferguson has tried all he can to make Mark Bosnich feel like he's not wanted. He's left him out of a pre-season tour to Malta. He's told him he's third in line behind a keeper who, last season, punched the ball into his own net. And he's roped in Martin O'Neill to see if he can force him to leave the country. But whatever the Manchester United manager tries, Bosnich always waddles back to his master's side like a flabby puppy demanding love and affection. What could Fergie try next to shoo the lovesick hound away? Humiliation on national television seemed as good an idea as any.

Sadly, Ferguson couldn't get such an impressive platform from which to address the nation, and instead had to make do with a five-minute snatch on MUTV (which we reckon must be a local cable station run by a load of cack-handed amateurs). When asked about Bosnich's aborted loan move to Celtic, Fergie let rip: "Well that was Mark's decision. I've not spoken to him, but I thought it was a good opportunity for him. Celtic are a great club, they have 60,000 fans and it would have given him the chance to play at the very best level. He's never been used to being number two or three at a club and it was a great opportunity."

If calling him a number two wasn't blatant enough, Fergie then ostentatiously showered a huge arc of love all over Fabien Barthez. "I think Fabien Barthez is the best goalkeeper in the world as far as I'm concerned," he cooed tautologically. "He has personality and character and he has been absolutely outstanding since he joined us, so obviously I'm going to play him." Let's all hope Bosnich finally takes the hint and changes his mind about Glasgow, because at this rate the only option left for Fergie will be to thrash him about the buttocks with a big stick. And none of us wants to see that.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I'll eat a horse if Demel plays in the first team or in [Big Cup] in the next two years" - Nimes football director Pierre Mosca talks down the abilities of new Arsenal signing Guy Demel. All this after accusing Arsene Wenger of "kidnapping" the 19-year-old French midfielder. He's not bitter. No way!

THE PLEAT MEET

The last time we caught up with David Pleat, he was about to jet off to steamy Amsterdam on the trail of Boudewijn Zenden. But now, after a rare failure in the transfer market, the Pleatster is back and ready to get his fingers dirty rather close to home - by sorting things out with Sol Campbell.

You see, at the start of the summer, Spurs and Sol had an cast-iron agreement. Talks on a new contract would - definitely, cross his heart and hope to die - take place before the start of the new season. And, with a bit of bonhomie from both sides, they might even come to a quick conclusion. But that was then and this is now, and Sol and Sugar have yet to exchange even a brief word about the subject - even in the lift.

Sol's hard-to-get games are obviously working, though. Pleat is reportedly ready and willing to offer the biggest deal in Tottenham's history - a £1m signing-on fee and wages well in excess of their current £25,000-a-week wage ceiling. "We are anxious to get this sorted out as soon as possible and we are hoping to meet with Sol's adviser Sky Andrew," crowed Pleat. "He has promised a meeting with us within the next fortnight."

And Sol's reaction? Well, last week he told Spurs he would stay if they started "acting like a big club" in terms of transfers and wages and ambition. So now they're doing that there's absolutely no reason to leave on a lucrative free transfer to Manchester United next summer, is there? Isn't there?

THE RUMOUR MILL

The chase for Monaco midfielder John Arne Riise is on, according to Planet Football, but Leeds now face competition from Liverpool and Arsenal. "He could still leave Monaco," Riise's mother and agent Berit said. "Leeds are very much in the picture but I can confirm that there are several - and they are big - clubs that want to buy him."

Internazionale defender Christian Panucci is once again on Gianluca Vialli's shopping list, according to Italian newspaper La Gazzetta dello Sport.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Leicester have set a deadline of midnight tonight for Neil Lennon to decide whether he will stay at the club or move to Celtic or Aston Villa.

Aston Villa have been handed a bye into the third round of this season's Worthington Cup, where they will join the six Premiership clubs who have qualified for European competition. They have been chosen because they were the highest-placed team in last year's league championship not to earn a place in Europe.

Birmingham have signed Toulouse midfielders Christophe Grondin, 16, and Mikael Sabathier, 18.

Manchester City striker Lee Peacock has agreed terms over a £600,000 move to Bristol City.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

Eurosport: Football - Live (5pm)
If you're quick you can dash back for Dynamo Kiev v Red Star Belgrade...

Sky Sports 3: Brian Moore Interviews (11pm)
... but perhaps heading to the boozer and getting paralytic is the better option, especially as Bore-o-Moore is interviewing Manchester City comedy act Steve Daley...

Sky Sports Extra: Live Football: Leeds United v 1860 Munich (7pm)
... and you can watch this while you're there. Unless you're slumped over a table drowning in a pool of your own vomit.

Which is interesting, because from where the Fiver is sitting the whole affair is becoming increasingly tedious. First he's joining Bradford, then he's not, then he might be, then he is, oh no look he's changed his mind, now he's signing for Coventry, hold on, no, it's Bradford, er, Coventry, actually no, it's... look for God's sake will you make up your mind, man! This whole process started a couple of days ago when Bradford chairman Geoffrey Richmond announced he was "very confident" of landing the tiny tot. Predictably enough, everything fell through early this morning after six hours of discussions in Milan. "Talks between Bradford and Benito Carbone broke down at two o'clock," announced City's managing director Shaun Harvey. "The player has decided not to accept the Bradford City offer," added chairman Richmond. "Our search for a new striker goes on." It appeared that Carbone had dumped Bradford in favour of Coventry - Gordon Strachan had come in with a late offer and the player was expected to sign for the Highfield Road outfit with immediate effect. So you won't be too surprised that Carbone will lay his Alice band for good at Valley Parade later today. "Mr Carbone's advisors rang back at 4am asking us if we could reconvene at 9am this morning," said Harvey, who went on to inform everyone that a press conference will be held just after the Fiver goes out (gah!). So expect tomorrow's papers to be full of Carbone parading around in his new shirt... probably a Charlton or Sheffield United one. ADVERTISEMENT Manage a fantasy football team online and win £25,000. Register for free here GO AWAY Alex Ferguson has tried all he can to make Mark Bosnich feel like he's not wanted. He's left him out of a pre-season tour to Malta. He's told him he's third in line behind a keeper who, last season, punched the ball into his own net. And he's roped in Martin O'Neill to see if he can force him to leave the country. But whatever the Manchester United manager tries, Bosnich always waddles back to his master's side like a flabby puppy demanding love and affection. What could Fergie try next to shoo the lovesick hound away? Humiliation on national television seemed as good an idea as any. Sadly, Ferguson couldn't get such an impressive platform from which to address the nation, and instead had to make do with a five-minute snatch on MUTV (which we reckon must be a local cable station run by a load of cack-handed amateurs). When asked about Bosnich's aborted loan move to Celtic, Fergie let rip: "Well that was Mark's decision. I've not spoken to him, but I thought it was a good opportunity for him. Celtic are a great club, they have 60,000 fans and it would have given him the chance to play at the very best level. He's never been used to being number two or three at a club and it was a great opportunity." If calling him a number two wasn't blatant enough, Fergie then ostentatiously showered a huge arc of love all over Fabien Barthez. "I think Fabien Barthez is the best goalkeeper in the world as far as I'm concerned," he cooed tautologically. "He has personality and character and he has been absolutely outstanding since he joined us, so obviously I'm going to play him." Let's all hope Bosnich finally takes the hint and changes his mind about Glasgow, because at this rate the only option left for Fergie will be to thrash him about the buttocks with a big stick. And none of us wants to see that. QUOTE OF THE DAY "I'll eat a horse if Demel plays in the first team or in [Big Cup] in the next two years" - Nimes football director Pierre Mosca talks down the abilities of new Arsenal signing Guy Demel. All this after accusing Arsene Wenger of "kidnapping" the 19-year-old French midfielder. He's not bitter. No way! THE PLEAT MEET The last time we caught up with David Pleat, he was about to jet off to steamy Amsterdam on the trail of Boudewijn Zenden. But now, after a rare failure in the transfer market, the Pleatster is back and ready to get his fingers dirty rather close to home - by sorting things out with Sol Campbell. You see, at the start of the summer, Spurs and Sol had an cast-iron agreement. Talks on a new contract would - definitely, cross his heart and hope to die - take place before the start of the new season. And, with a bit of bonhomie from both sides, they might even come to a quick conclusion. But that was then and this is now, and Sol and Sugar have yet to exchange even a brief word about the subject - even in the lift. Sol's hard-to-get games are obviously working, though. Pleat is reportedly ready and willing to offer the biggest deal in Tottenham's history - a £1m signing-on fee and wages well in excess of their current £25,000-a-week wage ceiling. "We are anxious to get this sorted out as soon as possible and we are hoping to meet with Sol's adviser Sky Andrew," crowed Pleat. "He has promised a meeting with us within the next fortnight." And Sol's reaction? Well, last week he told Spurs he would stay if they started "acting like a big club" in terms of transfers and wages and ambition. So now they're doing that there's absolutely no reason to leave on a lucrative free transfer to Manchester United next summer, is there? Isn't there? THE RUMOUR MILL The chase for Monaco midfielder John Arne Riise is on, according to Planet Football, but Leeds now face competition from Liverpool and Arsenal. "He could still leave Monaco," Riise's mother and agent Berit said. "Leeds are very much in the picture but I can confirm that there are several - and they are big - clubs that want to buy him." Internazionale defender Christian Panucci is once again on Gianluca Vialli's shopping list, according to Italian newspaper La Gazzetta dello Sport. NEWS IN BRIEF Leicester have set a deadline of midnight tonight for Neil Lennon to decide whether he will stay at the club or move to Celtic or Aston Villa. Aston Villa have been handed a bye into the third round of this season's Worthington Cup, where they will join the six Premiership clubs who have qualified for European competition. They have been chosen because they were the highest-placed team in last year's league championship not to earn a place in Europe. Birmingham have signed Toulouse midfielders Christophe Grondin, 16, and Mikael Sabathier, 18. Manchester City striker Lee Peacock has agreed terms over a £600,000 move to Bristol City. TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO Eurosport: Football - Live (5pm) If you're quick you can dash back for Dynamo Kiev v Red Star Belgrade... Sky Sports 3: Brian Moore Interviews (11pm) ... but perhaps heading to the boozer and getting paralytic is the better option, especially as Bore-o-Moore is interviewing Manchester City comedy act Steve Daley... Sky Sports Extra: Live Football: Leeds United v 1860 Munich (7pm) ... and you can watch this while you're there. Unless you're slumped over a table drowning in a pool of your own vomit.

fields.headline: A spectre gains substance
fields.standfirst: Real IRA influence on Northern IrelandÕs republican agenda is growing, argues Observer Belfast correspondent Henry McDonald
fields.trailText: Real IRA influence on Northern IrelandÕs republican agenda is growing, argues Observer Belfast correspondent Henry McDonald.
fields.body:
To borrow an infamous phrase from Karl Marx, a spectre is haunting Ireland - the spectre of republican dissent.

Almost exactly two years ago following the Omagh bomb atrocity the Provisional IRA organised a programme of mass intimidation directed at their former comrades responsible for the massacre.

Senior PIRA activists from Belfast travelled to Dundalk and other border strongholds of the Real IRA to warn them that if they did not desist from armed activity they would be attacked.

National and international outrage compounded by PIRA threats forced the Real IRA in the wake of Omagh to call a ceasefire. The homes of those associated with the anti-ceasefire republican organisation, particularly the Real IRAÕs alleged leader Michael McKevitt, were picketed by ordinary citizens of Dundalk who were disgusted that their town was seen as a support base for the terror group.

Two years on and the Real IRA are back in business. The first year of the 21st century has seen a marked increase in republican dissident activity illustrating that despite the Good Friday Agreement and the historic compromise with unionism, there are some republicans willing to continue their "armed struggle" to achieve the traditional goal of a united Ireland.

There have been 14 attacks against the security forces in Northern Ireland and strategic targets in Britain so far this year, most carried out by the Real IRA. They have included bombs on Hammersmith Bridge, which threw large sections of west London into traffic chaos. The Real IRA placed similar devices at railway stations last month with the aim of disrupting the Queen MotherÕs 100th birthday celebrations. There was a sophisticated attempt to kill British soldiers on the Belfast to Dublin railway line using a secondary explosive which, if troops had fallen for the bait, would have been triggered by a mobile phone. The organisation has also acquired sophisticated anti-jamming devices in the former Yugoslavia make it more difficult for the British Army to defuse bombs.

Two years ago the Real IRA and their political allies, the 32 County Sovereignty Committee, feared for their lives following the Omagh bomb believing they were about to be attacked by the Provisional IRA. Now the organisation feels confident enough to hold a fundraising event for its 33 prisoners held in jails in Britain and Ireland in the heart of Gerry AdamsÕs West Belfast constituency next week.

The Sinn Fein president complained yesterday that the Real IRA threat was merely a "spectre" being used by security chiefs in Northern Ireland to block further de-militarisation in republican redoubts like south Armagh. However, according to senior Irish government sources, Mr Adams used the spectre of the Real IRA earlier this year to urge Dublin to pressurise the British to quicken the pace of reform, especially in relation to policing. The Sinn Fein leadership argued at the time that the dissidents were growing in places like south Armagh and that only more change in nationalistsÕ favour could halt their advance.

On the one hand, Gerry Adams argues that the dissent threat is exaggerated by the British in order to slow down de-militarisation in areas where the Real IRA are in reality getting stronger by the day and, on the other, he uses the spectre to frighten Dublin into backing his demands for faster change regardless of unionist concerns.

Whatever way you look at it, the organisation which killed 29 men, women and children two years ago this month at Omagh are still colouring the agenda of the Northern Ireland peace process.

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The question: What's the best cost-free way to entertain kids during the school holidays?
fields.trailText: The question: What's the best cost-free way to entertain kids during the school holidays?
fields.body:
Annie Oliver Information officer at Single Parent Action Network UK

The most important thing is not to feel guilty about what you can't afford. Lots of single parents don't have a fortune to spend in the holidays, and you can get really depressed thinking everyone else is off to Disneyland or Legoland. Don't think that; think about what you can do, not what you can't. You can have lots of fun without spending any money at all. Go to the park with a rounders bat and you'll have a terrific afternoon. It really cuts down on costs if you steer clear of buying food and drink when you're out, so take picnics and drinks everywhere.

 Verdict: Go to the park

Harry Shier Co-ordinator of PLAY.TRAIN, playwork training agency

Don't entertain them. Instead become a resource person to inspire and support their own imagination and creativity (this is what all the best playworkers do). If you're at home, fill a whole room up with junk, eg really big cardboard boxes, cardboard tubes, cloth, paper, fabrics, rope and string, foil, plastic bottles, bins and buckets. Organise a tool kit with sticky tape, glue, scissors, coloured felt-tips or crayons. If you don't have these things in the house already, this is not strictly cost-free, but it is a sound long-term investment.

 Verdict: Give kids old boxes

Ally Simpson Mother of five and primary school teacher

Many local communities have set up play schemes which run during the day. They provide a variety of organised activities such as table tennis, cooking, arts and crafts, and outings to museums and the seaside. They usually operate on a first-come-first-served basis, but once the kids are enrolled they can choose their own activities. Otherwise we often spend days with friends who have children. We visit each other's homes and get the paddling pool out, or travel further afield. It pays to give kids a project for the day such as finding their favourite picture in an art gallery.

 Verdict: Vary your days

Melanie Dakin Editor, Kids Out magazine

There's masses to do in London for free. Increasingly the capital's museums are not charging for children under 16 or 17, and other institutions, including the British Museum and both Tate galleries, are free for all. There are annual free festivals in Ealing, Brick Lane and Coin Street, as well as the Notting Hill Carnival. In south London the Horniman Museum and Gardens are free, and the Bruce Castle Museum has recently opened an inventor centre where children can get to grips with all kinds of gadgets and even dream up some of their own.

 Verdict: Head for London

Tracey Nowell National events manager for the National Trust

The National Trust has a whole host of free things to do for families all around the country - you don't even have to be members to enjoy them. Lots of NT areas and properties have free walks, some themed, such as the ugly bug safari at Devil's Dyke in Surrey on August 20. Or how about a beach party 1,350 feet above sea level in Huddersfield on August 28? Another idea is cycling, maybe at an NT property like Carding Mill Valley in Shropshire. Visit the NT website at www.trusty.org for endless ideas, or phone 020-8315 1111 for the leaflet on free events.

 Verdict: Trust us for ideas

Peter Hampson Spokesman for the British Resorts Association

No one in Britain lives more than 70 miles from the sea, so the obvious answer in the summer has got to be: pack a picnic and your bucket and spade, and go to the beach. Unless it's absolutely pouring down the children will have a great time - they like the rock pools and won't mind if the sun isn't shining. Some resorts have lots of free entertainment for kids, such as Bournemouth, where there's a children's festival on this month. See our website at www.britishresorts.co.uk for information about it and the other 60 resorts in our association.

 Verdict: Go to the beach

fields.headline: Write it yourself
fields.standfirst: Homemade books are fun and educational - and not just for the kids, says  Adrienne Katz
fields.trailText: Homemade books are fun and educational - and not just for the kids, says Adrienne Katz
fields.body:
Once upon a time I was an art student. Now I'm a granny, but I feel like an art student again. I spend weekends drawing little ducks. I doodle when a meeting threatens to become dull. The reason? I have discovered the joy of making books for my little granddaughters.

I have a co-conspirator. My friend Bridget and I published "real" books together as young mothers when our children were small. Now she is a grandmother too, and we tailor our tales to each of our grandchildren's needs. My two granddaughters are still babies, so I stick to simple stories featuring their favourite toys, words they know and, most importantly, photographs of them and their families. Bridget's granddaughter is older, and has, among others, a book about the day she locked herself and the keys inside the empty new house her parents were looking at.

Homemade books are useful in all sorts of ways. As well as being fun and developing reading skills, they give children a sense of security and love. They are also useful in building up confidence; children experience feelings of success when they recognise words and objects. But the real joy is when a child climbs into your lap with the book you've made and asks for it to be read over and over again.

Anyone can make books like these. You don't have to be able to draw: illustrations can be made from photographs or pictures cut out of magazines. Words needs to be in large, clear letters: I produce text on the computer (Arial is a good choice of font) and paste the sentences into the book. Bridget often handwrites hers.

Although babies don't need text now, when they become readers they will know the books by heart and realise that the squiggles on the page give clues to the spoken word. Having text means that every adult who reads this book to the child will use the same words. Children need this dependable repetition to discover that within the pages of a book the story can be kept and brought out again and again. Gradually it will dawn on them that it is those dark squiggles that hold the secret.

If you try out some of these ideas, you may even find yourself looking at the world like a child again - the greatest rejuvenating remedy I know.

Planning the content

 For babies and toddlers, keep the book short - no more than 10 pages. Babies enjoy picture books and photos of themselves, family, pets, toys and animals; toddlers like repetition so they can anticipate and participate. Include numbers and colours.

 Ages three and four want a good story. I usually base the books on familiar routines, such as Suzie's Day; Patrick Plays (with his favourite toys); shopping trips; or walks to school turned into fantasies.

 Five- to six-year-olds love humour - try riddles and poetry.

 At around six and a half, try introducing non-fiction - How to Care for My Puppy, etc.

 At around seven and eight they can start making their own books; eights also love funny poems and horror.

 With young readers, it is essential to pay attention to the rhythm of the text.

Making the book

 You will need: a cheap craft knife; glue (Pritt Stick types are best, as they allow repositioning); lots of cheap copy paper; bright coloured stiff paper; paints or felt tips, pens, inks and pencils; binding rings from a print shop.

 Small hands find small pages easier - half a regular A4 sheet (A5). Older children can enjoy A4. Cut pages to size with a guillotine at the art shop before starting.

 Paste pictures - torn from magazines, cut from photos (something to do with all those rejects from the family album) or drawn on cheap copy paper - on to your pages.

 Copy shops can laminate each page, producing a hard, wipe-clean result. Very thick card does not laminate well. Ask for "pockets" rather than sheet plastic, and snip edges to a curve with nail scissors. Costly but perfect.

 Alternatively, cover stiff card pages with cheap sticky-backed plastic.

 Line up your laminated pages and punch holes using an ordinary office punch.

 Use binding rings through the holes. They are available at copy shops, have no sharp edges and can't be opened or bitten off by little ones. Always keep some space free at the binding edge, so that the binding rings don't intrude on words and pictures.

fields.headline: Where there's a will...
fields.standfirst: What would happen to your children if you and your partner died? Mother-of-three  Joanna Moorhead  thinks the unthinkable - and advises every parent to do the same
fields.trailText: What would happen to your children if you and your partner died? Mother-of-three Joanna Moorhead thinks the unthinkable - and advises every parent to do the same
fields.body:
What would happen to your children if you and your partner died? A terrible question, but one every parent should face; if you do not and the worst happens, you will have failed your children in their hour of greatest need. But knowing that does not make the practicalities any easier - especially if, like me, you have not just one, not just two, but three children to think about.

"Oh, don't worry, I'd have Miranda," trills my dearest friend, who is also my baby's godmother. But what about the other two? A moment's pause, as the enormity of what I am asking sinks in, and Emma imagines how she would feel as a mother of five. We joke about how unlikely it is to happen, but just occasionally it does. And taking on three bereaved young children is certainly a lot to ask of any friend.

Most couples ask family members, but for an increasing number that does not seem the best course. Leaving them to your parents does not make a lot of sense - even if they are fit and healthy today, if you died in five years their situation could be very different. Brothers and sisters with children are the obvious choice, but in our case we only have one sibling between us with children. Solicitor John Pears, who chairs the Law Society's probate section, suggests that you solve the conundrum by thinking of who you would want your children to be with if you were not around any more. "It's going to be someone they know well, who sees them on a regular basis, and that often narrows it down," he says.

Peter Norman, a senior educational psychologist working in Buckinghamshire and a specialist in dealing with bereaved children, says your children's ages are crucial - a 13-year-old will be more adaptable than a two-year-old, for example.

"I'd say there are three basic areas to be aware of. Firstly, the new carer's relationship with the child - you want someone who knows them as well as possible. Secondly, a similarity of situation - if you can avoid uprooting them, especially under-sevens, so much the better. Thirdly, you want someone who is familiar with children, ideally someone who either has similar-aged children themselves or has older children."

Whomever you choose, you have got to think about financial considerations as well as the children's welfare. "You've got to be aware of how the guardians will finance bringing your children up," says Pears. "Usually parents leave their money to their children in the event of their death, but they leave to the guardians the right to get at the money if they need to. For example, they may need to extend their home, or even buy a new house. You can't expect them to be at a financial disadvantage as a result of raising your children."

"It was tough, because I always felt we were prising him away from her," says Jackie. "If my brother had written it down, we'd have all known we were doing what he wanted."

Olivier came to live with Jackie and her family in Yorkshire for two years, but eventually decided to return to his mother in Corsica. She regrets that she could not fulfil her brother's wishes. Despite campaigns by the Law Society, only a third of us in the UK have made a will - the same proportion as 10 years ago. "If you die without making a will you die intestate and intestacy rules apply," he says. "They're quite complicated, but what they mean in general is that the first £125,000 you leave goes to your husband. Anything more is divided in half - half for your children and half for your husband. What goes to him, though, doesn't go outright - it's put in trust and all he gets is the interest from the trust. If you and your partner are not married, the case for making a will is even stronger because you do not have any rights under the intestacy rules. If you do not have a solicitor, ask friends for a recommendation. And don't wait - do it now.
