webTitle: The daydream of a deranged dad?

fields.headline: The daydream of a deranged dad?
fields.standfirst: Home and away:  The diary of a part-time father
fields.trailText: Home and away: The diary of a part-time father
fields.body:
The trouble with plane crashes is that everybody dies. This devastating truth forced me to be at my most madly inventive when gripped the other day by a ghoulish reverie about my former partner, Dilys. In it, she met an untimely end, leaving me as the sole parent of Gloria, Jed and Billy, and placing Chris the Pillock, the children's doltish pater presumptive, at a hopeless disadvantage in which I would revel for years.

This is how it went. The aeroplane flying the five of them to their summer holiday destination developed engine trouble somewhere over the Mediterranean, causing the pilot to implement splashdown procedure. With the ailing craft barely a spit above the ocean, Dilys - being Dilys - had decided that she knew better how to salvage precious life than the airline personnel. She barged past a strapping male trolley-dolly, grabbed the nearest lever, then plunged through the hatchway towards fish food oblivion.

Then, a miracle! The engine roar grew healthier, the awful impact failed to occur and, inch by inch, the plane regained height. "Emergency over," the pilot announced. "Cigarettes, wines, spirits and a selection of cosmetics will be on sale shortly . . ."

So, am I dangerous, deranged or simply being human in the way parents can be when assailed with dread about their children? Readers may be divided, judging by previous feedback. There are those who recognise this column as what it strives to be: an unvarnished disclosure of the bleaker inner landscapes of a father who knows that his relationships with his children are being deliberately undermined by their mother, his former partner. Others have reacted with the disapproving piety characteristic of those whose imaginations have become addled by ideology. They mistake disclosure for advocacy and candour for justification. An episode detailing my exasperated smacking of six-year-old Billy was condemned by one correspondent as advocating child abuse. My fury at Dilys over her brazen campaign to have Chris displace me in my own children's affection is taken as evidence of misogyny, in spite of my fierce devotion to my extraordinary wife, Angie, and the inconvenient fact that all the hate crimes in this stressed "shared parenting" scenario have been committed by Dilys, not by me.

It wasn't me who deserted the family home and all but deserted the children in order to indulge my infatuation with a ludicrous lover. It wasn't me who instructed Gloria, Jed and Billy to stop calling me Dad so that the ground could be prepared for Chris, his royal pillockship, to oust me from my children's hearts. What should I be writing? A thank-you note?

My remit for this fortnightly meditation is to draw your attention to the parts of a threatened parent that are most frightened, most wounded and most raw. I don't ask for sympathy, simply recognition that when any man or woman fears that their children are being stolen, there is bitterness, anger and pain.

Summer, as I know from lengthening experience, is the ripest time for these. For three whole weeks Gloria, Jed and Billy fly off to some resort the name and location of which are disclosed by Dilys only at the last minute, with the sour instruction that the contact telephone number should only be used in an emergency. I imagine the children wrestling their hand luggage into the overhead bins, buckling their seats belts, sucking hard on the complimentary boiled sweets. Then I imagine those air masks suddenly dangling, life belts inflating, Concorde crashing in a sheet of flame. Could I have saved them? Is there a God? If that God offered to fix it so that just Dilys would die and everyone else would survive, would I accept?

Reader, you don't have to like me. But you do have to wonder whether, were you in my position, you might sometimes feel as I do.

fields.headline: American Mom
fields.body:
Surely nobody could envy New York's Brooke Murphy-Petri more than Bill Clinton and Tony Blair. After giving a press conference for 30 minutes during which she said absolutely nothing, people around the world applauded wildly when she finished. Of course it helped that Brooke was only one day old and cute beyond measure, but even so, politicians could learn plenty from her. The sooner you begin your campaign, the better your odds of clinching it.

But here in the land of you-can-never-start-too-early, some would argue that Brooke was late in meeting the public 24 hours after her birth. Some babies hold their press conferences right after delivery.

Press calls by newborns could only be an American innovation, yet they will available at three hospitals in London by October.

BabyPressConference.com was set up in 1998 after Lee H Perlman, a New York entrepreneur, was asked by a hospital administrator to come up with a novel way to promote a new maternity ward. He hit on the idea of installing webcams in hospitals so new parents could broadcast footage of their babies live over the internet. To date 35 US hospitals have signed up and held a total of 700 press conferences, averaging 10 guests per broadcast.

Expectant parents supply a list of email addresses of people to invite to a live chat once their baby arrives. On the day of the press call, parents and baby sit in front of a camera in a hospital room while relatives around the world watch as they talk about the birth and show off their newborn. Cyberguests' questions appear at the bottom of a computer screen. The service is free to parents; BabyPressConference.com makes its money from CDs of the webcast and deals with baby goods retailers who sell through its site.

Ten people watched Brooke's internet debut, including her uncle Michael Murphy in Australia. "When we emailed him to let him know we were having a baby press conference on the web, he wrote back, 'Good grief, I don't believe this,' but he did get up at 2am to watch," says Brooke's mother Patrice Murphy.

webTitle: 'I can still smell my baby's scent. It's always with me'

fields.headline: 'I can still smell my baby's scent. It's always with me'
fields.standfirst: Selfish and irresponsible - that's how teenage fathers are usually described if their babies are put up for adoption. But new research by  Gary Clapton, whose daughter was adopted 30 years ago, paints a very different picture
fields.trailText: Selfish and irresponsible - that's how teenage fathers are usually described if their babies are put up for adoption. But new research by Gary Clapton, whose daughter was adopted 30 years ago, paints a very different picture
fields.body:
'Natural", "birth" or, disparagingly, "sperm" father: there is a variety of terms to describe men whose children have been adopted. Such fathers are shadowy figures, mostly assumed to be feckless lads or wicked seducers and abandoners. While the emotional and physical connection of birth mothers to the adopted child is now widely acknowledged, most people would question any such acknowledgment in relation to fathers. Indeed, there is little acknowledgment of their fatherhood in any sense.

However, I have just completed research - the first in the UK - to provide a glimpse into the experience and inner worlds of birth fathers and their perceptions of themselves as fathers. Thirty men, all teenagers at the time of conception, responded to an appeal for birth fathers to tell their stories. I spoke to men from places as far apart as Dundee and Southampton. The occupations and social classes of the 30 men were just as wide-ranging, and included a general practitioner in Surrey and a bus driver in Clydebank. The youngest was 35, the eldest 79 and living in a retirement home.

These men were eager to talk of their experiences of their girlfriend's pregnancy, the birth and adoption, and of immediate post-adoption events. They also spoke of their thoughts about the child in later life and the effects of the adoption on their own lives and subsequent relationships. A central finding - one that many may find surprising - is that these men cared and still do, some more deeply than others, but all seriously and durably. Martin, a 39-year-old factory worker from Essex, spoke for many of the interviewees when he said: "Mine has been a life of pining for my daughter."

Some of the men attended the birth, although the majority were excluded from this and the subsequent adoption proceedings. A number of men had highly specific memories of holding their child. Jack, a Glaswegian labourer, is 38, but says: "I can still remember his scent. To me, at times, it is as if it was only yesterday. I can smell him. It's always with me."

However, as many birth mothers have reported, parents and society intervened and adoption proceedings swung into action. Dave is 51 and an electrician in London. His experience is typical: "I felt that we had no choice, no option. I felt guilty. The impression was that this was nothing to do with me. I felt isolated."

A number of the men excluded from the birth and adoption process were left with highly charged feelings. Jim, 48, a car salesman from Paisley, remembers: "A very emotional time. It was tinged with great sadness and a certain amount of loss and anger." Although some of the men supported the decision to have their children adopted and talked of relief, many others said they were "devastated".

Michael, 58, is a supermarket manager in Sheffield. He was in the army and stationed abroad when his child was born. When he found out that the child had been adopted as a result of parental intervention, he was "gutted and could have committed suicide. I look back and I think, how did I live through it? It was a terrible pain."

There were many extreme reactions in the aftermath of the adoption. Some men got into fights and went on month-long drinking binges. John, a 47-year-old fitter from Edinburgh, said: "I became a very angry person after she was born. I used to go to dance halls looking for trouble. I turned violent for a long time. I turned to drink sometimes."

Such a depth of aftershock and self-abuse following the adoption echoes feelings described by birth mothers. Other men just closed down: "I shut it out," said Dave. "I literally put it behind me." Peter, a 52-year-old university lecturer from London, said that the adoption "rubbed me out legally but not emotionally".

Most of the men went on to marry or establish long relationships with other partners, but 18 of these ended in divorce or separation. John simply said that he felt "unlucky in love". Ian, now believes that he "got married [to someone else] on the rebound". Others found that they were unable to talk about their feelings to partners and wives, although as Tim, a 52-year-old consultant from Rotherham, said: "He [the baby] was always in mind. I have a kid out there. I have always remembered his birthday. It was a secret set of emotions." Nine out of the 30 men interviewed had had no other child than the one who been adopted.

Some of the men became tearful as they spoke of the feelings of powerlessness and disenfranchisement at having been denied a role by parents and welfare workers at the birth, and in the proceedings surrounding the decision to have the child adopted.

In the years that followed the adoption, thoughts of the child came to be a major influence. Colin, a 53-year-old church minister from Edinburgh, said that it was "not long before I began peeking into prams". They wondered whether the adoption was successful and whether their child was still alive. For some, like John, events later in their lives brought memories flooding back. After a nervous breakdown and during a session with a psychiatrist (which, coincidentally, was on the day of his adopted daughter's birthday), John collapsed: "I had never seen the adoption as my loss, always hers - the birth mother's. I completely broke down and cried."

Most of the birth fathers I interviewed were careful to make a distinction between themselves and their child's parents. Brian, 61, a retired care worker from Preston, said: "I am his father but I am not his dad." However, the men also spoke of a dilemma similar to that faced by birth mothers when asked how many children they had: "It depends who I'm speaking to," says Doug, a 47-year-old computer operator from Sheffield. He had two more children. "I sometimes say I've got three. But only when I feel safe."

Curiosity and concern featured highly: "One starts to worry about if there are tremendous difficulties in his life caused either by the adoption or just because of who he is," said Mark, 46, a social worker from Edinburgh. "I suspect, although I don't know because I don't have any other children, it is a sort of parental worry that I have."

Other men said that they felt guilt and shame arising either from their inability to influence events at the time or a feeling of not having "shouldered a burden". Many men felt a need to apologise and "set the story straight". All wanted to have contact or knowledge of their child's welfare. Two of the 30 - Joe, 59, a clerical officer from Cambridge, and Michael - had spent hundreds of pounds trawling blindly through records in the hope of turning up some identifying information that could assist in finding out how their children had fared. Although far outnumbered by birth mothers, a count of three UK adoption contact registers revealed that nearly 1,000 birth fathers were registered as interested in contact with their adopted children.

It may come as a surprise that birth fathers can feel as haunted by the child's absence as birth mothers do. I am sure, however, that this capacity should be cherished and nurtured, not ignored or denigrated. This would mean among other things that we accept the existence of birth fathers in any current adoptions and support moves to make contact easier between both birth parents and their children.

 Gary Clapton is 51. At the time of his own daughter's birth and adoption in 1969 and early 1970, he was 19. He now works as a post-adoption counsellor in Edinburgh. This research was carried out for a doctorate over the period 1996-2000. Identifying details have been altered.

 Adoption contact registers in England are run by Norcap: 01865 875000 and the Office of National Statistics 0151-471 4313. Family Care holds the Adoption contact register for Scotland at its Edinburgh office: 0131-225 6441.

After a nervous breakdown and during a session with a psychiatrist (which, coincidentally, was on the day of his adopted daughter's birthday), John collapsed: "I had never seen the adoption as my loss, always hers - the birth mother's. I completely broke down and cried." Most of the birth fathers I interviewed were careful to make a distinction between themselves and their child's parents. Brian, 61, a retired care worker from Preston, said: "I am his father but I am not his dad." However, the men also spoke of a dilemma similar to that faced by birth mothers when asked how many children they had: "It depends who I'm speaking to," says Doug, a 47-year-old computer operator from Sheffield. He had two more children. "I sometimes say I've got three. But only when I feel safe." Curiosity and concern featured highly: "One starts to worry about if there are tremendous difficulties in his life caused either by the adoption or just because of who he is," said Mark, 46, a social worker from Edinburgh. "I suspect, although I don't know because I don't have any other children, it is a sort of parental worry that I have." Other men said that they felt guilt and shame arising either from their inability to influence events at the time or a feeling of not having "shouldered a burden". Many men felt a need to apologise and "set the story straight". All wanted to have contact or knowledge of their child's welfare. Two of the 30 - Joe, 59, a clerical officer from Cambridge, and Michael - had spent hundreds of pounds trawling blindly through records in the hope of turning up some identifying information that could assist in finding out how their children had fared. Although far outnumbered by birth mothers, a count of three UK adoption contact registers revealed that nearly 1,000 birth fathers were registered as interested in contact with their adopted children. It may come as a surprise that birth fathers can feel as haunted by the child's absence as birth mothers do. I am sure, however, that this capacity should be cherished and nurtured, not ignored or denigrated. This would mean among other things that we accept the existence of birth fathers in any current adoptions and support moves to make contact easier between both birth parents and their children.  Gary Clapton is 51. At the time of his own daughter's birth and adoption in 1969 and early 1970, he was 19. He now works as a post-adoption counsellor in Edinburgh. This research was carried out for a doctorate over the period 1996-2000. Identifying details have been altered.  Adoption contact registers in England are run by Norcap: 01865 875000 and the Office of National Statistics 0151-471 4313. Family Care holds the Adoption contact register for Scotland at its Edinburgh office: 0131-225 6441.

fields.headline: Satellites to capture solar wind
fields.standfirst: Successful launch means Cluster will monitor the sun's most harmful radiation waves, writes Tim Radford, science editor
fields.trailText: Successful launch means Cluster will monitor the sunÕs most harmful radiation waves, writes Tim Radford, science editor
fields.body:
European scientists put two satellites called Rumba and Tango into orbit from a Russian rocket in Kazakhstan today - closing one story of humiliation and disaster and opening a new chapter in the understanding of the solar system.

The two satellites are part of a formation team called Cluster - their dancing partners Salsa and Samba were launched last month and are waiting for them. Together, they will glide in precise but changing formation, up to distances of more than 60,000 miles from the earth, measuring the electric wind from the sun.

The sun - a thermonuclear fusion reactor 93 million miles away - is vital to life, but a dangerous neighbour too. In an 11-year cycle, it grows more and more active, shooting dismantled atoms at a million miles an hour to crash against the planet's natural magnetic shield. Every now and then a more powerful-than-usual volley gets through, to create the celestial firework displays known as the northern and southern lights.

But it can also hit the planet too: in March 1989, a surge of blazing particles from the sun shattered a national power supply, plunging 6 million Canadians into darkness in temperatures of -15 C. As humans fly higher and rely more and more on satellites for communication, navigation and weather reports, they grow more and more alarmed about these bombardments from the sun.

The Cluster squadron - when engineers have finished testing their instruments and got them on station - will be part of an early warning system. Because they will fly through the free-fire zone in a fourpointed pyramid formation, they will be able to measure not just the speed but the volume of ordnance coming from the sun at hundreds of thousands of miles an hour and get the message back to earth at the speed of light. High flying aircraft will be warned to dip into the lower atmosphere to screen crew and passengers from radiation, satellites will be turned off or tilted away from the bombardment. The US National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration already has its own equivalent of a Beaufort scale for the solar storms. Some humans already routinely check space weather reports - now to be supplied in greater detail than ever, as Cluster joins other satellites turned towards the sun.

But Cluster almost didn't happen. The project was born in 1982, and got the go-ahead in 1988: it required four exquisitely tuned identical satellites with state of the art equipment. They were completed, and then packed aboard the maiden flight of Europe's new superlauncher, Ariane V in 1996.

Less than a minute after takeoff, Ariane exploded - a software bungle, it later turned out - and wiped out Cluster as well. Neither the rocket nor its payload were insured. Researchers prepared to abandon 14 years of work and write off both the £400m for Cluster and a decade of important science that might have followed.

But they didn't: the sun is too important to life on earth. Cluster II arose metaphorically from the ashes, and then literally, in two stages, from the Baiknour launch pad in July and today. The four satellites will be around to monitor the sun at what scientists called the "solar max", the most violent point in the sun's cycle of violence.

One recent flare-up from the sun was so furious that it completely silenced a satellite called Ace. This was an irony: Ace is one of the US satellites designed to catch the sun in its angriest moments. Cluster could be in business just in time.

Useful link
Cluster - European Space Agency

fields.headline: Front... to back
fields.trailText: Police have been unable to trace a man dressed in a Superman outfit who was seen running in and out of traffic on a busy road near Chelmsford, Essex.
fields.body:
Flying visit: Police have been unable to trace a man dressed in a Superman outfit who was seen running in and out of traffic on a busy road near Chelmsford, Essex. Essex Chronicle, 21.7.00 (Catherine McGarvey, Chelmsford)

False smiles: Organisers of an agricultural show at Moreton-in- Marsh, Gloucestershire, have this year included a pantomime cow category to cheer up depressed farmers. Midlands Metro, 17.7.00 (Jon Gurling, Birmingham)

Silent movies: Visitors to a new cinema in Birmingham can avoid annoying other film-goers by leaving their mobile phones in a creche, where staff will answer calls. Birmingham Metro News, 20.7.00 (K Handley, Birmingham)

God squads: Parishioners of a church in Hartlepool have set up security patrols because of the growing number of thefts from parked cars and handbags being snatched during services. Hartlepool Mail, 17.7.00 (Karen Jensen, Hartlepool)

Tartan barmy: A clothes designer in Scotland has made kilts with special zipped pockets to hold a mobile phone. Manchester Evening News, 25.7.00 (Gillian Oakes, Cheadle)

Out on a limb: A doll repairer was mistakenly invited to a medical seminar at East Surrey hospital, Redditch, on the rehabilitation of upper limb sports injuries. Epsom and Ewell Herald, 26.7.00 (S Cannadine, Epsom)

Present tension: Mechanics in Liverpool spent four days taking apart a £24,000 Mercedes to find a hamster the owner had bought as a surprise present for his son. Shropshire Star, 1.7.00 (St John Howell, Halesowen)

Batty idea: A man who put up fly paper at his home near Wadebridge, Devon, woke up the following morning to find 15 whiskered bats stuck to it. Western Morning News, 22.7.00 (L Peters, Cullompton)

Tall order: Police chiefs in Hampshire have ordered a fleet of specially modified Ford Fiestas for officers who are more than 6ft 3ins tall. Sunday Independent, 23.7.00 (Hetty Fletcher, Budleigh Salterton)

Choc horror: A box of Cadbury's Milk Tray left by a romantic admirer of the receptionist at an office in Bracknell, Berkshire, caused a bomb alert. Sunday Independent, 23.7.00 (Carol Pink, Bigbury on Sea)

One mouth good: The owners of an eco-friendly hotel in Somerset have bought a pig to act as a waste disposal unit. Oldham Chronicle, 21.7.00 (D Connor, Oldham)

Sunny side up: A couple who had a luxury house built in Sheffield plan to knock it down and rebuild it a few yards away in a sunnier position. Sheffield Star, 21.7.00 (S Pybus, Sheffield)

Gambling habit: Monks at a Cistercian monastery in East Lothian are hoping to raise money to restore a set of holy paintings by running a sweepstake on which of their herd of dairy cattle will be the first to calf. Sunday Mail, 23.7.00 (John Forster, Daventry)

Safe as houses: A prospective home buyer being shown round a former police station in Chipping Campden, Gloucestershire, was locked in for an hour when one of the cell doors slammed shut. Western Daily Press, 22.7.00 (P Fawkes, Stonehouse)

 Cuttings, preferably from local papers, which reflect interesting or amusing aspects of life in Britain, must be sent on a postcard (with source) to: Society, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. £15 will be paid for each one used.

fields.headline: Bad medicine
fields.standfirst: Mike George  on attempts to root out racism in the way mental health treatment is applied to black patients
fields.trailText: Mike George on attempts to root out racism in the way mental health treatment is applied to black patients
fields.body:
In some metropolitan circles, young black men are seen as cool. But a sizeable proportion of the white population fears them because they are so often portrayed as criminal, socially irresponsible and violent. White fear is also fuelled by the perception that they are unstable and prone to mental illness. But many black people are similarly fearful - not only of racism in general, but of what they regard as racial discrimination in the operation of Britain's mental health system.

These circles of fear have helped to prevent much-needed change in our mental health professions and institutions and today, in Birmingham, a small step is being taken to try to undo this paralysis. A meeting of black service users, carers and local mental health agencies is being held as part of the Sainsbury Centre for Mental Health's Breaking the Circles of Fear project. Two similar meetings have already taken place in London.

Frank Keating, senior research fellow for the project, explains that it is trying to explore impediments to change and investigate models that really work for black communities. He says evidence of discrimination - intended or unintended - has been available for 15 years and he thinks it is time for everybody involved in mental health to move on.

This evidence shows that people from African and African-Caribbean communities are between three and 13 times more likely than others to be admitted to hospital under the Mental Health Act. The prevalence of mental illness among black prisoners is three times higher than among their white counterparts. Black patients are given higher doses of neuroleptic drugs, are more likely to receive electro-convulsive therapy or be subject to restraint, and are less likely to be offered psychotherapy or other alternative treatments.

Through local meetings, like today's, and a broader programme of evidence gathering and consultation with black service users and their families - as well as with black agencies and other providers of mental health services - the centre aims to present some practical proposals to policymakers.

Oneal Thomas, who manages the Antenna Outreach Service for young black people in Tottenham, north London, reinforces the "circles of fear" message. He says the service, which is a leading partner in the project's work, is very aware that pressures caused by racism contribute to mental health problems. "For example, you hardly ever hear anything positive about black people; it's always about problems, so we all get locked into the disadvantaged communities debate and no one feels able to move on."

The general distress felt in black communities seems to affect young men more than women, Thomas says. "The mix of perceptions by white people about crime, violence and distress tends to focus on young men. Consequently, we find that they're less likely to engage with mental health services. So we view as our main task the reaching out to young people who are in need, and at risk, and who you know may have a major breakdown if we don't work with them as soon as possible.

"Our staff, who are African-Caribbean, are able to take a holistic view and so be able to look at people's aspirations and situations, rather than concentrate solely on their mental health problems."

But does this mean that change can only be effected by black mental health agencies? John Cox, president of the Royal College of Psychiatrists, accepts that many people from ethnic communities have a negative perception of mental health services. "That's a harsh reality, and there is obviously a double stigma in having a mental disorder and being from a minority ethnic community," he says. "This results in a tendency to report very late to mental health services, and this is perhaps one reason why we see the treatments we do."

Cox, who is directly involved in the Sainsbury project, accepts a need for psychiatrists to gain more understanding of customs and mores. "Training in cultural competence is one of our key aims: we'll be setting up an ethnic minorities committee in the college to help further this, and we're mounting a campaign to combat racial stigma in order to influence the, often defensive, attitudes of mental health services."

Cutting across these institutional and organisational issues is another, potentially powerful, intervention by researchers and psychiatrists. People from black communities are much more likely than white people to be diagnosed as having schizophrenia. But according to Kwame McKenzie, a north London consultant psychiatrist and honorary lecturer at the Institute of Psychiatry, the illness among black people may be very different.

What is the evidence for this? In essence, white people diagnosed with schizophrenia are several times more likely than their black counterparts to have an identifiable organic problem. There is no difference in brain structure among black people with the diagnosis, compared with a control group, and substantially fewer black people than white suffer from the form of long-term, persistent symptoms with which mental health services are familiar. But black people are more likely than whites to be regarded as having psychotic symptoms. Crises are more likely to be episodic and the prognosis is far better than for white people.

McKenzie says: "We've pretty well nailed down the fact that the risk factors for white and African-Caribbean people are very different, especially the life events and situations they have to face."

This undermines the whole idea of what we understand as schizo- phrenia in the African-Caribbean community, McKenzie maintains, and therefore the diagnosis of the illness itself becomes unstable. Startling as this may appear, debate about misdiagnosis of black people has been going on for several years. McKenzie believes that: "We need to look more closely at symptoms, such as hallucinations, depression, delusions, low motivation or manic symptoms, for example, and gain a broader understanding of the individual."

By doing this, he says, professionals can prescribe medication for particular symptoms and decide on other interventions, such as cognitive behavioural therapy, with the patient's agreement. This is not just theory, as McKenzie has been involved with treatment regimes based on this approach. "For example we found that low doses of anti-psychotics for a short period, and mood stabilisers to help a person get past an episode of manic or depressive disorder, allied to cognitive behavioural therapy which embraced the issues which led to the episode, have worked very well," he says.

This "dimensional", rather than "categorical", approach to schizophrenia - which appears to be gaining ground among professionals - may offer an effective clinical partner to culturally appropriate services. And today's meeting, which is hosted by Servol, another predominantly black mental health outreach charity in Birmingham, combines these themes with the practical experiences of black users and carers.

Hopes are high that the project will help change mainstream services. Not before time. Carl Douglas, who runs the National Schizophrenia Fellowship's African Caribbean development service in Birmingham, says: "Black people keep asking us what's happened to all the previous studies, and what's the point of them because nothing ever improves."

 The Sainsbury project can be contacted through David Robertson on 020-7403 8790

fields.headline: Eco soundings
fields.trailText: Load of hot air | Of mice and GM | That guilty felling
fields.body:
Load of hot air
The issue of cows and the production of methane - long known to be a cause of global warming - is the object of much research to try to find out how to stop them doing it. Contrary to popular belief, as Reading University puts it, all ruminant methane is released through the mouth (not the other end, as with termites) because it is part of the forestomach digestive system. Ruminants are responsible for about one-fifth of the world's methane production; with 2.3m dairy cows in the UK, that is 230,000 tonnes of methane a year, not to mention the efforts of beef cattle and sheep. The disappointment is that experiments giving cows cough lozenges appeared to work but the quantity involved proved alarmingly large. Now a bacteria - a bit like the stuff in yoghurt - has been developed. It works, but no one has yet thought of a way of getting farmers to feed it to cows - after all it only helps the environment and not the bottom line. Reading is seriously suggesting a methane tax. Honestly.

Of mice and GM
New figures from the Home Office on GM animal experiments due out next week show a growth industry. The total number of experiments in 1999 on animals of all sorts - mostly rats and mice - stands at 2.26m and did not rise overall, but the number on GM animals rose by 63,000 to 511,000. No word yet on what scientists are trying to achieve with GM rodents.

That guilty felling
Cause at last to thank Jack Cunningham, MP for Copeland. The embarrassment the government felt when Friends of the Earth revealed his new desk in the Cabinet Office and panelling for warships were made of illegally logged tropical timber caused a government rethink on the issue. Michael Meacher, the environment minister, announced that government departments will only buy timber from legal, sustainable resources. Let us hope they enforce the order.

It's good to talk
DTI minister Helen Liddell's Commons answer about BNFL's decision to take back nuclear fuel from Japan contained the following sentence: "The government's support for BNFL's decision followed full consultation across departments." Ten days later, on exactly the same subject, Michael Meacher said in another answer: "There was no consultation between ministers or officials from my department and the Department of Trade and Industry..." Oops.

It's good to talk DTI minister Helen Liddell's Commons answer about BNFL's decision to take back nuclear fuel from Japan contained the following sentence: "The government's support for BNFL's decision followed full consultation across departments." Ten days later, on exactly the same subject, Michael Meacher said in another answer: "There was no consultation between ministers or officials from my department and the Department of Trade and Industry..." Oops.

fields.headline: The walls come tumbling down
fields.standfirst: Jerry White
fields.trailText: Jerry White
fields.body:
A 90-year-old woman from south London is discharged from hospital to a nursing home, her care paid by the local council. Two months later, she dies of blood poisoning brought on by necrotic bedsores. The council blames the hospital for discharging her too early and claims no responsibility for the quality of her clinical care. Her relative has to complain both to the health service and local government ombudsmen to get a proper explanation.

Neighbours of a residential home in the west country complain to the council about smell from the home's sewerage; the council says it can't act because the environment agency has approved the quality of the effluent.

Wherever you look, real life spills over the boundaries between local and central government. Ministers have recognised this and efforts are being made to "join up" services. But if people are aggrieved by a service failure, to whom should they complain? The joint provider first, certainly. But then the council? The health authority? The health provider? All of them?

That's why, almost two years ago, the public sector ombudsmen for England proposed a one-stop shop for complainants, so the ombudsmen could follow the complaint across any boundary. It was potentially a small but significant proposal to join up government at a pinch point for the citizen.

Once stated, it seems self-evidently desirable. But I imagine it might have looked less straightforward from inside the varied constituencies involved: the whole of Whitehall, where departments had grown their own complaint-handling services; local government, justly jealous of its constitutional status; and MPs, who currently act as gatekeepers for complaints about central government and its agencies. Then there were implications for Scotland and Wales and - another jigsaw entirely - for the revolution taking place in civil justice, including the ever-growing compass of judicial review.

With many tender toes to dance around, it was to the government's credit that it didn't say "too difficult". Indeed, things have moved fast. In April, following a review, the cabinet office recommended merger of the public sector ombudsmen and the end of the MP filter. Ministers issued a consultation paper on reform, out for comment until September 29.

Merger would radically transform ombudsman arrangements established piecemeal since 1967. About 25 or 30 years ago, boundaries between various parts of the public service seemed set in stone. It just isn't like that any more.

 Jerry White is a local government ombudsman for England

fields.headline: Readers' letters
fields.trailText: Reforming a sacred cow
fields.body:
Reforming a sacred cow

Roy Lilley (Trapped in the twilight zone, August 2) repeats tired old anecdotes and cliche solutions for the NHS. His comments will be offensive to many. And I agree with almost everything he says.

Doctors in the UK work two to three times as many hours as most contracted workers, yet we still earn less in total than comparable professionals. I have regularly worked flat out for 24 to 36 hours for a lower hourly pay rate than the cleaners. So forgive us for appearing bitter when government, taxpayers, and the media attack us as God-complex, privileged toffs or "forces of conservatism".

We welcome an expanded role for nurses in protocolised aspects of care. I would love to work in a system capable of complete efficient service delivery 24 hours a day. I accept that staff must be more creative and adaptable.

Lilley contrasts NHS service quality with that of optician, laundry and exhaust-fitting industries. Fair, but simplistic. The biggest difference is that money follows these services, on a proper cost-incurred basis. If we want a proper health care system, we need investment. That is why I support the government's plan for the NHS, with the exception of some punitive aspects of the proposed contract for senior doctors.

Many parts of the plan are bold, imaginative, and highly commendable - a lifeboat in the short to medium term. If it fails, we must abandon our 52-year-old sacred cow and resort to an insurance-funded system that forces the population to spend more on health care than holidays, nights out, furniture, fashion, beer and fags.

Dr Elved Roberts

Cardiac research fellow
London

So Roy Lilley believes that doctors think shopping at midnight is unexceptional, but resist opening primary care services at weekends. Perhaps his accountant is prepared to see him in his office on a Sunday to discuss his tax return, and perhaps his solicitor sees him at midnight to discuss his will or help with conveyancing.

Doctors, like solicitors, do see people in emergencies of course. Indeed, GPs are responsible for their patients' care 24 hours a day, 365 days a year. But there is no medical evidence that providing routine care outside normal hours (usually 8am to 6pm Monday to Friday and on Saturday mornings) would improve the nation's health. It might be more convenient for the busy businessman, but if this is so then he could be accommodated in the private sector.

Doctors have families too and deserve to have family-friendly working patterns like everyone else. So do their staff.

Dr Amanda Lindsay
Leeds

Roy Lilley obviously learned very little from his tenure as a trust chairman. The staff attitudes he decries are chiefly a result of non-clinical managers (such as himself) interfering with, and judging, working practices they do not understand.

Also, did his friend with the cut finger not have plasters and Dettol at home, or a GP to go to? It is precisely such minor injuries that gum up the working of an A&E department and lead to people having to wait. I wonder that Lilley did not call an ambulance!

Adam Walker
University of Hertfordshire

Roy Lilley is right to suggest that we should expect more from the NHS than we do and that NHS staff should bring their own expectations of good service to work.

I returned from holiday this week to find an NHS outpatient appointment waiting for me. However, rather than being with the consultant to which my GP had referred me, the appointment was with a different consultant (and from previous personal experience, arrogant, patronising and unpleasant). I telephoned the outpatient department and although they did change the appointment, I was told this was routinely done if one consultant had a longer waiting list (ie was less popular) than another.

If I go out for a meal and decide on an Indian restaurant, I do not expect to be shown to a table in a bistro across the road. Why should this be acceptable in the NHS?

Rosemary Gillespie
Portsmouth

Measuring wealth

I suppose you would expect someone writing from the National Training Organisation for Engineering Manufacture to say that "wealth creation is caused by a vibrant engineering and manufacturing community" (letters, August 2). But it really is absolute nonsense and certainly should not appear in Society, of all places.

If "wealth creation" means anything (other than making lots of money), it includes all the things which improve people's lives: not only televisions and motor cars, but education, hospitals and social work, hairdressing, holidays and pubs and all the other services we rely on. It is true the UK had a tradition of exporting manufactures, but that has changed.

The reality behind the economy is that people produce goods and services which they or others then consume. If we all bore this in mind, we would be able to see what the important issues are and perhaps do something more to concentrate on the important outcome, which, in the broadest sense, is the improvement of people's lives.

Martin Wright
Parbold
Lancashire

Northern lights

Kilburn Festival may well claim to be the first to benefit from single regeneration budget (SRB) funding (Art and soul, July 26), but Blackpool has a highly successful community festival, Puppet Up!, which was funded by SRB money in 1997 and 1999 and will be again next year. I'm sure it's not the only one in the north either!

Rachel Riggs
 Festival director

Puppet Up! Festival

fields.headline: Growing pains
fields.standfirst: Two thousand years of farming one field, and still it's a struggle to make it pay.  Rob Stepney on the mixture of chemicals and crops
fields.trailText: Two thousand years of farming one field, and still it's a struggle to make it pay. Rob Stepney on the mixture of chemicals and crops.
fields.body:
The wheat growing in the field known as the Horse Ground is now tall, golden and ready to be harvested. With Cotswold cream houses as a backdrop, it is a scene any visitor would relish. But the farming practices that govern the field are not so picture-postcard.

In a 10-month growing season, it has been sprayed with herbicides, pesticides and growth regulators a minimum of seven times, as well as having two applications of liquid nitrogen.

Frequency of spraying is not everything, since chemical concentration also counts. But, by any standards, this farming is intensive. And it is potentially toxic - at least to those directly involved. The seed grain planted last September was itself coated with fungicide. The hazard data printed on the sack ran to seven paragraphs, including the warning that PVC gloves and a respirator should be worn when filling the seed drill.

"This is not what someone with a weekend cottage wants to hear," says the farm manager responsible for the Horse Ground's 14 acres, plus another 2,000 acres. "But we are producing a commodity, just as on a factory floor." He was prepared to speak about the field and the way it was farmed provided he was not named. "We have to maximise return," he says. "In the present financial climate, even the big farms are suffering."

The grain the Horse Ground grows this year will fatten pigs and poultry. Feed wheat that fetched £120 a tonne in the mid-1990s now sells for less than £60.

"Highly efficient farms are probably still an acceptable investment, but they are certainly not highly profitable," says Dr Dick Morris, senior lecturer in environmental systems at the Open University. "Intensive agriculture is like a treadmill. The more you put in, the more you have to put in. If you sow treated grain, you've paid for the treatment as well as the grain, and you've probably chosen an expensive variety. Faced with that investment, you would have to put in other treatments necessary to protect it."

Take out the herbicides, fungicides and insecticide and the yield would fall by a third from its current four tonnes an acre, the farm manager estimates. Take out the liquid nitrogen as well, and the yield would be down two-thirds.

For the Horse Ground, that would mean a reduction in income from the anticipated £3,250 to little more than £1,000. The chemicals used on the field cost around £700 (£50 an acre), and little labour is involved since the entire field can be sprayed in half an hour. So leaving out the chemicals saves little while slashing returns.

The best organic farmers in the UK harvest 70% of average non-organic grain yields. But it takes years of altered management to reach this level, and it is almost impossible to succeed with organic arable farming unless animals are part of the system. And that would require prohibitive capital expenditure.

Ironically, the Horse Ground was once part of a flourishing dairy unit, abandoned under the economic imperatives of the late 70s. "We moved from dairying into arable, taking the subsidy available from the Common Market to cull the cows," recalls Archie Piper, then land agent responsible for the field.

Cynics might suggest that as a result the field switched from contributing to a milk lake to contributing to a grain mountain. But Morris contends: "There were intermittent surpluses at the time, but in global terms they were molehills."

Whatever the economics at play, the 70s switch out of dairying ended at least 500 years of pastoral use. But the Horse Ground's long history as pasture began with an equally hard-headed financial decision. In the late 15th century the future was not cereals but sheep. Wool destined for the continent was England's dominant export.

"At the time, part of the Horse Ground was cultivated, but about a third of it was lived on," says Tim Copeland, an archaeologist who knows the area well. "It might have been home to 50 people. But it was more profitable for the lord of the manor to have a herd of sheep than a dozen tenants, and they would simply have been forced out." The abandoned village left its mark on the landscape for five centuries, until it was obliterated by the 70s' ploughing that prepared the ground for grain.

That was a loss to archaeology. But the environmental costs of farming the Horse Ground so intensively are probably more pressing.

Aside from the potential accumulation of chemical residues in food, pesticides and herbicides contaminate water supplies. Since privatisation, the water companies have spent an additional £970m in removing pollutants from drinking water. But they regard farmers as less to blame than local authorities and railway companies who spray herbicides on to hard surfaces with rapid run-off. A reduced range of flora and fauna is the undisputed price we pay for intensive farming.

What we gain from it is ample home-produced food. For Neil, who ploughs, plants, sprays and harvests the Horse Ground, that is a significant achievement. "I sometimes wish people in this country would go hungry for a while," he says. "Then they'd appreciate farming more."

Even on a small scale, commercial and environmental considerations do not always pull in different directions. Today's tight profit margins mean that, for example, agrochemicals that increase yield by 10%, but costs more than farmers recoup on the extra grain, will no longer be used.

And there is an appreciation that integrated crop management can maintain yields while lessening input of costly chemicals. One year in five, peas are grown to fix nitrogen in the soil, reducing the need for fertiliser.

The wheat the Horse Ground grows does not go to the mill at nearby Shipton-under-Wychwood, but prices there indicate the extra cost of not using chemicals. Organic Cotswold flour is 20% more expensive than the non-organic equivalent. If more consumers are prepared to pay that premium, history suggests that agriculture will respond.

The two big changes in the last millennium - when the Horse Ground shifted from arable land to pasture and back again - were both driven by economics. Pottery shards Copeland dug from the field show the Romans used the land, which lies close to the site of a large villa. "The Romans practised what we would recognise as commercial agriculture," he says. "And it is likely that even then someone was counting the sestertia it generated."

Field diary

Early September last year: pre-sowing application of herbicide.

September: sowing of wheat treated with fungicide to prevent seedling diseases such as blight.

Late autumn: second treatment with herbicide.

March: first application of liquid nitrogen; growth regulator to shorten and strengthen wheat stem (varieties bred for high yield have a large ear that needs support); fungicide.

April: second application of nitrogen fertiliser.

Mid-May: treatment with fungicide; growth regulator; insecticide (if needed) to combat thunderbugs and aphids.

At any time: herbicide applied to control specific weed problems - such as cleavers (known as "sticky willy") that might strangle the crop.

August: harvest.

webTitle: US public opinion on GM crops

fields.headline: Sowing seeds of doubt
fields.standfirst: US public opinion on GM crops is rattled by new research
fields.trailText: US public opinion on GM crops is rattled by new research
fields.body:
Bob Prevedell has fireflies, tree frogs, owls and plenty of other wildlife on his farm in Illinois. He would be a great advert for the environmental benefits of GM crops, except that he doesn't grow them. His 1,200-acre spread, with many oak trees, is as pretty as any stretch of English countryside and has at least as much wildlife - including deer, far more than it ever used to.

The US department of agriculture would like to think that this is because many of the neighbouring farmers grow GM crops which, its scientists say, use far less insecticides and herbicides than conventional crops. So far Prevedell remains unconvinced. The recovery of the wildlife started years before, he says, when the worst effects of DDT and other more potent killers were phased out in favour of less harmful successors.

His hundreds of acres of soya are grown by conventional methods, not because he objects to GM, but because he refused to sign an open-ended contract with Monsanto which bound him to buy their seed and allowed them to send inspectors to his farm and sue him if he broke rules which he believed infringed his freedom. "It dictated what I could and could not do on my own farm," he says. "And I was not having that."

He has grown BT maize with seed from another company. This is the sort that kills the European corn borer as it burrows into the plant, and so avoids the need to spray for a pest which can typically reduce yields by 25%. So far, however, he sees no economic advantage. In the three years he has grown it alongside the conventional crops, the corn borer has been absent in both, and the BT seed is far more expensive to buy. One day, when the corn borer returns, he may change his mind, he says.

The backlash of the British consumer against GM crops took the US administration by surprise. Despite the official reaction that UK fears were groundless, and threats of action through the World Trade Organisation because labelling for GM is a restraint on trade, the adminstration admits that matters might have been handled better. There is genuine alarm that EU objections might damage the advance of the technology.

Among those responsible for the mistakes is Monsanto. Hugh Grant, chief operating officer of the company, admitted his company's attempt to steamroller Europe into accepting the technology had been a blunder. He remained convinced of the benefits of GM, particularly to the developing world, but "we have decided to back off in Europe for at least two years. After that we will review the situation".

In the US, the technology proceeded without even a ripple of concern among consumers until the EU backlash became news. Interest peaked when lab research showed that larvae of the Monarch butterfly were killed by BT corn pollen if their food plant, the milkweed, was covered in it. This single piece of evidence showed up a giant gap in the US research programme: that the wider environmental impacts of growing GM crops had not been properly investigated, despite the fact that nearly half of all staple crops are now GM.

This omission has cost the industry and the administration dear, not least because it has given the UK a copper-bottomed excuse to hold up the introduction of GM crops, until the effect on the wider British environment can be studied.

The latest research on the Monarch butterfly, a potent symbol in the US of a healthy environment, is that GM crops do not lessen its chances of survival. Although BT pollen is toxic to the larvae, and other caterpillars, the insecticides and herbicides poured on conventional crops are probably more likely to destroy the wildlife than the GM equivalent. More research is being completed this summer.

But stand in a conventionally grown English cornfield just before harvest, after it has been dosed with fertiliser, insecticide and herbicide throughout the year, and there is not much left alive.

So far there is not enough evidence of advantage either way. At least consumer concern has forced both sets of complacent authorities to research the issue thoroughly.
fields.bodyText: Bob Prevedell has fireflies, tree frogs, owls and plenty of other wildlife on his farm in Illinois. He would be a great advert for the environmental benefits of GM crops, except that he doesn't grow them. His 1,200-acre spread, with many oak trees, is as pretty as any stretch of English countryside and has at least as much wildlife - including deer, far more than it ever used to. The US department of agriculture would like to think that this is because many of the neighbouring farmers grow GM crops which, its scientists say, use far less insecticides and herbicides than conventional crops. So far Prevedell remains unconvinced. The recovery of the wildlife started years before, he says, when the worst effects of DDT and other more potent killers were phased out in favour of less harmful successors. His hundreds of acres of soya are grown by conventional methods, not because he objects to GM, but because he refused to sign an open-ended contract with Monsanto which bound him to buy their seed and allowed them to send inspectors to his farm and sue him if he broke rules which he believed infringed his freedom. "It dictated what I could and could not do on my own farm," he says. "And I was not having that." He has grown BT maize with seed from another company. This is the sort that kills the European corn borer as it burrows into the plant, and so avoids the need to spray for a pest which can typically reduce yields by 25%. So far, however, he sees no economic advantage. In the three years he has grown it alongside the conventional crops, the corn borer has been absent in both, and the BT seed is far more expensive to buy. One day, when the corn borer returns, he may change his mind, he says. The backlash of the British consumer against GM crops took the US administration by surprise. Despite the official reaction that UK fears were groundless, and threats of action through the World Trade Organisation because labelling for GM is a restraint on trade, the adminstration admits that matters might have been handled better. There is genuine alarm that EU objections might damage the advance of the technology. Among those responsible for the mistakes is Monsanto. Hugh Grant, chief operating officer of the company, admitted his company's attempt to steamroller Europe into accepting the technology had been a blunder. He remained convinced of the benefits of GM, particularly to the developing world, but "we have decided to back off in Europe for at least two years. After that we will review the situation". In the US, the technology proceeded without even a ripple of concern among consumers until the EU backlash became news. Interest peaked when lab research showed that larvae of the Monarch butterfly were killed by BT corn pollen if their food plant, the milkweed, was covered in it. This single piece of evidence showed up a giant gap in the US research programme: that the wider environmental impacts of growing GM crops had not been properly investigated, despite the fact that nearly half of all staple crops are now GM. This omission has cost the industry and the administration dear, not least because it has given the UK a copper-bottomed excuse to hold up the introduction of GM crops, until the effect on the wider British environment can be studied. The latest research on the Monarch butterfly, a potent symbol in the US of a healthy environment, is that GM crops do not lessen its chances of survival. Although BT pollen is toxic to the larvae, and other caterpillars, the insecticides and herbicides poured on conventional crops are probably more likely to destroy the wildlife than the GM equivalent. More research is being completed this summer. But stand in a conventionally grown English cornfield just before harvest, after it has been dosed with fertiliser, insecticide and herbicide throughout the year, and there is not much left alive. So far there is not enough evidence of advantage either way. At least consumer concern has forced both sets of complacent authorities to research the issue thoroughly.

fields.headline: Walk in the past
fields.standfirst: After a lifetime spent down under, migrants from British children's homes are rediscovering their lost identities.  Janet Snell reports
fields.trailText: After a lifetime spent down under, migrants from British children's homes are rediscovering their lost identities. Janet Snell reports.
fields.body:
Between 1920 and 1960, more than 9,000 children - some as young as six - were sent to Australia by British children's homes, supposedly to a better life. Many made the best of it and went on to forge successful careers and have families of their own. Others have had a harder time, often as a result of lasting effects of physical and sexual abuse meted out in some homes.

But whatever their experience, all child migrants share, to some extent, a sense of loss of identity. As one former migrant told an inquiry by MPs: "For the vast majority of child migrants, the most often asked question is: 'Who am I?'"

Following that inquiry, by the Commons health select committee, the government in 1998 urged agencies that had been involved in child migrant schemes to offer assistance to their former charges. It said they should be allowed full access to their files and help should be given to those who wanted to trace their families here in the UK.

Some agencies have contracted out this work, but the NCH Action For Children charity decided to appoint Birmingham social worker, Joan Kerry, to set up a family tracing service. She also offers support to those who want to be reunited with family members - in some cases, parents they never knew they had.

John Grant had always believed he was rescued as a baby from a house fire in which both his parents had perished. But when Kerry reopened his file, almost 50 years after he was shipped off to Australia, she discovered his parents were still alive and in their 80s. Kerry has just set out on her third and final trip to Australia to meet up with those like Grant - not his real name - to help them piece together their fragmented past.

As National Children's Homes, NCH sent 129 children to Australia in the years just before and just after the second world war.

"The fact that the numbers are small has meant it's been a relatively manageable project for me," says Kerry. "I've managed to make contact with 80 of the original 129. Some told me I was half a century too late, but 50 of them have wanted to use the service. I've found out that 14 are dead and eight people are using an independent agency to trace their roots."

Her youngest client is 56 and the oldest 76. Kerry hires a hotel room to hold interviews and the sessions can be long and, occasionally, harrowing. One man had asked her to find his mother's grave; Kerry later discovered that the woman had died virtually destitute and been buried in an unmarked plot. As is the custom, after 14 years the grave had been re-used and, another 14 years on, a third person was buried there - this time with a headstone.

"On my next visit, I had to tell him what had happened and I took photos," Kerry says. "He was devastated. All his life he had planned to go to the grave and tell his mother all the things he'd stored up over the years."

Kerry feels very strongly that the sort of sensitive information she is dealing with should be given in person. "I'm also a bit obsessive about the surroundings where it happens," she says. "For many people, I'm telling them their parents are dead - and anybody who has had that news will know you remember every detail about where you were and how you were told. So you don't want it to be in some bleak office."

Part of Kerry's brief was to consider what lessons could be learned from the child migration schemes. She believes there are many.

"Lesson one is don't send youngsters 12,000 miles away," she insists. "Yet we're bringing in children from South America and China for adoption and moving kids from Kent to Yorkshire. It's totally contrary to the government's recommendation that children should be able to keep in touch with their birth families."

There is also the issue of recording family medical history. She says: "For my clients in Australia, when the doctor asks if there's a history of diabetes or heart problems in the family, they just don't know."

She has learned that, in care work, it should be essential, for possible future reference, to record information such as the names of aunts and uncles. "I chair an adoption panel and we still get cases where the file says 'interviewed the grandmother', without giving her name."

Staff should also be careful what they write in children's notes, she believes. One woman in Australia was very hurt that someone had recorded that she "tends to be jealous of younger children". She had been eight when that was written and felt it was unfair. A businessman was upset by a description of him in his notes as "a deceitful boy".

For some, the files brought good news. One man was thrilled to discover he had the same first name as both his father and grandfather. If he'd known earlier, he'd have kept up the tradition with his own son.

Another client discovered the father he thought had abandoned him had in fact sent maintenance money for 12 years until the boy was sent to Australia. The client told Kerry: "All my life I've damned my father for walking away from me, and it turns out he didn't. Seeing this file has been the most healing thing that's ever happened to me."

But not everyone felt so positive. One woman who shouted at Kerry had buck teeth as a child and was still angry that nobody at her NCH home had sent her for dental treatment. "With some of them," Kerry says, "just under the surface is the hurt little girl or boy sent to the other side of the world all those years ago."

The government has set aside a £1m fund for former child migrants to travel to Britain if they have a close relative here that they have never seen. One man has been over here to meet the brother he had not seen since 1948. Meanwhile, John Grant has been making plans to come and see the parents he never knew he had. Sadly, his father died recently, but Grant is still coming to see his mother.

"I can't help admiring their bravery," says Kerry as she prepares for her final trip to Australia. "I feel my job's nearly done now. I've contacted everyone I can and I've set up a system to deal with any future inquiries. I'm pleased at what we've achieved and I think they have found it useful. This is a very special group of people and, quite honestly, it's been a privilege working with them."

A passage of time

It is not often that an eight-year-old boy asks to be taken into care, but Bill Cunningham did exactly that. After the second world war, he and his mother who was in poor health were struggling to get by in a poor part of Liverpool. His father was dead, there was rarely food on the table and, in his own words, he "became a bit of an urchin" .

He told the authorities that his mother had suffered a stroke and could not look after him. According to his file, he asked to be taken into care. So he was sent to a then National Children's Home orphanage in Yorkshire.

Cunningham spent five happy years at the home, his mother never got in touch and the staff and the other children became his family. But then, shortly after his 13th birthday, he was told he had been "selected" to be sent to Australia. "There were four of us chosen and I remember thinking it might be a bit of an adventure," he says.

The four joined a party of 40 or so others who, in January 1950, boarded the SS Mooltan at Portsmouth for the long voyage.

"I was transferred to a home on the outskirts of Sydney and there was just no comparison with what we were used to back home," says Cunningham. "It was Methodist-run and very spartan and the first thing we had to learn was how to milk a cow, which was a bit of a culture shock for most of us."

He left at the first opportunity, when he was 15, and hitched around Australia, drifting in and out of different jobs. "I never made any secret of my background and you'd find that if anything went missing you'd be the first suspect as you were from a home," he says.

He finally settled in Melbourne and took on a clerical job. He was good at sport and carried the torch in the 1956 Olympics.

In 1960, he married Janet, a local woman, and the couple went on to have seven children. "Our only sadness was that our youngest daughter died of a heart problem when she was five," he says. "But, all in all, I've had a marvellous life. That's why I was quite aggrieved when the so-called 'scandal' of the child migrants broke. They presented the whole thing as negative, but it wasn't like that for all of us."

Cunningham has always been anxious not to let his background become an excuse when things have been tough. He says: "Some people are still bitter about being sent so far from home, but what's the point? My way of dealing with it has always been to be as positive as possible."

Last year, Joan Kerry took Cunningham his personal file and he asked her to find his mother's grave. At the age of 64, he has just travelled to the Everton district of Liverpool to visit it for the first time.

"Of course I felt very emotional, but seeing the grave and getting a copy of the death certificate makes me feel like I've dealt with some unfinished business," he says. "After a shaky start, I've done OK in life. I did 25 years as a health service manager and brought up a fantastic family. And I'm very proud of my association with NCH. As far as I'm concerned, they've done a good job."

fields.headline: Race against time
fields.standfirst: In 1997, the army pledged to embrace equal opportunities.  Chris Arnot and David Brindle look at the progress since then and the experiences of one Asian soldier forced out of the service
fields.trailText: In 1997, the army pledged to embrace equal opportunities. Chris Arnot and David Brindle look at the progress since then and the experiences of one Asian soldier forced out of the service.
fields.body:
From an early age, Gurmit Davatwal wanted to be a soldier. Not just any old soldier, but a member of the Household Cavalry. "My dad was keen on the services and used to take us to Horse Guards Parade," he recalls. "I remember looking at those guards and thinking: 'One day I'll do that'."

Sadly, his father died when Davatwal was just 16, and never did see his son sitting stock still astride an immaculately groomed horse. That was the young Sikh's only regret as his eyes stared straight ahead, steadfastly ignoring his sister's camera. He was a proud defender of Queen and country and a godsend to an army desperate to boost the number of minority ethnic soldiers in its ranks.

Even before he had completed his basic training, Davatwal's friendly face and open manner were being put to good use in recruiting offices. He could charm reporters at press conferences and reassure black and Asian youths that stories about racism were history. No wonder his superiors were impressed. When one asked him where he saw himself in 10 years' time, he replied: "Hopefully, sir, in your chair." The officer looked pleased and said: "Well done."

It is difficult to predict where Davatwal, 22, will be in 10 years' time, but right now he is selling sunglasses on commission at Heathrow airport. He was summarily dismissed from the Household Cavalry in March this year after an ill-fated night out in the West End with "the lads".

Although he is adamant that he has never taken drugs, and that his drink must have been spiked, traces of ecstasy were found in his bloodstream during one of the routine tests at Knightsbridge barracks in London. Ecstasy is an A-class drug and army rules are clear. No arguments. No way back.

Six others were caught by the same random test and they, too, were given an administrative discharge. They were all white, so there is no suggestion that the Sikh was treated more harshly than anybody else. All the same, his fall from grace seems particularly poignant in the context of his previous prominent role in army recruitment.

"He contributed a tremendous amount," Lieutenant-Colonel Mark Ridley concedes in next week's second programme of Channel 4's series, New Model Army. "He was a good soldier, quite clearly a future leader. What we owe him is thanks for his enthusiasm, but he did let us down . . . We invested a lot in his training [and] he let himself down."

More than 10 years have passed since Prince Charles noticed a distinct lack of black or brown faces in the ranks of those guarding his mother, and suggested that something must be done. Pressure built up in the early 1990s, when it emerged that a black mechanic had been refused entry on no other grounds than his colour.

Evidence of racist bullying emerged later from some of those black recruits who did make it into the ranks. Small wonder that Bob Purkiss, a commissioner at the Commission for Racial Equality, says of the efforts by the top brass to clean up their act: "If you can change the Household Cavalry, you can change any regiment in the British army."

Television producer Roger Mills and his team have spent 18 months recording the effectiveness of the army's 1997 commitment to turn itself into an equal opportunities employer. The Household Cavalry has accounted for the first two of the four-part series. Last week, viewers followed the progress of Marcelous Pusey, an Afro-Caribbean recruit from Birmingham, as he passed through basic training and looked forward to a rewarding career as a guardsman.

Yes, he was bawled at by NCOs, but then so was every other recruit. Yes, he put up with a bit of mildly racist banter and shrugged it off. But last December, he felt impelled to put in a complaint to the army's equal opportunities inquiry team. Exactly why is shrouded in mystery because the army has chosen to make it sub-judice. Nearly eight months on, the complaint is still being shunted around in Byzantine complexities of inquiry procedure. No verdict has been forthcoming - a marked contrast with the swiftness with which Davatwal was discharged.

Meanwhile, "Niggers don't belong here" was found scrawled in the washroom at the Knightsbridge barracks.

"We didn't go looking for racism when we set out on this series - it found us," says Mills, 63, who spent nearly two years in the Intelligence Corps during his national service and professes himself to be a "great lover of the army" with a fondness for military bands. He was evidently impressed by the commitment of Major-General Evelyn Webb-Carter, commanding officer of the Household Division, and very much one of the old school. "He has informed himself about ethnic issues and wants this policy of attracting more black and Asian soldiers to succeed," Mills says. "But if there are complaints about racism, they should be dealt with properly."

Pratap Rughani, who directed next Tuesday's programme about Davatwal, goes further. "The army top brass are appearing on platforms saying that, if there are problems, they will be dealt with swiftly," he says. "That's not the evidence we have. It's misleading."

Both programme-makers agree that however much the policy changes at the top, however many equal opportunities lectures are given to the ranks, it will take at least another gen eration for racist attitudes to be squeezed out of the barrack room. And even that's by no means guaranteed.

Pusey has another two years to serve. Davatwal has a whole lifetime to contemplate the folly of one night on the town. "I got up at six the next morning and reported for duty as usual," he recalls. "I couldn't believe it when they told me the result of the drug test. It was as though my heart had been ripped out."

For a while it had seemed that he had successfully straddled two cultures. The teenage fights he had had defending his mother and sister from racist taunts at home in Slough, Berkshire, had been forgotten when he found himself accepted in the army. "The officers seemed like father figures if I had a problem, and the NCOs didn't treat me any better or any worse than anyone else," he recalls.

As for his fellow recruits, he just felt glad to be accepted. He didn't mind being called Poppadum. That was just barrack-room humour, "a bit of a laugh". But he did sometimes resent being called away to pose in the recruitment office because he knew somebody else would have to cover for him. That problem was exacerbated when he needed compassionate leave to go looking for his sister, who had rebelled against an arranged marriage and run off with a Muslim. Davatwal found himself facing up to some prejudices of his own.

"I think the lad was under tremendous pressure all round," says Mills, sympathetically. In the circumstances, it's hardly surprising, as next Tuesday's programme points out, that he "tried extra hard to be in with the lads". Whatever happened on that night out was to cost him his career, the pride first engendered by his father, and acceptance by the national institution that he had come to regard as his second family.

The army in transition

In common with the other forces, the army is committed to a target that 4% of its recruits should this year come from British black and minority ethnic groups. At present, it is achieving about 3.2%.

Last year, the army failed to hit a 3% target, reaching only 2.2%. While that was an improvement on the year before, senior officers are under no illusion about the kind of signal that was sent. "It was a damaging failure," admits Brigadier Sebastian Roberts, the army's director of corporate communications. "We had been making good progress in shaking off the image of a 'white' organisation."

Roberts has viewed the Channel 4 series and, overall, is impressed by its balance. In particular, he thinks the Davatwal programme "one of the best documentaries I have seen for years". But he is anxious that viewers may rush to judgment on the first part, last week, which he feels presented unfairly the entangled disciplinary issues of the Pusey case.

Pusey, stresses Roberts, is a highly valued and contented trooper. Last week, he was on duty at the Queen Mother's 100th birthday celebrations. "He is loving it, but anybody seeing that first programme may get a misleading impression. I very much hope people will give the whole series a chance ," Roberts says.

Progress may be slow, but there is change. In the Household Cavalry, there are now two officers and 69 soldiers who are black and Asian. Seven years ago, there were none.

 Part two of New Model Army will be shown next Tuesday on Channel 4 at 9pm.
