Yes, he was bawled at by NCOs, but then so was every other recruit. Yes, he put up with a bit of mildly racist banter and shrugged it off. But last December, he felt impelled to put in a complaint to the army's equal opportunities inquiry team. Exactly why is shrouded in mystery because the army has chosen to make it sub-judice. Nearly eight months on, the complaint is still being shunted around in Byzantine complexities of inquiry procedure. No verdict has been forthcoming - a marked contrast with the swiftness with which Davatwal was discharged. Meanwhile, "Niggers don't belong here" was found scrawled in the washroom at the Knightsbridge barracks. "We didn't go looking for racism when we set out on this series - it found us," says Mills, 63, who spent nearly two years in the Intelligence Corps during his national service and professes himself to be a "great lover of the army" with a fondness for military bands. He was evidently impressed by the commitment of Major-General Evelyn Webb-Carter, commanding officer of the Household Division, and very much one of the old school. "He has informed himself about ethnic issues and wants this policy of attracting more black and Asian soldiers to succeed," Mills says. "But if there are complaints about racism, they should be dealt with properly." Pratap Rughani, who directed next Tuesday's programme about Davatwal, goes further. "The army top brass are appearing on platforms saying that, if there are problems, they will be dealt with swiftly," he says. "That's not the evidence we have. It's misleading." Both programme-makers agree that however much the policy changes at the top, however many equal opportunities lectures are given to the ranks, it will take at least another gen eration for racist attitudes to be squeezed out of the barrack room. And even that's by no means guaranteed. Pusey has another two years to serve. Davatwal has a whole lifetime to contemplate the folly of one night on the town. "I got up at six the next morning and reported for duty as usual," he recalls. "I couldn't believe it when they told me the result of the drug test. It was as though my heart had been ripped out." For a while it had seemed that he had successfully straddled two cultures. The teenage fights he had had defending his mother and sister from racist taunts at home in Slough, Berkshire, had been forgotten when he found himself accepted in the army. "The officers seemed like father figures if I had a problem, and the NCOs didn't treat me any better or any worse than anyone else," he recalls. As for his fellow recruits, he just felt glad to be accepted. He didn't mind being called Poppadum. That was just barrack-room humour, "a bit of a laugh". But he did sometimes resent being called away to pose in the recruitment office because he knew somebody else would have to cover for him. That problem was exacerbated when he needed compassionate leave to go looking for his sister, who had rebelled against an arranged marriage and run off with a Muslim. Davatwal found himself facing up to some prejudices of his own. "I think the lad was under tremendous pressure all round," says Mills, sympathetically. In the circumstances, it's hardly surprising, as next Tuesday's programme points out, that he "tried extra hard to be in with the lads". Whatever happened on that night out was to cost him his career, the pride first engendered by his father, and acceptance by the national institution that he had come to regard as his second family. The army in transition In common with the other forces, the army is committed to a target that 4% of its recruits should this year come from British black and minority ethnic groups. At present, it is achieving about 3.2%. Last year, the army failed to hit a 3% target, reaching only 2.2%. While that was an improvement on the year before, senior officers are under no illusion about the kind of signal that was sent. "It was a damaging failure," admits Brigadier Sebastian Roberts, the army's director of corporate communications. "We had been making good progress in shaking off the image of a 'white' organisation." Roberts has viewed the Channel 4 series and, overall, is impressed by its balance. In particular, he thinks the Davatwal programme "one of the best documentaries I have seen for years". But he is anxious that viewers may rush to judgment on the first part, last week, which he feels presented unfairly the entangled disciplinary issues of the Pusey case. Pusey, stresses Roberts, is a highly valued and contented trooper. Last week, he was on duty at the Queen Mother's 100th birthday celebrations. "He is loving it, but anybody seeing that first programme may get a misleading impression. I very much hope people will give the whole series a chance ," Roberts says. Progress may be slow, but there is change. In the Household Cavalry, there are now two officers and 69 soldiers who are black and Asian. Seven years ago, there were none.  Part two of New Model Army will be shown next Tuesday on Channel 4 at 9pm.

webTitle: Putin tries to calm anti-Chechen hysteria

fields.headline: Putin tries to calm anti-Chechen hysteria
fields.standfirst:
Audio: Ian Traynor in Moscow (1min 25)
Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Russian president Vladimir Putin sought to calm a rising tide of anti-Chechen hysteria today, following Tuesday's bomb blast in the heart of Moscow that killed seven people and left 90 injured.
fields.body:
Russian president Vladimir Putin sought to calm a rising tide of anti-Chechen hysteria today, following Tuesday's bomb blast in the heart of Moscow that killed seven people and left 90 injured.

Leaders of Moscow's large Chechen community were bracing themselves for a wave of repressive actions, including summary police searches, interrogations, detentions, and expulsions from the area, after the city's powerful mayor, Yuriy Luzhkov, declared the bomb "100 per cent Chechen."

The head mufti of Russia, leader of the country's large Muslim community, Sheikh Ravil Galautdin, warned that incendiary public statements blaming Chechens for the crime could spark "nationalist feuds" in the country.

But Mr Putin stepped in to try to calm the situation. "If we're talking about the terrorist version," he said, "it's not right to look for a national trace, a Chechen trace, or any other in this crime."

His statement was seen as an attempt to seize the moral high ground while criticising Mr Luzhkov, a political rival.

"Terrorism is not a national disease, it's an international disease," added Mr Putin.

Following yesterday's bomb, Russian police have found a bag containing explosives at the city's Kazansky railway station this morning.

Officers found a suitcase containing 4kg (almost nine pounds) of TNT and seven detonators in a lost luggage office at the station.

The explosives were not wired for detonation, but police are investigating a possible link to Tuesday's blast.

A wave of bombings that left 300 people dead a year ago was blamed on Chechen rebels, triggering Mr Putin's decision to launch the war in the north Caucasus against Chechen separatists.

Now Moscow residents are worrying that the city faces a new terror campaign.

The find came after Chechen president Aslan Maskhadov had denied that his separatist fighters were behind yesterday's attack.

The denial was made in a statement by Mr Maskhadov on the Chechen press agency's website. The agency claims to be the official voice of Mr Maskhadov, who is believed to be in the southern Chechen mountains.

"The press service of the president of the Chechen republic of Ichkeria is empowered to declare that attempts by the Russian side to blame the terrorist act in Pushkin Square on Chechen resistance fighters has no foundation," the statement said.

The FSB domestic security police said today that it was holding two men in detention over the blast, one of them from Chechnya and the other from the neighbouring North Caucasus republic of Dagestan.

The Federal Security Service - the main domestic intelligence agency that is heading the investigation - said that the suspects fitted descriptions of two men who were spotted moments before the bomb exploded. A third suspect is being sought.

Nikolay Patrushev, the head of the domestic intelligence service who broke off his holiday and returned to Moscow yesterday, said that 11 other bomb plots in various Russian cities had been foiled last month and strongly suggested that they were all the work of Chechens.

Apart from the two men detained in connection with the Moscow blast, another three Chechens were arrested on Wednesday in the Volga town of Saratov.

"They might have been planning a terrorist attack similar to the one in Moscow," the Interfax news agency reported.

Emergency officials said that two US citizens were among those injured in the blast, but had no other details. Eleven of the injured are in a critical condition.

As Muscovites returned to work this morning, many left flowers in Pushkin Square to mourn the dead, while other city workers washed blood off the walls of the passageway.

Scores of people attended local hospitals to donate blood for those who were injured in the bombing.

The underground passageway was located near three subway stations and is usually thronged with commuters and shoppers.

"We should stop speaking about freedom of movement ... We should realise we are living in the capital of a warring country," Alexander Muzikantsky, a Moscow city official, told ORT television.

Mr Luzhkov told reporters that the suspects apparently approached a kiosk in the passageway and tried to buy something with American dollars, but the vendor wouldn't accept them.

The suspects then said they would go and exchange the money for roubles, and left their bag behind.

"Almost right then, the bag exploded," Mr Luzhkov said.

The blast ripped through the passageway, tossing people to the ground and wrecking many of the kiosks that lined its sides. Blood-soaked people stumbled out into the street as terrified passers-by watched.

Rescuers later dragged burned corpses past charred heaps of kiosks that once filled the busy walkway. Officials have said that most of the bodies were so badly charred that identification is proving very difficult.

fields.headline: Montenegro and Serbia
fields.standfirst: As two British police officers face charges of terrorism and espionage in the Serbian capital Belgrade, after being arrested in Montenegro, Mark Tran explains the troubled relationship between these two republics
fields.trailText: As two British police officers face charges of terrorism and espionage in the Serbian capital Belgrade, after being arrested in Montenegro, we explain the troubled relationship between these two republics.
fields.body:
What is Montenegro?
Montenegro and Serbia are essentially all that is left of what was Yugoslavia, as cobbled together by the late president Tito. Slovenia, Croatia and Bosnia-Herzegovina all proclaimed independence because they wished to escape Serbian domination. Bosnia's declaration of independence triggered Europe's bloodiest conflict since the second world war. Kosovo is technically still part of Yugoslavia as it is described as an autonomous province, but it is under the protection of a multinational force and it is difficult to see Belgrade ever reasserting its rule in the province.

How are relations between Montenegro and Serbia?
Montenegro is run by pro-western president Milo Djukanovic, who would dearly like to leave the Yugoslav federation. In an example of the ill-feeling between the two, Montenegro agreed to cooperate with the UN war crimes tribunal, which indicted Mr Milosevic for war crimes committed by Serb forces last year in Kosovo. But Mr Djukanovic has to be careful because of the presence of some 15,000 Yugoslav troops in Montenegro. President Djukanovic controls the police but Serbia controls the army. The two British police officers were arrested by Yugoslav federal troops.

Are the police officers pawns in a bigger political game?
Very much so. The arrest is seen as a ploy by Serbian president Slobodan Milosevic to destabilise Montenegro and whip up anti-western sentiment in advance of snap presidential and federal elections called for September 24. Mr Milosevic has already begun to use the case to highlight what he claims are the west's continuing attempts to subvert the Serbian nation. The incident, whether or not it leads to a show trial, will be exploited for electoral ends, with Mr Milosevic cast by official media as a vigilant defender of Serb interests against vengeful Nato countries that failed to destroy him during the Kosovo war. Another case, that of four Dutchmen recently held and accused of plotting to kidnap or assassinate Mr Milosevic, can be expected to be used in a similar way.

What is Mr Djukanovic's attitude to the elections?
He has declared a boycott of the elections in another act of defiance of Mr Milosevic. There are fears in Washington and other Nato capitals that the Serbian leader will impose direct rule on Montenegro after the elections, in which he is the favourite to win. He knows that Nato would be reluctant to launch another Kosovo-style intervention to save Montenegro. Besides, the US would be preoccupied with its presidential election at that time.

Is there a united opposition to Mr Milosevic in the upcoming elections?
No, to the dismay of the west. The anti-Milosevic vote will be split between Vojislav Kostunica, the nationalist leader of the Democratic Party of Serbia, who was chosen by 15 Serbian opposition parties, and Belgrade mayor Vojislav Mihajlovic, who was nominated by biggest opposition party, the Serbian Renewal Movement (SPO).

webTitle: Diageo and Allied at war over Seagram

fields.headline: Diageo and Allied at war over Seagram
fields.trailText: Diageo and Allied Domecq look set for a head-on clash in the battle to buy Seagram's $7bn (£4.5bn) wine and spirits business, which is up for sale after the Canadian group's decision to concentrate on media and entertainment.
fields.byline: Andrew Clark  and Jane Martinson in New York
fields.body:
Diageo and Allied Domecq look set for a head-on clash in the battle to buy Seagram's $7bn (£4.5bn) wine and spirits business, which is up for sale after the Canadian group's decision to concentrate on media and entertainment.

Industry sources yesterday said Diageo was discussing a joint bid for the business with Bacardi, the Bermudan-based drinks group. A spokeswoman for Diageo refused to confirm this but said: "We're not hiding the fact that we're interested in Seagram's spirits business and we have said we're looking at all options."

Diageo is the world's biggest drinks company and insiders say the group is anxious to prevent Allied Domecq, its nearest rival, from growing in scale.

However, Diageo is unlikely to bid alone for regulatory reasons as it would not be allowed to add Seagram's Chivas Regal premium whisky to its own Johnnie Walker.

Diageo already has a good relationship with Bacardi, which bought its Dewar's whisky and Bombay gin brand two years ago.

Under a joint purchase, Diageo is tipped to pick up Seagram's Captain Morgan rum and Crown Royal whisky. An imminent move is unlikely, however, as both Diageo's chief executive John McGrath and his designated successor, Paul Walsh, are on holiday.

The group will have money to spend after the sale of Pillsbury, its US food business, and the partial flotation of its fast food chain Burger King. Mr Walsh, who takes over the top job next month, needs a plan to win over sceptical investors, who doubt the growth prospects of Diageo's remaining UDV spirits arm and Guinness beer company.

Seagram declined to comment yesterday. Its drinks operations employ 10,000 people in 190 countries, with sales last year of $684m. It wants to exit the industry following its decision to merge with Vivendi, the French media giant.

Allied Domecq's new chief executive Philip Bowman is anxious to make a big acquisition, following the group's £2.7bn sale of its pub estate last year. Analysts believe its portfolio would fit well with Seagram's, with the only obvious overlaps in cognac where Allied's Courvoisier competes with Seagram's Martell, and in a handful of port and sherry brands.

Several other contenders are considering entering the fray, including the Bronfman family who founded Seagram 76 years ago and still have a 24% stake. Charles Bronfman, co-chairman of Seagram, is believed to have appointed the US investment bank Bear Stearns to help prepare a multi-billion dollar buyout proposal.

Paris-based Pernod Ricard has been tipped as another bidder, although it has been hampered by its failure to off load its Orangina soft drinks operation. The French government blocked a sale of the business to Coca-Cola last year.

Diageo's shares slipped 4.5p to 600p yesterday, while Allied Domecq edged up 1.75p to 339.75p. Morgan Stanley, which is advising Seagram on the sale, is due to publish a book with details of the up-for-grabs operations later this month.

Top tipples

Seagram's leading drinks:

Chivas Regal premium Scotch whisky

Crown Royal Canadian whisky

Captain Morgan Original Spiced Rum

Absolut Vodka

Martell cognac

Don Julio Tequila

The Glenlivet 12-year-old Scotch whisky

Seagram's Gin

webTitle: Big labels accused of CD price fix

fields.headline: Big labels accused of CD price fix
fields.trailText: Governments in 28 US states yesterday accused the world's five largest record labels of illegally fixing the prices of compact discs in a lawsuit that could force the companies to pay substantial damages.
fields.body:
Governments in 28 US states yesterday accused the world's five largest record labels of illegally fixing the prices of compact discs in a lawsuit that could force the companies to pay substantial damages.

The suit charges Warner Brothers, the record arm of Time Warner, Sony Music Entertainment, Universal, which is owned by Seagram, BMG, the label owned by Bertelsmann of Germany and EMI of the UK of acting in collusion with retailers to stamp out the threat of competition from low-cost outlets.

Under the so-called "minimum advertised pricing" practice, the record labels are accused of subsidising advertising to retailers that agreed not to sell CDs below a minimum price set by the labels themselves. The policy was introduced in 1995 to counter competition from large retailers such as Walmart and Circuit City in the US, which had started to sell cheap CDs as a loss-leader to attract consumers into their stores.

In a statement yesterday, Eliot Spitzer, the state attorney general for New York, said: "Because of these conspiracies, tens of millions of consumers paid inflated prices to buy CDs." The amount of damages in the lawsuit, which was filed in New York, was unspecified.

The lawsuit was signed by 28 states, including Florida and Texas, on behalf of millions of US consumers. Three retailers were also among the defendents: Tower Records, Trans World Entertainment and MusicLand Stores.

Shares in EMI, the UK-based group that owns Capitol records, fell 9% to 591p in London following the announcement of the lawsuit. Shares in the other targeted companies, which are also fighting separate legal action against online copyright infringement, also suffered yesterday.

The practice of giving financial inducements to retailers who agreed to stick to prices determined by the labels has come under fire before in the US.

The US Federal Trade Commission, the competition regulator, conducted an in-depth investigation into allegations that the record labels were breaking US anti-trust laws by keeping prices artificially high and penalising retailers who refused to take part in the MAP scheme. The record labels reached a settlement with the FTC in May that agreed to outlaw the policy for seven years.

However, the prices of CDs are understood to have risen since this settlement and several US analysts expected the states to try to recover financial damages at some point.

The labels have argued that MAP was introduced to help smaller music retailers that did not have the option of offsetting the price of CDs to compete against larger businesses that did. They have also said that they received no financial gain from the policy as they kept the wholesale price the same to discounters and retailers who agreed to abide by MAP.

fields.body:
The damning report by the World Bank comes less than a week after a World Health Organisation report which accused the tobacco industry of a carrying out a covert campaign against anti-smoking initiatives in the developing world.

Big tobacco was accused of painting the WHO as the puppet of the developed world in a clandestine campaign which began in the late 1980s. The WHO report suggested that the tobacco industry also tried to set the multilateral agency at odds with other UN agencies in an effort to weaken it.

The conclusion read: "Top executives of tobacco companies designed and set in motion elaborate strategies to subvert a public health organisation is unacceptable and must be condemned."

This week, Dr Gro Harlem Brundtland, the head of the WHO, continued the attack by accusing tobacco companies of using "brutal marketing tools" to lure young people to smoking in developing nations. These promotions "made a mockery of the industry's claim that they are concerned about smoking among the young".

Last week's report argued that a 10% increase in tobacco taxes worldwide would persuade about 42m people to give up smoking and could prevent 10m deaths - 9m of them in developing countries.

Philip Morris, which controls almost 50% of the US cigarette market, and its combative chairman, Geoffrey Bible, were singled out for criticism.

webTitle: Hague: I drank 14 pints of beer a day

fields.headline: Hague: I drank 14 pints of beer a day
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: The Tory party leader, William Hague, will tomorrow use an interview with a glossy men's magazine to launch the boldest reworking yet of his personal profile.
fields.body:
The Tory party leader, William Hague, will tomorrow use an interview with a glossy men's magazine to launch the boldest reworking yet of his personal profile.

The new-look Mr Hague appears determined to counter the image of the precocious 16-year-old who spoke to a bemused party conference in 1977 and had a poster of Margaret Thatcher above his bed.

Nicholas Coleridge, managing director of Condé Nast, who conducted the interview for GQ magazine, described the new Mr Hague as taller than you expect and with a washboard stomach.

But Mr Hague told the magazine he had not always taken such good care of his body. Between the ages of 15 and 21 he drank 14 pints a day during a summer job hauling crates of drinks into pubs across South Yorkshire for his family's soft drinks firm.

"We used to have a pint at every stop and we used to have about 10 stops a day," he said. "You worked hard so you didn't feel you'd drunk 10 pints by four o'clock - you used to sweat so much."

And the day's drinking did not stop there, he explained. "Then [we would] go home for tea and then go out in the evening to the pub. I think when you're a teenager you can do that."

Yesterday people in Mr Hague's home town of Rotherham met this revised personal history with scepticism.

Terry Glossop, 47, assistant manager of the Angel, one of Rotherham's oldest pubs, said: "Some of the old boys have been coming in here for donkey's years and no one can remember Hague coming in for as much as a half of lager.

"He worked for his father's soft drinks company and was known as Billy Fizz and Billy the Pop. The idea of him sinking 14 pints is laughable. Nobody has seen him round here for years."

David Hargreaves, 54, a drinker in the nearby County Borough hotel, said: "I think his memory might have got confused by a couple of sherries. The Hague family have always been famous round here for soft drinks not the hard stuff."

But Mr Hague insisted most of his teenage holidays were spent loafing in bars rather than poring over Hansard, as previously claimed.

"It was a great education, actually: knowing what Labour voters feel like as well as Conservatives," he said. "I think I learned more going around the clubs in Barnsley than I learned at Oxford."

The Tory leader revealed that, as a young rebellious figure, he broke the heart of an unnamed Rotherham girl when he left her and set off for Oxford University.

"We split up after about a year," he said. "I haven't talked about this before," he added, hinting that there might be more broken hearts in Rotherham. His new profile as a lads' icon wavered only once, when he told the magazine he could not name the captain of the England football team.

The PR expert Max Clifford said the makeover was unconvincing. "It won't work because it is obvious - you don't look at him and see a 14-pint man."

webTitle: Families flee after anti-paedophile mob violence

fields.headline: Families flee after anti-paedophile mob violence
fields.trailText: Police today called for an end to mob violence against suspected sex offenders as four families in Portsmouth left their homes after a series of anti-paedophile riots.
fields.body:
Police today called for an end to mob violence against suspected sex offenders as four families in Portsmouth left their homes after a series of anti-paedophile riots.

The families who left were not connected to paedophiles or sex offenders but had chosen to leave the city's troubled Paulsgrove estate, where the riots were centred, because they did not like what was happening, said Hampshire Police spokesman Richard Horobin.

There have been violent demonstrations on the estate since last Thursday, when a policeman was injured and a car was torched by a mob.

That protest targeted a convicted paedophile who was "named and shamed" in the News of the World. He had now left the county, police said.

Mr Horobin said another family targeted by the mob had since left the estate but refused to confirm reports that protesters were working from a list of 20 suspected sex offenders.

Portsmouth City Council has said it will offer temporary accommodation to any individuals or families named by the protesters, and has asked for the list to be handed over. It has agreed a five-point "peace plan" with police and protest leaders and has said it is talking to two families about rehousing them.

Acting chief executive Roger Ching said: "We can only look to offer people a temporary change of address with their agreement.

"If they do not want to go, there is nothing we can do about it - and that was the biggest bone of contention with the protesters, although they now understand the reasons for that."

Mr Ching said talks between the council, police and the protesters had been productive, adding: "The bottom line is that they share our view in not wanting to see any more violence on the streets of Paulsgrove and we will all work full speed to achieve that aim."

The five points of the plan are:  All sides agreeing to work for the safety of children and public safety on the Paulsgrove estate in Portsmouth
 Regular meetings with protest leaders
 A council-appointed liaison officer will work with residents
 The council pledges to help residents campaign for a change in the law about the release of paedophiles into the community
: Protesters will consider handing over their list of alleged paedophiles. The council will then offer anyone on the list who is under threat a temporary "place of safety".

Police said an anti-paedophile demonstration was scheduled to take place in Paulsgrove Park this morning. There was another protest last night, with more than 100 demonstrators marching through the estate, but it was peaceful with no arrests, police said.

In Plymouth, meanwhile, police today called for an end to vigilante action after 50-60 people targeted the home of a suspected sex offender in the Southway area of the city yesterday evening.

The house, which is believed to be the home of a registered sex offender, has been the subject of several recent community meetings.

The crowd, which included many children, chanted "we want you out" and threw a stone through the window of the house, said a police spokesman.

No-one inside was injured, but police were called by neighbours who were concerned for their own safety. Officers dispersed the crowd within 30 minutes, but felt it was necessary to maintain a visible presence at the house through the night.

Some protesters had vowed to return night after night until the man left the area, the police spokesman said. Officers were today planning to meet local people to discuss the best plan of action, while ward officers would also be out in the community.

Devon and Cornwall Police spokesman John Wood urged people not to resort to vigilante action, saying: "A great deal of work is being done nationally and locally by all the agencies to review the procedures we have. "What we are doing is working, and there is a great danger that if these procedures break down sex offenders will be driven underground.

"Then we will lose the vital contact we have with them now and children will be less safe."

webTitle: Why can't the press like William Hague?

fields.headline: Why can't the press like William Hague?
fields.standfirst: As another laddish gambit explodes in his face, the Tory leader looks doomed always to bear the brunt of Fleet Street's barbs, says Gwyn Topham
fields.trailText: As another laddish gambit explodes in his face, the Tory leader looks doomed always to bear the brunt of Fleet Street's barbs, says Gwyn Topham.
fields.body:
Some are born geeks; others, like William Hague, appear to have embraced geekdom wholeheartedly, not least as a teenage Tory. But if a man suddenly realises he has spent his formative years way the wrong side of cool, the world should applaud him for trying to rectify matters.

But no sooner does the hapless Tory leader make a bid for cred than we laugh in his face. It's the kind of school playground reaction that makes a man want to grow up into a rightwing nut.

Beer monster (let's just take him at his word) Mr Hague must have woken up this morning hoping for accolades after his 14-pint-a-day revelation. Having trawled the pubs of Rotherham, the press instead find a landlord - who quite possibly was elsewhere during the legendary binges - alleging that Mr Hague was a strictly lemonade man known as Billy Fizz.

And William was reaching out to us. "It was a great education, actually: knowing what Labour voters feel like as well as Conservatives," he told GQ. You're spot on, Will: it's a state of constant beer-induced euphoria on the left.

Labour voters, more than anyone, need to show William their deep appreciation whenever he makes an effort. Because it's not long since William (or the much cooler Will, as he should have been known had spinner Amanda Platell done her job properly) was making all the right noises about multiculturalism. To top it, he went out shaking his booty at Notting Hill carnival.

Instead of being feted on the cover of Rolling Stone magazine, he was derided as a baseball-cap wearing idiot. Now we find an embittered Hague doing his best to whip up a storm against refugees.

Around the same time, switched-on Will was airing liberal opinions on questions of sexuality, and even voted in favour of reducing the gay age of consent to 16. Having tested the water, it should have made perfect sense to opt for a Soho-style No 1-crop haircut.

But again, the fickle media savaged him for his tonsorial homo chic. And now we see the result: an implacable opposition to the repeal of section 28.

So if in some future plea for popularity, Will starts revealing his seamier Oxbridge past, let us not mock. When Will 2001 talks about his time as a pill-popping pioneer, please find us no drug dealers scornfully sniffing at Billy Whizz, telling the world they never saw him leave the debating society. When Will 2002 says he was pleasuring Ffion 14 times a night, let us keep any kiss-and-tells and Billy Brewers gags firmly under wraps.

Otherwise he'll just get angry again. And the world will be a nastier, less tolerant place.

webTitle: Chinese try to speed up identification of Dover dead

fields.headline: Chinese try to speed up identification of Dover dead
fields.standfirst: Almost two months after 58 Chinese refugees died in a lorry, Mark Tran discovers that the identification process is still not complete
fields.trailText: Almost two months after 58 Chinese refugees died in a lorry, Mark Tran discovers that the identification process is still not complete.
fields.body:
Chinese community leaders are pressing the Kent police to release photos of the 58 Chinese people who suffocated in a lorry near Dover to speed up the identification process.

Although the bodies were discovered on 19 June, only two have been positively identified. Relatives of the victims have been reluctant to come forward because of their own uncertain legal status in Britain.

Chinese groups have been pressing the Kent police to release the photos of the victims to them as a way of getting around this problem.

When the proposal first emerged, the police said that the time was not ripe, but the Dover police appear to have shifted their position since another request was made last week. Kent police are expected to make a final decision in a few days.

"We have requested the photos to be released and we received a sympathetic response. We are waiting to hear from the chief constable," said Jabez Lam, chairman of the of Dover 58 co-ordinating committee, which was formed two weeks ago.

Twenty of the victims are believed to have relatives in Britain, but Mr Lam believes that the initial police approach to the tragedy scared off family members.

Kent police at first wanted the relatives to declare their own immigration status and to give information about the victims' routes.

Kent police have since completely separated the criminal investigation and the identification process.

Families who come forward will neither be asked about their immigration status nor will they be asked about details of how their relatives reached Britain.

But it been difficult to dispel the initial fears of the relatives says Mr Lam.

The co-ordinating committee proposed that the police release the photos to a small group within the Chinese community with proper procedures to verify that those who come forward are genuine family members.

The committee has authorised the Central London law centre in Soho and the Monitoring Group, which monitors race crimes, to hold the photos in their safekeeping during the identification process.

Mark Pugash, a spokesman from the Kent police, played down Chinese concerns over the identification process.

He said the police had received a great deal of cooperation from the Chinese government and the Chinese community in Britain.

"We are pretty confident we know who 46 of the people are," Mr Pugash said.

But there have been reports that cooperation between British and Chinese police has been less than smooth.

British DNA specialists postponed a trip to China amid reports of Chinese displeasure that Chinese officials would not be given access to the two survivors from the ill-fated lorry.

The British specialists are expected to go Fujian province, where the victims came from, at the end of the month or early next month after the Chinese have finished the preliminary work on DNA samples.

Three people have been charged with manslaughter in connection with the tragedy, a man and woman of Chinese origin, and the driver of the lorry.

The 58 bodies, four of them women, were found in a refrigeration container that had arrived by ferry from Zeebrugge.

Home Office pathologists, who completed post mortem examinations on the bodies, confirmed that all 58 had died of suffocation.

The number of Chinese asylum seekers coming to Britain is second only to those from Sri Lanka, with 400 Chinese asylum seekers arriving every month.

But the refusal of the Beijing government to take back Chinese nationals who have destroyed their documents has blocked attempts by the immigration authorities to remove hundreds of failed Chinese asylum seekers from Britain.

fields.headline: Rock in Cornwall
fields.standfirst: All you need to know about the hooray Henrys' (and possibly the Waleses') favourite resort
fields.trailText: All you need to know about the hooray Henrys' (and possibly the Waleses) favourite resort.
fields.body:
1. Rock in north Cornwall can mean two things: music and yobbery. Sometimes both.

2. The local Lib Dem MP, Paul Tyler, has complained that pretty little Rock on the Camel estuary (as opposed to Little Rock, Arkansas) is invaded each summer by public school louts.

3. Apparently Toby, Marcus and the other Hooray Henrys are making a perishing nuisance of themselves.

4. They hang around drinking till all hours, would you believe, cluttering up the road outside The Mariners Hotel.

5. Shame, really, when they could be having a wizard time in God's own county. Having a healthy walk, or putting in a round of golf, that sort of thing.

6. Or maybe making a literary pilgrimage to the grave of John Betjeman, who loved this part of the country.

7. Or exerting themselves a little by tracking down the Beast of Bodmin Moor, about which the indefatigable Mr Tyler has also been known to fret.

8. Still, the Mariners has its points. It's described by its landlord as "small and grotty". In fact, it has a fine restaurant called Samantha's (which must make the chaps feel at home) and 18 rooms.

9. If you don't care for the braying sounds of gilded youth, there are plenty of other nice places to stay around Rock, with gorgeous Cornish names like Splatt, Stoptide and Pityme, and they are all easy to reach.

10. But take care: you might bump into the young Waleses, William and Harry, who have put in a bit of time with the Rock set. Behaving impeccably, of course.

fields.headline: Knowledge Unlimited
fields.standfirst: Send your questions to the.boss@guardian.co.uk.
fields.trailText: Why is the German away strip green? we asked in a previous Knowledge Unlimited. The answer - according to hundreds of you who wrote in - was that it's all down to Ireland being the first team to play the Germans after the second World War. However, you were all wrong.
fields.body:
Why is the German away strip green? we asked in a previous Knowledge Unlimited. The answer - according to hundreds of you who wrote in - was that it's all down to Ireland being the first team to play the Germans after the second World War. However, you were all wrong.

"I asked this question of some of my student colleagues and all of them seemed to agree (in a typically German way) that the story relating to the Irish is, well, a pile of sauerkraut," says James Spackman. "It does date from this time, however, as the first match after WWII there were doubts over whether the nation would be playing as a unified team or not.

"In their second match this question had to be resolved, and by none other than the Bundeskanzler Adenauer himself. As a patriotic Rheinlander he made sure the new capital was to be Bonn, and the away colours of the national team would be the traditional heraldic colours of the Rheinland - silver and green - symbolising the river and the surrounding lush green landscape. Meanwhile the home strip remained in the traditional Prussian colours of white and black."

"This discussion caused another question to spring up, namely why did the East German team played in blue? This isn't a colour traditionally associated with the eastern states, and was hardly the colour of communism. If you could supply an acceptable and conclusive answer (to German intellectual standards!) then I'll for once be able to get them to shut up when they go on about how the English know nothing about German football."

A guy at my work has asked me to name a player who has played for Manchester United, Man City, Liverpool and Everton writes Katy Tuck. Brian Kidd has played for three out of the four, but I severely doubt that any player has played for all four. I suspect this is a trick question. Can anyone confirm this for me - or prove me wrong?

The man you're looking for, Katy, is none other than Peter Beardsley. The Geordie twinkletoes played one League Cup game for Manchester United in the 1982-83 season, and a handful of games on loan for Manchester City in the first division in the 1997-98 season. In between he was at Liverpool between 1987-91 (131 appearances, 46 goals) and at Everton from 1991-93 (81 appearances, 25 goals).

This week there's been tonnes more correspondence about Liverpool being a Protestant club and Everton being Catholic. Thanks to everyone who wrote in.

Our favourite anecdote comes from Dr C.P. Bailey of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx. He says one of his Grandad's favourite stories was that "when he married my Nana in the 20s, he had to renounce Catholicism (she was Protestant), and thereby severing all ties with his family. When asked to change is football team to Liverpool from Everton, however, he told his future in-laws where to go. He did get to marry my Liverpudlian Grandma, but remained a proud Evertonian!" he says.

However Sam Johnstone of the Football Research Unit at Liverpool University says those speculating on the origins of the Liverpool-Everton, Protestant-Catholic thing are talking nonsense. "Both clubs were founded by the same people (essentially the wealthy, protestant middle classes of 19th-century Liverpool) from the same church (St Domingo's, a protestant church)," he says.

"The story of Liverpool's formation is familiar to all. Everton were formed in 1878, team falls out with John Houlding (the guy who owns Anfield), Houlding forms Liverpool FC in 1892, the rest we know about. What is more interesting is the involvement of the Masons. The guys who formed LFC and EFC were wealthy, middle class, protestant, businessmen and, importantly, pillars of the political and religious establishment (Houlding went on to become Lord Mayor of Liverpool). Freemasonry attracted these very people (for many reasons) and it is known that Houlding and his friend W. Barclay were in the Lodge.

"And, of course, this was repeated nationwide. For those teams that didn't come specifically from the Catholic church (Celtic), it was likely that the factory and mill owners were involved in charitable organisations, religion and politics (all masonic activities). It is no coincidence that the meeting that led to the formation of the FA took place in a pub called the Freemason's Tavern. Or am I just a conspiracy theorist?"

Footballers are generally regarded as being a bit thick and people such as David Beckham and Robbie Fowler do nothing to improve this image. During Euro 2000 I noticed that there are several foreign footballers who are graduates. Are there any current Premiership players, British or foreign, who have a degree or even a couple of GCSE's? wondered Daniel Davies

Take a bow David Weatherall, who has a first in Chemistry from Sheffield, and several ex-Southampton players, including Barry Horne (who also has a Chemistry degree) and Ian Dowie, who has some sort of business degree. Also on the roll of honour is Watford's Steve Palmer, who is - according to James Lowther - the only current professional footballer with an Oxbridge degree (an Msc in computing).

Those with professional qualifications include Gudni Bergsson, who is a qualified lawyer and plans to practise in Iceland when he retires (says Ben Dudley), and Phil Whelan, who has a degree in accountancy from the UEA (according to Steve Moore). And legendary 40-fags-a-day Brazilian striker Socrates was a paediatrician by training.

Sometimes as a ball is going out of play a player will prevent the opposition from reaching it by "shielding" the ball but without actually touching it. In any other circumstance this would be obstruction. Why isn't it in this case? asked Peter Hayes.

"I once saw a referee asked this very same question on TV" says Craig Thomas, "and he stated that if the player doing the shielding is within reach of the ball then he is adjudged to be in possession and have control of the ball. However, obstruction will be called if the shielding player does not have the ball within his reach."

"I have a vivid memory of Socrates taking a penalty and bursting the net. Did it ever happen - or was it just the work of an over excited brain whilst sleeping? And if Socrates did not burst the net, has anyone else achieved such a feat?" wondered Jonathon Norman.

"I am an Ipswich fan, but far too young to say if this is true or not. But my father, who isn't too young, says that Ted Philips - the strong, powerful centre forward of the 50s and early 60s - did once break the net in a league game," says William Jennings.

Can you help?

Why did the goalkeeper in English teams always used to wear a green shirt? asks Luis Andrade Sa.

On the television I saw a brief newsclip of Emmanuel Petit's signing with Barcelona. At some point in the photography session, a rather buxom, to say the least, young lady was rushed over to pose with him. Who was she, and can her photo be found on the net? asks Gilbert Gregory.

Any questions?

Send your football asks to the.boss@theguardian.com and we'll do our best to give you some answers.

webTitle: In brief and the latest casting news

fields.headline: In brief and the latest casting news
fields.trailText: Gloucester Cathedral to star in Harry Potter pic, more medical care for Liz Taylor, James Bond may go green, and Rushmore team to reunite
fields.body:
 The 900-year-old Gloucester Cathedral looks set for a starring role in the Harry Potter movie - the building has been chosen to double as Hogwarts, the wizard school where Harry learns his craft. The film's backer, Warner Bros, initially had its heart set on using Canterbury Cathedral, but were turned down following accusations that the Potter stories were ungodly. Nicholas Bury, dean of Gloucester Cathedral, is of a more sensible opinion, describing Harry Potter as "a marvellous, traditional children's story". With the film's location now in place, there remains only one piece of the jigsaw to fit: Harry himself has yet to be cast.

 Elizabeth Taylor (pictured) was rushed into an LA hospital last weekend suffering from what a spokesman described as "mild pneumonia". It's merely the latest in a catalogue of medical woes for the 68-year-old actress, who has in her time tussled with high blood pressure, deteriorating hips, a brain tumour and a dependence on prescription drugs. Sources say that Taylor hopes to be released from Cedars-Sinai Medical Centre (the same place, incidentally, where new mum Catherine Zeta-Jones is currently in residence) by Saturday.

 007 star Pierce Brosnan has signed up to promote the Forest Stewardship Council in a series of conservation advertisements to be aired in Canada and the US. The Irish-born actor is also reported to be lobbying to have James Bond (normally the symbol of hardline capitalism) be made more conservation-conscious in future outings. "He's trying to persuade the powers that be to give his James Bond an eco-side," reckoned an unnamed source close to the actor.

 The people behind the critically-acclaimed Rushmore have reunited to create another quirky portrait of American life - this time, reportedly, to be in a similar vein to Orson Welles' 1942 pic The Magnificent Ambersons. Owen Wilson and Wes Anderson will, respectively, script and direct The Royal Tannenbaums: an offbeat comedy about a family of geniuses in present-day New York. The film shoots in January.

webTitle: A different sort of Lord's final

fields.headline: A different sort of Lord's final
fields.standfirst: James Schneider, 13, recently returned from a two-week cricket tour of Barbados, from where he wrote a daily diary. Here he reports on the final of the Sir George Allen Trophy for Under-10 cricketers, held at Lord's last Sunday
fields.trailText: Sunday's match was the final of the Middlesex Gubby Allen Under-10 Cup, played on the Nursery ground at Lord's. MCC has a special responsibility for youth cricket and has discharged that duty by eliminating all schoolboy matches on the main ground, other than the Eton v Harrow match. So it is a privilege for these boys to play on the Nursery ground.
fields.body:
Sunday's match was the final of the Middlesex Gubby Allen Under-10 Cup, played on the Nursery ground at Lord's. MCC has a special responsibility for youth cricket and has discharged that duty by eliminating all schoolboy matches on the main ground, other than the Eton v Harrow match. So it is a privilege for these boys to play on the Nursery ground.

Since returning from Barbados, Mum has been grappling with the Winchester College uniform list for September. I have also been reflecting on my captaincy in Barbados. As we set off for Lord's, some Australian friends rang from Melbourne to wish Timothy (my brother) luck. Next week we go to Scotland, so that noted Scot and Wykehamist, Douglas Jardine, was in my mind.

We only live around the corner from the ground, so I must have been there countless times. Only today did the significance of the Pavilion being flanked on the one side by the Allen Stand and on the other side by the Warner Stand occur to me: one declined to bowl Bodyline; the other was the ineffectual tour manager. Both were knighted; both were members of the Establishment. Jardine is long dead and forgotten. No tournament or monument for him, but he was the ruthless captain who did the job required and then was cut adrift. A similar fate met the four knights in "Murder in the Cathedral" once the job was done.

Perhaps the real problem with English cricket, or indeed with the English, is that we all want winners, but recoil from the hard men who, in Graham Greene's wonderful phrase "know when to put the razor blade in the potato". Is that why Steve Redgrave, the greatest sportsman this country has produced in the last 100 years (subject, I suppose, to the claims of CB Fry), is not universally lauded?

With these thoughts in mind, I watch the match. A word of explanation of the format may be necessary. The sides are eight-strong. They bat in four pairs. Each pair faces two overs. If a batsman is "out", he does not go back to the Pavilion, merely to the non-striker's end, and eight runs are deducted from the team's score. Each side starts with 200 runs. Wides and no-balls count for three runs and are not re-bowled. Each player, other than the keeper, has to bowl at least one, but no more than two, overs.

Brondesbury won the toss and batted but got off to a bad start, losing a wicket in the first over. Two boundaries in the second over helped to redress the balance. The second pair (which included my brother) managed just a leg-bye in their two overs but didn't lose a wicket. Then the third pair got out three times and that signalled the end. The last pair also lost a wicket, as Brondesbury collapsed to 192. For Eastcote the bowling of Steve Faux and Rishi Patel was notable. Eastcote walked it, losing just one wicket and ending up winners by 70 runs.

After the match, I looked up Jardine's obituary in the 1959 Wisden. Warner wrote: "If ever there was a cricket match between England and the rest of the world and the fate of England depended upon its result, I would pick Jardine as England captain every time". As Dr Johnson pointed out to another Scot, Boswell: "A man is not on oath in lapidiary inscriptions."

To read James Schneider's views on the state of colts cricket in this country, click here

webTitle: Young colts not given the best chance

fields.headline: Young colts not given the best chance
fields.standfirst: James Schneider, 13, has just returned from a two-week cricket tour of Barbados, from where he wrote a daily diary. Now he reflects on some of the problems faced by cricketers of his age in this country
fields.trailText: I speak from the lofty vantage-point of 13 years and as a veteran of five seasons of competitive cricket, including a Caribbean tour.
fields.body:
I speak from the lofty vantage-point of 13 years and as a veteran of five seasons of competitive cricket, including a Caribbean tour.

The first in a pair of Middlesex-Surrey Under-9 matches took place last Wednesday, when the weather turned Middlesex's certain victory into a disappointing draw. As highlights were like the overcast heavens, dim at best, I am taking this opportunity to share some observations about Colts learning cricket through match play.

The ECB are talking about grassroots cricket and asking what's wrong: why aren't we producing world-beaters? Why does Australia have so many good players and a brilliant production-line of young talent? What can we do? Let's try paying for these South African cricket mats, and encourage the junior county circuit. Still, we seem to be missing a piece to this puzzle.

One of our problems, overlooked by the ECB, is that different counties play different formats within the same age group. I play for Brondesbury in the Middlesex league at U13 level and we play 20-overs-a-side matches. This format teaches you little about building an innings, as it is most "successfully" played as a 20-over slog. By way of contrast, in Middlesex there is a U10 tournament that is a pairs game of 8-a-side. The final was held on the Nursery ground at Lord's on Sunday and my eight-year-old brother, Tim, (who got some bowling practice in the aforementioned county match with figures of 4-2-2-2) was playing for Brondesbury.

I can appreciate that this match format encourages an allround competence at fielding, batting and bowling; sadly, it also rewards defensive, bits-and-pieces playing. There is also an indoor league with U10s playing pairs and all older sides playing 12 overs each way. At the Dragon School in Oxford, I play timed games where victory was largely dependant on an ability to bowl the other side out. Surrey has U9s and U10s playing 20 overs, U11s, U12s and U13s playing 40, and U14s to U17s playing 50.

Different counties, schools and clubs organise themselves differently. Perhaps some time and attention should be paid to the way that matchplay contributes to learning the game of cricket, with a view to some sensible and universal guidelines.

In the meantime, it should not escape our notice that Australian children play 35-overs-a-side matches, as do the Bajans.

I heard this story on the way back from Barbados. Sir Garfield Sobers's entrance to the West Indies side was slightly peculiar: my source said that Sir Garfield has a brother, Gerald, who was a very good wicketkeeper-batsman. One day the West Indies sent a letter to the Sobers's home telling G Sobers to come to trials. Clearly, there are two G Sobers: they wanted Gerald, who was a merchant seaman and away at sea, so the other Sobers turned up and, as they say, the rest is history.

fields.headline: Bradford City
fields.trailText: It was at the ugly end of last season, as Bradford stared grimly at a return to the First Division, when their chairman Geoffrey Richmond suddenly announced he wanted to see the Bantams established as one of the biggest clubs in the Premiership, win the FA Cup, and qualify for Europe.
fields.body:
It was at the ugly end of last season, as Bradford stared grimly at a return to the First Division, when their chairman Geoffrey Richmond suddenly announced he wanted to see the Bantams established as one of the biggest clubs in the Premiership, win the FA Cup, and qualify for Europe.

It sounded like pure fantasy then, and - despite their miraculous final day escape - it still does now. For this season at least, Bradford's goal should still be Premiership survival.

But try telling that to the folk at Valley Parade, who have just enjoyed their first whiff of European football (via the Intertoto Cup), and are positively dreamy at the prospect of watching Dan Petrescu and - if the reports are true - Benito Carbone adding variety and panache to their attacks.

Yet come early September they will be waking up and smelling some rather strong coffee. Because in their first six games the Bantams will face Liverpool, Chelsea, Leicester City, Manchester United, Arsenal and Aston Villa - and despite being match sharp after their Intertoto exploits, they will be lucky to come away with four points.

And that will set the trend for the season. Expect Carbone and Petrescu to get all temperamental, the underrated gems (like captain David Weatherall and Dean Windass) to shine again without being especially noticed, while the rest of the Bradford squad - honest, slightly-over-the hill professionals almost to a man - will battle on without much success.

A huge amount depends on new manager Chris Hutchings. Will he be able to keep his head after a difficult start and motivate a diffident squad? And more crucially still - will he be able to handle two foreign stars used to bigger clubs than Bradford?

fields.trailText: It may not come as a surprise to hear that Coventry could be in for an up-and-down season. The club that last term had as many home wins as Leeds, but less away wins than Watford (ie: 0) promises to be no less inconsistent this year, especially after the sale of two of their most consistent and gifted players. fields.body:
It may not come as a surprise to hear that Coventry could be in for an up-and-down season. The club that last term had as many home wins as Leeds, but less away wins than Watford (ie: 0) promises to be no less inconsistent this year, especially after the sale of two of their most consistent and gifted players. But that doesn't mean there aren't reasons to be cheerful.

The main problem for Gordon Strachan must remain his defence. While Magnus Hedman is a good keeper who occasionally plays great, the rest of his back line tends towards the more depressing end of inconsistency. Paul Williams and Richard Shaw fit comfortably into this category - their occasionally masterful play is frequently let down by brainless errors - but both remain likely starters for the new season. And while Steven Froggatt and Paul Telfer are both half-decent players, they're more wingers than wing-backs.

So unless Strachan can come up with a radical overhaul in the next ten days, goals will continue to rain in on the Sky Blues. But on the other hand, they shouldn't have any problem scoring them either. McAllister's absence will be felt, but Chippo and Palmer could prove a useful midfield partnership with the promising John Eustace an able deputy. Add Telfer, Froggatt, Hadji, and now Thompson to the equation and you have the ability to create chances.

Of course, there is then the question of who will put them away. While Robbie Keane will undoubtedly become (if he isn't already) a striker of true international quality, Coventry aren't short of striking options. Cedric Roussell made an excellent impression last season (remember his brace at Old Trafford?) and Israel Zuniga showed that he has some nice touches. Then there is the permanently under-employed John Aloisi, former Arsenal starlet Jay Bothroyd and, more likely than not, another striker to come.

Coventry will continue to entertain this season but, unless Strachan develops some startling new tactics to help them on their travels, I wouldn't bet on them being safe before Easter.

fields.headline: Prescott derides Hague's boozy claims
fields.trailText: 9 August: Deputy prime minister John Prescott rounded on William Hague today over his claim to have drunk up to 14 pints of beer a day as a teenager.
fields.body:
The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, rounded on William Hague today over his claim to have drunk up to 14 pints of beer a day as a teenager, describing the Conservative leader's comments as sounding like an exaggerated "fisherman's tale."

Mr Prescott, whose own claims to downing his own ale "quite fast" as a young man are unlikely to be disputed, told BBC Radio 4's Today programme that Mr Hague's claims reminded him of "the fisherman's tale - how big was the fish you caught? This big. Okay, then keep on drinking."

Mr Hague made his claim in an interview with GQ magazine, which was published this morning.

Attempting to shake off his reputation as something of a political swot, he told the magazine that, during his teenage years, he had a summer job delivering drinks to the working men's clubs of Barnsley and Rotherham.

That, Mr Hague claimed, led to him drinking up to 10 pints of John Smith's bitter during the day - and four more in the evening when he went out socialising.

"Anyone who thinks I used to spend my holidays reading political tracts should have come with me for a week," he said.

Quite what voters will make of the contesting claims of politicians to have drinking pasts is unclear.

So far, the Liberal Democrats - whose leader Charles Kennedy is an enthusiast for the whisky that is produced in his West Highlands constituency - have stayed out of the fray.

The party's deputy leader, Alan Beith, looks unlikely to join in. He, at least, is teetotal.

webTitle: Comment, Jonathan Freedland:  Big Brother, we're watching you

fields.headline: We're watching it
fields.standfirst: Part docusoap, part gameshow, Big Brother was meant to be this summer's hot TV hit and it is
fields.trailText: Part docusoap, part gameshow, Big Brother was meant to be this summer's hot TV hit and it is.
fields.body:
Just this once, believe the hype. Big Brother was billed as the summer's monster hit, and it is. Part gameshow, part docusoap, the Channel 4 programme has not just edged in front of BBC1 in the ratings. It has pulled off a trick thought possible only in television's golden past - creating a shared, collective experience. Sixteen years after 1984, Britain can declare: "Big Brother, we're watching you."

The programme has become what American TV execs call "water-cooler television", a show that buzzes into office chat the next day. The premise could not be simpler: 10 strangers share a specially equipped house, remote-control cameras filming their every move. Each week they nominate two people for eviction; viewers vote on which one should leave, until only the winner is left - £70,000 richer.

That formula has already brought the show no fewer than three of the platinum hallmarks of modern success. First, its subjects have gained one-word name-recognition. Like Madonna and Elvis, we now have Sada and Nick - no surnames necessary.

Second, the show has spawned its very own tabloid campaign. While the News of the World was naming and shaming paedophiles, the Sun got busy exposing stockbroker Nick for his Iago-like manipulation of his housemates. The viewers have seen it all, but the contestants have remained horribly deceived: hence the Sun's attempt to airdrop Kick Out Nick leaflets into the Big Brother garden. Photographers have taken to firing tennis balls into the compound marked "Nick lies".

The third proof of the show's success has come in the form of that greatest of compliments: parody. Click on to the Labour party's website and you can visit the Tory house of horrors, where "Ten Tories have all been forced to share a political home together, but as months go by the tension is rising and cracks are beginning to show." William Hague is blamed for creating an "atmosphere of intolerance" in the house, while Ann Widdecombe is "the scary one". Your chance to vote on this lot won't come until next spring at the earliest.

The appeal of the show is not mysterious. The contestants are young and attractive, and they have so far complied with the rules of good narrative. We have had a hint of romance, courtesy of the (now-evicted) Andrew and Mel, and a pantomime villain in Nick. Thanks to the editing nous of the Big Brother controllers, we only get to see the best bits: the rows, the whispered bitching, the flirtations.

But there is a darker edge to the show's appeal, too - for there is something of the prison drama about Big Brother. We watch people bored rigid, denied the basics of human life: work, the company of loved ones, the stimulation of radio, television or newspapers. We wonder which one will crack first - who might be granted early release and who might try to escape. We see the inmates squabble and barter over supplies, reduced to regarding a Snickers bar as a valuable unit of currency. This is The Shawshank Redemption on closed-circuit TV.

But the real interest of the show is not them - it's us. Big Brother is exposing the watched, but it's also revealing a fair bit about the watchers. For one thing, we seem to have a collective sadistic streak. The housemates twice voted to kick Caroline out because she irritated them so much; the audience twice voted to keep her in - for much the same reason. She sparked conflict and that made good, gladiatorial television. When the audience saw the first glimmers of romance between Andy and Mel, they instantly moved to stamp it out, by giving him the boot. If Big Brother is a one-way mirror on the nation, it is not making us look good.

The success of the show also suggests we like power. In this internet era, the cybergurus bang on endlessly about interactivity: now Big Brother has vindicated them. The key difference between this show and its obvious 1990s precursors, MTV's The Real World and the BBC's Living Soap, is viewer-power. Those programmes also cooped up gangs of young strangers and hoped for fireworks. But where they cast the audience as passive viewers, Big Brother makes a different promise: "Ten people, one winner - you decide." People no longer defer to politicians and they don't want to defer to television programmers. Big Brother lets them believe they are in control.

The programme also confirms our current penchant for reality that feels like drama, and for drama that comes with an icing of reality. Big Brother is riding a trend that saw BBC2 launch Tinsel Town on Monday night, a drama filmed in the style of This Life - to look like a documentary. Meanwhile, a real documentary, this year's Oscar-winner One Day in September, is shot like a thriller. The genres are merging.

Which brings us to perhaps the most significant revelation the programme has yet provided - beyond Nick's perfidy or Nichola's bottom. It is the extent to which the line between private and public has been erased. Now we make a national pastime of what would once have been a furtive activity: spying on others. We pry into their lives and they are only too willing to show us. The Big Brother housemates cavort in skimpy shorts and bare chests, as if marooned on a Caribbean island, rather than sharing the same dismal weather as the rest of us - and they are happy to do it.

Indeed, it is clear that exposure is not the price of taking part, it is the reason. A majority of the contestants want jobs on TV or in the media and regard this shot of exhibitionist celebrity as their big break: the lure is certainly not the £70,000, which, in game-show terms, is small change, a routine prize on the last big TV thing, Who Wants to be a Millionaire?

In this, Big Brother is utterly a product of its time. We have got used to men and women making public what were once private emotions (think of the vogue for confessional columnists) and this lot are merely getting in on the act. It's striking that not a single minute of Big Brother has shown a discussion of what we used to call public affairs: there is not a word about politics. It is all about relationships - with each other, past loves or themselves.

We are not that different. We too are filmed constantly, by a CCTV presence that makes us the most watched-over society in the world, with cameras in every bank, every shop, every street corner. Thanks to new technology, we too perform for the camera, whether it's a home video or a webcam. We are slowly abolishing privacy as we used to understand it, replacing it with an acceptance that what was once hidden will now be on display - what was once on the inside will now be on show. We watch and we are watched. Maybe that was the twist George Orwell never imagined: we are Big Brother.

webTitle: Hanks goes to Perdition with Mendes

fields.headline: Hanks goes to Perdition with Mendes
fields.trailText: American Beauty director Sam Mendes is to make his return to film-making with a dark thriller set in the 1930s and starring Tom Hanks.
fields.body:
American Beauty director Sam Mendes is to make his return to film-making with a dark thriller set in the 1930s and starring Tom Hanks.

The Road to Perdition will be backed by DreamWorks from a script by David Self (who, rather ominously, wrote the garbled adaptation of The Haunting). According to the Hollywood Reporter, the film should begin shooting early next year.

After winning his Best Director Oscar for American Beauty, the 34-year-old Mendes appeared in no hurry to cash in on his Hollywood success, instead returning to theatre directing in his native London.

But observers felt that it was only a matter of time before he was lured back to big-budget film-making. The presence of Hanks - who allegedly commands a fee of $20m per movie - ensures that The Road to Perdition will be a costly production.

The film's story is taken from a long-running DC comic book written by Max Collins and illustrated by Richard Piers Rayner. Perdition plays out in Depression-era Chicago and focuses on a hitman named Michael O'Sullivan (aka the Angel of Death) who juggles career brutality with a loving home life. But when his family are slaughtered by a local crime cartel, O'Sullivan (and his surviving son) plot revenge. A spokesman for Mendes claimed that the film described it as "an epic that will move from 1930s Chicago to the Badlands of North Dakota, and Tom is going to be playing a very different role to his normal ones".

At first glance Hanks certainly looks a strange choice to play the complex O'Sullivan (one assumes American Beauty star Kevin Spacey would have been more appropriate). But the actor has reportedly been keen to take on more edgy and challenging roles, and the presence of the Oscar-winning Mendes behind the camera will surely have reassured him.

For DreamWorks, the production provides the dream team of a hot young director and an established, bankable star. Still months away from shooting, the film's critical and commercial success appears already guaranteed.

The Road to Perdition will be backed by DreamWorks from a script by David Self (who, rather ominously, wrote the garbled adaptation of The Haunting). According to the Hollywood Reporter, the film should begin shooting early next year. After winning his Best Director Oscar for American Beauty, the 34-year-old Mendes appeared in no hurry to cash in on his Hollywood success, instead returning to theatre directing in his native London. But observers felt that it was only a matter of time before he was lured back to big-budget film-making. The presence of Hanks - who allegedly commands a fee of $20m per movie - ensures that The Road to Perdition will be a costly production. The film's story is taken from a long-running DC comic book written by Max Collins and illustrated by Richard Piers Rayner. Perdition plays out in Depression-era Chicago and focuses on a hitman named Michael O'Sullivan (aka the Angel of Death) who juggles career brutality with a loving home life. But when his family are slaughtered by a local crime cartel, O'Sullivan (and his surviving son) plot revenge. A spokesman for Mendes claimed that the film described it as "an epic that will move from 1930s Chicago to the Badlands of North Dakota, and Tom is going to be playing a very different role to his normal ones". At first glance Hanks certainly looks a strange choice to play the complex O'Sullivan (one assumes American Beauty star Kevin Spacey would have been more appropriate). But the actor has reportedly been keen to take on more edgy and challenging roles, and the presence of the Oscar-winning Mendes behind the camera will surely have reassured him. For DreamWorks, the production provides the dream team of a hot young director and an established, bankable star. Still months away from shooting, the film's critical and commercial success appears already guaranteed.

fields.headline: Zeta-Jones has baby boy
fields.trailText: Catherine Zeta-Jones and Michael Douglas were last night celebrating the birth of a 7lb 7oz son at a hospital in Hollywood
fields.body:
Catherine Zeta-Jones and Michael Douglas were last night celebrating the birth of a 7lb 7oz son at a hospital in Hollywood. Dylan Michael Douglas was born just after 6pm on Tuesday evening at the Cedars-Sinai Medical Centre, near Beverly Hills. The news was later confirmed by the stars' respective spokespeople and merited a breathless message on the official Michael Douglas website.

"Everybody's doing fine," gushed Zeta-Jones's publicist Cece Yorke. "They're ecstatic," panted Allen Bury, a spokesman for Douglas's film production company.

Douglas and Zeta-Jones first met at the Deauville Film Festival in the autumn of 1998 and began stepping out (as they say) in April last year. At the time, various observers wrote the liaison off as a dubious publicity stunt to promote Zeta-Jones's fledgling Hollywood career, but the pair's relationship appears to have endured. Douglas proposed marriage at his Aspen retreat on New Year's Eve last year, though a wedding date has yet to be fixed.

Last night's new arrival was the first for Zeta-Jones, 30. Douglas, 55, has an adult son, Cameron, from his previous marriage to Diandra Douglas.

fields.headline: Lady Macbeth
fields.trailText: Lady Macbeth
fields.body:
Origins:
First appeared in print in 1623, with possible forerunners in Holinshed's Chronicle of Scottish History.

Appearance:
Calm, composed and sophisticated society dinner-party hostess.

Reality:
Ice-hearted and ultimately insane manipulator bent on realising her maniacal ambitions through her craven and desperate husband. And now, it seems, a crucial role model in the new Labour project, too.

I don't understand.
Remember the plot - a well-bred Scot abandons all his principles in a bid to fulfil a political destiny decreed by a mysterious "focus group", and ends up bitterly regretting it.

Sounds like that Philip Gould has gone too far with his memos now.
Actually, this time, it's a Tory shadow minister, John Bercow, who has reached deep into his sensitive understanding of 17th-century drama and fished out a somewhat dubious comparison between Cherie Blair and the murderous Lady M.

Ah, so that's what has become of Jack Cunningham.
To be fair, Bercow charges Cherie not with homicide but trying to "direct policy from behind the throne" by co-authoring a Daily Telegraph article on her husband's new Human Rights Act. The shadow cabinet's expert on home affairs and ill-considered buffoonery reckons that the British public "will not put up with anyone who thinks they can be an unaccountable cross between the First Lady and Lady Macbeth".

The Scottish play, Cherie-style:
"Parliament will be very slow to act in a way/Which defies a declaration of incompatibility/ If it expects the European Court in due course/To agree with the British court and declare that its Acts are incompatible with the Convention."

Do say:
"False face must hide what the false heart doth know, as I was saying to Ali Campbell just the other day."

Don't say:
"Is this a pitifully desperate piece of Tory point-scoring I see before me?"
