fields.headline: BBC1 parades 'quality' output
fields.standfirst:
Controller says channel must change but insists new season's schedules belie 'dumbing down' claims
Special report: the future of the BBC
fields.trailText: BBC executives launched a rearguard action yesterday to convince sceptical governors and politicians that their controversial plans to revolutionise the corporation's television channels do not amount to the "dumbing down" of BBC1.
fields.body:
BBC executives launched a rearguard action yesterday to convince sceptical governors and politicians that their controversial plans to revolutionise the corporation's television channels do not amount to the "dumbing down" of BBC1.

The channel controller, Peter Salmon, and drama chief, Alan Yentob, insisted there would be more quality programmes on all the BBC's channels.

Chris Smith, the culture secretary, and some BBC governors, have expressed reservations about proposals to cut the number of factual programmes on BBC1, make BBC2 a more serious channel and turn the digital channels BBC Choice and Knowledge into BBC3 and 4 - youth and culture networks respectively.

The governors have sent the plans back to BBC managers for more work.

Mr Salmon said yesterday there would be fewer factual programmes on BBC1, but stressed that current affairs, science and natural history would still form key parts of the schedule. Launching BBC1's autumn season, he said the BBC was "at the biggest crossroads in its history", and had to adapt to changing times.

"We know we've got to change to remain relevant, that we cannot preserve 15 or 20 year old schedules in formaldehyde just because they have always been there.

"But we never said that BBC1 would become a mono-thematic entertainment channel. It will not. There will always be room for genres like science, news, current affairs and natural history on BBC1 - what we are talking about is the balance of them in the schedule." The amount of drama would be boosted considerably, he said, but that meant "something has to give". The number of factual programmes on BBC1 would fall, he conceded.

This season, the drama budget has been increased by £10m. Among the highlights is a film about a child abuse victim by the creator of Ballykissangel, Kieran Prendiville.

Care, made by BBC Wales, will explore the emotional scars faced by a man whose cries for help as an abused youngster were ignored by adults, and has been in development over a period of years against a background of child abuse scandals.

Traditional costume dramas have been rested in favour of modern adaptations, including Joanna Trollope's Other People's Children - a drama about step parents from the makers of the award-winning film Warriors - and Take a Girl Like You, by Kingsley Amis with a screenplay by Andrew Davies.

Nancy Mitford's comedy of manners Love in a Cold Climate has been adapted for TV and stars Celia Imrie alongside Alan Bates, Sheila Gish, and Elizabeth Dermot Walsh.

The increasingly successful comedy drama genre is exploited in The Last of the Blonde Bombshells, about an all-women second world war swing band reunited for one last concert, with a cast including Judi Dench, June Whitfield and Cleo Laine.

Mr Yentob, who oversees the BBC's drama, entertainment and children's output, said that drama would feature strongly as the reorganisation of the BBC's television channels - which would not happen "overnight" - took shape.

The BBC had to respond to an age where more people are watching television in homes equipped with multichannel, digital equipment, he said.

In these homes, research shows that viewers are turning away from the traditional channels in favour of "niche", specialised services.

It was a question of getting the balance right between its new youth and culture networks alongside the broad-appeal channels BBC1 and 2, Mr Yentob said.

Autumn highlights

 BBC1 controller Peter Salmon brought in Fred Barron, creator of US hits Sienfeld and the Larry Sanders Show, to develop My Family, which stars Robert Lindsay and Zoe Wanamaker as parents of adolescents, and has a team of writers.

 Down to Earth , in a more traditional sitcom format, stars Pauline Quirke and Warren Clarke as a couple who quit London for life in the country. Two classics, The Royle Family and One Foot in the Grave, return.

 Pete Postlethwaite and Geraldine James lead the cast in comedy drama The Sins, the story of an ex-getaway driver struggling to go straight.

 Culture secretary Chris Smith said the BBC should produce more "landmark" programmes - the BBC has responded with two big factual series. State of the Planet , fronted by Sir David Attenborough, focuses on the natural world, while Robert Winston, who fronted the Human Body series, returns in Superhuman, which aims to show the body's capacity for reinvention.

fields.headline: Nixon 'wrecked early peace in Vietnam'
fields.trailText: On the eve of his election in 1968, Richard Nixon secretly conspired with the South Vietnamese government to wreck all-party Vietnam peace talks as part of a deliberate effort to prolong a conflict in which more than 20,000 Americans were still to die, along with tens of thousands of Vietnamese and Cambodians.
fields.body:
On the eve of his election in 1968, Richard Nixon secretly conspired with the South Vietnamese government to wreck all-party Vietnam peace talks as part of a deliberate effort to prolong a conflict in which more than 20,000 Americans were still to die, along with tens of thousands of Vietnamese and Cambodians.

The devastating new charge against Nixon, which mirrors long-held suspicions among members of President Lyndon Johnson's administration about the Republican leader's actions in the autumn of 1968, is made by the authors of a new study of Nixon's secret world in the latest issue of Vanity Fair magazine.

"The greatest honour history can bestow," reads the inscription on Nixon's black granite tombstone in California, "is the title of peacemaker." But if the charges by authors Anthony Summers and Robbyn Swan are correct, Nixon better deserves to be called a peacewrecker than peacemaker.

At the heart of the new account was Nixon's fear that Vietnam peace efforts by President Johnson in the run-up to the November 1968 US presidential election could wreck Nixon's bid to oust Hubert Humphrey, the Democratic candidate, and capture the White House.

Nixon's response to Johnson's efforts was to use a go-between, Anna Chennault, to urge the South Vietnam's president, Nguyen van Thieu, to resist efforts to force them to the peace table.

Nixon's efforts paid off spectacularly. On October 31, Johnson ordered a total halt to the bombing of North Vietnam, the precondition for getting the North and their Vietcong allies to join the talks. Two days later, under intense secret urgings from Nixon and his lieutenants, Thieu announced his government would not take part. Less than a week later, Nixon was elected president with less than a one-point margin in the popular vote over Humphrey.

Playing with US lives

The Vanity Fair article charges that Johnson knew what was going on. Intelligence reports to the president told him that Nixon and his running mate, Spiro Agnew, were playing politics with the lives of US soldiers. "Had it been made public at the time, it would surely have destroyed Nixon's presidential hopes at one stroke, and forever," the authors write.

Johnson offered Humphrey the chance to go public about Nixon, but Humphrey was afraid that the charges would be seen as election dirty tricks. Once Nixon had won, Johnson again contemplated revealing what he knew, but decided the national interest precluded it.

In the weeks running up to the election, Nixon's public stance was that, if elected, he would bring the war to an end more effectively than Humphrey. He promised not to interfere with pre-election peace efforts, pledging that neither he nor Agnew "will destroy the chance of peace".

In reality, however, Nixon used his campaign manager, John Mitchell, later his disgraced attorney general, to use go-betweens to encourage Thieu to believe he would get a better deal under a Nixon administration and to boycott the putative talks. Nixon constantly denied that he was conspiring with Thieu against the US government, but the release of previously classified FBI files used by the authors show this was exactly what he was doing.

Chennault, Nixon's main go-between with the South Vietnamese, was a right-wing Republican society hostess who was Chinese born and lived in a newly constructed Washington apartment complex - named the Watergate. She was vice-chairman of the Republican election finance committee and an inveterate lobbyist on behalf of right-wing and pro-American Asian interests.

Chennault regularly passed messages to Mitchell and Nixon during 1968 and they urged her to put pressure on the South Vietnamese leader to create delays and to refuse to take part in the peace talks.

US embassy spy operations, including wiretaps of Thieu's offices, revealed the Thieu-Nixon connection in October and Johnson was briefed about them. One message from Thieu's ambassador in Washington, Bui Diem, told Thieu: "Johnson and Humphrey will be replaced and then Nixon could change the US position."

When Thieu pulled out of the talks, Johnson exploded. He told his advisers that he would go public on a development that could "rock the world". That development, he said, was Nixon's "conniving" with the Thieu regime. An adviser had told Johnson that Nixon was "trying to frustrate the president by inciting Saigon to step up its demands". "It all adds up," Johnson told his advisers.

On October 31, with the bombing halt announced, Mitchell rang Chennault and told her: "Anna, I'm speaking on behalf of Mr Nixon. It's very important our Vietnamese friends understand our Republican position and I hope you have made that clear to them. Do you think they have decided not to go to Paris?"

Chennault made contact with Thieu once again. An FBI report said that she "contacted [the] Vietnamese ambassador and advised him that she had received a message from her boss (not further identified) which her boss wanted her to give personally to the ambassador. She said the message was that the ambassador is to 'Hold on, we are gonna win' and that her boss also said 'Hold on, he understands all of it'."

On November 2, three days before the election, Thieu announced that South Vietnam would not attend the talks.

Johnson's bad relations with J Edgar Hoover at the FBI meant that Hoover, a Nixon ally, did not tell the president everything that his agents had unearthed. Even so, Johnson had learned enough to speak to Nixon by phone the weekend before the election. Nixon denied Chennault was working for him. When the phone was put down, it was later reported, "Nixon and his friends collapsed with laughter".

Johnson was certain Nixon was lying, and told Humphrey what was going on. Humphrey learned about the Nixon-Thieu contacts while he was travelling by plane to a campaign. "By God, when we land I'm going to denounce Thieu. I'll denounce Nixon. I'll tell about the whole thing," he shouted to aides. But he never did.

In the five weeks leading up to the election of 1968, 960 Americans were killed in Vietnam. In the years to come, under Nixon, 20,763 more US soldiers would die.

"What the Nixon people did," the US diplomat Richard Holbrooke, then attached to the advance US guard to the Paris talks, tells Vanity Fair, "was perhaps even a violation of the law.

"They massively, directly and covertly interfered in a major diplomatic negotiation, probably one of the most important negotiations in American diplomatic history."

1957 Beginning of communist insurgency in South Vietnam

1959 Weapons and men from North Vietnam begin infiltrating the South

1960 US aid to the South Vietnamese president, Ngo Dinh Diem, increased

1962 President John F Kennedy provides US military advisers to South Vietnam (12,000 by end of year)

1963 Viet Cong, the communist guerrillas operating in South Vietnam, defeat units of ARVN, the South Vietnamese army. President Diem overthrown

1964 North Vietnamese patrol boats fire on the US destroyer Maddox in the Gulf of Tonkin, triggering start of US bombing raids on North Vietnam

1965 US troops in Vietnam number 23,000 at start of year

1966 400,000 US troops in Vietnam, rising to 500,000 in 1967

1968 Tet Offensive - a combined assault by Viet Cong and North Vietnamese army on US positions - begins. More than 500 civilians die in My Lai massacre

March 31 1968 President Lyndon Johnson (below right) announces on television that bombing north of the 20th parallel will stop and that he will not seek re-election in the fall. Hanoi responds by de-escalating its insurgency efforts, and in October Johnson orders total halt to bombing. US and Hanoi agree to preliminary peace talks in Paris

1969 President Nixon draws back US ground troops from Vietnam

1970 Nixon's national security adviser, Henry Kissinger, and Le Duc Tho of the Vietnamese politburo start talks in Paris

1973 Ceasefire agreement. Withdrawal of US troops completed by March

1975 North Vietnamese troops invade South Vietnam and take control of the whole country after South Vietnam surrenders

April 1975 Last members of US embassy staff evacuated by helicopter from roof of embassy

Human toll 3m military and civilian Vietnamese. 58,000 Americans

webTitle: Sex case man targeted by mob kills himself

fields.headline: Sex case man targeted by mob kills himself
fields.trailText: A grandfather charged with sex offences against young girls was driven to kill himself after a vigilante mob attacked his home, his solicitor claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
A grandfather charged with sex offences against young girls was driven to kill himself after a vigilante mob attacked his home, his solicitor claimed yesterday.

James White, 54, took an overdose on Saturday after he and his wife had been driven from their house in Oldham, Greater Manchester, and spent almost a week on the run.

After staying with members of his family and then in bed- and-breakfast houses, he drove to a service station on the M61 in Lancashire and swallowed 100 pills prescribed to him after a stroke.

He rang his wife to say: "I cannot put you through any more of this." He died in hospital the following day.

"He had been literally scared to death," said his solicitor, Milton Firman, who had represented him at court hearings over the past month. "He has been punished beyond all reason - and not just Mr White but his wife and five children too."

Mr Firman accused the News of the World, which had not named Mr White, of creating a climate of hysteria in which vigilantes took the law into their own hands.

Mr White, married for 34 years and with no previous convictions, first appeared before Oldham magistrates last month and admitted three charges of indecent assault on two girls in 1988, 1991 and June this year. He denied four other charges dating from 1982 and 1988. The case was not reported by the local media at that time.

"He was very badly shaken when he appeared in court," said Mr Firman. "He saw the court case as a blessing. You could say he wanted to purge his guilt. I took the view that he was in desperate need of help. By the time of his second court appearance, the News of the World's name-and-shame campaign had begun."

This time there was a short report in the Oldham Chronicle saying that Mr White had been remanded on bail. A group of neighbours then surrounded Mr White's home and threatened to firebomb it. They threw missiles and shouted abuse and Mr White and his wife, Jean, had to be rescued by police, leaving their possessions behind.

"They went bananas and wrecked the house," added Mr Firman. "It's now boarded up. The council later told him that he had abandoned the tenancy and could not return."

Mr and Mrs White stayed with members of their family but left after relatives received death threats. webTitle: Diplomats told to drop unauthorised screening of visa requests

fields.headline: Diplomats told to drop unauthorised screening of visa requests
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: The Foreign Office has ordered its diplomats in warring Sudan to halt an unauthorised and unprecedented scheme designed to prevent genuine asylum seekers entering Britain.
fields.body:
The Foreign Office has ordered its diplomats in warring Sudan to halt an unauthorised and unprecedented scheme designed to prevent genuine asylum seekers entering Britain.

The order follows inquiries by the Guardian and was welcomed by refugee and human rights organisations, which yesterday described the visa application procedure at the Khartoum embassy as a dangerous and appalling flouting of the 1951 refugee convention. People seeking a UK visa at the embassy have been asked to sign an additional declaration saying they had no reason to fear returning to Sudan.

It goes on: "I have not experienced harassment, persecution, detention or prosecution by any authority, organisation of individual, that might constitute a reason to seek refuge in the UK or elsewhere. I know of no reason why I should remain in the UK beyond the period I have stated to the interviewing officer."

The Refugee Council, Amnesty International, the UN high commissioner for refugees, and the Immigration Advisory Service condemned the practice. They pointed out genuine asylum seekers would either lie and sign - which might be held against them if they then applied in Britain for permission to remain - or could refuse to sign, denying themselves a visa and possibly exposing them to further repression.

Hope Hanlan, the UK representative of UNHCR, said: "This is a disturbing and dangerous development. We see it as another nail in the coffin of asylum." Nick Hardwick, chief executive of the Refugee Council, said: "We are appalled but not surprised. Whether authorised or not, it is consistent with the clear steer given to embassies abroad that they must do what they can to reduce refugees coming to the UK. We are particularly concerned that the very fact someone had been persecuted would make it less likely they would able to leave their country and find safety."

Amnesty said it was a "serious breach" of the convention. Keith Best of the Immigration Advisory Service said it would have driven asylum seekers into the hands of racketeers.

The Foreign Office agreed yesterday that the declaration put applicants in "an impossible position" and thanked the Guardian for drawing attention to the problem.

According to a spokesman, the declaration was a local initiative, composed by the deputy head of mission and consul general Lawrence Pickup, with the approval of the ambassador Richard Makepeace.

Mr Pickup advised the Foreign Office over the weekend that the scheme had begun in May. But, according to a reliable Sudanese source, similar questions had been asked for about two years.

After the form was withdrawn on Sunday, the Foreign Office said it had begun an investigation by the joint entry clearance unit, set up by the Foreign Office and the Home Office and in June to ensure a "fairer, faster and firmer entry clearance process".

It is unclear whether anyone at the embassy will be disciplined. Thirty Sudanese apply for asylum each month, mainly at port of entry. In May an Amnesty report said civilians in the south faced bombardment, killings, and torture.

webTitle: Go-ahead for asylum hostel enrages village

fields.headline: Go-ahead for asylum hostel enrages village
fields.standfirst:
Irate residents predict crime, tension and plummeting house prices
Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: The hamlet of Over Stowey, nestling in Somerset's Quantock Hills, would be a suitable place to house 74 asylum seekers, a planning inquiry ruled yesterday.
fields.body:
The hamlet of Over Stowey, nestling in Somerset's Quantock Hills, would be a suitable place to house 74 asylum seekers, a planning inquiry ruled yesterday.

Residents and parish councillors in the all-white community of 314 reacted with shock and disbelief at the news that the planning inspectorate had overturned Sedgemoor district council's refusal to approve a planned hostel for asylum seekers.

The Baptist charity Kaleidoscope said it now hoped to turn the former Quantocks boarding school into a temporary sanctuary for refugees from the Balkans, Sudan and Sierra Leone. It planned to keep them occupied with English lessons, sports and swimming while the Home Office decided on their cases. During the case, the charity argued that there was a need to rehouse asylum seekers to take the pressure off the south-east and London.

Embittered residents said the decision was a "disaster" for the local community, which has already been divided by the proposals.

Rocketing crime, begging, racial tension, and plummeting house prices could result, said residents, who have been backed by Tom King, the MP for Bridgwater and former Tory defence secretary. He sent a letter of objection to the planning inquiry.

The asylum seekers would be housed in two dormitory blocks. Some would be given full board but the rest would receive food vouchers worth £30 a week to spend in local supermarkets. Medical care would be provided by local GPs and the asylum seekers would be bussed into Bristol and Bridgwater for shopping trips, and to see their lawyers. There would also be an on-site team of counsellors.

Arthur Barrow, 55, who has lived in Over Stowey all his life, said the sale of his £600,000 farm collapsed yesterday after the purchasers said they would only buy his property if the decision went against the scheme. He described the ruling as "despicable".

"The majority of these asylum seekers will be 18 to 40. They are in an isolated rural area with nothing for them to do. I can't start to imagine the effect this will have on the area. Property values will plummet.

"I am resigning as a parish councillor forthwith. What point is there in having a parish council that acted on the wishes of the majority of the parish when its views are overturned?"

Chairman of the parish council, Mike Lampson, said: "Planning permission lasts for five years so even if the family that owns the old school decides not to go ahead and sells it, another buyer could still push ahead with the asylum scheme. It is a total disaster for the area."

The chairman of the planning inquiry, Philip Wilson, an architect who was appointed by the environment secretary, John Prescott, said the appeal proposal had been prompted by a "need arising from guidance issued by central government to ensure asylum seekers do not become concentrated in specific areas".

"I recognise the fear of some local residents concerning the presence of people from other ethnic backgrounds. I consider this is, in most cases, genuine but I do not consider it to be well-founded," he wrote. The Rev Martin Blakebrough, director of Kaleidoscope, said the centre would have 15 staff and the asylum seekers, including three families, would stay up to six months.

The former school, where Mr Blakebrough's uncle was headmaster, had approached the charity. He acknowledged that there were some strong feelings against the scheme, but said he felt that much of the acrimony had been "whipped up" by the rightwing press.

"The whole aim is to provide an environment where people can access support and work through trauma in a tranquil environment. People can be assured that it if did go wrong, we would close it. We are not there to make a profit from these people like ruthless landlords, but we will obviously recoup our costs."

The local vicar, the Rev Phil Denison, said: "Everything was taken into consideration at the hearing and those in the best position to judge these matters have made what they feel is the right decision.

"Somerset and Over Stowey are cosmopolitan places and have always been enriched by receiving visitors. I feel we will only benefit from having a more multicultural society here. Perhaps some people have invested quite a lot of time and money in opposing the scheme and don't like losing."

fields.headline: Revenue must simplify software, say MPs
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: The government will never be able to crack down effectively on fraud and error in social security payments, estimated at £4bn, until its systems are simpler and its computer software improved, the government is warned today.
fields.body:
The government will never be able to crack down effectively on fraud and error in social security payments, estimated at £4bn, until its systems are simpler and its computer software improved, the government is warned today.

"Making benefits simpler is crucial, as is investment in new technology," said a cross-party committee of MPs, which has been examining the inland revenue system, termed by some "the most complicated piece of software in Europe".

In its latest inquiry into the management of Britain's national insurance fund, the public accounts committee also advised ministers against over-reliance on too few software suppliers.

The MPs singled out Andersen Consulting, which runs the troubled national insurance recording system (called NIRS2), for deterring rival bids for the multimillion pound contract.

In effect, by announcing that it would keep the intellectual copyright to the NIRS2 system it designed for the inland revenue, Andersen Consulting was able to bid £100m less than its rivals.

"They had put a value of £100m on these rights when submitting their original bid, which was one reason why their bid was significantly lower than other bidders," said the PAC report.

When the contract comes up for renewal, bidders will have to pay Andersen £14m "in return for which they would be granted a licence to use the software", said the MPs, who said they wanted the inland revenue to re-examine the benefits of joint ownership of such rights.

Such decisions, warned the MPs, whose chairman is the Conservative David Davis, were "an important part of the management of risk" in these public/private projects.

The committee was told that the 4,500 glitches in NISR2, which have delayed its full implementation until the spring, were half the number which experts would have expected in a system its size and that, earlier this year, they had been reduced to below 700. About £2m had been paid as compensation to claimants for "unreasonable delays" caused by the backlog.

Andersen is one of the three main suppliers of software to Whitehall, along with the American company EDS, and Siemens of Germany.

webTitle: Top clubs on fast road to fresh riches

fields.headline: Top clubs on fast road to fresh riches
fields.trailText: Europe's leading football clubs are set to cash in on their popularity by joining forces with motor racing after the announcement yesterday of a unique commercial partnership between the two sports.
fields.body:
Europe's leading football clubs are set to cash in on their popularity by joining forces with motor racing after the announcement yesterday of a unique commercial partnership between the two sports.

Premier 1 Grand Prix will involve 24 cars, painted in the colours of Europe's leading football clubs, racing over the course of a season.

The likes of Manchester United, Barcelona, Real Madrid and Juventus have been asked to take part in what could be a lucrative extension of their brand names, generating millions of pounds in extra revenue.

The clubs - there will be four each from England, Italy, France, Spain, Germany and the Netherlands - will not have to invest any money in the new racing category but are likely to receive a share of the profits.

Initially, there will be 12 races in 2002, with 11 being staged in Europe and one in South America.

Graham Kelly, the former chief executive of the Football Association, is one of the directors of Premier 1 and has been liaising with English clubs and those on the continent.

The organisers have picked the 24 clubs on the basis of their domestic performances over the past six years and it is believed that, as well as Manchester United, Liverpool, Chelsea and Arsenal from the Premier League have been approached.

Kelly said: "Nobody has turned us down. There is quite a lot of interest and things are looking pretty positive. Motor racing can bring to football an extension of the club's brand images and there is also potential for fresh revenue streams, which are important with the transfer market going up and up.

"Clubs in Italy and Spain were much more receptive to the idea. There will be a cap on transfers [for drivers]. The last thing clubs want is a situation like the present one in football."

The project is the brainchild of SMC Capital Investments, a company owned by the millionairess Elizabeth Evans, who attempted to buy Silverstone three years ago and is a long-time acquaintance of the formula one commercial rights holder Bernie Ecclestone.

Premier 1 is not being seen as a rival to formula one and races will not clash with grands prix. All the cars in Premier 1 will be the same so there will be no constructors' competition and pit stops will be allowed only for tyre changes.

Plans for the new competition are to be formally submitted by the Motor Sports Association, the UK's national club, to the council of the FIA, the sport's world governing body, in October.

If the go-ahead is given then the new competition will be up and running by the start of 2002. An FIA insider said: "The requirement for a new formula is that it should be backed by a national club, and conforms to all the required safety regulations."

The organisers are hoping that by combining the money and high profile of football and motor racing, Premier 1 will provide a crossover for fans of both sports and generate huge funds in the process.

It is still not known what sort of crowds the new racing category could attract and how much involvement clubs and players would have in promoting it but clearly the commercial possibilities are immense.

According to Kelly, 38% of all season-ticket holders are also formula one fans. The Premier 1 competition, however, is far from completion. Organisers concede that they still have not got a television deal or an agreement with race tracks to host their competition.

The cars taking part will be single-seater and manufactured by the Italian firm Dallara. Its owner Gianpaolo Dallara said: "It is a very exciting project which we are tackling with great enthusiasm."

It is believed that the BBC might be interested in screening the new races following the loss of its formula one coverage in 1996. However a BBC spokesman said that it was too early to say whether the corporation would do so.

webTitle: Mobile phone safety leaves experts divided

fields.headline: Mobile phone safety leaves experts divided
fields.standfirst: Special report: mobile phone fears
fields.trailText: The Consumers' Association yesterday accused the government of having used the wrong tests to assess the safety of hands-free kits for mobile phones, saying the association stood by its claim that the devices failed to protect users against radiation.
fields.body:
The Consumers' Association yesterday accused the government of having used the wrong tests to assess the safety of hands-free kits for mobile phones, saying the association stood by its claim that the devices failed to protect users against radiation.

A government report on Monday sowed confusion among mobile users by endorsing hands-free kits, saying they reduced exposure to radiation from handsets.

This contradicted a Which? report in April, which found that hands-free kits increased the amount of radiation heading for the brain.

Yesterday it became clear that the real dispute between Which? and the government was over how the radiation from hands-free kits should be measured. The conflicting findings were from different tests. Which? measured how much radiation was transmitted by the devices; the government's scientists measured how much radiation was received by the brain. This explains the different conclusion.

Which? found that the radiation emitted by hands-free kits was, in some cases, three times that emitted by the radio transmitters in the handsets themselves. But the government found that, however much radiation the hands-free wires channelled, the amount reaching the brain was much less than if the mobile user had a handset clamped to their ear.

Which? said yesterday that it was studying the tests used by the government, and would announce its findings in two months. "We think there are problems with current testing for hands-free kits, and we are carrying out more research ," said Helen Parker, editor of Which?

"We stand by our results published earlier this year. Consumers need to be aware that hands-free kits are no guarantee of lowering radio emissions from mobile phones, and in some cases, they actually increase it."

The government used what are known as SAR (specific absorption rate) tests - a measure of the energy absorbed in living tissue, which determines, in this case, how much the brain heats up. Scientists use a model of a head filled with simulated brain liquids to assess how much energy gets inside the human head.

A spokesman for the Department of Trade and Industry, which commissioned the latest tests, said SAR tests were the "rational and scientific way to proceed. Measuring emissions will not tell you about absorption in the head, which is the key health risk here".

In the past, the Australian Consumers' Association has recommended the use of hands-free kits.

The spat between Which? and the DTI tells the public nothing about the underlying, unresolved issue of mobile phone use, which is whether the radiation is dangerous.

This was addressed last month by the Stewart inquiry, which failed to find a conclusive answer: there was no evidence that mobile phones damaged health, and no evidence that they did not. Mindful of the slow-burning but eventually devastating BSE crisis, the committee called for further research, and urged mobile users, particularly children, to be cautious.

A government report on Monday sowed confusion among mobile users by endorsing hands-free kits, saying they reduced exposure to radiation from handsets. This contradicted a Which? report in April, which found that hands-free kits increased the amount of radiation heading for the brain. Yesterday it became clear that the real dispute between Which? and the government was over how the radiation from hands-free kits should be measured. The conflicting findings were from different tests. Which? measured how much radiation was transmitted by the devices; the government's scientists measured how much radiation was received by the brain. This explains the different conclusion. Which? found that the radiation emitted by hands-free kits was, in some cases, three times that emitted by the radio transmitters in the handsets themselves. But the government found that, however much radiation the hands-free wires channelled, the amount reaching the brain was much less than if the mobile user had a handset clamped to their ear. Which? said yesterday that it was studying the tests used by the government, and would announce its findings in two months. "We think there are problems with current testing for hands-free kits, and we are carrying out more research ," said Helen Parker, editor of Which? "We stand by our results published earlier this year. Consumers need to be aware that hands-free kits are no guarantee of lowering radio emissions from mobile phones, and in some cases, they actually increase it." The government used what are known as SAR (specific absorption rate) tests - a measure of the energy absorbed in living tissue, which determines, in this case, how much the brain heats up. Scientists use a model of a head filled with simulated brain liquids to assess how much energy gets inside the human head. A spokesman for the Department of Trade and Industry, which commissioned the latest tests, said SAR tests were the "rational and scientific way to proceed. Measuring emissions will not tell you about absorption in the head, which is the key health risk here". In the past, the Australian Consumers' Association has recommended the use of hands-free kits. The spat between Which? and the DTI tells the public nothing about the underlying, unresolved issue of mobile phone use, which is whether the radiation is dangerous. This was addressed last month by the Stewart inquiry, which failed to find a conclusive answer: there was no evidence that mobile phones damaged health, and no evidence that they did not. Mindful of the slow-burning but eventually devastating BSE crisis, the committee called for further research, and urged mobile users, particularly children, to be cautious. webTitle: Even in Germany, seven into five won't go

fields.headline: Even in Germany, seven into five won't go
fields.standfirst: Phone auction poses questions
fields.trailText: Like its British counterpart, in Germany the auction of third generation mobile phone licences has got off to a slow start.
fields.body:
Like its British counterpart, in Germany the auction of third generation mobile phone licences has got off to a slow start. Yesterday was day seven and the 85th round of bidding saw the total of leading bids top the DM20bn (£6.15bn) finance minister Hans Eichel had pencilled into his budget calculations. A milestone of some sort, perhaps, but a very long way short of the £20bn the auction is tipped to raise.

Expect the pace to quicken. The rules of the auction say successive bids have to top the previous best offer by an amount set by the regulator at 10%. So the bid total is going up by more than DM2bn a throw and rising exponentially.

It is a time for deep pockets. Though a total of 12 blocks are on offer, a winner needs to win at least two to secure a licence and the expectation - shared by the regulator - is that at least two groups will want three blocks. That would mean a total of five licences to share between the seven bidders.

The betting is already focusing on some familiar names; T-Mobil which is part of Deutsche Telekom, Vodafone's Mannesmann Mobilfunk, Viag Interkom and Mobilcom, which are linked to BT and France Telecom respectively, and E-Plus-Hutchison.

If the bidding does reach the level expected and if the line-up of successful bidders is as predicted, it is bound to re-ignite the debate about the cost of licences under an auction system and the knock-on effects that could have on future pricing of the service or the pace at which new networks can be rolled out - and about the competitive effect of a system which favours those with the greatest resources.

Oil measure

Once upon a time there were the seven sisters. Now - pace TotalFinaElf - the world's oil industry is dominated by the big three - ExxonMobil, Royal Dutch Shell and BP Amoco.

Competition is fierce as the three seek to establish themselves as the leading player in the oil industry's premier league. With sky high oil prices each is firing on all cylinders. Last month Exxon Mobil reported second quarter figures up 123%. Last week Shell turned in a 95% improvement. Yesterday BP Amoco - complete with a first time contribution from Atlantic Richfield - turned in a 164% improvement. The question is how the three will differentiate themselves. Exxon Mobil has always seen itself as natural top dog. Certainly there is much about its financial discipline and consistent return on capital to admire.

For its part BP Amoco has been a key player in the rationalisation of the oil industry with a string of acquisition - Amoco, Arco and Burmah Castrol. Shell, by contrast, has been very quiet on the merger and acquisition front.

Yet the Europeans both share the view that big oil needs to present an environmentally friendly face to the world. BP Amoco is pushing the marketing boat out behind its new Beyond Petroleum campaign. A recent Shell advert carried the headline: Protect endangered species... or become one?

Whether such an approach will help them appear more progressive than Exxon Mobil remains to be seen. Winning an eco-friendly reputation is not an easy one for an oil company. Yesterday, for example, Greenpeace activists spent a second day on a BP Amoco barge in protest against the development of the Northstar field off Alaska.

But as the battle to be first among equals intensifies, the financial community will become ever keener to decide on a benchmark which will allow consistent comparison of the trio's respective performances.

Dump dollars

Here's a test for tyro forex dealers. An economy is running a trade deficit of $1bn a day. Its employment growth is slowing. Its stock market is 5% down since the start of the year and 75% of the shares quoted on it have fallen. Would you buy that country's currency or not?

The textbook answer is, of course, no. All the fundamentals point to that currency falling rather than rising. In the real world, however, the answer is that you thrust rationality to one side and buy truckloads of the US dollar (the currency in question, in case you had not guessed).

So, despite the fact that there are signs of an incipient slowdown across the Atlantic and despite the US economy becoming increasingly uncompetitive, the dollar has recently resumed its upward trend against the euro. Yesterday, the single currency dipped below 90 cents for a time, with some dealers expecting it to test its record low of 88.40 within the next couple of weeks.

Plausible explanations for this are rather thin on the ground. If anything, US growth is likely to surprise on the downside over the coming months, while euroland activity should remain strong. The euro may have further to fall, but not much further. There are times when the textbooks are right. This is one of them.

webTitle: McGee sees shares in fledgling rercord label soar

fields.headline: High note McGee sees shares in fledgling rercord label soar
fields.standfirst: McGee sees shares in fledgling rercord label soar
fields.trailText: McGee sees shares in fledgling rercord label soar
fields.body:
Alan McGee, founder of Creation Records and the man credited with discovering Oasis, struck the right notes with the stock market yesterday when shares in his new venture moved to a 38% opening day premium. Poptones shares climbed 0.75p from their placing price of 2p to close the day at 2.75p, valuing the fledgling record label at £15.7m.

The punk rock fan from Glasgow, above, who saw his own stake valued in excess of £6m, said he enjoyed his first experience of the Square Mile. "How could I not enjoy the stock market when my share price at one stage on its first day of trading climbs 50%?" he said.

Brokers said the share price rise was largely caused by demand from retail investors for the new issue, which is backed by Julian Richer and Mike Edelson, two directors of Knutsford.

The former bid-vehicle saw its shares move sharply upward late last year before falling back sharply.

"This is not some incubator, it is a real business and today's support shows that people truly believe in what I stand for," Mr McGee said.

"We're a record company that will embrace the internet, build for the future by signing bands up for very little money, develop them and hopefully some will become superstars. We're in this for the long-haul."

Mr McGee said he plans to sign 14 or 15 bands within the next six weeks, have a website up in three weeks and eventually embrace digital radio and broadband technologies.

fields.headline: BP invests £664m in North Sea
fields.standfirst: Record second-quarter profits increase leaves petrochemical group awash with cash
fields.trailText: BP yesterday promised a resurgence in North Sea activity, earmarking almost £664m to be spent on a range of projects in untapped reserves.
fields.body:
BP yesterday promised a resurgence in North Sea activity, earmarking almost £664m to be spent on a range of projects in untapped reserves.

Spending next year is to be increased further in what the petrochemicals group described as an "exciting" area as oil prices remain close to a nine-year high.

The global oil industry's second largest company is awash with cash after reporting record second-quarter profits - 164% higher at £2.4bn - and is under pressure to spend it or give it back to shareholders through buybacks.

Chief executive Sir John Browne said BP had encouraging oil and gas discoveries in offshore US fields, Angola and the Caspian Sea, but that the UK sector should not be seen as an area in decline.

"Obituaries for the North Sea have been written somewhat prematurely. There are some exciting things to do, and North Sea investment is rising for several reasons," he said, pointing to developments in technology with advanced control systems and enhanced recovery techniques.

BP's production of crude and natural gas in the UK sector fell in the first half of the year to 550,000 barrels a day from 575,000 in the same period last year, but overall North Sea output is not in decline.

Experts say the number of offshore jobs is unlikely to increase, and yards that build big platforms will continue to struggle as oil is produced via hi-tech sub-acquatic systems controlled from the shore.

BP plans to raise its overall capital spend by £900m to £8.9bn per annum over the next three years as it aims to increase oil production by up to 5% each year and gas output by nearly 10%.

Capital spending in the second quarter was £1.6bn, up 35% compared with 12 months ago - of which £199m went to the North Sea.

The record pro-forma result, adjusted for special items, at £2.4bn compared with analyst expectations of £2.19bn to £2.3bn and came on the back of strong crude prices and cost-cutting undertaken following a series of mergers.

But the company came under fire from financial analysts at a presentation to them in London. They argued that the series of mergers had made it difficult to compare like with like. Mark Horn, an oil analyst with T Hoare, said afterwards: "We are told they [the figures] are good, but it's not that easy to measure them."

Sir John tacitly admitted he was frustrated that the BP share price had underperformed those of its peers, and accepted that the takeover of Amoco, Arco, Vastar Resources and then Burmah Castrol had clouded the picture for investors.

The future should be better, he insisted "now we can demonstrate with simplicity what the results have been".

The BP chairman said the group had continued to beat its targets on savings with the integration of BP and Arco saving up to £600m during the last six months.

"These results represent the cumulative impact of the progress we've made over the last few years - growth in volume and, equally important, growth in total productivity," he explained.

BP claimed to have a return on capital of 21%, whereas Shell last week said it was on par with Exxon Mobil at 16%. The American oil group, which is the world's largest, reported a 123% rise in second-quarter profits while Shell showed a 95% growth. Analysts said each had used different calculations to produce their data. BP shares ended the day down 14p at 593p.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Negative equity 'still a problem'
fields.body:
Negative equity 'still a problem'

Negative equity is still a problem, said financial consultant Mortgage Express yesterday. Its latest survey shows that property owners in the north west - particularly Salford - are among the worst affected, said Tim Dawson, managing director of Mortgage Express. "The people affected are primarily those who bought at the height of the property boom in the late 1980s and early 1990s, and whose properties are still struggling to get back to those levels after the crash of the 1990s."

Dunbar sues former staffer

Allied Dunbar has issued a high court writ against a former employee who it claims stole £1.77m from its Piccadilly private bank, Dunbar Bank. Beryl Rowlands, 57, is accused by the bank of making "regular and unauthorised" withdrawals over a period of ten years. Her husband Paul is also named on the writ. No criminal charges have been laid in connection with the case.

Dunbar Bank, which deals with wealthy private clients from its offices off Piccadilly, says that no client money is at risk.

Sonera in merger talks

Telecoms operator Sonera, a pioneer in wireless technology widely seen as a takeover target, said yesterday it was holding merger talks. "We're looking for a strategic partnership," Sonera spokesman Jyrki Karasvirta said yesterday. "The company is holding talks about some kind of merger... There are several candidates."

The Finnish state holds a 52.9% stake in Sonera, and has a mandate to sell its entire holding. Its shares gave up early gains and were 2.17% lower at €38.30 in early afternoon trading yesterday.

Arrow appoints financial chief

Privately owned British biotech firm Arrow Therapeutics has appointed Naiem Hussain, a former consultant with Arthur Andersen, to the new post of chief financial officer.

The company has identified compounds against three novel antibacterial targets and expects a product from at least one of its programmes to enter clinical trials in 2001.

Cheery Leeds & Holbeck

Leeds & Holbeck building society yesterday announced record results during the first half of the year, allowing it to pass on £14m to members in the form of higher savings rates and lower borrowing costs.

WPD to buy Hyder bonds

US-owned WPD yesterday offered to buy back Hyder's bonds if its £526m bid for the company succeeds, increasing the likelihood that the Welsh multi-utility will be broken up after it is sold. WPD's offer to buy back four sterling bonds issued by Hyder and two issued by Welsh Water Utilities Finance followed negotiations with major bondholders.

webTitle: Slug and Lettuce buy excludes style creator

fields.headline: Champion lost
fields.standfirst: Slug and Lettuce buy excludes style creator
fields.trailText: Sheila McKenzie, creator of the relaxed style of Slug and Lettuce bars, will not be part of the firm when it is taken over by SFI Group in a deal worth £27.7m.
fields.body:
Sheila McKenzie, creator of the relaxed style of Slug and Lettuce bars, will not be part of the firm when it is taken over by SFI Group in a deal worth £27.7m.

The 42-year-old managing director who is seen as the driving force behind the chain, has decided not to join the enlarged board. "We didn't ever get to the stage when we could agree on a role that would be challenging for me", Ms McKenzie says.

Her decision to quit came to light yesterday following publication of SFI's preliminary results for last year.

Tony Hill, executive chairman of SFI, which runs several pub chains, was keen to keep Ms McKenzie but appears confident that he can strengthen the chain.

"The Slug and Lettuce is not a daunting challenge", Mr Hill said. However, one analyst yesterday said that although SFI are good retailers and operators, the loss of Ms McKenzie is negative because of her "brand champion" status.

SFI Group reported a 52% rise in pre-tax profit to £11.2m for the year to May 31; turnover increased 51% to £61.7m. There was also a 7% increase in like for like sales for June and July, partly helped by Euro 2000.

Profits exclude £400,000 exceptional costs and a £1.4m charge relating to new accounting standards.

Central distribution, allowing SFI to negotiate directly with drink makers, is expected to save £1.5m over three years. SFI hopes to use the Slug and Lettuce brand to compliment its existing outlets; its shares closed at 209.5p, up 14p.

webTitle: Founding family angry about Elastoplast sell-off

fields.headline: Founding family angry about Elastoplast sell-off
fields.trailText: Members of the Smith family, who founded the health care corporation Smith & Nephew, are upset about the company's decision to sell its Elastoplast dressings brand, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Members of the Smith family, who founded the health care corporation Smith & Nephew, are upset about the company's decision to sell its Elastoplast dressings brand, it emerged yesterday.

Descendants of the Hull pharmacist who established the 144-year-old company told the firm's chief executive, Chris O'Donnell, of their reservations about the disposal at Smith & Nephew's extraordinary shareholders' meeting earlier this month.

Mr O'Donnell said: "They're sad to see Elastoplast go on a personal level. It's been part of the business since about 1935."

Smith & Nephew has sold Elastoplast to Beiersdorf, a German health care company, as part of its strategy of shifting from consumer goods to hi-tech medical devices.

Mr O'Donnell wants to concentrate on products such as artificial joints, endoscopy tools and dressings grafted from human skin.

Smith & Nephew's latest reinvention takes it a long way from its origins - the company originally specialised in cod liver oil. It moved into dressings in a big way to treat soldiers injured in the first world war.

Several members of the founding family, some with the surname Charlton, still have small shareholdings and retain an active interest. Mr O'Donnell said: "Usually they come to shareholders' meetings, although I don't consult them about strategic issues."

He defended the sale of Elastoplast, saying that it needed to be part of a bigger organisation: "It's a very well known brand. You need to have a global franchise in first-aid dressings," he insisted.

Other sales have included Nivea soap and Lillets tampons. The reorganisation has been well received in the City - Smith & Nephew's shares rose 23.75p to 276.5p yesterday after an 8% rise in half-year profits to £91.3m.

Growth was driven by sales of artificial hips and knees - which can cost anything up to £5,000 each, depending on the amount of mobility patients require. The group is close to agreeing a joint venture with Beiersdorf to collaborate on bandages and castings.

An announcement is likely at some time next month, and Mr O'Donnell warned that this could mean job losses in Smith & Nephew's wound care division.

Smith & Nephew has high hopes for Trivex - a new device designed to remove varicose veins quickly and easily.

It expects to launch Dermagraft - a dressing for foot ulcers which is made from baby boys' foreskins, in the United States next year.

Several members of the founding family, some with the surname Charlton, still have small shareholdings and retain an active interest. Mr O'Donnell said: "Usually they come to shareholders' meetings, although I don't consult them about strategic issues." He defended the sale of Elastoplast, saying that it needed to be part of a bigger organisation: "It's a very well known brand. You need to have a global franchise in first-aid dressings," he insisted. Other sales have included Nivea soap and Lillets tampons. The reorganisation has been well received in the City - Smith & Nephew's shares rose 23.75p to 276.5p yesterday after an 8% rise in half-year profits to £91.3m. Growth was driven by sales of artificial hips and knees - which can cost anything up to £5,000 each, depending on the amount of mobility patients require. The group is close to agreeing a joint venture with Beiersdorf to collaborate on bandages and castings. An announcement is likely at some time next month, and Mr O'Donnell warned that this could mean job losses in Smith & Nephew's wound care division. Smith & Nephew has high hopes for Trivex - a new device designed to remove varicose veins quickly and easily. It expects to launch Dermagraft - a dressing for foot ulcers which is made from baby boys' foreskins, in the United States next year.

webTitle: Police chief steps up fight to clear name

fields.headline: Police chief steps up fight to clear name
fields.trailText: "Robocop" police chief Ray Mallon has formally accused senior colleagues in Cleveland of conspiring to pervert the course of justice in the long and bitter row over his "zero tolerance" methods.
fields.body:
"Robocop" police chief Ray Mallon has formally accused senior colleagues in Cleveland of conspiring to pervert the course of justice in the long and bitter row over his "zero tolerance" methods.

Lawyers for the superintendent, who remains suspended after he was cleared in June of criminal misuse of informers, have sent allegations to the home secretary, Jack Straw, and are demanding a criminal investigation.

The move follows the revelation that a separate claim of "dirty tricks" against Mr Mallon, made under recent legislation to protect whistleblowers, came from the head of the force's media department.

Joanne Malone has worked for Cleveland for 13 years and supervised much of the official reaction to the 2 year investigation of Mr Mallon, Operation Lancet. She is understood to have wanted to resign because of the manoeuvrings she alleges went on.

Her whistleblowing claim accuses the chief constable of Cleveland, Barry Shaw, of sanctioning the leak of a severely critical analysis of Mr Mallon's policing methods by independent barristers advising the Home Office.

The QCs described the superintendent, nicknamed "Robocop" after admiring comments on zero tolerance from Tony Blair, Jack Straw and Michael Howard, as having run a "woeful and chaotic" regime in Middlesbrough, including deals with criminal informants which showed "a complete indifference" to the law. Ms Malone, who made her allegations under the Public Interest Disclosure Act to Cleveland's assistant chief constable Della Canning, is due back from leave next week.

Her claims are being investigated by South Yorkshire's chief constable, Michael Hedges, at the request of Cleveland police authority, which decided last week not to suspend Mr Shaw during the inquiry.

Mr Mallon made his fiercest accusations to date on yesterday's Radio 4 programme On the Ropes, when he told interviewer John Humphrys: "I am making an allegation of a conspiracy against me to pervert the course of justice, and I expect that allegation to be investigated with as much vigour as the investigation into me was performed.

"I feel very much aggrieved in relation to the way that I've been treated and I want justice. But that doesn't mean to say I want vengeance. I feel extremely strong, as strong now as what I was on the day [prior to my being suspended], and this is something I will not walk away from."

His lawyers, Rowe and Cohen of Manchester, said the Home Office was the last resort, because all the official complaint channels in Cleveland involved people concerned with Operation Lancet or accused of leaks or other alleged malpractice.

Mr Mallon, 45, is a Teesside undertaker's son who left school at 16 with no qualifications. He has made it clear that he believes senior colleagues resented the publicity given to his work and the way that zero tolerance was linked with his name.

Cleveland police declined to comment yesterday, but Mr Shaw has linked informant handling in parts of his force with the disastrous collapse of one of Britain's biggest drug cases in 1992, and stated publicly last month that he believed some officers in his force should be in jail and others sacked.

The Home Office said the lawyers' letter would be seen by Mr Straw on his return from holiday later this month. The normal course of events, said a spokesman, would be that the matter would be passed to Cleveland police, who have the powers to bring in an outside force to investigate if necessary. An inquiry would be the fourth related to Operation Lancet, which began with Mr Mallon's suspension in December 1997.

fields.headline: Banks score in musical chairs
fields.standfirst: Market forces  Neil Hume
fields.trailText: Sector rotation was the name of the game yesterday as the City's larger broking houses managed to drum up a bit of business by persuading institutions to switch out of one sector into another.
fields.body:
Sector rotation was the name of the game yesterday as the City's larger broking houses managed to drum up a bit of business by persuading institutions to switch out of one sector into another.

So down went the recent defensive favourites - oil and pharmaceutical stocks - and up went the laggards - the financials.

The net result of the shift was that the FTSE 100 closed down 29.7 points at 6,358.1 - but of course that did not matter because brokers were earning commission.

Admittedly, they will not have made much - market turnover reached a meagre 1.2bn, and 275m of that was in Vodafone - but for a wet Tuesday in August it was not a bad effort at all.

The banking sector was the undoubted star of the show, providing no less than four of the FTSE 100's eight best performing stocks. The line being pushed by the commission-hungry brokers was primarily one of valuation - stocks such as Alliance & Leicester (up 11p to 499p) yield around 6% and have fallen 500p since the start of the year.

Set against last week's soft, government-sponsored banking review and whispers of corporate activity at Woolwich (1p stronger at 269p on volume of 13.4m) it proved to be a very persuasive argument.

Bank of Scotland motored up 30.5p to 576.5p, Lloyds TSB advanced 13.5p to 615.5p and Barclays - given an additional push by a Goldman Sachs upgrade - advanced 63p to £16.64.

That said, HSBC Holdings was weak, surrendering 23.5p to 901p. But dealers were quick to point out that the stock has had a very strong run since interim figures, recently breaching the psychologically important 900p level.

The flip side of these sector shifts was a weak day for oil and pharmaceutical stocks, which, as recently as Monday, were being hailed as sound defensive plays.

BP Amoco fell 14p to 593p, despite producing a sparkling set of second quarter figures, while Shell dipped 7p to 547p. Over in the drugs sector, Glaxo Wellcome fell 41p to £19.17 and SmithKline Beecham lost 21p to 871p while AstraZeneca finished 40p weaker at £29.65.

Vodafone eventually closed 3.5p higher at 276.25p after a volatile session that saw the shares touch 265.5p early on. This followed speculation that Hutchison Whampoa, the Hong Kong group, was off-loading its 3.46% stake in the mobile phone group.

But Vodafone quickly recovered as it became clear that Hutchison has to maintain its holding until September 1.

Hutchison agreed to this condition back in March, when it sold a third of its then 5% Vodafone stake in what was the world's largest share placing.

Elsewhere in the telecoms sector, Colt Telecom tumbled 191p to £19.65p hit by news that co-founder Paul Chisholm is standing down as chief executive next year. The shock announcement came with unexpectedly strong second-quarter figures.

EMI declined in late trading, shedding 49.5p to 600p, unsettled by news that 28 US states have filed a lawsuit against the world's five largest record labels, accusing them of fixing compact disc prices.

Meanwhile, Morgan Stanley was giving water utilities a good push. Citing the "huge growth opportunities" of international expansion, Morgan increased its valuation of the sector by £500m and raised its fair value target for United Utilities - 21p higher to 712p - from 735p to 770p.

There were also upgrades from FTSE 250 stocks Anglian Water , up 13.5p to 624p, and Thames Water , which rose 17p to 822p.

Lower down the corporate scale, software firm Cedar Group shot up 50p to 800p after Shell signed up for its "Twister" product and James Fisher , a small shipping and transport group, put on 1p to 83.5p amid speculation of corporate activity.

fields.headline: A lift for Kingfisher
fields.trailText: Shares in Kingfisher, the company behind Woolworths and B&Q, leapt 16p to 529p yesterday after heavyweight broker Merrill Lynch upgraded its near-term rating on the stock to "buy" from "neutral" and set a 12-month price target of 620p. The move followed a meeting with the company that left Merrill analyst Mal Patel with the view that the group was undervalued.
fields.body:
Shares in Kingfisher, the company behind Woolworths and B&Q, leapt 16p to 529p yesterday after heavyweight broker Merrill Lynch upgraded its near-term rating on the stock to "buy" from "neutral" and set a 12-month price target of 620p. The move followed a meeting with the company that left Merrill analyst Mal Patel with the view that the group was undervalued.

In the past month Kingfisher shares have fallen around 25% as a number of brokers have moved to reduce their forecasts to take account of the tough trading environment for general merchandise and the costs of rolling out new formats. This has left the stock trading on a 2001 price-to-earnings ratio of around 16, which Mr Patel feels more than discounts risks.

Mr Patel believes the company will use interim results, due on September 13, to reassure the market regarding its strategy and earnings prospects. This, he feels, will justify a re-rating for the shares.

fields.headline: At this price?  BOC
fields.trailText: BOC, the industrial gases group, has seen its share price fall to 983p since the agreement to be taken over by Air Liquide of France and Air Products of America evaporated in a puff of American regulatory smoke.
fields.body:
BOC, the industrial gases group, has seen its share price fall to 983p since the agreement to be taken over by Air Liquide of France and Air Products of America evaporated in a puff of American regulatory smoke.

The question for management is how it can satisfy the enhanced appetite of investors now that the 1,406p offer is history, and whether shareholders should bet on another offer coming forward.

Chief executive Tony Isaac showed yesterday that management had not lost its focus on the business despite the distraction of a potential takeover. He unveiled strong third quarter figures with pre-tax profits before exceptional items up 7% at £117.6m - at the top end of market expectations - and turnover up 16% at 983.7m. In the first nine months BOC profits were up 14% at £328.7m year-on-year, while turnover rose 16% to £2.82bn.

Isaacs promised double-digit growth in both revenues and earnings in the "current phase of the business cycle" and the City seemed willing to believe he can deliver this. The share price moved ahead modestly 4p to 991p.

But BOC has under-performed the FTSE all share index by 26% this year and is rated lower than Air Liquide, though it is still on a price earnings multiple of around 16 times, compared with ICI, on 10.5.

Peter Cartwright, analyst at Williams de Broe, sees BOC as a "hold" believing it will be hard-pressed to move its share price rapidly upwards without some kind of rekindled offer. He does not rule out a bid, although he says it would be unlikely to materialise until next year.

Isaac throws cold water on such speculation, remembering only too well how US regulators crawled all over the last one. Instead, Isaacs said, it is time BOC knuckled down to generating value on its own.

A restructuring plan outlined before the Air Liquide offer will be dusted down.

webTitle: Man held over arson attack as detectives play down race link

fields.headline: Man held over arson attack as detectives play down race link
fields.trailText: Detectives investigating the death of a mother and her two teenage daughters in an arson attack arrested a man yesterday and will continue questioning him this morning.
fields.body:
Detectives investigating the death of a mother and her two teenage daughters in an arson attack arrested a man yesterday and will continue questioning him this morning.

The local man was taken to Telford police station in Shropshire, close to the blackened shell of the modern terrace house in Leegomery where Linda Lowe, 49, and her daughters Sarah, who would have been 18 today, and Lucy, 16, were burned to death early on Saturday.

West Mercia police said there was no evidence of a racist motive for the fire, which broke out early in the morning while Lucy Lowe's partner Azhar Mehmood, a 25-year-old taxi driver, was at the house. The couple's 15-month-old baby, Tazneem, was saved by being thrown from a bedroom window. The baby girl is being treated at the Princess Royal hospital in Telford for facial burns.

Mr Mehmood, who escaped the blaze along with Linda Lowe's husband, George, 55, said that the relationship had not caused any trouble locally. Telford has been the scene of a high-profile investigation into the deaths of two black men, Harold and Jason McGowan, who were found hanged within six months of one another - deaths originally treated by West Mercia police as suicide until details of racist death threats emerged.

Mr Mehmood, who was treated with Mr Lowe for burns and smoke inhalation, said Lucy had just told him she was pregnant for the second time. He said: "We were both ecstatic. We were going to get married and I have been doing up a place for us all to move into."

West Mercia police said no one involved in the tragedy had suggested racist motives - something which automatically turns an inquiry into a racist crime investigation since the Macpherson report into the murder of the black student Stephen Lawrence.

fields.headline: Bottomley backs Hague family focus
fields.standfirst: Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: A leading liberal Conservative MP last night spoke up in William Hague's defence after it emerged that a leaked policy document showed grassroots party activists to be less wedded to the "traditional family" than first claimed.
fields.body:
A leading liberal Conservative MP last night spoke up in William Hague's defence after it emerged that a leaked policy document showed grassroots party activists to be less wedded to the "traditional family" than first claimed.

A survey of members of the Conservative Policy Forum group in which 270 local branches took part found that 40% of the Tories questioned favoured tax breaks for families with children or elderly parents, whether the couple involved were married or not.

That finding was at variance with claims that the CPF survey showed party activists, many of them middle aged or older, are in danger of placing "too heavy an emphasis on traditional marriage.

But the survey did confirm that Mr Hague is going with the grain of party sentiment in his campaign to retain section 28, which outlaws the promo tion of homosexuality in schools, and that Ivan Massow, the gay insurance tycoon who defected from the Conservatives to Labour last week, was entitled to feel uncomfortable in the party.

"There is overwhelming opposition to the inclusion of overtly homosexual or lesbian couples in any definition of a family," say party analysts. But Tories too have difficulty defining a modern family, they also conclude.

While 65 CPF groups suggested that married couples living with children and/or other family members remains the core model, twice that number - 124 groups - include "stably cohabiting couples" in the definition.

Just 22 groups' definitions included "long term social units including same sex ones".

There is also evidence of support for working women, through tax breaks, childcare, longer school terms and other options in the part of the sur vey which was designed to ask what the Conservatives should do "to appeal to the modern working woman".

But some activists found the phrase itself "insulting".

Last night Peter Bottomley, an ex-minister entrenched on the liberal wing of his party - along with his wife, Virginia, who is also an MP and a for mer health secretary - told the Guardian that the defeat of the hardliner Adrian Rogers, by Ben Bradshaw, Labour's openly gay candidate at Exeter in 1997, showed that narrow views of family life are not popular.

But the MP for Worthing West insisted that the party leadership was more in touch with public feeling on key family issues such as pensions, section 28 and family structure than Labour.

"On section 28 no less an authority than the prime minister himself admits they are regarded as out of touch," said Mr Bottomley.

The Tories are engaged in a debate on the family which would encompass both majority and minority lifestyles, he added.

However it was defined, families were the place where people felt they could rely on others for comfort, said the MP who has three grown-up children.

webTitle: Death crash coach driver faces manslaughter charge

fields.headline: Death crash coach driver faces manslaughter charge
fields.trailText: The Scottish driver of a coach that overturned in central France, killing a 15-year-old boy and seriously injuring three others, was last night expected to be charged with manslaughter.
fields.byline: Jon Henley in Paris and Kirsty Scott in Edinburgh
fields.body:
The Scottish driver of a coach that overturned in central France, killing a 15-year-old boy and seriously injuring three others, was last night expected to be charged with manslaughter.

Judicial sources said that Adrian MacDonald, who was on his first trip to the continent on Monday when the coach careered off the A71 motorway outside the town of Vierzon, was questioned by police "as a suspect". They concluded that he had fallen asleep at the wheel and it was believed he would be formally charged last night. They said his co-driver, Craig Linton, who was sitting in the crew seat at the time of the crash at 6.25am, was questioned as a witness and would not be charged. Both were still suffering from shock, they added.

A British embassy spokeswoman said that five people, including the drivers, were still in hospital in the towns of Bourges, Tours and Vierzon following the crash, in which an Edinburgh teenager, Craig Norsworthy, died.

Another boy, Ross Buckmaster, 15, from the Chadwell Heath Foundation school in Essex, suffered serious injuries to his neck and spine, and may be permanently disabled. A group leader had sustained a leg injury and another schoolgirl had been badly cut, but would probably be released today, the spokeswoman said.

The coach, chartered by PGL Travel from a firm in Dunfermline, Rennies, was carrying 38 children and eight adults from the Chadwell Heath school and the 41st Edinburgh Boys' Brigade company to a holiday camp near Brive in southern France.

Thirteen of the Essex schoolchildren, looking bruised and battered, returned to Heathrow airport on Monday night, and most of the Boys' Brigade members flew back to Scotland yesterday afternoon.

The troop's acting leader, Alan Meikle, 23, said on arrival that the group was "shattered" both mentally and physically. He added: "This has been a very traumatic time for everyone. Our thoughts are with Mr and Mrs Norsworthy and all the friends of Craig. We are without a friend, but we will take steps to remember Craig in an appropriate way. There is no more that can be said about the incident. Most people on board were asleep at the time, and were awoken only on impact."

Nicola Goggin, 24, a teacher at the Chadwell Heath school, who sprained her knee in the crash, praised the French authorities for their handling of the crash but said her thoughts were with the injured and those who had lost a friend.
