webTitle: Analysis: Presidents Fujimori of Peru and Chávez of Venezuela

fields.headline: The strongman's return
fields.standfirst: Presidents Fujimori of Peru and Chávez of Venezuela show that Latin America's predilection for authoritarian leaders lives on
fields.trailText: Presidents Fujimori of Peru and Chávez of Venezuela show that Latin America's predilection for authoritarian leaders lives on
fields.body:
One gets re-elected with a handsome majority; the other is inaugurated amid ugly violence. President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela and President Alberto Fujimori of Peru may not appear to have much in common. Yet they do.

Both are men of the people, outsiders who emerged from obscurity to win power. They mean to keep it. They play by the rules when the rules suit and change them when they do not. They are modern examples of caudillos - the strongmen who figured so often in the past government of Latin American countries. (See some of the better known below; there are many more.) Democracy in South America is not yet secure.

Riots accompanied President Fujimori's inauguration last month for a third term. The anger was provoked by his "victory" on May 26 in an election decider that lacked such niceties as an opponent and a referee. Monitors from the Organisation of American States warned that the election could be "neither free nor fair" and withdrew. Alejandro Toledo, Fujimori's opponent, had already withdrawn, saying that abuses in the first round of the election should be investigated. But Mr Fujimori - a stickler for the rules on this occasion - said that not he but the national electoral body should decide whether the election should go ahead. Strangely enough, it said yes. President Fujimori therefore won to extend his 10 years in power.

That Fujimori should be running for office was itself controversial. A third consecutive term is unlawful. It seemed plain enough that he had already had two terms. But he counted differently. Another term, he claimed, would be only a second under the new constitution, which was drawn up after he closed the congress in 1992 - the first time on which the cry of dictator was raised. Today's congress, dominated by his supporters, agreed with Mr Fujimori's argument. The way to a third term was paved.

Yet simply to see Fujimori as an unpopular dictator is an error. He still has the support of half the population. Once he was more popular still, as Chávez is today. His Japanese parentage helped him to win the presidential election in 1990 against the writer Mario Vargas Llosa, a man from the light-skinned elite. Ruthless effectiveness sealed Fujimori's popularity. He assaulted both hyper-inflation and the Shining Path guerrilla movement, slashing spending to balance the budget and relying on his shadowy security adviser, Vladimiro Montesinos, to hunt down the terrorists. His economic therapy was brutal, his anti-terrorist strategy unscrupulous. But Peruvians thanked him: times had been desperate and his solutions worked.

Success has led to arrogance. Many Peruvians were concerned by his ability to open up the way to another term. Rumours of corruption and military involvement in drug-trafficking abound. Foreign investors are wary of Fujimori's whims and his reluctance to stand down. Peru is poor and needs foreign investment. Now the economy will suffer. Fujimori's love of power will cost Peruvians dear. The caudillo, once the solution, has become the problem.

President Chávez in Venezuela is still in the popular phase: super-popular, in his case. Yet he has, as yet, solved nothing. He took office just 17 months ago. He is being re-elected so soon because he, like Fujimori, required a new constitution. The elections it precipitated have, conveniently, enabled him to capitalise on his popularity and take half the state governorships and 60% of the congress. Now he dominates his country, as every caudillo wants to do.

Like Fujimori, Chávez emerged as an answer to disaster: Venezuela's steady decline, its growing poverty, crime and bitterness. Oil had made the country wealthy in the 1970s. Oil buys less nowadays. But the poor wonder where their oil wealth has gone. They see the rich and the politicians as thieves. Chávez agrees. His popularity stems not from action but from his denunciation of all who have preceded him. Venezuelans are angry and he is the channel of their anger.

But the truth is that oil is not enough to make this nation of 24m prosper. It needs a non-oil economy too. To develop it, reform is needed. President Pérez, famously corrupt in a first term in the affluent 1970s, attempted free-market reforms in 1989. He was never forgiven. A middle-ranking army officer tried in 1992 to oust him - Hugo Chávez. Robin Hood was born, the champion of the poor against the powerful and corrupt. Now Robin Hood has power.

He has no policies, however. Chávez is a great orator, South America's best since Fidel Castro of Cuba in his prime. He speaks often of Simón Bolívar (1783-1830), the "great liberator", born in what is now Venezuela, who led the revolt against Spanish rule. But dreaming of Bolívar does not amount to a strategy. Chávez' economic ideas hark back to the old days of state intervention - the ideas that got Venezuela into its mess. He is inconsistent. He threatened to default on debt then went to New York and charmed investment bankers by quoting Frank Sinatra. This is a pattern with him: threats followed by charm. Only in his efforts to consolidate his power has he shown a sense of direction.

Poverty and desperation, the lot of so many Latin Americans, favour the emergence of charismatic strongmen. It has happened so many times before in Latin America's turbulent history. Fujimori and Chávez were unknowns who exploded upon the political scene. Their challengers now are equally unknown and might prove equally unreliable if they one day win power.

The caudillos are given licence, for, in desperate times, anything that might work is deemed to be good. But the patient business of building sensible rules and democracy is Latin America's only way ahead. Respect for the rules builds the justice and stability in which people and business can thrive. Growth eases the plight of the poor and creates stability. But this virtuous circle has mostly eluded South America.

Ian Campbell is a South American specialist
isccnc@gis.net

Past dictators

Humberto Branco 1900-67, led Brazilian coup 1964, dictator to 1967

Juan Peron 1895-1974, Argentine president 1946-55, 1973-4

Augusto Pinochet 1915-, deposed Salvador Allende 1973, Chilean dictator to 1990

Anastasio Somoza 1896-1956, Nicaraguan president 1937-47 and 1950-56. His son, same name, was dictator 1967-72 and 1974-79

Alfredo Stroessner 1912-, led Paraguayan coup 1954, dictator to 1989. "Re-elected" eight times

Rafael Trujillo 1891-1961, Dominican Republic dictator 1930-61

fields.headline: Anti-wrinkle cream 'puts skin at risk'
fields.trailText: Skincare specialists yesterday warned women of the dangers of using anti-wrinkle creams which could make the skin more prone to ageing.
fields.body:
Skincare specialists yesterday warned women of the dangers of using anti-wrinkle creams which could make the skin more prone to ageing.

Alpha hydroxy acids (AHAs), which are an ingredient in many of the products, get rid of wrinkles and discolouring by removing the outer layer of the skin.

They have become popular with women, but experts are worried that people who use them could be more at risk of damage from the sun, causing long-term skin harm.

The European commission is looking into concerns about AHAs and is consulting experts on the safety of the ingredient.

In 1997, guidelines from the cosmetic ingredient review said that a concentration of 10% of certain AHAs in cosmetic products should be safe. But a recent report by the US food and drug administration said people who used AHAs had greater sensitivity to the sun.

The commission could decide to limit the amount of AHAs used to very low percentages and force manufacturers to put warnings on packaging.

Nick Lowe, a consultant dermatologist in London and clinical professor at the University of California and Los Angeles, said that women should be aware of the potential problems associated with using creams containing AHAs.

"Some people who use AHA creams can be at risk of greater damage from the sun if they do not protect their skin," he said.

"The problem is that AHAs are a largely unregulated industry because they are not seen as a drug, but as an ingredient."

AHAs can be useful for people with skin problems and diseases, Professor Lowe added. "What is needed is more research and for the issue to be brought to the attention of the public.

"And I would always advise women to use a good sun cream with at least a sun protection factor of 15."

webTitle: Lifer who spurned parole gets case review

fields.headline: Lifer who spurned parole gets case review
fields.trailText: When Harold Williams was found guilty of murdering his lover, he vowed he would stay in jail until he died rather than leave without clearing his name.
fields.body:
When Harold Williams was found guilty of murdering his lover, he vowed he would stay in jail until he died rather than leave without clearing his name.

Twenty-three years later - and 12 years after he was offered early release if he confessed to killing Margaret Davies - he has finally been given the chance to prove his innocence.

Yesterday the criminal cases review commission announced that his conviction was being referred to the court of appeal, after a three year investigation by West Mercia police.

Friends of Williams, 67, said he was "delighted and overjoyed", but his daughter, Tereyna Wheatstone, said there was still a long way to go. "We will not be able to celebrate fully until he has been cleared and is out of prison."

Williams, a coach driver, was jailed for life at Worcester crown court for murdering Mrs Davies, 41, a divorcee.

The two had been occasional lovers for 12 months but had split up in January 1977. Soon afterwards, Mrs Davies was found bound, gagged, strangled and stabbed at her home in Tupsley, Hereford. Williams was one of three suspects and was charged six months later.

The prosecution admitted that its case was based on circumstantial evidence. Williams had been seen outside her house days before she was killed, and when detectives searched his room they found a magazine which had a picture of a woman lying gagged on a bed next to a man with a knife.

Williams claimed that he was asleep at his parents' house when the murder took place, but it was a weak alibi and hard to substantiate.

He did not give evidence at the trial. He denied murder but was found guilty by a 10-2 majority verdict.

Doubts about the case emerged when his family began to investigate. Mrs Davies's diary, which contained the names of several lovers, was lost by detectives and was not produced in court.

The timing of the murder was also questioned. A pathologist's report prepared for the police said she had been killed between 11pm on Friday and 6.30am the next morning. However, a schoolgirl claimed that she had seen Mrs Davies alive and well much later on Saturday morning.

Two years ago the CCRC received a 250-page dossier from David Hallam, a former MEP for Shropshire and Hereford who took up Williams's campaign. The dossier detailed inconsistencies about the timing of Mrs Davies's death.

"We don't know the grounds of the CCRC decision yet, but we know a 40-page statement of reasons has been sent to the appeal court," said Mr Hallam.

"We are aware there is someone out there who knows who committed this crime, and we would ask them to come forward to end this tragic story as quickly as possible."

He added: "This might seem strange, but Harold bears no grudges against the police. He believes they acted in good faith on the evidence they had, but the evidence was incomplete."

Williams is at Sudbury open prison in Derbyshire. After he refused to sign a licence admitting his guilt to win parole, he told a Sunday newspaper: "I know I could be outside fighting this case, but I was innocent when I came in, and that's how I want to leave.

"If I took the offer of parole I would have to agree to be released on licence, which would in effect mean signing a document saying I was a murderer. And I am not a murderer."

webTitle: ETA hits back hours after deadly own goal

fields.headline: ETA hits back hours after deadly own goal
fields.standfirst:
Bombers strike in Madrid and Bilbao despite losing four of their own

Special report: bombs in Madrid
fields.trailText: Barely 12 hours after four members of the separatist group ETA apparently blew themselves apart transporting a bomb in Bilbao on Monday night, a prominent Basque businessman was killed yesterday by a car bomb.
fields.body:
Barely 12 hours after four members of the separatist group ETA apparently blew themselves apart transporting a bomb in Bilbao on Monday night, a prominent Basque businessman was killed yesterday by a car bomb.

A third blast, caused by another car bomb, injured 11 people in a mainly residential area north of Madrid's city centre yesterday evening. Several politicians live in the area. A security guard suffered serious head injuries after being struck by shrapnel; two children, aged three and five, were among others hurt.

Police said they received a telephone warning minutes before the bomb went off from a man who claimed to represent ETA.

The two attacks yesterday may have been staged at short notice to prove that the organisation - which is thought to have relatively few "commando" units - had not been crippled by the deaths in Bilbao.

But the sudden upsurge in violence is more likely to reflect the determination of ETA's newly installed hardline leadership to escalate its campaign, which has now claimed 12 lives since the group ended its ceasefire in December.

The killings have damaged relations between the governing Popular party, under Jose Maria Aznar, in Madrid and the Basque regional government. The regional and national leaders disagree about the breakdown of last year's abortive peace talks.

The victim of yesterday's first attack was identified as Jose Maria Korta. He was killed outside his machine tool factory in Zumaia, near San Sebastian, when a device packed into another car was triggered as he parked his vehicle alongside.

Married with three children, Korta was the president of an association of local businessmen and an outspoken critic of ETA. Businessmen in the Basque region are regularly threatened if they fail to pay "revolutionary taxes" to ETA and have often been targeted for assassination.

Forensic experts in Bilbao spent yesterday examining the wreckage left after a car carrying four ETA activists disintegrated in an explosion on Monday night. The car was said by police to have been carrying up to 30kg (66lb) of explosives which were accidentally detonated.

Initially three people were believed to have died but it was later confirmed that there was a fourth victim. Officers had difficulty identifying the bodies because of the force of the blast.

Among those thought to have died was one of ETA's most wanted commanders, Patxi Rementeria, the leader of the Vizcaya commando, one of the group's most active units, and was suspected of taking part in the 1997 kidnapping and murder of the Basque politician Miguel Angel Blanco whose death brought 6m Spaniards on to the streets in protest.

The conservative Popular party said the ETA members' deaths had averted another attack. But Basque regional political leaders lamented the loss of life and urged that dialogue be reopened.

ETA called a ceasefire in September 1998, but the peace process ended in failure after just one negotiating session with the government in 1999. ETA called off its ceasefire in early December.

The government offered to move prisoners back to jails nearer home, but refused to concede any more ground on the issue of Basque self-determination, which it fears will lead to Spain's fragmentation.

The Basque regional government already has considerable autonomy: tax-raising powers, use of the Basque language in schools, and its own police force. It is run by the Basque National party.

ETA's political wing, Herri Batasuna, has seen its political support waning - ETA called for a boycott of the general election in March. The organisation, which used to copy IRA techniques and follow Sinn Fein's political progress in Northern Ireland assiduously, has fallen under the control of hardline factions.

One of the organisation's dominant strategists is thought to be Soledad Iparaguirre, whose boyfriend was killed by the security forces in 1981.

The Basque National party, which persuaded ETA to call a ceasefire, cut its links with Herri Batasuna after the killings resumed. The separatists have been blamed for nearly 800 deaths since they began their campaign in 1968.

Following is a chronology of the main events of the campaign by the Basque separatist group ETA for independence from Spain. In the course of this, about 800 people have been killed

A history of bloodshed

1959 ETA is founded during the Franco dictatorship, its name standing for Basque Homeland and Freedom

(Euskadi Ta Askatasuna). It vows to fight for Basque self-determination

1968 First planned ETA killing. Victim is Meliton Manzanas, police chief in Basque city San Sebastian

1973 Franco's designated successor, the prime minister Luis Carrero Blanco, killed by car bomb in Madrid.

1980 ETA's bloodiest year: 118 killed in attacks

1987, June ETA's worst single attack: 21 shoppers die when bomb explodes in Barcelona supermarket

1997, July Basque town councillor Miguel Angel Blanco is kidnapped, then killed by ETA. Six million Spaniards march in protest

1998, September ETA announces truce, but in August 1999 suspends talks with the government

1999, December 3 ETA's ceasefire ends

2000 ETA violence takes 12 lives including, apparently, four of its own

Businessmen in the Basque region are regularly threatened if they fail to pay "revolutionary taxes" to ETA and have often been targeted for assassination. Forensic experts in Bilbao spent yesterday examining the wreckage left after a car carrying four ETA activists disintegrated in an explosion on Monday night. The car was said by police to have been carrying up to 30kg (66lb) of explosives which were accidentally detonated. Initially three people were believed to have died but it was later confirmed that there was a fourth victim. Officers had difficulty identifying the bodies because of the force of the blast. Among those thought to have died was one of ETA's most wanted commanders, Patxi Rementeria, the leader of the Vizcaya commando, one of the group's most active units, and was suspected of taking part in the 1997 kidnapping and murder of the Basque politician Miguel Angel Blanco whose death brought 6m Spaniards on to the streets in protest. The conservative Popular party said the ETA members' deaths had averted another attack. But Basque regional political leaders lamented the loss of life and urged that dialogue be reopened. ETA called a ceasefire in September 1998, but the peace process ended in failure after just one negotiating session with the government in 1999. ETA called off its ceasefire in early December. The government offered to move prisoners back to jails nearer home, but refused to concede any more ground on the issue of Basque self-determination, which it fears will lead to Spain's fragmentation. The Basque regional government already has considerable autonomy: tax-raising powers, use of the Basque language in schools, and its own police force. It is run by the Basque National party. ETA's political wing, Herri Batasuna, has seen its political support waning - ETA called for a boycott of the general election in March. The organisation, which used to copy IRA techniques and follow Sinn Fein's political progress in Northern Ireland assiduously, has fallen under the control of hardline factions. One of the organisation's dominant strategists is thought to be Soledad Iparaguirre, whose boyfriend was killed by the security forces in 1981. The Basque National party, which persuaded ETA to call a ceasefire, cut its links with Herri Batasuna after the killings resumed. The separatists have been blamed for nearly 800 deaths since they began their campaign in 1968. Following is a chronology of the main events of the campaign by the Basque separatist group ETA for independence from Spain. In the course of this, about 800 people have been killed A history of bloodshed 1959 ETA is founded during the Franco dictatorship, its name standing for Basque Homeland and Freedom (Euskadi Ta Askatasuna). It vows to fight for Basque self-determination 1968 First planned ETA killing. Victim is Meliton Manzanas, police chief in Basque city San Sebastian 1973 Franco's designated successor, the prime minister Luis Carrero Blanco, killed by car bomb in Madrid. 1980 ETA's bloodiest year: 118 killed in attacks 1987, June ETA's worst single attack: 21 shoppers die when bomb explodes in Barcelona supermarket 1997, July Basque town councillor Miguel Angel Blanco is kidnapped, then killed by ETA. Six million Spaniards march in protest 1998, September ETA announces truce, but in August 1999 suspends talks with the government 1999, December 3 ETA's ceasefire ends 2000 ETA violence takes 12 lives including, apparently, four of its own

webTitle: Bush to decide on execution today of man with IQ of 70

fields.headline: Bush to decide on execution today of man with IQ of 70
fields.trailText: A mentally disabled man will almost certainly be executed in Texas today unless George W Bush, the front-runner to become next president of the United States, applies his doctrine of "compassionate conservatism" to this emotive case.
fields.body:
A mentally disabled man will almost certainly be executed in Texas today unless George W Bush, the front-runner to become next president of the United States, applies his doctrine of "compassionate conservatism" to this emotive case.

But even the condemned man's lawyer believes that there is only one chance in five that the supreme court or Mr Bush, governor of the state where more people are put to death than any other, will stay the execution of Oliver Cruz, 33.

"We think it's a go for both of them," said Larry Todd, Texas department of criminal justice spokesman, referring to Cruz and Brian Roberson, 36, also due to die today. "We're preparing as we do for any execution." The men's execution dates were set by different judges and are the same day by coincidence.

Cruz, whose IQ has tested between 63 and 76, has spent 12 years on death row and does not dispute his conviction for the rape and murder of a 24-year-old woman.

A psychologist called by the defence told his trial that Cruz was mentally impaired. "That's the tragedy of this case," said Jeffrey Pokarak. "The law is going to prevent the execution of people like Cruz in six to eight months, so he would be the last retarded person to die under the old law."

The state did not contradict the psychologist's trial evidence but rather contended that this simply made Cruz more dangerous. At the time he could hardly read or write: three times he failed the army entrance exam and he could not understand a job application form.

Thirty-eight of the 50 states allow capital punishment but, of these, 13 do not put mentally impaired killers to death. The Texas legislature failed last year to approve a law banning such executions but is thought to be likely to do so next year.

Two hundred and twenty- five people have been executed in the state since the death penalty was restored there 18 years ago, 138 of them - more than three-fifths - under the Bush administration that won power in 1995.

Mr Bush has granted only one temporary reprieve and a spokesman for him said: "Governor Bush believes that the jury should consider all the evidence regarding mental impairment and decide whether a death sentence is appropriate."

His brother, Jeb Bush, the governor of Florida, refuses to sign death warrants for people with "severe retardation" and executions have been suspended in Illinois after unease about a number of cases.

But the issue is unlikely to have an impact on the presidential election campaign, even though the latest poll showed that support for the death penalty had fallen to 66%, the lowest in 19 years.

webTitle: Farmers given cash to protect wildlife

fields.headline: Farmers given cash to protect wildlife
fields.trailText: A hugely expanded scheme to encourage farmers to conserve wildlife and avoid overproduction is to be launched today.
fields.body:
A hugely expanded scheme to encourage farmers to conserve wildlife and avoid overproduction is to be launched today.

This year 3,500 farmers have applied to join a scheme that provides 10-year grants to allow birds to nest and insects to thrive where intensive methods had wiped them out. Surveys show that up to 20% of insect species became extinct in England in the last century.

The government has increased the budget for the scheme from £13m in 1997 to £126m by 2006 in response to public anxiety about the fate of the countryside and the enthusiasm of farmers to take part.

Elliot Morley, the farming minister, is to visit the biggest scheme in England today at Willoughby Farm, Alford, Lincolnshire, which will maintain 70 miles of hedges, ponds and field margins in exchange for subsidies.

Gaye James, managing director of 6,000 acres of arable land and 500 acres of woodland, said: "Up to now we have been forced to crop right up to hedges and ditches in our fields to make a living. This scheme will allow us to repair hedges and fences and keep large margins round the field for wildlife. We are hoping it will restore the nesting sites for birds like lapwing."

Farmers get between £4 and £280 a hectare for the scheme each year, depending on how much income they lose from taking land out of production and the cost of restoration work on hedges and other features that encourage wildlife.

Mrs James is likely to be one of 3,000 successful applicants which the Ministry of Agriculture believes will move Britain away from the intensive agriculture encouraged by Europe's common agricultural policy.

webTitle: Church says Guatemalan army traded in Mayan children

fields.headline: Church says Guatemalan army traded in Mayan children
fields.trailText: The Roman Catholic church in Guatemala has accused the country's armed forces of kidnapping, and possibly trading in, hundreds of Mayan children during the civil war that ended in 1996.
fields.body:
The Roman Catholic church in Guatemala has accused the country's armed forces of kidnapping, and possibly trading in, hundreds of Mayan children during the civil war that ended in 1996.

"What we have in our hands is the confirmation that children were used as war booty, that forced disappearance was used as an instrument of war against those most vulnerable, the children," said Neri Rodenas, director of the archdiocesan human rights office in Guatemala City.

The church has released the results of a seven-month investigation into 86 documented cases of minors who reportedly disappeared during the 36-year conflict.

The 200-page document, entitled Until we find you: the case of children disappeared in Guatemala's civil war, reveals that 74 of the children were abducted, almost exclusively by the army - but in some cases by pro-government militia, or leftwing guerrillas. The investigators said they have as many as 400 similar cases to investigate.

Presenting the report to a news conference in the capital, Bishop Mario Rios Montt said: "This report aims to prevent such instances of pain and suffering from occurring again in our country."

An spokesman for the army said it would cooperate fully with any investigations stemming from the report. Captain Jose Valladares said: "We have absolutely nothing to hide _ if we are summoned to court we will go."

The report says that most of the children were from the majority Mayan population and went missing in the west ern highlands in the early 1980s at the height of army repression against indigenous communities.

According to a 1999 UN-sponsored Truth Commission, more than 400 indigenous villages were razed by the military as it attempted to stamp out Mayan support for the leftwing guerrillas. More than 200,000 people are estimated to have been killed during the war.

One of the report's authors, Claudia Anleu, said: "Previously, it was thought that there were no children disappeared as in Chile or Argentina and that the war here had been so cruel that survivors had not been left."

But investigators now believe that the army deliberately seized the children from their fleeing parents, perhaps to prevent them joining the guerrillas, or to sell them into adoption.

Only three missing Guatemalan infants have so far been located and reunited their families.

Among them is Denise Becker, a young Mayan woman, who returned to Guatemala in June, 18 years after being taken away by soldiers during an army massacre in her village. Her real name is Dominga Sic. She grew up with an adoptive family in the US state of Iowa.

Investigators believe that tracking down other children will be a difficult task, especially as Guatemala was renowned for easy adoptions to foreign couples. Ms Anleu said: "We have not found the children yet. All we've done is confirm that there was forced disappearance of infants, and that if there are further investigations carried out, with a larger team of investigators, then the results will be greater."

The church could also find itself in trouble with the military, which still wields considerable power, if it begins to investigate the military's role in the country's murky past.

In April 1998, two days after publishing a damning report into army human rights abuses during the war, the report's principal architect, Bishop Juan Gerardi, was bludgeoned to death outside his parish home.

fields.headline: Random views
fields.standfirst: What darts fans are watching on television
fields.trailText: What darts fans are watching on television
fields.body:
Marie Morgan: "I like murder-mystery style things, with lots of action and someone good in them. Can I think? No, not really, not at the moment, I've had quite a lot to drink as you might notice, heuiihihihih! Let me think... I like a bit of Morse, detective stuff. I like that Sopranos thing, I thought that was great, smashing. Do I watch darts? When it's on. It's going to be on Sky now, shame it's not BBC. Do I fancy darts players? I must do - my husband is one!"

Clive Apark: "I remember a little known programme in the 80s with Jim Bowen called Bullseye. Now a better sports game show you couldn't get. The Jim Davidson snooker game is nothing compared to that one, my love. Yeah, some people might have laughed but to get darts on mainstream TV would be one heck of a feat now, know what I mean love? You tell me though, whether you think that the game won't be on the telly in five years. I sense a revival. I can feel it in my water, hehehehehehherugh! [Looks a bit peaky.]"

Sandra Moore: "I watch anything, I'll watch it at midnight when my other half is fast asleep and I'll watch it first thing when he's still asleep. I get the children up and we watch the Big Breakfast. Lisa Tarbuck's leaving day was so sad, I've really warmed to her - didn't like her at first, I thought she looked uncomfortable with Johnny, but you can tell they really get on, can't you? I like things like Collectors' Lot and Watercolour Challenge and all the quiet stuff in the afternoons, not like Jerry Springer, can't stand him. I want peace. I'd have the TV on all day if I could just watch Test Card,!"

Ben Hitchen: "Last thing I watched? Some old crap. I don't know. Something from the 70s, hahah! I really don't know, probably a Carry On Film. I sound like Sid James, better than Kenneth Williams, hahahah! Wish my wife was like Barbara Windsor, hahahaha! Hang on, I like EastEnders, I like that. Riiiiiioooicky! Good show. Good show. Where's my drink?"

 Sin Pattenden spoke to darts fans in Essex

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: That Hamilton Woman | All The President's Men | Great Expectations | Delicatessen
fields.body:
That Hamilton Woman

(Alexander Korda, 1945)

7am, Carlton Cinema

Vivien Leigh is Emma Hamilton, her real-life husband Laurence Olivier supplying the Nelson touch. A decorous romance that merely flirts with the admiral's two-timing, since there was a serious motive behind the film: in the hard, late days of the last war, the British needed a reminder of their glorious past.

All The President's Men
(Alan J Pakula, 1976)

8pm, Sky Cinema

How Washington Post reporters Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein traced the Watergate break-in back to President Nixon's office. William Goldman's masterly screenplay extracts all the suspense of the investigation and its riveting detail. And Pakula is in his element, showing reporters Redford and Hoffman - and Jason Robards as editor Ben Bradlee - delving into many shades of mucky dealing from their gleaming, bright-lit newspaper office.

Great Expectations
(Alfonso Cuaron, 1997)

8pm, Sky Premier

The shadow of David Lean's masterly adaptation looms over Dickens's novel but the Mexican director Cuaron has risen to the challenge. He updates the action to 70s Florida, then 80s New York, breathing a new urgency into the classic tale, and the cast is terrific: Ethan Hawke as Finn, aka Pip; Robert De Niro the escaped convict; Anne Bancroft as the mad auntie and Gwyneth Paltrow an icy Estella.

Delicatessen

(Jean-Jacques Jeunet and Marc Caro, 1991)

8pm, FilmFour

This makes the Coen brothers look like Blake Edwards. The hero is little Dominique Pinon, an out-of-work circus clown who becomes oddjob man at a dismal boarding house, his predecessor having been axed by the cannibalistic butcher downstairs. Amid the monstrous meatiness a touching love blossoms between Pinon and butcher's daughter Marie-Laure Dougnac, and only his circus skills can save him from the chop.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Twin Cities | Them And Us
fields.body:
Donald Trump's latest megalomaniac ambition is to build the world's highest apartment block. But, as Jonathan Glancey discovers in Twin Cities (11.0am, Radio 4), he's bucking New York's latest environmental trend. On the whole, its citizens would rather feel fresh air circulating through their urban canyons. Not so in Manhattan's traditional rival. Chicago, miffed that its native skyscrapers are now lower than Asia's, is embarking on a 2,000-foot monster.

It may turn out that August is, indeed, the cruellest month. Just when we might reasonably expect to focus exclusively on sea and sand, along comes Diana Madill to drag us to the waste land of reality. The new season of Them And Us (8.0pm, Radio 4) doesn't allow fantasies: the topic facing the burghers of Coventry is whether they'd be better off joining the euro. Many of them are well aware what the high pound can mean for jobs. Listeners elsewhere can vote by phone.

fields.headline: From striker to linesman
fields.trailText: Football Stories | Jackpot | Paddington Green | White Sox And Stilettoes | Journey Into Evil
fields.body:
Diego Maradona's current party trick is balancing a glass on his forehead and climbing out of a swimming pool. It is a quite a comedown from his glory days of playing for Boca, Barcelona, Napoli and, of course, Argentina when he was a player as deft, dexterous and artistic as any. Now, after years of cocaine use, a heart attack and the evaporation of his skill, he looks like any other dumpy, middle-aged man in too-tight trunks. He waddles. When heroes go down, they plummet.

The story of Maradona's fall from grace to his "rehabilitation", told in Football Stories (C4), was a cautionary tale about believing the hype and giving into one's hubris. Whether he was screaming at a football match on TV or justifying himself to camera, being waited on - and hosed down - by nubile young women or being excused by his manager/ friend/gatekeeper Guillermo Coppola, the one-time world's greatest footballer came over as a petulant child. Maradona has never grown up, perhaps because he never had the chance to, but more likely because he never needed to.

His addiction to cocaine only matched by his addiction to celebrity, it was clear the man had no sense of his own fallability. With his ceramic smooth skin, pot belly and weird beard, Maradona sat like a Toby jug, musing on the past. Which, hosings down from young women aside, is all he has left to do. "People are waiting on him to die", a friend of Maradona's said. Certainly for icons, that is the only way to go out on top. A Norma Desmond in football shorts.

In the main, Dave Ulliot knows, in the immortal words of Kenny Rogers, knows when to hold them, knows when to fold them, knows when to walk away and when to run. Known as "Devilfish" on the poker circuit because of his shark-like propensities, Ulliot was trying to build up a big enough stake to play in Vegas. He estimated he needed $250,000. While his four sons (there were another three children somewhere) sat at home having grilled beefburgers for their dinner, dad was off out winning and losing thousands of pounds and fancying himself as a bit of an entertainer. An unsympathetic character, the most poignant, revealing moment in this first part of Jackpot , BBC2's new documentary series on gambling, was when one of Ulliot's sons said how much he missed him when his dad was away. For once, Ulliot was lost for words, the stakes evidently higher than he thought.

There must have been unbearable tension down Albert Square when it was announced Paddington Green (BBC1) was returning for a fourth series. With Ross Kemp over on ITV, who would now narrate the docusoap? Would Phil take over from where his bruvver left off? Would Steve hope his voiceover skills impressed Melanie? Would the entrepreneurial Ian expand his empire further? Answer: none of the above, for Mark traded his fruit and veg stall for another set of bananas - Denny, Matt and Camilla, the fruitloop in chief.

As sweet, irritating and endearing as the trio were, Paddington Green has lost its sparkle. More fun was to be had watching the paint in Denny's bathroom dry.

Further east, White Sox And Stilettoes (C5) started with an interesting question: what have the good folks of Essex done to deserve their reputation as stupid, promiscuous and loud-mouthed? It would have been interesting to explore the reasons for this but there was none of that. Instead of asking, say, whether the working-class people made good from Essex were the victims of middle-class snobbery or working-class accusations of class betrayal, this programme, in the worst traditions of the modern documentary (ie, point a camera and film indiscriminately and don't bother to edit), lacked any kind of analysis or intelligence.

It must be hard when your surname looks like it belongs on the periodic table. Charles Ng found it so difficult he took to murdering people. Journey Into Evil (C5), which could well have been a made-for-TV movie about true-life injustice starring Donna Mills but was an actually a not-too-cheesy documentary telling of Ng and Leonard Lake's murderous careers, asked why we find serial killers so irresistible. It could be that, as with heroes like Maradona at his peak, we suspect there is a little bit of them in us. Not a thought you need last thing at night.
fields.bodyText: Diego Maradona's current party trick is balancing a glass on his forehead and climbing out of a swimming pool. It is a quite a comedown from his glory days of playing for Boca, Barcelona, Napoli and, of course, Argentina when he was a player as deft, dexterous and artistic as any. Now, after years of cocaine use, a heart attack and the evaporation of his skill, he looks like any other dumpy, middle-aged man in too-tight trunks. He waddles. When heroes go down, they plummet. The story of Maradona's fall from grace to his "rehabilitation", told in Football Stories (C4), was a cautionary tale about believing the hype and giving into one's hubris. Whether he was screaming at a football match on TV or justifying himself to camera, being waited on - and hosed down - by nubile young women or being excused by his manager/ friend/gatekeeper Guillermo Coppola, the one-time world's greatest footballer came over as a petulant child. Maradona has never grown up, perhaps because he never had the chance to, but more likely because he never needed to. His addiction to cocaine only matched by his addiction to celebrity, it was clear the man had no sense of his own fallability. With his ceramic smooth skin, pot belly and weird beard, Maradona sat like a Toby jug, musing on the past. Which, hosings down from young women aside, is all he has left to do. "People are waiting on him to die", a friend of Maradona's said. Certainly for icons, that is the only way to go out on top. A Norma Desmond in football shorts. In the main, Dave Ulliot knows, in the immortal words of Kenny Rogers, knows when to hold them, knows when to fold them, knows when to walk away and when to run. Known as "Devilfish" on the poker circuit because of his shark-like propensities, Ulliot was trying to build up a big enough stake to play in Vegas. He estimated he needed $250,000. While his four sons (there were another three children somewhere) sat at home having grilled beefburgers for their dinner, dad was off out winning and losing thousands of pounds and fancying himself as a bit of an entertainer. An unsympathetic character, the most poignant, revealing moment in this first part of Jackpot , BBC2's new documentary series on gambling, was when one of Ulliot's sons said how much he missed him when his dad was away. For once, Ulliot was lost for words, the stakes evidently higher than he thought. There must have been unbearable tension down Albert Square when it was announced Paddington Green (BBC1) was returning for a fourth series. With Ross Kemp over on ITV, who would now narrate the docusoap? Would Phil take over from where his bruvver left off? Would Steve hope his voiceover skills impressed Melanie? Would the entrepreneurial Ian expand his empire further? Answer: none of the above, for Mark traded his fruit and veg stall for another set of bananas - Denny, Matt and Camilla, the fruitloop in chief. As sweet, irritating and endearing as the trio were, Paddington Green has lost its sparkle. More fun was to be had watching the paint in Denny's bathroom dry. Further east, White Sox And Stilettoes (C5) started with an interesting question: what have the good folks of Essex done to deserve their reputation as stupid, promiscuous and loud-mouthed? It would have been interesting to explore the reasons for this but there was none of that. Instead of asking, say, whether the working-class people made good from Essex were the victims of middle-class snobbery or working-class accusations of class betrayal, this programme, in the worst traditions of the modern documentary (ie, point a camera and film indiscriminately and don't bother to edit), lacked any kind of analysis or intelligence. It must be hard when your surname looks like it belongs on the periodic table. Charles Ng found it so difficult he took to murdering people. Journey Into Evil (C5), which could well have been a made-for-TV movie about true-life injustice starring Donna Mills but was an actually a not-too-cheesy documentary telling of Ng and Leonard Lake's murderous careers, asked why we find serial killers so irresistible. It could be that, as with heroes like Maradona at his peak, we suspect there is a little bit of them in us. Not a thought you need last thing at night.

webTitle: Leader: The Tories' new campaign is maladroit

fields.headline: Wrong on rights
fields.standfirst:
The Tories' new campaign is maladroit

Special report: Tories in opposition

Role model who fears falling off the tightrope

Tories aim barbs at PM's 'Lady Macbeth'
fields.trailText: The right has been mobilising around rights. Tory MPs and their allies in the Murdoch and Conrad Black newspapers are working up a head of steam about the Human Rights Act. To them it is mainly a stick with which to beat Europe, as if the "fundamental charter" now being discussed inside the European Union had anything to do with the implementation of the HRA, two years after it was enacted amid silence on Tory benches and a year after it peacefully came into force in Scotland.
fields.body:
The right has been mobilising around rights. Tory MPs and their allies in the Murdoch and Conrad Black newspapers are working up a head of steam about the Human Rights Act. To them it is mainly a stick with which to beat Europe, as if the "fundamental charter" now being discussed inside the European Union had anything to do with the implementation of the HRA, two years after it was enacted amid silence on Tory benches and a year after it peacefully came into force in Scotland.

To their gallery of stock villains, the Tories were this week delighted to add Caesar's wife - triply stained as a lawyer, an enthusiast for the statute and, unpardonable sin on the right, a woman with political views possibly different from her spouse's. In sum, the Tory position on the new human rights law is a farrago of tabloid headlines and plain ignorance - manifest in the continuing confusion between the European Court of Justice (Luxembourg, part of the EU) and the European Court of Human Rights (Strasbourg, under the Council of Europe).

This is a pity. For legitimate questions can be asked about the act and the case made for it by Cherie Booth QC. A sharper opposition might have picked up her argument that human rights can be confined to tried and trusted terrain: race, employment, the behaviour of the police and public authorities. Why should her "new rights culture" stop there? Perhaps Mrs Blair knows that a third way government is none too keen on positive rights, to employment, minimum standards of welfare or health. It might have to spend more than even generous Gordon has allowed.

Human rights are often couched in individualist, anti-collective terms, which is another reason why Tory opposition to the act is so puzzling. People are to be protected against misuse of power by police and other agents of the state. But other rights contained in the act, to privacy, against racial or gender discrimination, will need to be policed; government will have to be strong in order to enforce them. Ms Booth cited, for example, litigation under the act requiring the state to protect demonstrators from attack. A careful line will have to be followed by courts and legislators if the rights culture is not to become a charter for selfishness, nimbyism and weak government. She is absolutely right to say that there is an ideological and party political dimension to all this.

Ms Booth belongs to swish new lawyers' chambers which by all accounts will be kept busy as the thing beds down. The "learning curve" - Lord Chief Justice Woolf's phrase - may last a long time. But there will be no bonanza for lawyers while legal aid is so tightly laced. The quid pro quo for any increased state support for litigation has to be further reform of the professional training and practices of the lawyers. As long as the Law Society is dilatory at handling complaints against solicitors; as long as senior judicial appointments are a private mystery for Lord Irvine and his cronies; as long as bar promotions lack transparency, the most dramatic effects of the Human Rights Act ought to be felt in the courts themselves.

The Tories are running a risk with this campaign. To claim, as they do implicitly, that Lord Bingham and his colleagues in horsehair are agents of subversion is strange, to say the least, for the would-be party of law and order. To say, as they do explicitly, that the focus the act will put on the rights of individuals against the state is constitutionally destabilising sounds distinctly odd coming from the relicts of Margaret Thatcher.

webTitle: Tories aim barbs at PM's 'Lady Macbeth'

fields.headline: Tories aim barbs at PM's 'Lady Macbeth'
fields.standfirst:
As opposition frontbencher criticises Cherie Booth over human rights article, her supporters condemn 'stream of misogyny' in public life

Special report: Tories in opposition

Role model who fears falling off the tightrope

Leader: Wrong on rights
fields.trailText: The Conservatives last night intensified their "Lady Macbeth" attack on Cherie Blair and objected to her public defence of the new Human Rights Act on the grounds that her law firm stands to make millions of pounds from cases the act provokes.
fields.body:
The Conservatives last night intensified their "Lady Macbeth" attack on Cherie Blair and objected to her public defence of the new Human Rights Act on the grounds that her law firm stands to make millions of pounds from cases the act provokes.

Far from backing down in the face of accusations of misogyny, officials at party headquarters in London stood by the attack - and said there was no question of William Hague reproaching its author.

"This is a significant issue," said one Hague aide. But party officials took their cue from Conservative newspapers which dislike the prospect of the European convention on human rights being used in British courts from October 2.

In a personalised attack, which caused offence beyond the Labour ranks, the junior shadow home affairs spokesman, John Bercow, likened the prime minister's wife to Hillary Clinton - a radical, feminist lawyer who planned a political career after years of "unaccountable" power behind the scenes.

British voters would not tolerate "an unaccountable cross between First Lady and Lady Macbeth", said Mr Bercow, 37, MP for Buckingham and an energetic backbench rottweiler.

"Take him with you," one MP called when Speaker Betty Boothroyd announced her retirement. Yesterday he was attacked by one of Labour's own guard dogs, Fraser Kemp, the MP for Houghton and Washington, who predicted that "millions of working women" would be insulted.

"It is significant that this unpleasant and unwarranted attack comes on the day when we have a leaked report from the Tories themselves, saying that they are anti-family and anti-women," said Mr Kemp. "The bottom line is they simply don't like the idea of working women."

Amid more complaints about the Blairs' income and current free holiday in Italy and France, some solidarity was shown by Fiona Buxton, author of a pamphlet on women in politics for the Tory think tank, the Bow Group.

Conceding that voters would be interested in "much more important issues", Ms Buxton said of Ms Booth - as Mrs Blair is known professionally: "I think it is really unrealistic to expect that she will not pursue her political ambitions or political interests in some way. I think she is not a good target."

In a co-authored article, Ms Booth argued in the Daily Telegraph that human rights legislation underpinned "the belief that all human beings are equal".

Ms Booth, a QC at 40, warned judges not to countenance unwarranted claims. Her critics, who surfaced in the Daily Mail, Times and Telegraph, argued that the law firm she helped found, Matrix, will specialise in such rights litigation - and make huge sums from it.

Mr Bercow again complained of "noises off" from Ms Booth on a range of policies, including her decision to chair a fringe meeting at Labour's conference on the government's record on women's issues.

"These are deeply contentious areas of public policy," he said. "By convention, prime ministers' spouses do not intervene in public debate. It would be helpful if she would respect that long-standing convention."

Ms Booth, already an employment law specialist, a field not hit by the government's legal aid cuts, was said to make up to £200,000 a year before her husband's job - and new baby - cut her earnings.

webTitle: Comment, Dea Birkett: Victims' siren voices

fields.headline: Victims' siren voices
fields.standfirst:
The testimonies of those who suffer crime deserve to be heard - but they are no basis for making laws

Special report: child protection

Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: The testimonies of those who suffer crime deserve to be heard - but they are no basis for making laws
fields.body:
The parents of Sarah Payne are soon to meet Home Office ministers to urge them to introduce a public register of sex offenders. This seems almost unbearably reasonable of the Payne family. If I thought that a convicted sex offender had brutally murdered my eight-year-old, I wouldn't rest at public notification. I'd want them all chopped up into little pieces, starting at the extremities, and in full knowledge of what was happening. I'd want painful and certain death. There wouldn't be a glimmer of forgiveness.

I consider that a pretty healthy reaction to elephantine grief. But I would not consider it a proper response if Home Office ministers took account of my fresh, raw, enormous emotions. Legislation should not be enacted because we feel sad or mad, but because it furthers justice - because it will lead to a more fail-proof, just and equitable legal system.

The Paynes are not the only people whose impassioned views are being sought. Earlier this year, the lord chief justice promised to let James Bulger's parents have a say in the fate of their son's teenage killers. Lord Woolf declared that their views would inform his final decision on how long Robert Thompson and Jon Venables should serve.

But there is a bigger agenda here beyond the rare cases of murdered children. Within a month of announcing that he would consult the Bulger family, Lord Woolf expanded his commitment to involve the victims' families in the review of all 140 sentences of juvenile offenders detained indefinitely.

This urge to take account of the feelings of those who have suffered, lies behind much new and proposed legislation. Last month the home secretary told an assembly of Labour lawyers: "Too often the victim feels that their needs and opinions have been ignored or relegated to a distant second place at key stages in the process." This week Jack Straw reiterated: "I want victims to feel that they are at the heart of the criminal justice system."

An equitable criminal justice system, however, should not put anyone at its heart - neither the complainant nor the defendant - but should be heartless. If any juror is found to have any interest or knowledge of any of the parties involved in a case, he or she is quite rightly dismissed. The wigs that judges wear depersonalise them, emphasising their role as detached assessors able to deliver unprejudiced opinion. Impartiality is what a fair trial is all about.

Victims are not voiceless. Measures are already being implemented to make sure they are heard. A "victim personal statement" scheme is to be introduced early next year to "give victims a greater say in the criminal justice system". Modelled on the American system of "impact statements", this will enable victims to record the effect the crime has had on them, in a statement closely resembling that provided by witnesses. The statement will be taken into account by the police, crown prosecution service and the court.

The introduction of this scheme is to be broadly welcomed. It is clear that within such a system, if well regulated and checked, the Bulger and Payne families, among others, could have an input in the course of a trial.

But in their drive for a "victim-led" criminal justice system, the government is not content to rest there. Just this week it was announced that, from next month, men accused of rape will no longer be allowed to cross-examine the alleged victim, a stark exception to the established right of defendants to defend themselves. In order to give a voice to the victim, the accused is being summarily silenced.

There are many other proposals under consideration for increasing "victim involvement". These include clearing the public gallery when witnesses and complainants are likely to be distressed by the defendant's supporters. (The fact that a complainant's supporters could just as easily intimidate a defendant does not seem to be countenanced.) Giving victims legal aid for their own representation independent of, but in addition to, the prosecutor, is also being investigated. A victims' charter is to be introduced.

One unexpected voice of reason in this rush to right so many wrongs was heard this weekend. The Bishop of Dorking, who will preside over Sarah Payne's memorial service, advised against allowing our hearts to rule our heads. He warned that rash decisions on public policy should not be made so close to the crime. The Paynes may feel that a so-called "Sarah's law" is what is needed just weeks after their daughter's murder, but neither we nor they can truly tell what they will feel like in months, or years. Perhaps then, they will have very different views on what should happen to convicted sex offenders. Should victims be consulted by government on a regular basis? Should ministers adjust the law according to the immediacy of their grief?

One tabloid newspaper called Sara and Michael Paynes' "the only voice that counts". But all of our voices should be heard, not only those in the throes of immeasurable pain, and not only those who have suffered. We do not need a "victim-led" criminal justice system. We need a fair and impartial one.

webTitle: Amnesty upsets members with shock tactics

fields.headline: Amnesty upsets members with shock tactics
fields.trailText: Amnesty International has been inundated with complaints after sending its members an official-looking letter warning that they were to face criminal charges, torture and even public beheading.
fields.body:
Amnesty International has been inundated with complaints after sending its members an official-looking letter warning that they were to face criminal charges, torture and even public beheading.

The respected human rights organisation yesterday stood by the shock tactics contained in a mailshot to raise money and awareness for its campaign against rights abuses in Saudi Arabia.

Thousands of people received the letter, which purports to be signed by the senior minister of judicial affairs. Only when it is turned over is the true purpose revealed.

Gretel Prescott, 64, is one of 150 people who have so far complained to Amnesty International about its mailshot, after being taken in by its apparent authenticity.

Mrs Prescott, a member of the campaigning organisation for 30 years, said: "I was shocked, I was actually shaking, my heart was pumping. I thought it had stopped when I read it."

"Prepare to defend yourself" was stamped on the envelope. The letter bore a case number and stamp in the top right corner and started with the recipient's name.

It read: "I am writing to inform you that following investigations by this department, we are intending to bring charges against you concerning certain matters.

"I cannot go into more detail at this stage _ the exact nature of the charge is to be kept secret from you.

"I have in my possession a full confession awaiting your signature. Its exact content, however, will also be kept secret from you. Should you show any reluctance to sign this confession you will be tortured until such time as you change your mind."

The letter said there would be no lawyer and that the trial would be held in secret.

It continued: "When you are found guilty, you will not be told what your sentence is, but it may well involve flogging, amputation or public beheading _ You will be hearing from us very soon."

On the other side, however, the letter said: "What you've read may seem like an absurd nightmare. But in Saudi Arabia it is a terrifying reality."

Mrs Prescott said: "It's shock tactics, and you feel: 'I'm not going to support them anymore if they're going to give me heart failure. I want nothing more to do with them.'"

An Amnesty spokesman said it had written to those who had complained apologising for any distress caused.

The campaign aimed "to focus attention on the inadequacy of the Saudi Arabian judicial system," he said. The letter was "mainly intended to raise awareness, money and support for that campaign _

"The work we do revolves around very distressing things. There is no easy way to talk to people about how people in Saudi Arabia are tortured into signing a false confession."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Two girls, aged 15 and 16, and two boys, 14 and 16, appeared at West London youth court yesterday after an attack, in July, on a woman beside the Grand Union canal, Ladbroke Grove. They were charged with witness intimidation.
fields.body:
Teenagers in court after rape

Two girls, aged 15 and 16, and two boys, 14 and 16, appeared at West London youth court yesterday after an attack, in July, on a woman beside the Grand Union canal, Ladbroke Grove. They were charged with witness intimidation.

The woman, 37, was allegedly raped three times after being thrown into the canal, and fled home naked.

Four boys, aged between 12 and 16, are on police bail. The total number of arrests is eight.

Cliff site dead and injured

Police yesterday discovered two bodies at Beachy Head, East Sussex, and rescued a third man in his late 30s who plunged over the 534ft cliff and landed on a ledge, suffering only a broken ankle. A coastguard helicopter crew flew him to Eastbourne hospital.

Detectives are not linking the three incidents.

Stones end gig for Oasis

Oasis condemned the "hooligans" whose stone missiles hit drummer Alan White during the Sudoeste festival in Odemira, Portugal, on Sunday. The band was forced to leave the stage

Holy hideout for Hollywood Harry

Warner Brothers has picked Gloucester Cathedral as a set for its Harry Potter film. Production of The Philosopher's Stone, JK Rowling's first story about the trainee wizard, is likely to begin in October.

Rapper cancels shows in UK

US rapper Eminem pulled out of his UK shows, including the Reading festival later this month, to attend court in America. The rapper, allegedly involved in a brawl, has pleaded not guilty to assault with a dangerous weapon

Chemistry not working

Freshers expecting to start their pharmacy degree at John Moores University learned that the Royal Pharmaceutical Society had refused to approve the course, saying the college had not dealt with concerns over funding.

fields.headline: Construction work
fields.trailText: Wenlock Edge
fields.body:
Wenlock Edge

Maybe it is because the birds have poor spit, or maybe our walls have the wrong texture, or maybe the winds which rattle round our eaves are too strong, but every year the house martins' nests fall off. This year the martins arrived a couple of days after I heard the first cuckoo in April. A few pairs made investigative swoops around the house and seemed agitated that the nests - one front, one back - had gone.

They were probably even more perplexed because, for reasons which are still not entirely clear, we decided to paint the house bright yellow. Perhaps the martins were disorientated or didn't think building new nests was worth the bother but our house remained nestless - until now. A couple of weeks ago a little group began to show interest in the spot under the eaves where last year's nest had fallen from.

They dived around and clung momentarily to the wall, making rapid chickering noises. Then four of them began building. I supposed that these four were last year's brood, returned from the south but not yet involved in breeding, and were taking on the restoration of the family home in their spare time. They worked in fits and bursts, but mostly in late afternoon and evening when the martin community gathers together to feed and play communally.

The nest at the back was finished in about a week. Then work was started on the front nest, a third of which was still stuck to the wall. This nest is still only half-finished and work has been abandoned because of the rain. Whether the front nest construction is being carried out by the same four martins or a completely different crew, I don't know.

The builders may not be breeding this year but preparing for next. It could be that the martin community, concerned not to lose more dwellings in the village, is keeping its options open for the future by keeping the non-breeders busy. In my experience, house martins are intensely communal, cooperative creatures and their dwellings are a source of interest and concern for the whole community.

fields.headline: Marquess 'stole from top store'
fields.trailText: The Marquess of Blandford stole two pairs of designer sunglasses and a stick of deodorant from the exclusive department store Harvey Nichols, a jury heard yesterday.
fields.body:
The Marquess of Blandford stole two pairs of designer sunglasses and a stick of deodorant from the exclusive department store Harvey Nichols, a jury heard yesterday.

The 44-year-old aristocrat, who has a history of drug use, was collared by security guards with the items stashed in his pockets as he left the store in Knightsbridge, central London, Middlesex Guildhall crown court was told.

Duncan Penny, prosecuting, said Blandford, appearing under the name Charles James Spencer-Churchill, had been spotted acting suspiciously by a security guard, Steve Hopkins, who was monitoring the sunglasses department on the store's CCTV system.

Mr Hopkins said he had radioed plainclothes colleagues once he saw Blandford appear to remove security and price tags. Store detectives followed the aristocrat, who counts Winston Churchill among his ancestors, until he left the store.

The alarm system was triggered by a security tag on one of the pairs of sunglasses and Blandford was stopped. He then produced two pairs of Cutler and Gross sunglasses and a stick of Clinique deodorant, worth a total of £257, from the pockets of his combat trousers, Mr Penny said.

Blandford told security guards: "I have forgotten to pay. It's OK, I'm an account holder." But police were called, Blandford was arrested and taken to Chelsea police station.

Blandford had insisted to police that the sunglasses were in his hand and not in his pocket, Mr Penny said. The marquess said his girlfriend, the Welsh ceramic artist Edla Griffiths, was "giving him gyp" over a trip to America the next day, Mr Penny added.

Blandford told police he had spent more than £700 in the store earlier that day and had a credit limit of more than £3,000 at the shop, so had no need to steal the glasses, the court heard.

The court later heard from a consultant psychologist, Mark Collins, who said he was treating Blandford for various disorders caused by his history of drug use, a recurrent depressive illness and post traumatic stress disorder brought on by two car crashes.

Dr Collins, assistant medical director at the Priory Clinic, said he had seen Blandford on November 10 1999, a few hours before the alleged incident, and that Blandford was "anxious, agitated and a little bit fearful" about a trip to America for treatment.

Dr Collins said the sleeping pills and painkillers that Blandford had been prescribed could cause memory disturbance, mild confusion and sedation but said the effects would be minor.

Blandford, of Lawrence Street, west London, denies theft. The case continues today. Press Association

fields.headline: Lala Amarnath
fields.standfirst: The grand old man of Indian cricket
fields.trailText: Lala Amarnath, who has died aged 88, was the original rebel of Indian cricket who became its grand old man. He scored brilliant centuries, bowled, kept wicket and fielded in a manner that belied his build. He played for India in 24 Tests between 1933 and 1952, and led his country against Australia in 1947-48, the West Indies in 1948-49 and Pakistan in 1951-1952, a series which India won by two games to one.
fields.body:
Lala Amarnath, who has died aged 88, was the original rebel of Indian cricket who became its grand old man. He scored brilliant centuries, bowled, kept wicket and fielded in a manner that belied his build. He played for India in 24 Tests between 1933 and 1952, and led his country against Australia in 1947-48, the West Indies in 1948-49 and Pakistan in 1951-1952, a series which India won by two games to one.

Off the pitch, he was involved in countless scraps with officialdom, and was famously sent home from the 1936 tour of England for indiscipline - even though he was heading the batting averages with an aggregate of 613 runs, and the bowling with 32 wickets at 20.78 runs apiece.

Amarnath - his nickname "Lala" meant lion - was also the most outspoken player of his time, and remained brutally candid, in his broadcasts and writings, long after his playing days were over.

He was a right-handed batsman in the classical mould. In 1933, he scored the first ever Test century of any Indian player, on his debut against Douglas Jardine's England side at Bombay. As he came off, with 118 runs, women cascaded him with jewellery; later, a millionaire presented him with £800, while another gave him a car.

Some thought the 1936 sending-home would end his career with India. It did not. In 1946, he toured England, with the team captained by the Nawab of Pataudi.

India fared badly against Australia in 1947-48, but Amarnath impressed their captain, Don Bradman, with his artistic, oriental batsmanship. "We knew Amarnath to be a brilliant run-getter," said the Australian, "and those who saw his innings (228 not out) against Victoria rate it among the best ever seen on the Melbourne cricket ground." Bradman recalled the season as one of his most pleasant cricket years.

Born in Kapurthala, in the Punjab, Amarnath began as a wicket-keeper while still a student at Aligarh University. Later, he demonstrated that he had not forgotten his trade when, with P Sen injured, he held five catches in the first Bombay Test of the 1948-49 series against the West Indies.

As a bowler too, Amarnath was out of the ordinary. He appeared to deliver the ball off the wrong foot. Sharp inswingers, mixed with leg-cutters, brought him close to a hat-trick in the Lord's Test in 1946, when he dismissed Len Hutton and Denis Compton, and finished with Cyril Washbrook and Wally Hammond for figures of five for 118 from 57 overs.

At the end of that tour, Raymond Robertson-Glasgow wrote: "My chief memory is not of our own players, fine as they often were, but of Amarnath baffling the best England batsmen with his subtleties of swerve." In a first-class match against Patialaat Bombay in 1958-59, Amarnath bowled so beautifully that his dream figures read: 7-7-0-4. In his Test career, he scored 878 runs at 24.38, including a century, and claimed 45 wickets at 32.91. In his first-class career, he scored 10,323 runs at 41.62, including 31 centuries, and took 457 wickets at 22.93.

Amarnath later served as manager, selector and chairman of India's selectors. His assessment of Australia's weakness against off-spin bowling on a turning track was the telling factor in India's historic triumph at Kanpur in 1959. Crucially, he insisted on the inclusion of the otherwise forgotten Jasu Patel, and his instructions to captain GS Ramchand to bowl the off-spinner from the pavilion end - to exploit the "rough" made by fast bowler Alan Davidson in his follow-through - did much to engineer the batting collapse.

Amarnath's sons, Surinder, Mohinder and Rajeender, all played first-class cricket. Surinder and Mohinder also represented their country, although both suffered for their father's reputation. The selectors, Mohinder observed, either did not like his face, or his surname.

In his old age, Amarnath entertained journalists covering Test matches at Delhi and Kanpur with his fund of cricketing stories. He always kept his head high, and age could not diminish his swagger or temper his provocative nature. As Bradman said, half a century ago, he was a splendid ambassador for Indian cricket and the Indian nation.

He is survived by three sons and two daughters.

fields.headline: Abe Lincoln
fields.trailText: Stylistically, the jazz trombonist Abe Lincoln, who has died aged 93, was always happy to defer to his great contemporaries Tommy Dorsey and Jack Teagarden, but there is little doubt that his value as a soloist was insufficiently appreciated, not least in Europe, since he left California so seldom, and because many of his recordings were never widely distributed.
fields.body:
Stylistically, the jazz trombonist Abe Lincoln, who has died aged 93, was always happy to defer to his great contemporaries Tommy Dorsey and Jack Teagarden, but there is little doubt that his value as a soloist was insufficiently appreciated, not least in Europe, since he left California so seldom, and because many of his recordings were never widely distributed.

A musician's son, he came from Lancaster, Pennsylvania, and took up the trombone at the age of five. By his mid-teens, he was proficient enough to play, and improvise, in his brother Bud's band. By the mid-1920s, he had become a session musician for live radio and recording dates in New York. He also toured with dance bands, such as the lauded California Ramblers, where he replaced Tommy Dorsey, alongside the influential Adrian Rollini, a gifted multi-instrumentalist. His solo contributions on many of the group's New York recordings show Lincoln to have been comparable to other great players of the day.

After a period running his own band, which employed three of his brothers in the brass section, Lincoln joined a number of nationally known orchestras, including those led by Roger Wolfe Kahn and Paul Whiteman.

After travelling to California with Ozzie Nelson and company in 1936, he stayed on in Los Angeles and became a first-chair trombone in radio studios for 25 years. During this period, Lincoln worked with everyone from Woody Woodpecker (or at least his cartoon representation) and Judy Garland to Bing Crosby and Hoagy Carmichael.

With the revival of interest in small-group Dixieland jazz in the 1940s, Lincoln began to perform with local all-star groups, like those led by trumpeter Bob Scobey and the clarinettists Pete Fountain and Matty Matlock. It was with the latter's Rampart Street Paraders that he made one of his finest and most influential recordings, the 1953 Jam Session Coast To Coast, on which he unleashes some powerful solo work, fit to stand comparison with that of the great Teagarden himself.

A modest man, Lincoln enjoyed the appreciation of his peers. He continued to work with the likes of Wild Bill Davison and, until relatively recently, to appear at Dixieland festivals in California. Last year, he was happy to play at a party held at his Van Nuys home to celebrate his 92nd birthday.

 Abraham 'Abe' Lincoln, jazz trombonist, born March 29 1907; died June 9 2000
