fields.headline: Barbara Kahan
fields.standfirst: Childcare pioneer whose 'pindown' scandal report prompted residential care reform
fields.trailText: A cross the last half century, Barbara Kahan, who has died aged 80, had a decisive influence on local authority children's departments and their successors, the all-purpose social services departments. She also played a seminal role in the chequered story of residential care for children and young people, and, in 1991, with Allan Levy QC, published The Pindown Experience And The Protection of Children.
fields.body:
A cross the last half century, Barbara Kahan, who has died aged 80, had a decisive influence on local authority children's departments and their successors, the all-purpose social services departments. She also played a seminal role in the chequered story of residential care for children and young people, and, in 1991, with Allan Levy QC, published The Pindown Experience And The Protection of Children.

Barbara chaired the Nat- ional Children's Bureau from 1985 to 1994, was director of the Gatsby educational project from 1980-91, and was a member of the 1969-73 Finer committee on one-parent families. She had an unwavering faith in children, their potential, and in the need for first-class services to care for them.

Her report with Levy was the fruit of their investigation into so-called "pindown" abuse at four children's homes in Staffordshire between 1983 and 1989. Under the regime, which was later ruled illegal, more than 150 youngsters, some as young as nine, were isolated in a bare room, wearing only nightclothes, for periods ranging from one day to nearly three months.

Labelled "brilliant and exhaustive" by the local MP, Mark Fisher, Kahan and Levy's report focused on the neglect of residential care by management, which had allowed the abuse to flourish. It also led to a series of government inquiries into residential care, which have culminated in current initiatives, like Quality Protects, aimed at transforming children's services.

Barbara was born the daughter of a railwayman in Horsted Keynes, West Sussex. It was a Methodist and Labour-party supporting home that revered books; her grandfather (also a railway man) read to her everything from fairy tales to The Pilgrim's Progress and the Bible. With her mother, she participated in good works - including the workhouse Christmas pantomime - and she never forgot the plight of strikers and their families during the 1926 general strike. In the 1930s, at Barbara's prompting, a refugee Jewish girl went to stay with the family, and became Barbara's "foster sister".

In 1939, Barbara won a scholarship to Cambridge. She graduated in English and took a social science course at the London School of Economics (then in wartime exile in the town). While at Cambridge, she helped re-start the university Labour club, worked for Richard Acland's leftist Commonwealth party, which flourished during the second world war, and joined the Peace Pledge Union.

After working from 1943 to 1948 as a factory inspector, Barbara became a children's officer in Dudley, from 1948 to 1950. She then moved in Oxfordshire, where she remained until the children's department was absorbed into the department of social services in 1970. Children's officers were a remarkable group of (mainly) women, who, against institutional odds, pioneered a service which proved to be one of the most far-reaching social reforms of the immediate postwar years.

Bliss it was to have been alive when the children's departments were created, and Barbara could also savour the very heaven of being so young an appointee. But the beginnings were unpropitious. She had one room and piles of public assistance files. After six weeks, she was permitted to appoint a 17-year-old secretary. She shouldered a caseload of her own, as well as managerial responsibilities. Nor was she past taking a child home for the night when no other place could be found.

She was certainly an innovator. In Dudley, she opened the local authority's first children's home. In Oxfordshire, corporal punishment in homes was abolished in 1951, and imaginative fostering was introduced - 40 years ago, special rates were paid as an incentive for people to take difficult children. Preventive work was the cornerstone of childcare policy, staffing ratios were high, and there was close liaison with families.

Barbara believed that young people in trouble needed help not punishment, and that the distinction between deprived young people and young offenders was artificial. Both in her Oxfordshire work and in her extra-mural activities, with bodies like the Association of Children's Officers (of which she was president in 1964), she helped pave the way for the 1969 Children And Young Persons Act, which regarded young people in trouble as deprived, not depraved. It was partly what a colleague called her "obsessional antagonism" to approved schools that helped bring about their abolition.

Barbara always sought to unite children with their families whenever possible; this was remarkable at a time when the axiom was to sepa rate a child from its "bad" family background. Her practice was strongly influenced by the child-rearing theories of George Lyward, David Wills, John Bowlby, Donald Winnicott, and her own husband, the child psychiatrist Vladimir Kahan, whom she married in 1955.

Barbara was not always the easiest of employers, but she was a nurturer of talent. Many academics and directors of social services could thank her for the start and encouragement they received in Oxfordshire. A vocal advocate of social services departments, she came to regret that their generic approach squandered the specialist skills built up in children's departments. Sadly, she never became director of social services in Oxfordshire; fighting her corner had left her with too many enemies.

From 1970 to 1971, she was deputy chief inspector of the children's department at the Home Office. In 1971, she moved to the Department of Health and Social Security as assistant director of the social work service, where she remained until 1980.

Barbara remained a proponent of residential care for children long after this approach had gone out of fashion; her belief was that it foundered for lack of advocates among directors of social services. This view was perhaps a necessary corrective to the disfavour in which residential care found itself with both statutory and voluntary agencies. Her most concrete memorial will be her work on "distance learning" for the professional group she regarded as the most neglected - residential childcare workers.

She had discovered the idea in Canada. Thus it was, in 1980, that she became the Gatsby Project's director, and only staff member. The ideas it promoted were ones she had long cherished - recognising the specialist skills of residential staff, raising their status and expanding their training. In 1991, the project was absorbed into the Open University.

It was an irony for so powerful an advocate of residential care as Barbara that, in recent years, she was employed as an expert witness for solicitors representing those who had been abused in the very system of care she had so long supported. Among her publications there was Growing Up In Care (1979), a pioneering work in allowing young people to give their views.

From 1983-1990, Barbara was professional adviser to the House of Commons select committee on social services. Among her many other appointments was that of vice-president of the National Children's Bureau, for the last six years, and a life fellowship of the National Institute For Social Work.

Barbara enjoyed good food, wine, gossip, argument and books, and was an accomplished amateur musician. She maintained that her husband had been the making of her culturally. While she never suffered fools gladly, and often exhibited little patience with those whom she perceived to be her intellectual inferiors, for her friends she was delightful, amusing and stimulating.

"The trouble with her," an Oxford councillor once complained of Barbara, "is that she is always on the side of the children." There could be no greater praise.

fields.bodyText: A cross the last half century, Barbara Kahan, who has died aged 80, had a decisive influence on local authority children's departments and their successors, the all-purpose social services departments. She also played a seminal role in the chequered story of residential care for children and young people, and, in 1991, with Allan Levy QC, published The Pindown Experience And The Protection of Children. Barbara chaired the Nat- ional Children's Bureau from 1985 to 1994, was director of the Gatsby educational project from 1980-91, and was a member of the 1969-73 Finer committee on one-parent families. She had an unwavering faith in children, their potential, and in the need for first-class services to care for them. Her report with Levy was the fruit of their investigation into so-called "pindown" abuse at four children's homes in Staffordshire between 1983 and 1989. Under the regime, which was later ruled illegal, more than 150 youngsters, some as young as nine, were isolated in a bare room, wearing only nightclothes, for periods ranging from one day to nearly three months. Labelled "brilliant and exhaustive" by the local MP, Mark Fisher, Kahan and Levy's report focused on the neglect of residential care by management, which had allowed the abuse to flourish. It also led to a series of government inquiries into residential care, which have culminated in current initiatives, like Quality Protects, aimed at transforming children's services. Barbara was born the daughter of a railwayman in Horsted Keynes, West Sussex. It was a Methodist and Labour-party supporting home that revered books; her grandfather (also a railway man) read to her everything from fairy tales to The Pilgrim's Progress and the Bible. With her mother, she participated in good works - including the workhouse Christmas pantomime - and she never forgot the plight of strikers and their families during the 1926 general strike. In the 1930s, at Barbara's prompting, a refugee Jewish girl went to stay with the family, and became Barbara's "foster sister". In 1939, Barbara won a scholarship to Cambridge. She graduated in English and took a social science course at the London School of Economics (then in wartime exile in the town). While at Cambridge, she helped re-start the university Labour club, worked for Richard Acland's leftist Commonwealth party, which flourished during the second world war, and joined the Peace Pledge Union. After working from 1943 to 1948 as a factory inspector, Barbara became a children's officer in Dudley, from 1948 to 1950. She then moved in Oxfordshire, where she remained until the children's department was absorbed into the department of social services in 1970. Children's officers were a remarkable group of (mainly) women, who, against institutional odds, pioneered a service which proved to be one of the most far-reaching social reforms of the immediate postwar years. Bliss it was to have been alive when the children's departments were created, and Barbara could also savour the very heaven of being so young an appointee. But the beginnings were unpropitious. She had one room and piles of public assistance files. After six weeks, she was permitted to appoint a 17-year-old secretary. She shouldered a caseload of her own, as well as managerial responsibilities. Nor was she past taking a child home for the night when no other place could be found. She was certainly an innovator. In Dudley, she opened the local authority's first children's home. In Oxfordshire, corporal punishment in homes was abolished in 1951, and imaginative fostering was introduced - 40 years ago, special rates were paid as an incentive for people to take difficult children. Preventive work was the cornerstone of childcare policy, staffing ratios were high, and there was close liaison with families. Barbara believed that young people in trouble needed help not punishment, and that the distinction between deprived young people and young offenders was artificial. Both in her Oxfordshire work and in her extra-mural activities, with bodies like the Association of Children's Officers (of which she was president in 1964), she helped pave the way for the 1969 Children And Young Persons Act, which regarded young people in trouble as deprived, not depraved. It was partly what a colleague called her "obsessional antagonism" to approved schools that helped bring about their abolition. Barbara always sought to unite children with their families whenever possible; this was remarkable at a time when the axiom was to sepa rate a child from its "bad" family background. Her practice was strongly influenced by the child-rearing theories of George Lyward, David Wills, John Bowlby, Donald Winnicott, and her own husband, the child psychiatrist Vladimir Kahan, whom she married in 1955. Barbara was not always the easiest of employers, but she was a nurturer of talent. Many academics and directors of social services could thank her for the start and encouragement they received in Oxfordshire. A vocal advocate of social services departments, she came to regret that their generic approach squandered the specialist skills built up in children's departments. Sadly, she never became director of social services in Oxfordshire; fighting her corner had left her with too many enemies. This view was perhaps a necessary corrective to the disfavour in which residential care found itself with both statutory and voluntary agencies. Her most concrete memorial will be her work on "distance learning" for the professional group she regarded as the most neglected - residential childcare workers. She had discovered the idea in Canada. Thus it was, in 1980, that she became the Gatsby Project's director, and only staff member. The ideas it promoted were ones she had long cherished - recognising the specialist skills of residential staff, raising their status and expanding their training. webTitle: Comment, Julia Langdon:  Tory attacks on Cherie Booth

fields.headline: They just can't stand a successful working mum
fields.standfirst:
Tory attacks on Cherie Booth exemplify their problems with women

Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Tory attacks on Cherie Booth exemplify their problems with women
fields.body:
It would be really quite difficult to dream up a political issue that better suited the agenda of the Conservative newspapers and the Tory party in this country than a "story" that somehow managed to bring together the subject of human rights and the person of Cherie Booth QC.

This one has got everything that Conservative opinion in Britain most detests: a rich, powerful, clever, successful, working mother with a professional commitment to enforcing the new Human Rights Act as enshrined in legislation carried through parliament by - of all things - her husband's government.

Conservative opinion does not like human rights much. It isn't quite in tune with the subject, which can be about all sorts of uncomfortable issues for Conservatives - such as equality under the law for homosexuals, or being treated fairly at work whatever your race or gender, or being dealt with equally by the police irrespective of the colour of your skin or your social cachet.

And if all that isn't bad enough, Conservative opinion must be additionally suspicious about the new Human Rights Act, not only because it has been introduced by a Labour administration with what is now perceived as a hidden socialist agenda, but because the dreaded word "Europe" is hovering around there in the background. The new law is an enactment within British legislation of the European Convention on Human Rights and, without actually pausing to consider what is implied by this, Conservative opinion is wholly against the very notion of enforcing anything that may have been suggested by anything European.

Yet all of this high principle and low politics is as nothing compared with Conservative opinion about the prime minister's wife. She is one of the leading human rights lawyers in Britain. She is recognised as such, paid as such and has been professionally honoured as such by being given silk. She has decided to establish a new set of chambers planned specifically to handle the human rights cases predicted in consequence of the implentation of the new human rights law, which comes into force on October 2.

This seems a wholly pragmatic and businesslike attitude for a professional woman such as Ms Booth to have adopted. As well as being a forceful advocate, it is the kind of approach which must have got her to the top of her profession. I don't know Ms Booth myself, I have never spoken to her and, as it happens, I have my reservations about lawyers and the way they make their money. But I do believe in human rights. I think they should be laid down by law and enforced and that this exercise therefore seems to be the acceptable face of legal profiteering. Had I not known the Conservative party better I might even have imagined - silly me - that Conservative opinion would applaud such enterprise and initiative and money-making potential. Isn't that what Conservatives do all the time? Isn't that what they're for ?

Yet Conservative opinion has leapt upon Ms Booth, unleashing the most extraordinarily venomous attacks upon her. The Tories were given their cue by their newly appointed home affairs spokesman, one John Bercow, a young man of 37 of whom it has been said that only his hair is parted in the centre. In what ranks as a typically outspoken outburst, he suggested that Cherie Booth was a cross between Lady Macbeth and Hillary Clinton and opined that it would be "helpful" if she would observe the convention by which those married to prime ministers do not push their own political agendas upon the populace.

What convention? Some prime ministers' spouses choose not to work, but few of them deny themselves the opportunity to express themselves. Denis Thatcher pushed his political agenda at every opportunity. He did not speak in public. He did not air his views. But he continued making money and privately telling people exactly what he thought about everything that was going on in politics. Cherie Booth is a working woman. She has, against all difficulties -including every middle-aged working woman's nightmare, an unexpected late pregnancy - managed to continue to operate efficiently and independently. She has represented individuals in court in cases specifically brought against her husband's government - for example in challenging British opposition to European law.

What Mr Bercow is saying in reality, of course, is that women shouldn't work, that Cherie's place is back at home with the baby, being supportive of her husband and helping the teenagers with their homework. It is an absurd argument, but in order to try to convey some potency to his outdated ideas, he then ludicrously couples the names of Lady Macbeth and Hillary Clinton as appropriate independent-minded wives whom he apparently thinks might serve to frighten the voters - and get his name in the newspapers.

It is only with reluctance that I mention Mr Bercow, whom I do know slightly. He is a very assertive rightwing Conservative with a style which is widely prevalent in today's Tory party. Before becoming an MP in 1997 he was a lobbyist. He is also a former member and secretary of the Monday Club, and it is hard to imagine why anyone in public life should take lessons in human rights from a former secretary of the immigration and repatriation committee of that offensive and unpleasant organisation. He has said recently, upon his appointment to the front bench by William Hague, that his membership of the Monday Club was a long time ago, he was very young and it didn't last long. He was indeed only 18 when he became the club's secretary, he was only - only ! - secretary of the immigration and repatriation committee for a year but he still managed to put in three years' membership of the Monday Club. He resigned in the same year as he became chairman of the Essex University Conservative Association.

The obnoxious Mr Bercow - he doesn't like his name pronounced to rhyme with "cow" incidentally, but prefers it to chime with "low" - has to be heeded, however, because his comments have sparked the debate. The Daily Telegraph launched it, shrewdly recognising what an apparently innocuous article by Ms Booth and a fellow barrister from her new chambers about the changes that we might expect as a result of the Human Rights Act would say to Conservative opinion. Mr Bercow then plunged in and before anyone can say "human rights?" a woman Conservative parliamentary candidate is pontificating to the World at One about the outrageous possibility that Cherie Booth might benefit financially as a direct result of legislation introduced by her husband. All this on a day when a leaked internal Conservative report suggests that perhaps the Conservative party is in danger of being out of touch with the electorate on women's issues.

webTitle: British pay the price for Eurostar venture

fields.headline: British pay the price for Eurostar venture
fields.standfirst: News Analysis Survey finds travellers from London charged 30% more than their continental counterparts
fields.trailText: It was the grand project. A stylish plan which would bring Britain closer to the European mainland and attract millions of free-spending continentals to British shores. And the best thing about the Channel tunnel, Margaret Thatcher trumpeted from the rooftops, was that it would not cost the British taxpayer a penny.
fields.body:
It was the grand project. A stylish plan which would bring Britain closer to the European mainland and attract millions of free-spending continentals to British shores. And the best thing about the Channel tunnel, Margaret Thatcher trumpeted from the rooftops, was that it would not cost the British taxpayer a penny.

Its inauguration was suitably impressive. The Queen stood alongside French president François Mitterrand in 1994 and wished Eurostar all the best. Champagne corks popped and French, Belgian and British officials fell over themselves to slap each other on the back. Six years later it has captured almost two-thirds of market share on the busy London-Paris route and just under half of passenger traffic between London and Brussels.

Despite its symbol as a triumph of post-war cooperation between European states, Eurostar is being undone by the travelling habits of tourists and the ebb and flow of the money markets.

A survey by the Guardian found that British Eurostar travellers pay nearly 30% more than their European counterparts for comparable journeys between Brussels and Paris and are heavily subsidising the group's less popular Brussels route.

In a comparative price study which reinforces the claim that Britons are often charged over the odds, the Guardian found that a "standard flexi return" at £270 costs 27% more to buy in London than in Brussels, where it is just £198.

The most glaring disparity, however, is in the cost of a weekend day return which at £70 costs 34% more in Britain than in Belgium where it is just £46, a fact that will hit travellers hard when a promotional offer expires next month.

On average, British passengers have to pay 21% more for their tickets to Brussels than people who want to do it the other way round, and 11% more for their tickets to Paris.

"The key problem that Eurostar has with its ticketing policy is that Brits like going to France and Belgium but the French and the Belgians are less keen to come here because it's expensive. They have to price to those levels to get bums on seats," Phil Evans, a senior policy adviser at the Consumers' Association, said. "It's price discrimination in the single market and should not be allowed."

The European commission, which polices the single market, is unlikely to act. "Unless it is the result of a cartel or an abuse of monopoly power there is not much the commission can do about it," a spokesman said.

The only answer then, according to Mr Evans, is to shop around and see if there are any special offers available, or even try phoning Eurostar in Belgium and France to order tickets from that end.

Eurostar has 21 different fare combinations on its London-Brussels route. Nineteen of these are more expensive than the Belgian equivalent, with differences varying from 11.5% to 34%. The situation on the popular London-Paris route is slightly better. Out of 23 fare combinations, 15 are dearer than their French equivalent, with the differences varying from 21% to 4%.

Eurostar admits that there are differences in ticket prices but nevertheless insists that it is not ripping off British travellers. "The markets have got a bit adrift," Eurostar spokesman Roger Harrison acknowledged, "but we can't ask the Belgians to pay a bit more because of the strength of the pound - which has steadily increased."

Eurostar has been making a loss since it started operating at the end of 1994, but its chief executive Dave Azema predicted this month that it would break even by 2003 or 2004. It is thought to have lost £80m last year and £95m the year before.

On its website it claims to offer "value for money" fares and has recently started selling tickets over the internet. A price list is conspicuously absent, however, so it is not possible to compare the cost of tickets in Britain, Belgium and France.

It is no cheaper to buy a ticket on the net, despite the customer having to proces his or her own order. The company argues that French law prevents it from discounting tickets in France, and claims that it would be too complicated to have a separate policy for Britain. Controversially, the setting of prices is a collective exercise and because the group is a three-way venture between French railways, Belgian railways and Eurostar UK, officials in Paris and Brussels have a say over how much British travellers should pay.

The extent of Eurostar's accumulated losses are a closely guarded secret but it is known that the vast majority of its ticket sales are for its London-Paris route.

Eurostar rejects accusations that it is using British travellers to subsidise the Brussels route, however, and claims to offer good weekend deals for Londoners to both Brussels and Paris.

"We don't accept any argument about subsidy. That is not a premise we recognise. We still give very good value packages for Brits," the company said.

The fact remains that Eurostar is still more popular with the British. Surprisingly, though, the British division of Eurostar, which is owned by British Airways and National Express among others, is thought to account for most of the group's losses.

Fare differences:

Standard Flexi rtn to Brussels £270 (London) £198 (Brussels)

Business rtn to Brussels £350 (London) £290 (Brussels)

Weekender rtn to Brussels £200 (London) £153 (Brussels)

Leisure Flexi rtn to Brussels £140 (London) £107 (Brussels)

Weekend day rtn to Brussels £70 (London) £46 (Brussels)

Child rtn to Brussels £58 (London) £46 (Brussels)

Standard Flexi rtn to Paris £270 (London) £240 (Paris)

Business rtn to Paris £350 (London) £320 (Paris)

Information: Guardian survey

fields.headline: Court ends Pinochet immunity
fields.standfirst: Special report: Pinochet on trial
fields.trailText: The supreme court of Chile formally confirmed yesterday that it upholds a lower court ruling in May that stripped parliamentary immunity from the country's former dictator, Augusto Pinochet.
fields.body:
The supreme court of Chile formally confirmed yesterday that it upholds a lower court ruling in May that stripped parliamentary immunity from the country's former dictator, Augusto Pinochet.

The bench's vote, by 14 votes to 6, means that General Pinochet's position as senator for life is suspended. "Five years ago, this was unthinkable," said Sebastian Brett, Chile representative for the US organisation Human Rights Watch.

The ruling cannot be appealed and lays Gen Pinochet open to prosecution for human rights offences under his rule, which lasted from 1973 to 1990. Kidnapping, murder and torture are among the allegations.

An investigating judge, Juan Guzman Tapia, is now expected to order mental tests, mandatory for defendants over the age of 70. If Gen Pinochet, 84, is diagnosed as "demented" the case will be terminated.

But the general's supporters and children say they will defy any judicial orders for medical tests, to protect the former leader's dignity.

Hundreds of anti-Pinochet demonstrators celebrated the supreme court's decision in central Santiago with champagne, balloons and posters showing the general behind bars - though it is unclear whether this will ever come to pass.

Dozens of mothers carried photos of their disappeared children.

fields.headline: Michael Harrison
fields.trailText: Michael Harrison, who has died aged 74, was a real-life Mr Chips, who comfortably exceeded that fictional schoolmaster's long association with one seat of learning. Man and boy, he spent 48 years within the walls of Birkenhead school, the last 15 as headmaster of its lower, or junior, school. Even with an extra spell when he was recalled from retirement during the first world war, the hero of James Hilton's novella could barely notch up 40 years at Brookfield.
fields.body:
Michael Harrison, who has died aged 74, was a real-life Mr Chips, who comfortably exceeded that fictional schoolmaster's long association with one seat of learning. Man and boy, he spent 48 years within the walls of Birkenhead school, the last 15 as headmaster of its lower, or junior, school. Even with an extra spell when he was recalled from retirement during the first world war, the hero of James Hilton's novella could barely notch up 40 years at Brookfield.

A direct grant school until the 1970s, then a keen sup porter of the assisted places scheme, Birkenhead maintained a long tradition of drawing a substantial proportion of its boys from local families unable to afford fees.

Harrison, the son of a not-very-well paid evangelist with the Mersey Mission to Seamen, started at the school at 11. Puffing up the hill on his bike each morning, he reckoned, gave him his stamina as a sportsman. He finished up as scrum-half of the 1st XV, captain of hockey and a star track athlete. He was also a leading light in school drama pro ductions, an enthusiasm he was to carry into adult life.

In 1943, he went to Merton College, Oxford on a Royal Navy short course, was commissioned and served in destroyers. On demob, he returned to Merton to read English. He took his degree in 1949, and was wondering what career to pursue when his old headmaster telephoned to ask if he would help out for a short while in an emergency.

Harrison had not thought of schoolteaching, and had no educational qualification - he never did get one - but he agreed to help. He liked it, and stayed on. In one of his early classes was Andy Smith, to become better known as Andreas Whittam Smith, founder and first editor of the Independent.

Harrison had an instinctive gift for drawing learning out of his pupils, rather than trying to hammer it in. As each new English class faced him for the first time, he would ask them how many nursery rhymes they could remember. Less than five was the usual reply, but, as Harrison began to recite them, the boys would be astonished to discover they knew up to 50. "You see," he would tell the boys, "you've been carrying more poetry around than you thought." One of his few laments, as he grew older, was that he could no longer call on familiarity with myths, legends and Bible stories; children simply did not know them.

As a headmaster, Harrison succeeded not by courting popularity - he had no favourites, keeping all his charges at arm's length - but by reassuring the most timorous of new boys with the calmness and order he exuded. That he no longer taught English in this job was a wrench, but he managed to keep a toehold in literature by instilling a little poetry into the future boffins of the science sixth.

After his retirement in 1990, he conducted memorably popular adult poetry classes all over the Wirral. His passions ranged from the English metaphysical poets to Welsh and Scottish bards and the relatively little-known American, John Crowe Ransom.

Harrison's many other interests included birdwatching, acting with a semi-professional company formed by his friend, the writer Roger Lancelyn Greene, and singing with the Liverpool Philharmonic Choir. He reached the rank of commander in the Royal Naval Reserve and was made an MBE for organising summer adventure courses for sea cadets.

In his first years back at Birkenhead, he met and married a preparatory school-teacher, Marguerite, always known as Bunty. She survives him, along with their three sons, two daughters and two grandsons.

 John Michael Delamere Harrison, teacher, born August 25 1925; died July 12 2000

webTitle: Bombs and ballots push him to top

fields.headline: Bombs and ballots push him to top
fields.trailText: Key dates in the Putin era
fields.body:
Key dates in the Putin era

 August 9 1999 Vladimir Putin is chosen as acting prime minister by President Boris Yeltsin. He is confirmed in office five days later

 September 9 Blast destroys a Moscow building, killing 94 people and injuring more than 200, the first of a series of apartment bombs blamed on Chechens

 September 23 Russian warplanes bomb the Chechen capital, Grozny, for the first time, marking the start of the second war against Chechnya in the space of five years

 December 20 Unity bloc of candidates supporting Putin triumphs in parliamentary elections

 March 26 2000 Putin wins presidential election by a landslide. At the age of 47, he becomes the country's youngest ruler since Stalin

webTitle: Fair trial Landmark ruling in Kosovo clears Serbs of killing ethnic Albanian

fields.headline: Fair trial Landmark ruling in Kosovo clears Serbs of killing ethnic Albanian
fields.standfirst: Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: A Kosovo court yesterday cleared three Serbian men of murdering an ethnic Albanian last year.
fields.body:
A Kosovo court yesterday cleared three Serbian men of murdering an ethnic Albanian last year.

The verdict marked the first time the UN-run Kosovo courts, which are dominated by ethnic Albanian judges, had cleared a Serb charged with killing a member of the majority Albanian population in the region.

The verdict on Miroljub Momcilovic, 60, and his sons Jugoslav, 32, and Boban, 25, pleased international observers, who said the case had become a test of the ability of the courts to deliver impartial justice.

The Momcilovics were accused of killing Afrim Gagica in a shootout outside their house in July last year, after a gang of ethnic Albanians tried to storm their home.

The US eventually admitted that one of its peacekeeping soldiers had shot Gagica, but has still not explained why it took months to claim responsibility.

The UN put a French judge, Patrice de Charette, on to the panel, after ethnic Albanians were accused of mishandling proceedings by the human rights group Amnesty International.

webTitle: Renewed call to arms in Kashmir

fields.headline: Renewed call to arms in Kashmir
fields.standfirst: Special report: India and Pakistan
fields.trailText: The main Pakistan-based militant group opposed to Indian rule in Kashmir yesterday ended a ceasefire it declared a fortnight ago when it had hopes Delhi would talk to it about the status of the Muslim-majority state.
fields.body:
The main Pakistan-based militant group opposed to Indian rule in Kashmir yesterday ended a ceasefire it declared a fortnight ago when it had hopes Delhi would talk to it about the status of the Muslim-majority state.

India's prime minister effectively stifled any negotiations this week when he said talks would have to be in line with the Indian constitution. It says Kashmir is an integral part of India.

This declaration, and yesterday's lifting of the ceasefire, extinguish the brightest hope for peace in the Himalayan state for more than a decade.

Syed Salahuddin, chief of Hizbul Mojahedin, the largest group fighting in Kashmir, declared yesterday that hostilities would resume. He made his announcement at one of Islamabad's smartest hotels, flanked by three armed bodyguards.

"We direct all the commanders and mojahedin in the field to break the ceasefire and go ahead with target- oriented missions and actions against the enemy," Mr Salahuddin said.

His group had put its "entire credibility of the past 12 years" of fighting on the line in offering talks which other militant factions opposed, he said, and India had let it down. But he said he would review his decision to return to arms if "India breaks the barrier of rigidity".

India has never held the referendum on Kashmir's status which it promised the international community through the United Nations in 1948.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In a report, page 26, Sport, yesterday, headed Keegan attacks England pay-TV plan, we said that U-direct would use the Sky Sports Digital channel for its broadcast. That is incorrect. U-direct is an independent broadcaster that has bought the Finland v England game. Sky digital simply distributes U-direct's programmes. Sky Sports is not involved in any way. BSkyB says, "Sky digital is regulated as an open platform, which means that the service is obliged to offer distribution on fair and reasonable terms to anyone willing to broadcast legitimate material."
fields.body:
In a report, page 26, Sport, yesterday, headed Keegan attacks England pay-TV plan, we said that U-direct would use the Sky Sports Digital channel for its broadcast. That is incorrect. U-direct is an independent broadcaster that has bought the Finland v England game. Sky digital simply distributes U-direct's programmes. Sky Sports is not involved in any way. BSkyB says, "Sky digital is regulated as an open platform, which means that the service is obliged to offer distribution on fair and reasonable terms to anyone willing to broadcast legitimate material."

The potentially fatal E. coli virus, mentioned in a report headed Holidaymakers to sue over stomach bug, page 5, yesterday, is not, in fact, a virus but a bacterium.

The person questioned by Robin Day about his links with prostitutes, page 3, yesterday, was Lord Lambton, not Lampton.

The final sentence of the article headed Someone to watch over me, pages 10 and 11 (health), G2, yesterday, should have read [with the missing bit in square brackets]: So when the contractions kick in next time, I can't help [thinking a bit of motherly reassurance would do us both good.].

Stephen Joseph, mentioned in the profile of Alan Ayckbourn, pages 6 and 7, Saturday Review, August 5, was the son of Michael Joseph and Hermione Gingold, not Hermione Baddeley. Apologies.

In a column in Media, page 7, August 7, we suggested that readers of the Times were about to enjoy a bylined Diary for the first time. In fact, the Times Diary has carried a byline since 1997.

In our piece about the band Shellac, pages 16 and 17, Friday Review, August 4, we said that Steve Albini had produced three of the most important American albums of the past few years: Surfer Rosa (Pixies); Nevermind (Nirvana); and Spiderland (Slint). In fact Albini produced only the first of those. Nevermind was produced by Butch Vig; and Brian Paulson produced Spiderland.

One more hyphen perhaps in the following, from our report about the day it rained sprats in Great Yarmouth, page 2, August 7: "The two inch-long sprats covered a garden shed and several lawns in the area ..."

fields.headline: Tackling 'brutality' behind bars
fields.trailText: I was astonished to see your report of an assertion by the Howard League that I should have acted sooner over the allegations of abuse at Portland young offenders institute (Inquiry into 'brutal' prison, August 5)
fields.body:
 I was astonished to see your report of an assertion by the Howard League that I should have acted sooner over the allegations of abuse at Portland young offenders institute (Inquiry into 'brutal' prison, August 5).

The Howard League first released details of the alleged brutality to the Guardian and other papers in November last year. I wrote immediately to the League's assistant director urging her to pass on the details of the allegations to me as soon as possible so that I could ensure that they were investigated effectively. On November 30, when I spoke to the League's annual general meeting, I again urged it to let me have those details and promised that I would not hesitate to call in the police. I said that staff who abuse prisoners need to be convicted and dismissed. The Howard League did not let me have the details and I wrote again asking for them on December 7 and again on February 16 this year. Finally, I wrote on May 9: "The key issue here is the extent to which you accept my determination to reform Portland and deal appropriately with allegations of prison officers abusing prisoners. I would therefore urge you once again to consider whether you could disclose them to me personally_ Needless to say, the alternative of putting the material to the police remains open."

It is for the Howard League to explain why it has chosen not to let me have the allegations sooner.
Martin Narey
Director general,
Prison Service

webTitle: Leader: Anwar's trial has been a travesty

fields.headline: Justice, Malaysia style
fields.standfirst: Anwar's trial has been a travesty
fields.trailText: First of all they said the chauffeur was sodomised in a private block of flats in May 1994. When an alibi was produced, they said the offence took place in May 1992. After defence lawyers pointed out the flats had not yet been built, they changed the story again, to an unspecified date between January and March 1993. But if prosecutors in the Anwar Ibrahim indecency trial did not know what day it was, they knew the exact moment of the chauffeur's trauma. Seven forty-five pm, m'lud. Well, thereabouts.
fields.body:
First of all they said the chauffeur was sodomised in a private block of flats in May 1994. When an alibi was produced, they said the offence took place in May 1992. After defence lawyers pointed out the flats had not yet been built, they changed the story again, to an unspecified date between January and March 1993. But if prosecutors in the Anwar Ibrahim indecency trial did not know what day it was, they knew the exact moment of the chauffeur's trauma. Seven forty-five pm, m'lud. Well, thereabouts.

High court judge Arifin Jaka said it was only a detail. This eminent justice, who yesterday sentenced Anwar to nine years' jail, had a lot of similar "irregularities" to put up with during the proceedings against Malaysia's sacked deputy prime minister. They included the beating of the defendant by police; the retraction of testimony by prosecution witnesses who said they had been coerced and physically abused; the arrest for sedition of one of Anwar's attorneys for statements made in open court; an apparent contempt by Malaysia's prime minister, Mahathir Mohamad, who publicly proclaimed Anwar's guilt despite the court's specific instruction to refrain from comment; and the unreliable evidence of the discomfited chauffeur, Azizan Abu Bakar, who told the court police had coached him on his testimony.

But Judge Arifin, who was unexpectedly assigned to the case in place of a much-respected colleague, struggled on manfully. In reaching his unanimous verdict, he was doubtless helped by the fact that he was the jury, too. "You are a sick man," he told Anwar, ruling that his sentence would run consecutively, not concurrently with a previous, equally dubious six-year term for corruption handed down last year. "Only a sick judge would say so," replied the man who in 1998 dared to challenge Dr Mahathir's almost 20-year-long stranglehold on power.

For championing reform on behalf of younger generations, for presuming to question corruption and cronyism, and for daring to suggest that Dr Mahathir might one day go the way of Suharto, Indonesia's now deposed and indicted dictator, Anwar has been ruined and disgraced. His trial was indeed a case of perversion, but of justice, not domestic staff. It was a political, not a judicial act, a travesty from start to finish. Such a Cocklecarrot court proceeding would be funny were it not so serious. As it is, it deeply shames Malaysia and its vengeful leader.

webTitle: Leader: Bradford City - builders of vision

fields.headline: Builders of vision
fields.standfirst:
Scoffing and swigging sure beats sport

Football Unlimited
fields.trailText: The exuberance with which Bradford City, so nearly relegated from the Premiership at the end of last season, have been looking forward to the new one has been dampened by the discovery that their new hospitality suites had been put up the wrong way round, affording an excellent view of the car park but none of the pitch. These were temporary creations, designed to fill in until a new stand is ready, but that would have been small consolation to customers hoping to see City's exotic, expensive signing Benito Carbone, rather than just Carbone's exotic, expensive car.
fields.body:
The exuberance with which Bradford City, so nearly relegated from the Premiership at the end of last season, have been looking forward to the new one has been dampened by the discovery that their new hospitality suites had been put up the wrong way round, affording an excellent view of the car park but none of the pitch. These were temporary creations, designed to fill in until a new stand is ready, but that would have been small consolation to customers hoping to see City's exotic, expensive signing Benito Carbone, rather than just Carbone's exotic, expensive car.

Yet maybe the builders were not entirely misguided in getting things back to front. Perhaps they were trying to make some kind of sardonic comment on the way City played for most of last season before, in a few thrilling games, they hauled themselves out of trouble. There used to be a comparable arrangement at Fulham before the building of a riverside stand: when the home side were playing badly, as they often were, disconsolate spectators could climb to the top of the terraces, turn their backs on the football, and watch the boats on the river instead.

Or maybe these builders had sometimes paid good money to go to Test cricket and had noted how in hospitality suites the cricket takes a poor second place to the banqueting and the booze, so that even when the game is at its most gripping hardly anyone seems to be watching, though everyone seems to be drinking.

Those who complain are told that hospitality suites pull in big money, without which the game might perish. But the builders of Bradford have hit on an answer to that. Hospitality with a view of the ground should be confined to those with some proven interest in the game they have been invited to see: the rest, with their hampers and champers, could then be confined to suites with a view of the car park. Far from being required to apologise, the back to front builders of Bradford should be lauded as pioneers.

fields.headline: Shameful
fields.trailText: As the News of the World abandons naming and shaming, the Department of Health sends "hit squads" into hospitals it has named and shamed (Report, August 8).
fields.body:
 As the News of the World abandons naming and shaming, the Department of Health sends "hit squads" into hospitals it has named and shamed (Report, August 8).

As David Walker says (Analysis, August 8): "taking money away from an under-performing hospital doesn't make political sense".

"Failing" services, whether hospitals or schools, need supporting, not hitting. Naming and shaming only shames those who call the names.
John Nicholson
Manchester

"Failing" services, whether hospitals or schools, need supporting, not hitting. Naming and shaming only shames those who call the names. John Nicholson Manchester

fields.headline: A round of applause
fields.trailText: Beethoven and Mendelssohn were instrumental (literally!) in discouraging applause between movements of symphonies and concertos (Letters, August 7) by linking them together without a pause.
fields.body:
 Beethoven and Mendelssohn were instrumental (literally!) in discouraging applause between movements of symphonies and concertos (Letters, August 7) by linking them together without a pause. Obvious examples are Beethoven's Piano Concerto No 5, second to third movement without a break, and Mendelssohn's Violin Concerto with deliberate bridge passages between each movement denying the audience the opportunity to applaud. But the most brazen example - and it is indeed brazen - is the use by Mendelssohn of brass fanfares between the movements of his Piano Concerto No. 1 which effectively drown any attempt to applaud, let alone cough!
Brian M Poag
Beckenham,
Kent

 I was intrigued by the definitions based on the word "Blair" (Letters, August 7). My French dictionary has the best entry, though. Je ne peux pas le blairer: I can't stand him.
Christopher Strachan
Harrow,
Middx

 I think you'll find that Blairism is actually pronounced "Blurism". It describes any short-sighted political ideology that is indistinguishable from its opposite number.
Paul Palmer
Ellesmere Port,
Wirral
pauljamespalmer@netscapeonline.co.uk

 Good for you, Mrs Meredith, 70, from Northumberland (Grandmother has her day in court, August 8). We need more people like yourself who actually stick by their beliefs and do something about it. I'm truly inspired.
Neil Jones
Holywell,
Flintshire
jonesneiljones@hotmail.com

 Apparently, Joan Meredith attended court "dressed in a purple T-shirt and matching socks". Is that all?
AP Langman
London

fields.headline: Disaster for Zimbabwe's landless poor
fields.trailText: Chris McGreal is right that the seizure of 3,041 of Zimbabwe's 4,200 commercial farms will have severe economic consequences for Zimbabwe and its commercial farmers (Down on the farm, August 7). But he should also have mentioned farmworkers and their dependants.
fields.body:
 Chris McGreal is right that the seizure of 3,041 of Zimbabwe's 4,200 commercial farms will have severe economic consequences for Zimbabwe and its commercial farmers (Down on the farm, August 7). But he should also have mentioned farmworkers and their dependants.

Commercial agriculture provides Zimbabwe with 18% of its GDP and 40% of its exports and employs 26% of the workforce. The knock-on effects of the farm-seizures are being felt throughout the economy. With South Africa's businessmen only too happy to buy bankrupt parts of its economy for a knockdown price, Zimbabwe is more likely to become an economic colony of South Africa than a pastoral idyll of small but profitable farms.

But the accelerated land reform programme, whose outlines are extremely unclear, is also likely in its present form - unplanned, contradictory and barely financed - to be disastrous to the landless poor, its supposed beneficiaries. Land reform must be well-planned and supported not just by the provision of infrastructure and technical expertise, but also by being part of a well-planned agrarian transformation programme, against the background of a stable economy.

The landless and rural smallholders need policy commitments to greater security of tenure to provide not just land, but a process of transferring power from the state to the poor, particularly poor women. Otherwise markets, as sites of unequal power, and political relations will act to marginalise those who cannot participate.

There also needs to be an intermediate layer of devel opment-oriented institutions such as credit unions, savings or loan associations, marketing cooperatives, water users' associations and the like.

Land reform needs to be driven by the poor to be successful, not by the state alone. It is unlikely that the present chaotic process, driven by Zanu-PF as a means of rewarding its most loyal supporters, will see an increase in smallholder production. Certainly there will not be enough to recoup the income and opportunities lost with the commercial farms.

The tragedy is that land reform could have taken place in the 1980s but internal indifference and corruption, plus suspicious funders who reneged on promised money, ensured it did not happen.
Dr Steve Kibble
Catholic Institute for International Relations

fields.headline: All is not tickety-boo
fields.trailText: Those people who can now buy cheap rail tickets from their local stations and fear they are about to lose this service do not know how lucky they are
fields.body:
 Those people who can now buy cheap rail tickets from their local stations and fear they are about to lose this service do not know how lucky they are (Anger at threat to rural rail ticketing, August 7). For some time now, many who live in urban areas have been unable to buy any kind of ticket in advance or to book a seat.

My mother is one. She is 85 and lives in Nelson, Lancashire. She either has to travel to Clitheroe, a round-trip of 30 miles, only possible with a lift from a friend, or has to rely on me to buy a ticket for her by phone. She is partially deaf and has tried and failed to use the telephone to buy tickets herself.

In theory, she should be able to buy a ticket in nearby Burnley. But every time she has gone to the considerable trouble of taking two buses there to buy a ticket, the office has been closed. She has also discovered that it is not possible to phone Burnley ticket office in advance to find out if it is open. Most people would just give up and stay at home instead.
Maggie Watson
London

 So there are going to be fewer stations issuing advance tickets. I get my tickets from the trainline.com. My latest journey was from Yorkshire to Perth, involving three changes and four operators. My tickets, with seat reservations and discount for disabled traveller's railcard, came in the next post, and thetrainline was so pleased to have my business that it knocked £1 off each ticket.

My high street retailer sells a PC quite good enough for such internet operations for £399, including VAT, and throws in a printer for another £69. It is obviously within the reach of even quite a small business to offer such a facility and, if thetrainline made simple adjustments to its system and produced preprinted forms, it could transmit a code that would allow local outlets to print tickets on the spot.
JM Carter
Huddersfield
jmmc@cwcom.net

 A possible solution to the problem of rural rail ticketing may lie with franchising the role of stationmaster. This idea, briefly flirted with in the dying days of British Rail, has proved to be remarkably successful in limited trials, for example at Ledbury on the Cotswold line. Here individual entrepreneurial flair and determination has delivered a first- class service where otherwise there would have been an unstaffed halt. Rail privatisation may yet prove to be a triumph for public/private sector co-operation.
Andrew J Newens
Darlington
andrew_newens@talk21.com

fields.headline: Cherie and a poisoned pen
fields.trailText: I was sitting at the same table in the library of the House of Commons when John Bercow MP was penning his pathetic but poisonous attack on Cherie Blair (PM's wife under fire from Tories, August 8).
fields.body:
 I was sitting at the same table in the library of the House of Commons when John Bercow MP was penning his pathetic but poisonous attack on Cherie Blair (PM's wife under fire from Tories, August 8).

When I asked him what he was doing there he was acutely embarrassed, which at least shows that the little fella is capable of shame.

His assertion that there is a long-standing convention that the wives and husbands of prime ministers do not push their own political agenda is a figment of his imagination.

I seem to remember that Denis Thatcher bumbled his way through politics and that Norma Major raised the profile of the arts and was instrumental in part in persuading her husband to provide more resources.

As for the Queen, she is not, as Bercow suggests, the first lady but the head of state, ie first among men as well as women.

Keep up the good work, Cherie. You've certainly rattled them in relation to the new European law on human rights.
Brian Sedgemore MP
House of Commons

 If Tony Blair really believes that Cherie will win women's votes for him, he is even more ignorant of the needs of women than I realised. She is completely out-of-touch with the "ordinary" women to whom Cristina Odone refers (Cherie the women's champ, G2, August 8).

Cherie certainly is a "professional high-flier, wife and mother all rolled into one", but this is because she earns enough money to buy in support for her family responsibilities. Most "high-flying" graduates, male and female, don't earn anywhere like her salary, especially if they have chosen careers in the public sector or academia.

Cristina Odone feels that Cherie will appeal to feminists because she persuaded Tony to take paternity leave. Yet we all know that she could easily have afforded several nannies to help her at that time. And to distract the prime minister as she did gave the impression that she cared little for the general welfare of the country.

It also showed how out-of-touch she is with the pressures on households today. Most men are too worried about short-term contracts, early redundancies and cuts in salaries to fight for paternity leave.

We are expected to warm towards Cherie because she had a modest background in a broken home, is a bit "naff" and has a "difficult son". But where was Cherie when her son needed her most?

Give me Hillary Clinton any day.

Nest Adams
Prenton,
Merseyside
Nest@xef6.demon.co.uk

 So it's back to the kitchen, Cherie, where you belong.
Chris Young
Bebington,
Wirral
young@art-cp.fsnet.co.uk

webTitle: Sure-footed Putin firms up his quiet revolution

fields.headline: Sure-footed Putin firms up his quiet revolution
fields.standfirst:
The Russian leader came into office a year ago. Yesterday's bomb will test his ability to use his growing powers

Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Vladimir Putin's minders were horror-stuck recently when their boss was floored during a visit to Japan. The combative Russian president's showpiece bout with a Japanese judo wrestler left him on the rug in his shirt and tie.
fields.body:
Vladimir Putin's minders were horror-stuck recently when their boss was floored during a visit to Japan. The combative Russian president's showpiece bout with a Japanese judo wrestler left him on the rug in his shirt and tie.

"I wasn't expecting this. It wasn't necessary," said Yevgeny Murov, Mr Putin's chief bodyguard. "The health of the president is the health of the nation."

It was a rare fall for the surefooted president. In the months since Boris Yeltsin stunned Russia and the world by naming the obscure Mr Putin as his new prime minister, a year ago today, and declaring that he should be the next president, the Russian leader has ushered in a quiet revolution where mishaps have been only of the carefully staged variety.

As Mr Putin repairs to the Black Sea resort of Sochi for his summer holiday, he is in an unassailable position, only four months after the electorate rubber-stamped the Kremlin's decision and made him president in March.

"Under Putin the Russian state is being renewed and reinvigorated. There's a new respect for government and politics," said Mikhail Kozhokin, editor of the influential daily newspaper Izvettia. "That's his main achievement. He's been a surprise, but he has a strong instinct for politics. He feels what kind of Russia he wants, although he hasn't quite formulated it yet."

There is a striking discrepancy between perceptions of Mr Putin abroad and how he is viewed at home. While editorial writers in New York, Berlin, or London lambast the "authoritarianism" and control freakery of the former career KGB officer, his popularity has soared to 70% among the public. At the elite level, too, he enjoys broad support. "There is no political opposition," said Alexander Oslon, director of the Public Opinion Fund polling organisation. "Even our focus groups of regional elites and communicators outside Moscow show very favourable results for Putin."

For the best part of his year in the public eye, Mr Putin did little, with the brutal exception of the war in Chechnya, which critics decry as cynical ruthlessness and admirers hail as proof of steely resolve.

But since March he has launched several offensives on a broad front, provoking showdowns with the big vested interests of Mr Yeltsin's Russia and emerging victorious every time. Some say that, tactically, Mr Putin has made too many powerful enemies too quickly, and that scores will be settled at a later stage. But so far, the gamble has paid off.

"Putin's modus operandi is to go strongly on to the attack and then back down a little, offer concessions and compromises," said Igor Bunin, of the Centre of Political Technologies thinktank.

Mr Putin's quiet revolution entails a radical shift in the way in which Russia is run. All the key instruments of Mr Yeltsin's Russia are either being co-opted or attacked, intimidated or marginalised: the over-powerful governors of the 89 regions, the so-called oligarchs or business magnates who exercised disproportionate influence under Mr Yeltsin, and the media, especially national television.

The duma, or lower house of parliament, and the general prosecutor's office, both focal points of opposition to Mr Yeltsin, are already Kremlin toys. The upper house is being stripped of its powers in favour of a new state council headed by Mr Putin and staffed by his appointees.

New regime

"He's dismantling the Yeltsin system of power and creating a new regime," said Liliya Shevtsova, of Moscow's Carnegie Centre. "Under Yeltsin, power was fragmented horizontally across Russia among various interests. Putin is recentralising, consolidating personal power, not that of institutions. His concept does not tolerate alternative centres of gravity."

Privately, the president's aides are contemptuous of the riotous Yeltsin years. Mr Putin's mission, they say, is to reverse that dysfunctional state, and make Russia "effective and strong".

"In 10 years this country has been reduced to complete chaos," said a Putin aide. "The president knows he has two, at most two-and-a-half years of strong support to make the changes he needs before tackling tough decisions which will be unpopular. That's why he is moving so fast."

The aim is to tame first Chechnya, then the governors, the oligarchs, and so on.

The aide conceded that in fashioning his new Russia, Mr Putin might view democracy, market economics and civil liberties not so much as values in themselves but as tools in building a stronger, more successful and cohesive state. "But how long did it take for Germany, for example, to become a democracy?"

"Putin believes in democracy as a means to an end, he's a conditional democrat," said Sergei Markov, head of the Centre for Political Studies. "If it helps to make a great Russia, fine. If not, he'll give it up."

Alongside the dizzying pace of domestic streamlining, coercing loyalty to the Kremlin, Mr Putin has been keeping up a punishing but successful schedule abroad, visiting the Pope, Tony Blair, Gerhard Schröder, staging a summit with Bill Clinton in Moscow, going to China, North Korea and Japan. There have been no embarrassing Yeltsin-style gaffes on the foreign stage. The performance has been polished, helping Russians to feel better about themselves after a decade of growing resentfulness towards the west.

The anti-western novelist Alexander Zinoviev wrote last week that Mr Putin's election was the keynote event of post- Soviet Russia, and that he had the potential to become "an outstanding president".

Mr Markov says that Mr Putin is constructing a "limited democracy", trading some freedoms gained in the Yeltsin era for order and predictability. Television is a case in point. The two national channels, the state ORT and the private NTV, are controlled or owned by rival oligarchs, Boris Berezovsky and Vladimir Gusinsky. Both are under intense Kremlin pressure to surrender control of the networks and toe the political line. The Kremlin is also planning a new network of regional TV and newspapers in the seven super-regions, under new Putin envoys, to dictate its agenda and bypass the regional governors, many of whom control local media.

Sweeping powers

Such moves have liberal critics crying foul. Mr Yeltsin's 1993 constitution confers sweeping powers on the president. Mr Putin's moves are increasing those powers and eliminating the checks and balances that existed under Mr Yeltsin.

"It's an elective monarchy, where everything is subordinate to the president, not the law," said Ms Shevtsova.

An appeal organised by Mr Berezovsky and signed by several prominent public figures yesterday warned of the threat of a new wave of authoritarianism. "While the president's aim of creating an effective and responsible government is natural and understandable", the statement declared, "the main gains of the past decade are under threat: the free press, free entrepreneurship and - the main thing - freedom of thought."

The signatories included Alexander Yakovlev, the architect of Mikhail Gorbachev's glasnost.

"Putin's policies are a cause for concern," Ms Shevtsova said. "But I don't want him to fail, because his successor might be much more totalitarian, aggressive and nationalist."

Bombs and ballots push him to top: Key dates in the Putin era

 August 9 1999 Vladimir Putin is chosen as acting prime minister by President Boris Yeltsin. He is confirmed in office five days later

 September 9 Blast destroys a Moscow building, killing 94 people and injuring more than 200, the first of a series of apartment bombs blamed on Chechens

 September 23 Russian warplanes bomb the Chechen capital, Grozny, for the first time, marking the start of the second war against Chechnya in the space of five years

 December 20 Unity bloc of candidates supporting Putin triumphs in parliamentary elections

 March 26 2000 Putin wins presidential election by a landslide. At the age of 47, he becomes the country's youngest ruler since Stalin

webTitle: Smugglers' plans go up in smoke

fields.headline: Smugglers' plans go up in smoke
fields.trailText: Italian magistrates have unravelled a cigarette smuggling empire that united Balkan gangsters, Italian housewives and Swiss judges and bankers in a multi-million pound rip-off.
fields.body:
Italian magistrates have unravelled a cigarette smuggling empire that united Balkan gangsters, Italian housewives and Swiss judges and bankers in a multi-million pound rip-off.

Six Swiss citizens, including two judges, are among 87 people accused of laundering profits and running speedboats across the Adriatic to land an estimated 250 tonnes of cigarettes in Italy each month.

Police wire-taps revealed that the gang was planning to buy a stake in the Italian state tobacco-producing monopoly, MS, which is due to be privatised.

The gang allegedly bought MS cigarettes for export through offshore companies, then smuggled them back into Italy where they were sold tax free.

Franco Verda, 59, the president of a court in Lugano, an Italian-speaking Swiss town, is in a Zurich jail accused of tipping off the gang about the imminent freezing of their accounts. He denies the charge. A second judge under investigation was not named.

A Swiss banker, civil servant and head of a money-changing outlet have also been implicated.

The Yugoslav republic of Montenegro was used as a base from which high-powered speedboats ferried the contraband to Italy.

Dozens of housewives and unemployed people in Bari were discovered to have lent their names as owners of the boats to protect the gang.

webTitle: Defeat for Sri Lanka peace plan

fields.headline: Defeat for Sri Lanka peace plan
fields.trailText: The Sri Lankan government yesterday suffered a setback in its plans to alter the country's constitution and end the 17-year-old civil war that has cost 60,000 lives.
fields.body:
The Sri Lankan government yesterday suffered a setback in its plans to alter the country's constitution and end the 17-year-old civil war that has cost 60,000 lives.

Senior ministers indefinitely postponed the bill after they realised they could not get the two-thirds majority to get the changes approved by parliament.

The decision to drop the reforms is a personal rebuff for President Chandrika Kumaratunga, who over the last five years has made the issue her top priority.

In the run-up to the vote members of the cabinet were frantically lobbying MPs from smaller parties and the main opposition United National party to give their backing to the changes.

Disgruntled ministers allege that the reason they were forced to postpone the vote was because 10 opposition members who favoured the new constitution were flown out of the country by their party to prevent them from voting. "It looks as if the opposition has won this battle of the backroom negotiations." a government minister said.

A key part of the constitutional changes included a devolution package that the president hoped would eventually persuade Tamil Tiger rebels to abandon their separatist war.

fields.headline: Missile advice delayed
fields.trailText: The Pentagon is postponing making a recommendation to President Clinton about whether to proceed with the US's controversial national missile defence (NMD) system, the defence secretary, William Cohen, announced yesterday.
fields.body:
The Pentagon is postponing making a recommendation to President Clinton about whether to proceed with the US's controversial national missile defence (NMD) system, the defence secretary, William Cohen, announced yesterday.

Mr Cohen issued a brief statement saying that "a number of difficult issues remain to be resolved" and that he would need a few more weeks before making his recommendation to Mr Clinton.

Until now, Mr Cohen was on a timetable to make his recommendation by the middle of this month, but a combination of domestic politics, international hostility and the latest failure of the prototype missile interceptor in a test last month has made a decision to go ahead increasingly implausible.

Last month's test failure is currently being evaluated by Pentagon missile experts who are taking longer than expected to report to Mr Cohen. "I will make no recommendation about the future of the NMD programme until I have analysed their findings," Mr Cohen said. "I expect that to happen and to report to the president within the next few weeks. Recent reports that I have made a decision on this matter, preliminary or otherwise, are wrong."

Mr Clinton's decision is also complicated by US presidential election considerations. The Republican candidate George W. Bush favours a more extensive programme than the one currently under evaluation.

fields.headline: Diary  Richard Adams
fields.trailText: • The rumours, it must be said, have been circulating for years. But the truth has never been made public - until now. I can reveal that David Yelland, the editor of the Sun and one of the most powerful figures in the British media, has been outed - as an anorak.
fields.body:
 The rumours, it must be said, have been circulating for years. But the truth has never been made public - until now. I can reveal that David Yelland, the editor of the Sun and one of the most powerful figures in the British media, has been outed - as an anorak.

Today we publish the evidence, hidden for 15 years in a dusty corner of the Stanley office of the Northern Echo newspaper in Co Durham, where the young David began his career. Note the lovingly sewn "Yelland D" name-tag (although the stitching is a bit rough). By night he would cut a dash in the clubs of Consett and Darlington, wowing locals with his beloved green-hooded anorak from C&A (his 40-inch chest no doubt helped).

But David, as we know now, was destined for greater things and he soon moved on, abandoning the garment. This is obviously a valuable piece of media history, and should perhaps be donated to the V&A. Or perhaps David would like it back? We rang him to make this kind offer, but sadly he again (tsk, tsk) failed to ring back. So we may auction it off instead. Any offers?

 Filming is going on for the next series of Kavanagh QC, the Carlton TV drama series starring John Thaw as the eponymous barrister. But Carlton got a bit edgy over the script for one show, where a silk passes a note to a colleague reading: "Tosser". No, no, no, said Carlton's script censors, we can't use a word like that before the watershed. "Use the word 'arsehole' instead," it advised.

 There are only two months to go before Verso publishes its book Reading The Guardian, described as providing "an invaluable critique of the Guardian's steady drift downmarket". How true, and this Diary is living proof. But the book, supposedly written by an anonymous clique called the Farringdon Therapy Group, seems to have run into turmoil.

Tariq Ali, one of the group's leading lights, has insisted on penning a 30,000-word fictional account, using a female nom de plume, of a disaffected Guardian reader. At one point, Tariq's character is so disgusted with the Guardian that she uses it as lavatory paper. I can't go into the other details, but they involve oral sex and Hugo Young. Verso's editors are still struggling to fit the book together, but can't bring themselves to tell Tariq that his bit is rubbish.

 After successful direct action at Seattle and Washington, similar protests are being lined up for the World Bank and IMF's next meeting in Prague. The London chapter of S26, the group organising the protests, has helpfully compiled a five-page list of Czech translations, including: "You fascist pig", "Long live anarchy" and, of course, "Where is the nearest McDonald's?"

 A candidate for lamest press release of the year limps on to the desk, as PR firm Holmes & Marchant Counsel attempts to sex up the English women's bowling championships in Leamington Spa - not the easiest of tasks, you will agree. "There will be a police presence at the event, but we are not anticipating any disturbances," it quotes Sgt Dave Wright of the Warwickshire police. Ah yes, but most of the trouble happens in the bars outside the venue, surely?

Oh dear, Oofy Wegg-Prosser, what's become of you? According to a draft list of contents, the next issue of Conservative Network magazine includes: "Ben Wegg-Prosser, former adviser to Peter Mandelson, on the elephant traps the Tories must avoid before the next election."

fields.headline: 'Rich yobs' invade holiday village
fields.trailText: The Cornish village of Rock, a summer retreat for princes William and Harry, was yesterday damned by its MP, Paul Tyler, as having become a holiday haven for "upper class yobs".
fields.body:
The Cornish village of Rock, a summer retreat for princes William and Harry, was yesterday damned by its MP, Paul Tyler, as having become a holiday haven for "upper class yobs".

The Liberal Democrat member for North Cornwall called for a crackdown on the annual influx of "spoilt brats" who came for the watersports and were taking over the village. He said residents were fed up with "rich yobs from elsewhere who have more money than sense".

Holiday retreats far outnumber homes around the seaside resort, which has been dubbed "Sloane-on-Sea" by locals. Mr Tyler said: "Acts of vandalism, all-night noisy parties and intimidation of residents have become all too frequent. Underage drinking and drug use would appear to be widespread.

"When one gentleman complained that a rowdy gang had invaded his garden at 4am, his car tyres were slashed. Another typical response has been 'you can't touch me, my father is a barrister', or similar boasts."

Mr Tyler said many visiting parents "seem only too happy to leave teenagers in holiday accommodation unsupervised, to use pubs as unofficial babysitters, and to take their offspring to and from all-night beach parties

"One or two convictions of public school louts - with a real black mark against their future employment chances, as well as their present school - might bring their parents and teachers up short."

With no nightclubs to go to, teenagers often drive to a beach at nearby Daymer Bay for large all-night parties, as their parents take the ferry back from the restaurants across the Camel estuary in Padstow.

However, Eddie Miller, the landlord of the Mariners hotel in Rock, said problems with teenagers had been exaggerated. "I've been here 15 years, and in that time I can't think of more than one person being arrested outside the pub."

A North Cornwall district councillor, Tyrrell Sandry, disagreed, saying that the main problem was the large numbers of youngsters gathering outside pubs and blocking the streets. He said the council was consulting villagers about having an alcohol free zone for next summer.

"A lot of [the visitors] are under age, and they can get somebody else to get them a drink or they can bring their own," Mr Sandry said. "Some are as young as 14, 15 or 16.

"They mainly come when the public schools break up. They are all well educated and well brought up, but when they get together they do things they would not do on their own."

However, Mr Sandry added that poor behaviour from the upper classes was nothing new for the village. "People like this have been coming to Rock for more than 50 years."
