webTitle: Clinton flies in as 11 states go up in flames

fields.headline: Clinton flies in as 11 states go up in flames
fields.standfirst: President meets some of the 20,000 firefighters struggling to contain 66 major wildfires across America's west
fields.trailText: New wildfires spread yesterday in the western United States in what the White House described as the worst outbreaks in half a century. President Clinton flew to one of the worst hit areas in Idaho to meet some of the 20,000 firefighters battling with the blazes.
fields.body:
New wildfires spread yesterday in the western United States in what the White House described as the worst outbreaks in half a century. President Clinton flew to one of the worst hit areas in Idaho to meet some of the 20,000 firefighters battling with the blazes.

There are now 66 major fires ablaze in 11 states and hopes that some of the worst outbreaks could be contained swiftly proved unfounded.

Evacuations were being planned for more homes as the fires reached more populated areas.

Wildfires now engulf more than 866,000 acres of land across the western states as a combination of lightning, dry forests and dry air takes its toll. Idaho is the worst hit state with more than 350,000 acres consumed and new, mostly small, fires starting there every day.

Mr Clinton was due to visit the Payette national forest in Idaho where the wildfire that has wiped out 23,000 acres started 26 days ago.

"They're the worst wildfires in 50 years and the president very much wanted to go out and see the people working on them," said the White House spokesman Jake Siewert.

During his visit, the president was scheduled to meet some of the troops from Fort Hood in Texas who have been trained up to bolster the weary full-time civilian firefighting service.

The government announced that it was releasing $150m (£100m) to assist the firefighting process.

The governor of Idaho, Dirk Kempthorne, said: "This could shape up to be the worst fire season in Idaho in 65 years of records kept. The conditions will only worsen." He predicted a long, hot summer.

"I think it's highly likely we'll be looking to the military for more help," the forest service chief, Mike Dombeck, said in Idaho, "Our fire season could be another two months, maybe a little longer."

The loss of land to wildfires so far this year totals more than 4m acres - already more than double the average over the last 10 years.

Forest service officials are concerned that the fires have already spread so far at what is a relatively early time in the wildfire season.

The national interagency fire centre in Boise, Idaho continued to show flashing "new" signs on its website page that charts the fires. Nevada reported four new wildfires and in Montana there was a fresh outbreak at Ryan Gulch which officials feared would lead to further evacuations.

In the Umatilla national forest in Oregon, there were fears for some endangered species as the fires spread.

A fire in the Mesa Verde national park in Colorado, a popular attraction for British tourists, was only 5% contained, prompting concerns for the local research centre and museum which contains valuable artefacts. Firefighters were finding it difficult to reach the heart of the blaze.

While lightning is thought to be the main cause of the fires, it is believed that barbecues and smokers who ignore the warnings dotted through the forest landscape are also to blame. Temperatures have also been at record highs in many areas.

Possibly the oddest cause of a fire was noted just north of the Grand Coulee dam in Washington state. There a grasshopper that had jumped on to an electric fence and burst into flames was being blamed for causing a fire that has already covered more than 3,500 acres on the Colville Indian reservation, according to local officials.

webTitle: Sodomy verdict fails to crush Anwar's spirit

fields.headline: Sodomy verdict fails to crush Anwar's spirit
fields.trailText: The former Malaysian deputy prime minister Anwar Ibrahim gave a defiant speech from the dock yesterday as he was sentenced to nine years in jail on sodomy charges.
fields.body:
The former Malaysian deputy prime minister Anwar Ibrahim gave a defiant speech from the dock yesterday as he was sentenced to nine years in jail on sodomy charges.

Anwar, 53 tomorrow, told a packed court in Kuala Lumpur that he was "the victim of a political conspiracy through a web of intrigue orchestrated by the maestro, [prime minister] Mahathir Mohamad".

There was a fierce clash as Anwar told the judge that the judgment "does not disgrace me, it disgraces you, the judiciary and this nation of ours". Judge Arifin Jaka, who said that the sentence should reflect the "public interest", repeatedly tried to silence Anwar and said he was "a sick man". He called a recess and stormed off the bench after Anwar retorted that he was "a sick judge".

Mr Anwar then comforted his wife, Wan Azizah, who has taken over his political role. "He told me to be strong, not to cry, and to calm the children," she said later. Dr Azizah said they would appeal against the verdict but added that "the result is already known".

More than 500 protesters gathered outside in spite of police warnings that even peaceful demonstrations were forbidden. Tian Chua, a leader of the National Justice party founded by Dr Azizah, was arrested.

The judge said Anwar would serve the nine-year term after finishing a a six-year sentence imposed last year for allegedly trying to suppress the charges against him when he was still deputy prime minister.

In spite of Anwar's characteristic defiance, he is now effectively removed from the political scene for good.

Many Malaysians believe such an outcome had been the prime minister's objective ever since he decided that Anwar, who had been his chosen successor, was becoming a political threat.

Within days of Anwar's arrest in 1998, Dr Mahathir claimed to have "incontrovertible proof" of the sodomy allegations. Defence lawyers pleaded in vain that the prime minister often committed contempt of court by publicly pronouncing Anwar guilty.

Yesterday Judge Arifin dismissed conspiracy claims as "irrelevant", and said that the evidence of the key prosecution witness was credible in spite of "some discrepancies".

Anwar was accused of sodomy by a former family chauffeur, Azizan Abu Bakar, who gave confusing testimony.

The prosecution originally said that Anwar committed sodomy in May 1994, but amended that to May 1992 based on the driver's evidence. The defence showed that the building where the sodomy allegedly took place was not built until 1993. Prosecutors then amended the timing to the first three months of 1993.

Anwar's adoptive brother, Sukma Darmawan, 39, was found guilty of abetting Anwar. Sukma, who said a confession was forced from him by police, was given a six-year jail sentence and four lashes. Anwar was excused the lashing because of his age.

International observers have expressed serious doubts about the integrity of the Malaysian judicial system in the light of Anwar trials.

Amnesty International said yesterday that the verdict "highlights the vulnerability of all Malaysians to selective, politically motivated prosecutions". Anwar had been brought to trial "because of his dissenting political activities and the challenge he posed to government leaders".

The US-based Human Rights Watch listed a series of legal irregularities including the severe beating of Anwar while he was in custody, and the attempted coercion of key witnesses - one was threatened with the death penalty for a minor firearms offence.

Anwar's chief lawyer, Karpal Singh, faces trial for sedition over statements made in court while defending his client.

J'accuse My fight for justice
Extracts from Anwar's address to the court

The pronouncement of your judgment today was a mere formality, according to [the] preordained script of the conspirators. [Dr Mahathir] is a coward who would not take responsibility for his own evil.

... I was loyal to the government and the prime minister. But ... if justice, the law or public interest were threatened, I would defy Dr Mahathir. I objected to the use of massive public funds to rescue the failed businesses of his children and cronies.

And it was precisely because I defied him ... that I was dismissed and persecuted. This is a small sacrifice to pay in the cause of democracy and justice.

This nation needs reform and renewal. To Dr Mahathir and his greedy family and cronies, I say beware the wrath of the people, for the people are rising to reclaim justice.

In spite of Anwar's characteristic defiance, he is now effectively removed from the political scene for good. Many Malaysians believe such an outcome had been the prime minister's objective ever since he decided that Anwar, who had been his chosen successor, was becoming a political threat. Within days of Anwar's arrest in 1998, Dr Mahathir claimed to have "incontrovertible proof" of the sodomy allegations. Defence lawyers pleaded in vain that the prime minister often committed contempt of court by publicly pronouncing Anwar guilty. Yesterday Judge Arifin dismissed conspiracy claims as "irrelevant", and said that the evidence of the key prosecution witness was credible in spite of "some discrepancies". Anwar was accused of sodomy by a former family chauffeur, Azizan Abu Bakar, who gave confusing testimony. The prosecution originally said that Anwar committed sodomy in May 1994, but amended that to May 1992 based on the driver's evidence. The defence showed that the building where the sodomy allegedly took place was not built until 1993. Prosecutors then amended the timing to the first three months of 1993. Anwar's adoptive brother, Sukma Darmawan, 39, was found guilty of abetting Anwar. Sukma, who said a confession was forced from him by police, was given a six-year jail sentence and four lashes. Anwar was excused the lashing because of his age. International observers have expressed serious doubts about the integrity of the Malaysian judicial system in the light of Anwar trials. Amnesty International said yesterday that the verdict "highlights the vulnerability of all Malaysians to selective, politically motivated prosecutions". Anwar had been brought to trial "because of his dissenting political activities and the challenge he posed to government leaders". The US-based Human Rights Watch listed a series of legal irregularities including the severe beating of Anwar while he was in custody, and the attempted coercion of key witnesses - one was threatened with the death penalty for a minor firearms offence. Anwar's chief lawyer, Karpal Singh, faces trial for sedition over statements made in court while defending his client. J'accuse My fight for justice Extracts from Anwar's address to the court The pronouncement of your judgment today was a mere formality, according to [the] preordained script of the conspirators. [Dr Mahathir] is a coward who would not take responsibility for his own evil. ... I was loyal to the government and the prime minister. But ... if justice, the law or public interest were threatened, I would defy Dr Mahathir. I objected to the use of massive public funds to rescue the failed businesses of his children and cronies. And it was precisely because I defied him ... that I was dismissed and persecuted. This is a small sacrifice to pay in the cause of democracy and justice. This nation needs reform and renewal. To Dr Mahathir and his greedy family and cronies, I say beware the wrath of the people, for the people are rising to reclaim justice.

webTitle: Bodies of babies found in basket

fields.headline: Bodies of babies found in basket
fields.trailText: Detectives investigating the deaths of up to three babies revealed at an inquest yesterday that two small bodies had been found hidden in a laundry basket at a house near Doncaster.
fields.body:
Detectives investigating the deaths of up to three babies revealed at an inquest yesterday that two small bodies had been found hidden in a laundry basket at a house near Doncaster.

One of the babies had been dead for an estimated three weeks, but the remains of the other were up to four years old, according to South Yorkshire Police. Officers are using a radar scanning device to search for a suspected third corpse in gardens at Rossington, a coalfield village.

A mother of five, Alison Johnson, 38, has been charged with the murder last month of the first baby, a one-day-old girl, and is due to appear before Doncaster magistrates on Friday.

Detective Superintendent Derek Deakin, heading the investigation, told the inquest in Doncaster that officers searched a house in Rossington last week following information from a reliable source. He said: "The body of the first baby had been placed in a laundry basket, along with bundles of clothing, in an outbuilding at the address.

"The whole basket was taken away for further examination. When we examined the contents further, that's when we discovered baby number two."

The inquest heard that tests on the baby girl's body suggested that the child had been born alive at full term. Doctors are now carrying out further checks to discover the identity of the child's parents.

Mr Deakin said: "We have spoken to a gentleman who thinks he may be the father but the only way to confirm this is by forensic examination of the DNA profile."

Pathologists are still working to determine the sex of the second baby and whether it was also born alive.

The Doncaster coroner, Stanley Hooper, adjourned the inquest pending further information, as officers began to dig up sections of garden at three houses in Rossington. Sniffer dogs are being used along with a radar device and fibre optic surveys of crevices and floor cavities in the three houses are being carried out.

Mr Deakin said: "There is a strong possibility that we will discover another body at some point and we will use everything we can to assist our search."

webTitle: Staffing crisis in the social services

fields.headline: Crusade for change
fields.standfirst: Chief inspector of social services addresses the staffing crisis
fields.trailText: Chief inspector of social services addresses the staffing crisis
fields.body:
Officially it's a crisis. Denise Platt, chief inspector of social services, has admitted that local authorities are having "utmost difficulty" recruiting social care staff and has accepted that many posts offer worse pay than do less demanding jobs in supermarkets.

In typically trenchant remarks in her annual report, Platt warns that the government's drive to ratchet up the quality of social services will falter if recruitment and retention problems are not addressed. But she says low pay is only one of the issues that have to be tackled.

Other problems threatening to hamper progress are that people who have been awarded the diploma in social work are "said not to have the experience, skill and knowledge necessary to do the job"; that too many apparently experienced workers seeking promotion are "said not to have the competencies required"; and that the government has sought to expand services in areas such as children and young people, and in regulation and inspection, without expanding the supply of staff.

Training and qualification issues will be dealt with in the government's forthcoming consultation paper on social care quality. As social care minister John Hutton recently hinted, the paper looks likely to lay a path towards the three-year social work training that many in the profession have long campaigned for. But Platt is making clear that the onus is otherwise on local authorities.

"Councils responsible for social care services... need to consider how they develop, recruit and retain essential staff," she writes in the report.

As she did last year, the chief inspector expresses concern about the assessment of people's care needs, which she describes as insufficiently rounded, the commissioning of appropriate services and the consistency of approach and delivery. Noting that more than one in three authorities has reconfigured traditional social services departments - linking, typically, with housing or education - she warns: "Whatever arrangements are put in place, they must deliver a genuine difference for the many people who rely on social care services and not just be change for change's sake."

The report, Modern Social Services - A Commitment to People, names the 18 English authorities put on "special measures" because of poor performance, although six of them -Buckinghamshire, Bury, Ealing, Kingston upon Hull, Newcastle upon Tyne and Sefton - have since made sufficient progress to be removed from the list.

Platt says it takes two to three years to turn round a poorly performing authority, achieving acceptable standards and the necessary cultural change, and points out that, often, poor performance and chronic staffing problems go hand in hand.

"Some [of the 18] experienced social worker vacancy rates of 30% or more. Some had vacancies at senior management level, such that only the director of social services was in post; others had 'acting' arrangements in all posts in the senior management team, with a very thin layer of experienced people from whom to draw."

In contrast to such criticism, Platt also uses the report to fight the corner of social services - not only by highlighting good practice, but also by pointing to failings elsewhere.

Ministers, she says, have bemoaned the lack of joint working between social services and the NHS. Yet this is attributable sometimes to a multiplicity of mandatory planning processes, often overlapping, and sometimes to inconsistent boundaries for authorities and agencies. "It would be helpful," she observes, "when NHS bodies consider the reconfiguration of services and the progression of primary care groups to primary care trusts, if the impact on local partnership arrangements could be formally and explicitly addressed with partners".

Interestingly, Platt comments about problems in the NHS last winter that caused such trouble for the government. Social services has been blamed in some quarters for not doing enough, quickly enough, to ensure elderly patients were discharged from hospital when ready, leaving much needed beds blocked. But Platt says that "the most significant reasons that can be identified for the majority of the delays" lay elsewhere.

These were: observing elderly people's right of choice to a specific care home; a shortage of care home capacity in some parts of the country; a lack of funding experienced by some local authorities; high levels of staff sickness; and, in some areas, the fact that "people waited a very long time for discharge to other NHS facilities".

Foreshadowing an end to sniping between health and social care on this critical issue, Platt says: "A national standard is needed for timely and appropriate discharges from hospital, particularly for older people, so that we can improve practice and resource development across the whole country to remedy problems. The Department of Health is already working on the production of a clearer definition for 'delayed discharge' and its causes."

 Modern Social Services is available free from DH Publications, PO Box 777, London SE1 6XH

webTitle: Care worker pay less than shop wages

fields.headline: Care worker pay less than shop wages
fields.trailText: Many jobs involving care for the most vulnerable children and adults are offering lower pay than supermarket jobs, the chief inspector of social services has admitted.
fields.body:
Many jobs involving care for the most vulnerable children and adults are offering lower pay than supermarket jobs, the chief inspector of social services has admitted.

Local authorities are reporting "utmost difficulty" finding staff to fill posts critical to the challenge of improving care services says Denise Platt in her annual report.

Warning that low pay is one of the issues that must be tackled if services are to improve, Ms Platt writes: "Initiatives have been delayed in their implementation because of recruitment problems."

Unions representing care workers have long argued that pay rates have fallen behind the wages of staff employed in shops and expanding sectors such as call centres, but this is the first time the point has been accepted by the government.

Sandra Howell, a national officer for the public services union Unison, said: "The issue is, unfortunately, that as a society we put a very low value on social care jobs even though they are utterly essential."

An estimated 1m people work in social care, in jobs ranging from home helps to assistants providing 24-hour support for profoundly disabled children and adults. About 80% of this workforce has no qualifications. There are no national pay rates, but a survey last year found that night care assistants in residential homes were earning on average £3.71 an hour, and domestic assistants the statutory minimum of £3.60.

Ms Howell said public sector care staff who went to the homes of elderly and disabled people and worked unsupervised, holding considerable responsibility, were typically paid £5.27 an hour.

In her report Ms Platt says that "many posts in social care offer less pay than less demanding jobs in supermarkets". But staff shortages are present at all levels, causing vacancy rates of 30% or more in some areas for qualified social workers on hourly rates ranging from £7.88 to £11.50.

According to a survey last month by the Association of London Government one, unnamed, social services department in the capital had a staff vacancy rate of 52%.

Ms Platt says: "Staff recruitment and retention problems are particularly evident in children's services, where there is a shortage of experienced, competent social workers. The shortage is also becoming evident in adult services, especially in mental health care."

Government programmes to improve care services had "expanded the demand for people with similar experience and knowledge without the equivalent expansion of supply".

Social care leaders are worried that recruitment problems could worsen because of the government's focus on boosting health service staffing levels. Rather than continuing to try to poach workers from other social services departments, some local authorities are now recruiting overseas. Earlier this year Essex county council started to bring in social workers from South Africa to fill its long-standing vacancies in areas including Basildon and Southend.
